entry.sense: The twenty-seventh letter of the alphabet; called waAwN: it is one of the class termed Xafahiy-ap [or labials], and is a letter of augmentation.

For the uses of w as a particle see Supplement; for w in the sense of bl see a verse in art. qaSada; w giving fulness of sound to _u, see naZara; w used lilt-acak-uri, see Oalifu Alt-aEaAyiI in art. A, and see Oalifu AlUisotinokaAri; w in the sense of b, see a verse in art. Easiyla.
As a numeral it denotes Six.
R. Q. 1. waOowaOa, inf. n. waOowaOahN, He (a dog) barked. (A.)
Also inf. n. waOowaMCN ([respecting the form of which see ZaOoZaOa] in the CK and a MṢ. copy, waOowaON) He (a jackal, Aibonu MwaI,) cried, or barked. (Ḳ.)
[See also waEowaEa.]
1. waOaba, aor. yaYibu, inf. n. waOobapN [app. a mistake for waOobN and UibapN], It (a hoof) was contracted in its edges, or in its fore edges. (Az.) See waOobN.
waOaba, aor. yaYibu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. waOobN (Ṣ) and UibapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) He contracted himself, or drew himself together, or shrank; and was ashamed. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
waOaba (TA) and Aet-aOaba↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) He was ashamed, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) mino XaIoCK of a thing. (TA.)
waOaba, aor. yaYibu, i. q. Anf [app. meaning He was disdainful]. (TA.)
waYiba, [aor. yawoCabu: see waTiYa:] He was angry. (Ḳ.)

4. OawoCabahu He did to him an action of which one should be ashamed: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he made him angry: [mentioned twice in the Ḳ: once as though there were no difference of opinion respecting it:] or he turned him, or drove him, back with ignominy, from his affair, or from the object of his want: (so in the copies of the Ḳ; but in an old copy, relied upon as correct, of the Tahdheeb el-Af'ál, from his companion, En SAHbh: TA:) as also Ait-aOabahu↓; (Ḳ;) meaning he turned him, or drove him, back with ignominy: (TA:) or AwCbh also signifies he turned him, or drove him, back from his affair, or from the object of his want. (Ṣ.)
8. Ait-aOaba: see 1 and 4.

waOobN, as an epithet applied to a solid hoof, Strong, contracted in the edges, or in the fore edges, and light: (Ḳ:) or simply strong: (L, art. rDH:) or round like a cup (such as is called qaEobN); cup-shaped; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and that takes [app. meaning occupies] much of the ground: [(see also tanaAhaba:) accord. to Freytag, hollowed within, so that it takes up (tollat) much earth:] (Ḳ:) or i. q. HfyZ: (Az, as cited in the TA:) [but this I incline to think a mistake for xafiyfN light:] or of excellent size: (Ḳ:) or of moderate size; not wide, nor contracted. (T.)
waOobu AlHawaAfiri Having hoofs contracted in the edges, or in the fore edges. (Az.) See also waOobN above.

waOobN A large, or big, and wide, arrow: (Ḳ:) [but I think that, for mina AlqidaAHi, in the Ḳ, we should read mn AlOqodaAHi; and that wOb is therefore an epithet applied to a cup, such as is called qadaHN; as Golius and Freytag have understood it; and not to a qidoH: see what follows]. UinaACN waOobN A large, or big, and wide, vessel: a wide vessel: pl. OawoMbN. qdHN wObN A large, or big, deep, and wide, [cup]. (TA.)
qidorN waOobapN A wide, or ample, cooking-pot. (TA.)
See also waviybN.
waOobN A great camel: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) accord. to some. (Ṣ.)
waOobapN A short and broad she-camel, or woman. (TA.)
A female of middling make, between good and bad, or handsome and ugly. (TA.)
A small hollow, or cavity, in a rock, that retains water. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
biYorN waOobapN A wide and deep well: (Ḳ:) or a deep well. (L, Ḳ.)
waYiybN Wide, or ample: syn. ragiybN. (TA.)
qidorN waYiybahN A deep cooking-pot. (T, Ḳ.)

UibapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in which the p is a substitute for the [incipient radical] w, (Ṣ,) and tuWabapN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in which the t is originally w, (Ṣ,) and mawovibapN↓, (Ḳ,) A disgrace; a shame; a thing of which one should be ashamed: disgrace, or ignominy: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) shame; (Ḳ;) and a contracting of one's self, or shrugging: (TA:) a vice; fault; or the like. (Aboo-ʼAmr Esh-Sheybánee.)
Ex. nakaHa fulaAnN fiI UibapK [Such a one married in a manner that was disgraceful; or, of which one should be ashamed: i. e., married a woman of low origin, or the like]. (Ṣ.)

Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
UicaA AlmaraYiI-u Xab-a lahu banaAt
EaSabona biraOosihi UibapF waEaAraA
[When the Maraee has daughters that have attained to puberty, they bind upon his head disgrace and ignominy]. (Ṣ.)
TaEaAmu tuWabapK↓ (or TaEaAmN cuw tuWabapK, as in the TA,) Food of which one should be ashamed to eat. Mentioned by AA on the authority of an eloquent Arab of the desert. (Ṣ.)
tuWabapN and mawoYibapN: see UibapN.
muwYibaAtN Foul, or disgraceful, qualities, or dispositions. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

1. waOada, aor. yaYidu, (inf. n. waOodN, Ṣ, L, &c.) He buried his daughter alive (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) in the grave, (Ṣ, L,) and put a load of earth upon her. (A.) It was customary for a man in the time of paganism, when a daughter was born to him, to bury her alive when her mother brought her forth, from fear of reproach and want: but this is forbidden in the Ḳur. xvii. 33: and some of them used to bury their children alive in times of famine: (L:) the tribe of Kindeh used to bury their daughters alive. (Ṣ, L.)

AlwaOodu AlxafiI-u a term used in a trad. as meaning Extractio penis tempore concubitus, ne conciperet femina: as also AlmawoWuwdapu↓ AlS-ugoraI because this act resembles that of burying a child alive, and is done with the same motive. (L.)
5. twO-dt Ealayohi AlOaroDu The earth, or the land, hid, or concealed him, and [as it were] removed him: (T,:) formed by transposition from twd-Ot, [q. v. in art. wdO]. (T.) See 8.

8. Ait-aOada (originally AiwotaOada, Ṣ,) and tawaO-ada↓ He acted, or behaved, with moderation, gentleness, or deliberation, moderately, gently, deliberately, or contr. of hastily: with gravity, staidness, sedateness, or calmness: (T, Ṣ, M, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) from tuWadapN [q. v.]: (Ṣ:) or from waOodN: or, as some say, formed by transposition, and from taOaw-adat fiI qiyaAmihaA, meaning “she (a woman) bent in her rising, by reason of her heaviness.” (T, L.) Ex. At-Od fiI Oamorihi, and twO-d↓ fiyhi, He acted with moderation, gentleness, &c., in his affair: (Ṣ,* A, L,* Mṣb:) and fiI maXoyihi in his walk, or pace, or gait. (Ṣ, L.)
wOodN and waYiydN↓ A sound, or noise; (Ḳ;) absolutely: (TA:) or a loud sound or noise; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) as that of a wall falling, and the like. (L.)
The sound occasioned by vehement or heavy treading of the ground: the heavy sound of the feet of camels. (L.)
Also the former, (L,) or both, (Ḳ,) The braying (hadiyr) of a camel. (L, Ḳ.)
waYiydN and waYiydapN (L, Ḳ) and mawoWuwdapN↓, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and, by abbreviation, mawodapN, (Abu-l-ʼAbbás, T,) A daughter buried alive. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
AlmawoWuwdapN↓ AlS-ugoraI: see AlwaOodu AlxafiI-u, voce waOada. (L.)
See waOodN.
See also tuWadapN.
waAYidN A man burying, or who buries, his daughter, or daughters alive. (L.)
tawoCadN: see tuWadapN.

tuWadapN (T, Ṣ, M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and tuWodapN (M, L, Ḳ) and twdp, without C, [i. e., tuwadapN or tuwdapN,] (TA,) and tawoCadN↓ (M, L, Ḳ) and waYiydN↓; (Ḳ;) the first originally wuWadapN; like as tukaOapN is originally wukaOapN; (T, L;) Moderation; gentleness; deliberateness; a leisurely manner of proceeding, or of deportment, &c.; contr. of hastiness: and gravity; staidness; sedateness; calmness: syn. naOan-K, (T, M, L, Ḳ,) and tamah-ulN, (T, L,) and razaAnapN, (M, L, Ḳ,) and sakiynapN. (Mṣb.) Ex. faEalahu fiI tuWadap [He did it in a moderate manner; with gentleness;, &c.] (A.) And maXaI EalaI tuWadap (Ṣ, Mṣb) [He walked moderately; gently;, &c.;] calmly; or quietly. (Mṣb.) maXaI maXoyFA waYiydaA↓ i. q. EalaI tuWadapK [He walked moderately; gently;, &c.]; (Ṣ;) calmly, or quietly. (Mṣb.)
mawoWuwdapN and mawodapN: see waYiydN and waOada.
mawaAYidu Calamities,: (IAạr, T, Ḳ:) formed by transposition from maMwidu. (IAạr, T.) See art. Awd.
1. wab-a (originally Oab-a, the O being changed into w, Az,) inf. n. wab-N; and wabawba↓, inf. n. wabowabapN; He prepared to charge, or make an assault, in battle. (Ḳ.) See art. Ob.
R. Q. 1. wabowaba: see 1.

hom.sense: 1. wabiYati AlOaroDu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. tiybaOu, (Ḳ, TA,) or tayobaOu, (CK,) and tawobaOu, (accord. to the Ḳ: in the (Ṣ and) L and other lexicons, only this last aor. is mentioned; but it is asserted on the authority of AZ, who says that this form of the pret. is of the dial. of the Kusheyrees, that the aor. is tiybaA, with kesr to the t, [contr. to analogy,] TA,) inf. n. wabaON; (Ḳ;) or wabaMCapN; (Ṣ;) and wabiyat, aor. tayobaA and tawobaA; (Mooʼab and Jámiʼ) and wabuWat, inf. n. wabaMCN and wabaMCapN and OabaM and OabaMpN (Ḳ, the w being changed into O in the latter two); and with w without _u, [i. e., wabuwat]; (Mooʼab and Jámiʼ) and wubiYat, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like EuniIa, [i. e., pass. in form, but neut. in signification,] (Ḳ,) aor. tiybaOu, (L and other lexicons,) in which, the w being changed into I, the vowel of the first letter necessarily becomes kesr, (TA,) or tuwbaOu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. waboCN, (Ḳ, TA: in the CK wabaON,) or wabaMCN; (Ṣ, L, &c.;) and OawobaOat↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiybaMCN; (TA;) The land was, or became, afflicted with wabaO: (Ḳ:) or, much afflicted with disease. (Ṣ.)

wabaOa, aor. yawobaOu; (Ḳ; contr. to rule, which requires that the aor. should be yabaA; MF;) and wb-O↓; He put the utensils, or goods, one upon another; or packed them up: or he prepared, set in order, or arranged, them; syn. EabaOa. (Ḳ.)

wabaOa Uilayohi; (Ṣ, Ḳ: Ibn-El-Mukarram says, I think that Th has mentioned wabaOotu, without teshdeed; but I am not confident of it; TA;) and AwbO↓, inf. n. UiyobaMCN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) dial. vars. of wamaOa and OawomaOa; (Ṣ;) He made a sign to him: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or AwbO Alyh signifies he made a sign to him with his fingers, forwards, that he should approach; and AwmO Alyh “he made a sign to him with his fingers, backwards, that he should retire, or remain behind.” So accord. to the Ḳ; but this is at variance with what the leading lexicographers have transmitted. In the L it is said, wbO Alyh and AwbO are dial. syns. of wmO and AwmO he made a sign to him: or, accord. to some, AwmO Alyh signifies “he made a sign with his hand to him, (i. e., to a person before him,) turning his fingers towards the palm of his hand, in order that he should approach him;” [in doing which, the palm of the hand is held towards the person beckoned;] and AwbA Olyh↓ he made a sign to him; (i. e., to a person behind him,) opening his fingers [from the palm] towards the back of the hand, in order that he should retire, or remain behind; [in doing which, the palm of his hand is towards himself]. El-Ferezdaḳ says,
taraI Aln-aAsa Uino sironaA yasiyruwna xalofanaA
waUino naHonu wab-aOonaA UilaI↓ Aln-aAsi waq-afuwA
[If we journey on, thou seest the people journey on behind us; and if we make a sign to the people to remain behind, they stop, one after another]. OawobaOonaA↓ is also read in this verse for wab-aOonaA. Ibn-Buzruj says, that AwmO signifies “he made a sign with the eyebrows, and the eyes;” and wb-O↓, he made a sign with the hands, and a garment, and the head. (TA.)
wabaOato Uilayohi, aor. tabaOu, She (a camel) yearned towards it [i. e., towards her young one]; or uttered to it the cry produced by yearning: syn. Han-ato. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.

hom.sense: 4. AwbO It became unwholesome: syn. SaAra wabiyoOF. (TA.)
See 1.
OuwbiYa He (a young weaned camel) suffered in the stomach from indigestion, in consequence of repletion. (Ḳ, TA.)
maACN laA yuwbiYu, like yuwbiI, Water that does not fail, or stop. The like is said of pasture. (TA.)

entry.sense: 10. AstwbA (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and twb-O↓ (TA) He found, or deemed, a country, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or water, (TA,) unhealthy, or unwholesome: (Ḳ, TA:) [see wabaON:] or, much afflicted with disease. (Ṣ.)

wabaON and wabaMCN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and also without _u, [wabFA,] (TA,) Plague, or pestilence; syn. TaAEuwnN: (Ḳ:) or a common, or general, [or an epidemic,] disease: (Ṣ:) or any such disease: (Ḳ:) or a quickness, and commonness, of death among men. (TA.) Accord. to Ibn-En-Nefees, it is a corruption happening to the substance of the air, by reason of causes in the heavens or the earth; as stinking water, and carcases, such as are the result of bloody battles. Accord. to the hakeem Dá-ood, it is a change effected in the air by events in the higher regions, as the conjunction of beaming stars; and by events in the lower regions, as bloody battles, and the opening of graves, and the ascending of putrid exhalations; with which causes conspire the changes of the seasons and elements, and the revolutions of the universe. They mention also its signs; among which are fever, small-pox, defluxions, itch or scab, tumours, &c. What is said in the Nuzheh necessarily implies that the TAEwn is one of the different kinds of wbA; as the physicians hold to be the case:
but the opinion which the critics among the professors of practical law and the relaters of traditions hold is, that these two diseases are distinct, the one from the other; the wbA being an unwholesomeness in the air, in consequence of which diseases become common among men; and the TAEwn being that kind [of disease] with which men are smitten by the jinn, or genii: an opinion which they corroborate by the words in a trad. Uin-ahu waHozu OaEodaAYikumo mina Aljin-i [Verily it is the unpenetrating thrusting of your enemies among the jinn]. (TA.) The pl. of wabaON is OawobaMCu; and of wabaMCN↓ OawobiyapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) or OawobiYapN. (CK.)
biYapN The state of a land being afflicted with wabaO. (Ḳ.)
OaroDN wabiYapN, and wabiyoYapN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and mawobuwoCapN↓, (Ṣ, L,) and muwbiYapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) a land much, or often, afflicted with wabaO: (Ḳ:) or, much afflicted with disease. (Ṣ.)
wabaACN: see wabaON.
wabiIoCN Sick; unwell; (IAạr:) See OroDN wabiYapN.
wabiIoCN Unwholesome water. (TA.)
muwbiYN Engendering wabaO. (TA.)

juroEapa XaruwbK OanofaEu mino EacobK muwbK A draught of brackish water is more profitable than sweet water that engenders wabaO. (A trad.) Here the _u is omitted in the last word to assimilate it to Xrwb. It is a proverb, applied to two men; one, superior in station, and more slim; the other, inferior in station, but more useful. (TA.)
See wabiYapN.
muwbiYN Water that is little in quantity; and failing, or stopping. (Ḳ.)
mawobuwoCapN: see OaroDN wabiYahN.
1. wabata biAlmakaAni, aor. yabitu, (inf. n. wabotN, L,) He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, in the place. (Ḳ.)

2. wb-xhu, inf. n. tawobiyxN, He reproved him, or lamed him, (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) bisuwoCi fiEolihi for his evil action or conduct: (L:) reproved or blamed him, or did so severely, or with the utmost severity; and threatened him: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) reproached or upbraided him. (El-Fárábee, Mṣb.) Ab-xhu is a dial. form of the same: (IAạr:) or its hemzeh is a substitute for the w. (ISd.)
waboxapN A burning reproof: (L:) as also wmoxapN; (IAạr;) in which the b is changed into m because of the nearness of their places of utterance. (AM.)

1. wabida, (Ḳ,) aor. yawobadu, (TA,) inf. n. wabadN, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) It (life, or manner of living,) was, or became, hard, strait, or difficult: (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ:) it (a man's state, or condition,) was, or became, evil, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) by reason of the largeness of his family, and the littleness of his property: (M, L:) you say wabidato HaAluhu. (M, L.) See also wabadN below.
wabida Ealayohi, (Ṣ, M, L,) aor. _a {yawobadu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. wabadN, (M, L, Ḳ,) He was angry with him: (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ:) like wamida. (Ṣ, L.)
wabida, aor. _a {yawobadu}, inf. n. wabidN, It [a day, &c.] was, or became, hot, (M, L, Ḳ,) and without wind: (M, L:) like wamida. (M, L.)
wabida, aor. _a {yawobadu}, inf. n. wabadN, It (a garment) became old and worn-out. (M, L, Ḳ.)
wabodN: see wabadN.

wabadN Hardness, straitness, or difficulty, of life, or manner of living: evilness of one's state, or condition, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) by reason of the largeness of his family, and the littleness of his property: (M, L:) indigence; (M;) poverty, adversity; (T, L;) largeness of family, and littleness of property: (Ḳ:) pl. OawobaAdN. See 1.

wabadN, an inf. n. used as an epithet, and [therefore] sing. and pl., A man, and men, in an evil state, or condition: and sometimes OawobaAdN is used as its pl.; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) as though it were imagined to be a proper epithet: (Ṣ, L:) or this is for cawuwA OawobaAdK: (M, L:) also musotawobidN↓ signifies the same [applied to a single person]: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) and wabadN, (TA,) or wabodN↓, (L,) a poor man: pl. OawobaAdN. (L, TA.)
wabadN A vice, fault, or defect. (M, L, Ḳ.)
musotawobidN: see wabadN.
1. wabira, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. _a {yawobaru}, inf. n. wabrN, (Mṣb,) He (a camel) had much wabar [i. e. fur, or soft hair]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

hom.sense: waborN, a pl. [or rather a coll. gen. n.] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is with p {waborapN}; (Ṣ, Mgh;) or a masc. n., of which the fem. is with p, (Lth, T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and also a pl. [or coll. gen. n.], (M,) [The hyrax Syriacus; believed to be the animal called in Hebr. שָׁפָן;] a certain small beast, (Lth, T, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like the cat, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) or of the size of the cat, (Lth, T, M, Mgh,) or smaller than the cat, (Ṣ,) of the beasts of the desert, (M,) of a dust-colour, (Lth, T, Mgh, Mṣb,) or of a hue between dust-colour and white, (TaHolaMCu, this epithet being applied to waborapN, Ṣ,) or white, (TA,) having beautiful eyes, (Lth, T, Mgh,) or having eyes bordered with black, or very black eyes, (kaHolaMCu, Mṣb,) having no tail, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or having a small tail, (Mgh,) [Golius says, on the authority of Dmr., “longiore caudâ,” which is a mistake, for it has no tail,] said to be of the weasel-kind, (Mṣb,) very shy, (Lth, T, Mgh,) living in low grounds, (Lth, T,) and dwelling in houses [of its own or of men], (Ṣ,) or it is confined in houses, and is taught; and it is eaten, because it feeds upon leguminous plants: (Mgh:) it is [said to be] a ruminant; [but this is not the case;] and therefore it is said in a trad., that when a man in a state of UiHoraAm kills it, he must sacrifice a sheep or goat: (TA:) [a full and correct description of this animal is given in art. “Shaphan” of Dr. Kitto's “Cyclopædia of Biblical Literature:”] pl. wibaArN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and wubuwrN and wibaArapN (M, Ḳ) and UibaArapN, (M, TA,) with hemzeh in the place of the w. (TA.) One says, fulaAnN OasomaHu mino mux-api Alwabori [Such a one is more liberal than the marrow of the webr]: because the marrow of the webr comes forth easily. (IAạr, T.) And fulaAnN Oacam-u mina AlwibaArapi [Such a one is more dispraised than the webrs]. (Fr, T.)

Alwaboru One of the days called Oay-aAmu AlEajuwzi, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) which are seven, falling at the end of winter: or it is called waborN, without the article: for the Arabs say, Sin-N waSin-aboro waOaxay-uhumaA waboro [Ṣinn and Ṣinnabr and their little brother Webr]: but this may be for the sake of the rhyme. (M.)

entry.sense: wabarN The Suwf, [here meaning the fur, or soft hair,] of the camel, (Lth, T, Ṣ,* M, A, Ḳ,) and of the hare or rabbit, and the like; (Lth, T, M, A, Ḳ;) and in like manner, that of the sam-uwr [or sable], and of the fox, and of the fanak [or marten]: (T:) or it is to the camel like wool (Swf) to the sheep; and so to the hare or rabbit, and the like: (Mṣb:) originally an inf. n.: (Mṣb:) n. un. with p {wabarapN}: (Ṣ:) pl. OawobaArN. (M, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

Oaholu Alwabari ‡ The people of the deserts; [or rather the people of the tents;] because they make their tents of the wabar of camels [as well as of goat's hair, which is not included in the term wabarN, but is called XaEarN]: opposed to Oaholu Almadari the people of the cities and of the towns and villages. (TA.) See also madarN.
Oaxaca AlX-aIoCa biwabarihi ‡ He took the thing altogether; he took the whole of the thing: as also Oaxacahu bizawobarihi. (A.)

wabirN A camel having much wabar [i. e. fur, or soft hair]; (Ṣ, M,* A,* Mṣb, Ḳ;) and in like manner, a hare or rabbit, and the like; (Ḳ;) as also Oawobaru↓: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) fem. of the former, wabirapN; (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and of the latter, waboraMCu. (M, A, Ḳ.)
Oawobaru: see wabirN.

banaAtu Oawobara, (Aṣ, AʼObeyd, AḤn, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and banaAtu AlOawobari, (AZ, T, Ṣ, M,) the art. being added by poetic license, (M,) A species of kamoOap [or truffles], downy, (AZ, Aṣ, AʼObeyd, T, Ṣ, M, [the epithet thus rendered is written in copies of the Ḳ muzogibapN, and in the T, Ṣ, M, muzag-ibapN, but in art. zgb in the TA it seems to be indicated that it is probably muzogib-apN,]) small, and of the colour of earth: (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ:)
or, accord. to AḤn, truffles (kmOp) like pebbles, small, found in places where they have broken through the crust of the soil, in number from one to ten; they are bad in flavour; and are the first of kmOp: or, as he says in another place, they are like kmOp, but are not kmOp; and they are small: (M: [see also jaboCN:]) n. un. Uibonu Oawobara. (Aṣ, AʼObeyd, T.) You say, Uin-a baniI fulaAnK mivolu banaAti Oawobara [Verily the sons of such a one are like benát-owbar]: one imagines that there is good in them [when there is none]. (M.) And laqiytu minohu banaAta Oawobara I experienced from him [a disappointment, or] a calamity, or misfortune. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
daAhiyapN waboraMCu, (Ṣ, A, art. XEr), ‡ An evil, a foul, or an abominable, calamity, or misfortune. (TA, voce OaXoEaru, q. v.)
2. wb-X (TA,) or wb-X OawobaAXFA, (Ṣ, L,) inf. n. tawobiyXN, (TA,) He collected companies, bodies, or forces, of various tribes, for war. (Ṣ,* L, TA.)

waboXN (ISd, TA,) and wabaXN↓ (ISd, Ḳ,) sings. of OawobaAXN (ISd, Ḳ, TA) which signifies A medley, or mixed multitude; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and the lowest or basest or meanest sort, or refuse, or riffraff; (A, Ḳ;) of men, or people; (Ṣ, TA;) or of troops, or soldiers; (A;) like OawoXaAbN; [and similar to OaXowaAbN, but more particular;] and said to be a pl., formed by transposition, of bawoXN [q. v.]: (Ṣ) or sundry, or separate, sorts, of men, or people: (Aṣ, ISd, TA:) and of trees and plants: (ISd, TA:) or a small number, and those separate, of trees and plants. (A, TA.)
[Hence, app.,] waboXu AlkalaAmi † What is bad of speech, or language. (TA.)
wabaXN: see waboXN.

1. wabaSa, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yabiSu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. wabiySN (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and waboSN (M, Ḳ) and biSapN, (M, TA,) said of lightning, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and of other things, (Ṣ, M,) It shone, gleamed, or glistened. (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, [also,] wabaSati Aln-aAru, inf. n. wabiySN, The light shone, or shone brightly; accord. to AḤn; and OawobaSato↓ naAriI, signifies my light shone, or shone brightly: (M:) or the latter signifies my light showed its flame: (Ḳ:) or my light began to show its flame: (ISk, Ṣ:) or AwbSt↓ Aln-aAru signifies the fire appeared on being struck. (TA.) And wabiySu AlT-iybi signifies The shining of perfume. (Mgh, TA.)

hom.sense: 4: see 1.
[Hence,] AwbSt AlOaroDu † The land began to show its plants, or herbage. (ISk, Ṣ.)
OawobaSotu naAriI I made my fire to burn, or blaze, intensely. (A.)

entry.sense: wabaSapN: see waAbiSN.

waboSaAnu (Fr, M, Ḳ) and wuboSaAn, (IDrd, Ḳ,) [or wabuSaAnN and wabiSaAnN, (see art. bSn,)] in some copies of the Jm., buS-aAnN, [which see in art. bS,] (TA,) The month of rabiyEN AlMxiru: (M, Ḳ:) i. e. the name of that month in the Time of Ignorance: pl. waboSaAnaAtN. (TA.)
wabiySapN: see waAbiSN.
wab-aASN: see what follows, in four places.

waAbiSN Shining, gleaming, or glistening: (Mṣb:) and wab-aASN↓, (as in some copies of the Ḳ,) or both, (M,) shining, gleaming, or glistening, much: (M, and some copies of the Ḳ:) or the latter, shining, gleaming, or glistening much in colour; (so in other copies of the Ḳ;) in which last sense, both are added to the epithet OaboyaDu: (TA:) and wab-aASN↓, applied to a cloud, signifies also intensely shining, or gleaming, with lightning. (M.) You say qamari wab-aASN↓ [A moon shining brightly]. (A.) And Alwab-aASu↓ signifies The moon. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

raHulN waAbiSapu Als-amoEi, (M,) or waAbiSapu samoEK, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) means A man who relies upon what is said to him: such a man is called OucunN: and the epithet is made fem. because OucunN is meant: or the p may be added to render it intensive: (M:) or the meaning is, who trusts in all that he hears: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or who hears speech and trusts in it: (A:) or who hears what is said and relies upon it, and thinks it true, but is not yet sure. (TA.) You say also, waAbaSapu samoEK bifulaAnK [One who relies upon what he hears of, or from, such a one]: and waAbiSapu samoEK bihecaA AlOamori [One who relies upon what he hears of this affair]. (TA.)
wat-N (L, Ḳ) and wut-N and wut-apN (Ḳ) or wat-apN (L) The cry of the bird called waraXaAn. (AA, L, Ḳ.) OawotaI signifies He cried as cries the wrXAn. (IAạr, L.)
wataAwitu i. q. wasaAwisu Evil suggestions, &c. (Ḳ.) The s is thus changed, in poetry, into t, as in naAtN and OakoyaAtN. (MF.)
1. wataOa, aor. yataOu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. watoCN, (TA,) He was heavy and slow in his gait, by reason of age, or by nature. (Ḳ.) Not mentioned by J. because esteemed by him not chaste. (TA.)
tayotaO: see art. tO.

1. wataba, aor. yatibu, inf. n. watobN, He remained fixed in the place, and did not move. (Ḳ.) Omitted by most of the lexicographers; and said by some to be a word mispronounced [app. for wavaba]. (TA.)
1. watuHa, aor. yawotuHu, inf. n. wataAHapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and wutuwHapN (Ḳ) and watoHapN, (L,) It (a thing, Ṣ, or a gift, Ḳ) was little, or small, and paltry, mean, or contemptible. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
wataHa EaTaMCahu, aor. yatiHu; (Ḳ;) and AwtHhu↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and wat-Hhu↓, inf. n. tawotiyHN; (Ṣ;) He made his gift little, or small, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and paltry, mean, or contemptible. (Ḳ.)
AwtH↓ lahu AlX-aIoCa He made the thing little to him. (L.)
AwtH↓ He became a person of little property. (Ḳ)
2: see 1 and 4.
4: see 1.
AwtH fulaAnFA He harassed and distressed him; syn. jahadahu wabalaga minohu; (L, Ḳ;) and in like manner, AwtH jahodahu, and AwtH minohu, and wt-H↓. (L.)
AwatH, in this sense, occurs in a verse as related by Th: as related by IAạr it is Awtx. (TA.)
5. twt-H mina AlXraAbi He drank a little of the beverage: (Ṣ, L:) or, as also twt-H AlX-araAba, he drank the beverage by little and little. (TA.)

XaIoCN watoHN, and watiHN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and wataHN↓, and watiyHN↓, (Ḳ,) A little, or small, and paltry, mean, or contemptible, thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) One says also XaIoCN wataHN waEorN A small, or little, or scanty, thing: the latter of the two epithets being an imitative sequent; (Ṣ;) or, correctly, a corroborative. (Marg. note in a copy of the Ṣ.)
maA OagonaI wEan-iI wataHapF↓, a phrase like mA AgnI En-I EabakapF, (L,) or He, or it, was of no profit, or advantage, to me. (L, Ḳ.)
TaEaAmN watoHN Food in which is no good; like waHotN. (L.)
rajulN watHN↓ A vile, mean, or contemptible, man. (Ṣ.)
wataHN see watoHN.
wtiHN see watoHN.
wataHapN see watoHN.
watiyHN see watoHN.

1. watada, aor. yatidu, imp. tido, inf. n. watodN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, &c.) and tidapN; (M, L, Ḳ, &c.;) and Awtd↓; (A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and wt-d↓, (M, Mgh,) inf. n. tawotiydN; (TA;) He knocked with a mallet, (Mgh,) and fixed, or made from or fast, a wooden pin, peg, or stake, (Ṣ,* M, A,* L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in the ground or in a wall. (Mṣb.)
watada, (M, L, Ḳ,) [aor. yatidu,] inf. n. watodN and tidapN; (M, L;) and wt-d↓; (M, L, Ḳ;) It (a wooden pin, peg, or stake,) was, or became, fixed, firm, or fast. (M, L, Ḳ.)
wat-ada Qll-ehu AlOaroDa biAljibaAli, and OawotadahaA↓, ‡ [God made the earth firm, or fast by means of the mountains]. (A.)
wt-d↓ rjolahu fiI AlOaroDi † He fixed his foot firmly upon the ground. (L.)
wt-d↓ fiI bayotihi ‡ He remained fixed in his house. (L.)
wt-d↓ It (growing corn) put forth its stalks, and became firm and strong. (L.)
wt-d↓, (Ṣ, L,) inf. n. tawotiydN, (Ḳ,) ‡ Libidine veneres exarsit vir: (Ṣ, L:) erexit penem. (Ḳ.)

It was said to an Arab of the desert, What is naToXaAn? and he answered, yuwat-idu↓ AlEaToXaAna ‡ [It corroborates the word ETXAn]: or, as some relate it, XaIoCN natidu bihi kalaAmanaA [A thing, meaning a word, by which we corroborate our speech]. (A.)
2: see 1.
4: see 1.
watadN and watodN and wad-N: see watidN.

watidN, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ, &c.,) of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz, and the most chaste form, (Mṣb,) and watadN↓, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and watodN↓, (L, Ḳ,) and wad-N↓, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) of the dial. of Nejd, (Mṣb,) the t being made quiescent, and then changed into d, and incorporated into the final d, (Ṣ,* Mṣb,) and watiydN↓, (L, art. wd,) A wooden pin, peg, or stake, which is fixed in the ground or in a wall: (M, L, Ḳ:) pl. OawotaAdN. (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ.) [You say,] Oacal-u mano watidK biqaAEK [More vile than a wooden peg in a plain]: because it is always knocked. A proverb. (TA.)
watidN waAtidN, an expression like XugolN XaAglN, (Aṣ, Ṣ,) the latter word a corroborative; (Ḳ;) or A wooden pin, peg, or stake, firm, or fast, (A, L,) and erect. (L.)
OawotaAdu AlOaroDi ‡ [lit. The pegs, or stakes, of the earth; i. e.] the mountains: (A, L, Ḳ:) so called because they make the earth firm, or fast. (L.)
OawotaAdu AlbilaAdi † The chiefs of the towns, provinces, or countries. (L, Ḳ.)
OawotaAdu Alfam ‡ The teeth. (L, Ḳ, TA.)
watidN, of a sandal, † The part that projects from the ear [or loop]. (L.)

watidN † [A peg of a bayot, q. v.;] a portion, or division, of a foot of a verse, consisting of three letters: (L, Ḳ *:) it is of two kinds: one consisting of two movent letters followed by a quiescent letter; as faEuw and Eiluno; which kind is called watidN maqoruwnN, a conjoined peg; because each two letters are conjoined by a vowel: the other consisting of three letters; one movent, then one quiescent, then one movent; as laAtu in mafoEuwlaAtu; which kind is called watidN maforuwqN, a disjoined peg; because the quiescent letter disjoins the two movent letters: pl. OawotaAdN. ziHaAf does not take place in the AwtAd, because the foot depends upon them; but it does in the OasobaAb. (L.)

watidN (A, L, Ḳ) and watidapN (L) of the ear., ‡ [The tragus;] the small prominent thing in the anterior part, (A, L, Ḳ,) like a teat, (A, L,) next the uppermost part of the side of the beard: (L:) or the prominent part next the temple: (L:) or the watidaAni of the two ears are the two parts in the interior thereof resembling a watid, also called the EayoraAni. (Ṣ.)
watiydN: see watidN.
waAtidN ‡ A man standing fixed, or firm, or motionless. (A, L.)
‡ An erect horn. (A.)
Fixing, or making firm or fast, a wooden pin, peg, or stake. (L.)
mawotuwdN A wooden pin, peg, or stake, fixed, or made firm or fast. (L.)
miytadapN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and miytadN (L, Ḳ) A mallet (mirozab-ah, L, Ḳ,) with which wooden pins, pegs, or stakes are knocked [into the ground or a wall]. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. watarahu, aor. yatiruhu, inf. n. watorN; (Mṣb;) and Awtrhu↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) He made it, (a number, Mṣb,) sole; or one, and no more: syn. Oafac-ahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or Oaforadahu. (Mṣb.) It is said that the latter verb only is used in relation to a number; but both are said to be thus used in the M [as well as in the Mṣb.] (TA.)

[And He made it to be an odd number.] You say, watara Alqawoma, (M, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yatiru}, inf. n. watorN; (M;) and Oawotarahumo↓; (M, Ḳ;) He made the people, they being an even number, to be an odd number. (M, Ḳ, TA.) ʼAṭà says, kaAna Alqawomu witorFA faXafaEotuhumo wakaAnuwA XafoEFA fawatarotuhumo [The people were an odd number and I made them an even number, and they were an even number and I made them an odd number]. (TA.) You say also, watara AlS-alaApa, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and OawotarahaA↓, (T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and wat-arahaA↓, (Ḳ,) and Oawotara↓ fiI AlS-alaApi, (Lḥ, M,) He made the prayer to be such as is termed witor [i. e., to consist of an odd number of rek'as; as is done in the case of a prayer which is performed in the night, consisting of three rek'ahs, and particularly called SalaApu Alwitori]; (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ;*) he performed prayers of double rek'ahs, two and two together, and then performed the prayer of one rek'ah at the end, making what he performed an odd number: (T:) and Oawotara↓, alone, signifies he performed the prayer called Alwitor [explained above]; (T, M, A, Mgh, Ḳ;) or he performed prayers of [an odd number of rek'ahs,] two and two together, and then a single rek'ah at the end. (TA.) It is said in a trad. Uin-a Qll-eha witorN yuHib-u Alwitora faOawotiruwA yaA Oahola AlquroMni [Verily God is one only: He loveth the odd number: therefore perform ye the prayer of an odd number of rek'ahs, O people of the Ḳur-án]. (T.) And in another trad., UicaA Qsotajomarota faOawotiro When thou employest stones in the purification termed UisotinojaMC, use an odd number; (TA;) i. e. use three stones for that purpose, or five, or seven, and not an even number. (T.)

watarahu, (T, Ṣ, A, Mgh,) aor. yatiruhu, inf. n. watorN (Ṣ,) and witorN and tirapN, (T, Ṣ,) He slew his relation, and so separated him from him, and rendered him solitary: (A, Mgh:) or he slew a person belonging to him, or related to him, without the latter's obtaining revenge, or retaliation, for the blood of the slain: (Ṣ:) or he slew a person belonging to him, or related to him; or took property belonging to him. (T.) It is also doubly trans.: you say, watara fulaAnN fulaAnFA Oaholahu Such a one committed a crime against such a one by slaying his family; or by taking them away: (T:) and watarapu maAlahu (T, M, Ḳ) † he committed a crime against him by taking away his property: (T:) or † he made him to suffer loss or detriment in respect of his property; or he deprived him of it in part, or altogether; syn. naqaSahu Uiy-aAhu: (T,* M, Ḳ:) and watarahu Haq-ahu, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. as above, (Mṣb,) ‡ he made him to suffer loss or detriment in respect of his right or due; or he abridged him, or deprived him, or defrauded him, of it partially, or wholly; syn. nqShu. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., mano faAtatohu SalaApu AlEaSori fakaOan-amaA wutira Oaholahu wamaAlahu (T, M,* Mṣb,* TA) By whomsoever the prayer of the afternoon passeth unobserved, he is as though he had his family slain and his property taken away: or as though he had his family and his property taken away: (T:) or as though he were deprived (nuqiSa) of his family and his property, (T, M, Mṣb, TA,) and remained alone: (T, TA:) the loss of the family and property is thus likened to the loss of the recompense: Ahlh and mAlh being in the accus. case as objective complements: (Mṣb:) Ahlh is a second objective complement: for the first is understood, as implied in the verb: but if we read Oaholuhu wamaAluhu, accord. to another relation, Ahlh supplies the place of the agent, nothing being understood, and the family and property are the objects to which the loss is made to relate. (TA.) And it is said in another trad., mano jalasa majolisFA lamo yacokuri Qll-eha fiyhi kaAna Ealayohi tirapF † He who sitteth in an assembly in which God is not mentioned is obnoxious to detriment, or loss: or, as some say, to a claim of reparation for wrongful conduct. (TA.) And it is said in the Ḳur, [xlvii. 37,] walana yatirakumo OaEomaAlakumo † And He will not deprive you of aught of the recompence of your deeds: (Zj, T:) or will not make you to suffer loss in respect of your deeds; like as you say daxalotu Albayota, meaning daxalotu fiI Albayoti. (Ṣ.)

[Also,] watarahu, (M, Ḳ,) aor. yatiruhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. watorN (M, Ḳ) and witorN (TA) and tirapN, (M, Ḳ,) He executed blood-revenge upon him: or did so wrongfully: (M,* Ḳ,* TḲ:) expl. by OaSaAbahu bicaHolK. (TḲ.)
He overtook him (Oadorakahu) with some displeasing, or abominable, or evil, action. (M, Ḳ.)
He frightened him; terrified him. (Fr, Ḳ.)
watara Alqawosa: see 2, in two places.
2. wt-r AlS-alaApa: see 1, near the beginning.

wt-r Alqawosa He fastened, bound, firmly, or braced, the string of the bow; expl. by Xad-a watarahaA; (Lḥ, M, Ḳ;) as also OawotarahaA↓; (Lḥ, M, Mṣb;) both these signify the same; (Ṣ, in which the meaning is not explained;) and watarahaA↓, (M, TA,) inf. n. watorN: (TA:) or AwtrhA↓ signifies he put to it a string: (M, Ḳ:) and watarahaA↓, (M, Ḳ,) aor. yatiruhaA, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tirapN, (TA,) he attacked to it its string: (M, Ḳ:) this, accord. to some, is the proper signification of the last. (M.) It is said in a proverb, UinobaADN bigayori tawotiyrK [Twanging the bow without bracing the string]: (Ṣ:) or laA tuEojili AlUinobaADa qabola Alt-awotiyri [Hasten not the twanging of the bow before the bracing of the string]: alluding to the hastening a thing before its proper time. (M.) [See also art. nbD. And see 2 in arts. jnb and Hnb.]

entry.sense: 3. wAtr bayona OaxobaArihi, (A, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or Oawotara↓, (M, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) and byn kutubihi, (M,) and wAtr OaxobaArahu, (M, Ḳ; in the latter of which waAtarahu is put by mistake for waAtarahaA, as is observed in the TA,) and kutubahu, (M, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. muwaAtarapN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and witaArN, (M, Ḳ,) He made his tidings, or narrations, and his writings, or letters, to follow one another: (M, A, Ḳ:) or with some intervals between them; for mwAtrp between things is only when there is some interval between them; otherwise it is mudaArakapN and muwaASalapN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or wAtr Alkutuba signifies he made the writings, or letters, to follow one another nearly, one by one, without ceasing: (Ṣ:) or he made them to follow one another with a small interval between every two: (T:) and waAtr Alxabara he made the tidings, or narration, to follow one part after another: or, accord. to Aṣ, with a small space between every two portions thereof: from witorN in the sense of farodN. (T.) You say also waAtr bayona miyarihimo He made their supplies of wheat to come to them without stopping; time after time. (TA, from a trad.) And it is said in a trad., laA baOosa Oano yuwaAtira qaDaMCa ramaDaAna There will be no harm in his performing the fast of Ramadán at intervals, fasting one day and breaking fast one day: (TA:) muwaAtarapu AlS-awomi is the fasting one day and breaking fast one day, or two; performing it separately: it does not mean AlmuwaASalapu, because it is from Alwitoru, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) i. e., Alfarodu. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4: see 1, in seven places, first part.
Awtr bayona OaxobaArihi: see 3.
Awtrhu He made him to attain, or obtain, his blood-revenge. (Az, TA; and L in art. vOr.) See an ex., voce vaOorN.
Awtr Alqawosa: see 2, in two places.

entry.sense: 5. twt-r ‡ It (a sinew, or nerve, T, M, A, Ḳ, and a vein, M, TA, not the neck, for AlEunuqu in the Ḳ is a mistake for AlEiroqu, TA) became tense, (M, Ḳ, TA,) like a bow-string. (M, TA.)

6. twAtr It was consecutive: or was so with intervals: (M, A, Ḳ:) or was so with separation, or interruption. (Mṣb.) You say, twAtrt AlUibilu, and AlqaTaA, and so of any other things, The camels, and the birds of the kind called AlqTA, &c., came one near after another, not in a rank. (Lḥ, M.) And twAtrt Alxayolu The horses came following one another. (Mṣb.) And twAtrt Alkutubu The writings, or letters, came one near after another, separately. (Ṣ.)
watorN: see witorN, throughout.

hom.sense: witorN and watorN↓, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) the former, [which is the more common,] in the dial. of Nejd, (Lḥ, M,) and of the tribe of Temeem, (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) and of the people of El-ʼÁliyeh, (ISk, as on the authority of Yoo, and Ṣ) or the latter in the dial. of the people of El-ʼÁliyeh, (T, as on the authority of Yoo,) or of the people of El-Ḥijáz, (Lḥ, Ṣ, M,) Single; sole; only; one, and no more: syn. farodN: (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or maA lamo yuXofaEo mina AlEadadi: (M, A, Ḳ; except that in the Ḳ, instead of yuXofaEo, we find yataXaf-aEo:) or contr. of XafoEN: (Mgh:) [and an odd number:] all [even and odd] numbers are termed [respectively] XafoEN and witorN, whether many or few. (T.)
witorFA witorFA [Singly; separately; one by one]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See XafoEN.]
Alwitoru, one of the names of God, The Single; the Sole; the One; He who has no equal, or like; the Unequalled; syn. Alfac-u and Alfarodu. (TA.)
SalaApu Alwitori, and Alwitoru alone: see 1, first part: it was sometimes said by Moḥammad to be a single rakoEap. (T.)

In the words of the Ḳur, [lxxxix. 2,] waQlX-afoEK waQlowatori by the former is meant all creatures which are created in pairs; and by the latter, God: (T:) or [by the former, Adam and his wife; and] by the latter, Adam, who was made a pair with his wife: (I’Ab, T:) or by the former, the day of the sacrifice; (T;) and by the latter, the day of ʼArafeh. (T, Ḳ.) [See more voce XafaEN.]

Also witorN and watorN↓, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the former, [which is the more common,] in the dial. of Nejd, (Lḥ, M,) and of the tribe of Temeem, (Lḥ, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) and of the people of El-ʼÁliyeh, (T, as on the authority of Yoo,) and El-Ḥijáz, (Ṣ,) or the latter in the dial. of the people of El-'Aliyeh, (ISk, as on the authority of Yoo, and Ṣ) and El-Ḥijáz, (Lḥ, M,) Blood-revenge; or retaliation of murder or homicide: or a seeking to revenge, or retaliate, blood: or a desire, or seeking, for retaliation of a crime or of enmity: syn. caHolN: (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or wrongful conduct therein: as also tirapN↓ and watiyrapN↓, in either sense: (M, Ḳ:) or a crime which a man commits against another by slaughter or by plundering or by capture: (TA:) pl. [of witorN] OawotaArN and [of tirapN] tiraAtN. (A.)

entry.sense: watarN The string, and the suspensory, syn. XiroEap and muEal-aq [the latter signifying properly the appendage, (see xaTama Alqawosa biAlwatari, and see nayATN,)] (M, Ḳ,) of a bow: (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [and in like manner, a chord of a lute and the like:] pl. OawotaArN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and witaArN. (Fr, Ṣgh, TA.)
Also pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of watarapN [q. v.] in all the senses of the latter. (Ḳ.)

watarapN, of the nose, The partition between the two nostrils [consisting of the septum and subseptum narium, or the subseptum alone]; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb;) as also watiyrapN↓: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or the former signifies what is between the two nostrils: (M:) or the junction that is between the two nostrils: (T:) or the edge of the nostril: (M, Ḳ:) accord. to Lḥ, (M,) what is between the tip of the nose and the sabalap [or middle of the mustache; app. meaning, the subseptum narium]: (M, Ḳ:) and the latter, the partition between the two nostrils, of the fore part of the nose, exclusive of the cartilage; [i. e., app. the subseptum narium:] (AZ, T:) and the former, in a horse, what is between the tip of the nose and the upper part of the lip: (M:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of the former, in all its senses, watarN. (Ḳ.) In a trad. in which it is said that the fine for destroying the watarap is a third of the fine for homicide, by this word is meant the watarap of the nose. (TA.)
The sinew, or nerve, (Eaqabap,) of the back (mtn). (M.)
watiyrN: see watiyrapN, near the end.

hom.sense: watiyrapN: see witorN.

A way, course, mode, or manner of acting, or conduct, or the like: (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and nature, or disposition: (A, Mgh:) from tawaAtara: (Th, M, A, Mgh:) or a road keeping close to a mountain, (Ḳ, TA,) and pursuing a regular, uniform course: (TA:) or constancy, or perseverence, in a thing, (AO, T, Mṣb, TA,) or in a work. (TA.) You say, maAzaAla EalaI watiyrapK waAHidapK He ceased not to follow, or continue in, one way, (&c.,) of acting or the like: (T, Ṣ, M, A:) or one disposition. (A.) And humo EalaI watiyrapK waAHidapK They follow, or continue in, one way,, &c. (A, Mgh, Mṣb.)

Remissness, or languor, syn. fatorapN, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in an affair: (M, Ḳ:) and syn tawaAnK [which signifies the same]: and faultiness; syn. gamiyzapN, (M, Ḳ, [in some copies of the latter, gamiyrapN, with the unpointed r.]) You say, maA fiI Eamalihi watiyrapN There is no remissness, or languor, in his work. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb.) And sayorN layosa fiyhi watiyrapN A journeying, or pace, in which is no remissness, or languor. (Ṣ.)
Delay. (M, Ḳ.)
Confinement; restriction; restraint. (M, Ḳ.)
I. q. watarapN, as explained above.

A ring (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) of Eaqab [or sinew], (Ṣ,) by aiming at which one learns the art of piercing with the spear; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) also called dariyoYapN: (Ṣ:) or a ring that is made at the end of a spear or spear-shaft, by aiming at which one learns the art of shooting, or casting [the lance]; made of bow-string or of other string or thread. (M.)
A white rose: (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) or red rose: (Kr, M, Ḳ:) or a rose-flower; a rose-blossom: (AḤn, M, Ḳ:*) n. un. of watiyrN↓. (AḤn. M.)

A star, or blaze, or white mark, on the forehead or face of a horse, when round, (T, M, A, Ḳ,) and small: (A:) when long, it is called XaAdixapN: (AO, T:) likened to the ring above mentioned, thus called; (T;) or to a white rose, which is also thus called. (A.) See gur-apN.

entry.sense: tirapN: see witorN. The t is substituted for the elided w. (TA.)

jaAWuwA tatoraI, and tatorFI, with and without tenween, and with t substituted for the original incipient w, (T,* Ṣ,* M, A,* Mṣb,* Ḳ,) in the former whereof, (Ṣ, M,) which is the better, (Ṣ,) and the more common, (Fr,) pronounced by Hamzeh and Ibn-'Ámir and Ks with imáleh, [i. e. tetrè,] (Bḍ, xxiii. 46,) the A [which is written I] is a sign of the fem. gender, and in the latter whereof it is an A of quasi-coördination, (Ṣ, M,) from witorN in the sense of farodN, (Ṣ,) They came following one another; one after another; (A, Mṣb;) syn. mutawaAtiriyna: (M, Ḳ:) or interruptedly. (Yoo, T.) It is said in the Ḳur, [xxiii. 46,] vam-a OarosalonaA rusulanaA tatoraI, or tatarFI, Then we sent our apostles one after another: (Ṣ:) or interruptedly; at intervals: (Yoo, T, M:) or making a long time to intervene between every two. (T.)
farasN muwat-aru AlOanosaMCi ‡ A horse contracted in the [veins called] OanosaMC, [pl. of nasFA,] as though they were braced, or made tense. (A,* TA.) See XanijN.

mawotuwrN One who has his relation slain, and so is separated from him, and rendered solitary: (TA:) and one who has a person belonging to him, or related to him, slain, and has not obtained revenge, or retaliation, for his blood: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) a seeker of blood-revenge, or retaliation; one to whom belongs the revenging of blood, or retaliation. (TA.) [See an ex. voce vaOorN.]

mutawAatirN Consecutive, but with small intervals: thus differing from mutadaArikN and matataAbiEN. (Lḥ, M. [But see tataAbaEa.]) You say, jaAWuwA mutawaAtiriyna: explained above, voce tatoraI. (M, Ḳ.) xabarN mutawaAtirN Tidings, or a narration, told, or related, by one from another: (T:) or by one after another. (TA.)
wavowavapN Weakness; impotence. (L.)
wavowaAvN A weak, impotent, man. (L.)

1. wavaOato yaduhu, aor. tavaOu, inf. n. wavoCN; (AZ;) and waviYato, (a form disapproved by some, TA,) aor. the same, inf. n. the same and wavaOo, (Ḳ, TA,) or wavaMCN; (CK and a MṢ. copy) and wavuWato; and wuviYato, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) like EuniIa, [i. e., pass. in form, but neut. in signification,] (Ḳ,) which is the chaste form of the verb; and to the inf. ns. are added, on the anthority of the Wáʼee, wavuwoCN and wavoOapN; (TA;) [but it is not said to which form or forms of the verb these belong;] His hand became affected by what is termed wavoCN. (Ḳ.)
wavaOa yadahu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and AwvO↓, (Ḳ,) He caused his hand to be affected by what is termed wavoCN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Qll-ehum-a vaOayadahu [O God, bruise his hand!, &c.] is a form of curse used by the Arabs. (IAạr.)
wavaOa All-eHoma He, or it, (i. e. a blow,) deadened the flesh. (Ḳ.) Alwatada
wavaOa ‡ i. q. XaE-ava, q. v. (A.)
4: see 1.

wavoCN and wavoOapN A breaking of the flesh without separation of the parts, (waSomN,) not reaching to the bone, (Ḳ,) producing a swelling: (TA:) or a pain in the bone, without fracture: (IḲooṭ, Ḳ:) or a dislocation (Ḳ, TA) and concussion of the joints, which affects the hand, without fracture: (TA:) or [an injury] resembling dislocation; in the flesh as a fracture in a bone: (AM:) or a bruising or breaking of the flesh without breaking the bone: (IAạr.:) or a bruising of the skin and flesh, reaching to the bone, without its breaking: (TA:) or a bruising of the bone, without breaking: (Lth, Ṣ:) in which last sense, Lth uses also the word wavaON. (TA.) The _u in wavoCN is sometimes omitted, and the word is written wavN, like yadN and damN. wavoIN is condemned as vulgar. wavN is authorized by Aṣ; but wavoIN (which is said by the vulgar, Ṣ, [and is disallowed in the Ḳ,]) and wavowN are disallowed by him. (TA.)
waviYN Having a broken hand: (TA: [but see wavoCN:]).
yadN waviYapN, and waviyoYapN↓, (Ḳ,) and mawovuwoCapN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) A hand affected by what is termed wavoCN. (Ḳ.)
waviyYapN and mawovuwoCapN: see waviYN.
miyvaOapN A mallet with which pegs, or stakes, or tent-pins, are driven. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. wavaba, aor. yavibu, inf. n. wavobN and wuvuwbN (the latter agreeable with analogy, TA,) and wavabaAnN and waviybN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and wivAabN (Ḳ; but this is generally affirmed to be an inf. n. of waAvaba, TA;) and vibapN, (Ibn-Málik and others) He leaped; jumped; sprang; bounded: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he leaped down, or downwards. (Mgh, Mṣb, art. Tfr.)
wavaba AlmawoDiEa [He leaped, or jumped, upon, or over the place]. (TA.)
wavaba UilaI AlX-arafi wavobapF ‡ [He made a single leap to eminence, or nobility]. (TA.)
wavaba Uilayohi [app., He leaped, or sprang up, or he hastened, to him]. (TA.)
Alwuvuwbu, except in the dial. of Himyer, signifies The act of rising, or standing up. (TA.)
It is also much used by the vulgar as signifying The act of hastening to a thing; as observed by MF, who is wrong in saying that there is nothing in the lexicons that favours its being so used. (TA.)

wavaba, [aor. yavibu,] inf. n. wavobN, in the dial. of Himyer signifies He sat; sat down. (Ḳ, TA, from a trad.) vibo in that dial. signifies Sit; sit down. (Ṣ.) It is related that Zeyd Ibn-Abd-Allah Ibn-Dárim came as an envoy to one of the kings of Himyer, and found him at a hunting-place belonging to him, on a high mountain, and he saluted him, and mentioned to him his lineage, or relationship; whereupon the king said to him vibo, meaning Uijoliso, Sit; but the man thought that he commanded him to leap from the mountain; and he said, “Thou shalt find me, O king, very obedient:” then he leaped from the mountain, and perished. So the king said, “What ailed him?” And they explained to him his case, and his mistake respecting the word: upon which he said layosato EinodanaA Earabiy-ato mano daxala ZafaAri Ham-ara i. e., [“Arabic is not current with us:” (for, probably, in the time of this king, the term Earabiy-ap was only applied to the general language of Arabia:) “whoso entereth Dhafári,] let him learn [or, rather, speak, as MF says,] the Himyeree language.” (Mz., 16th nwE.) [The principal facts of this anecdote are also mentioned in the Ṣ, on the authority of Aṣ.] By the king's saying Earabiy-ato was meant AlEarabiy-apu: the p is pronounced t in the case of a pause (which is the case here) in their dialect. (Ṣ.) Or, accord. to another relation of the above anecdote, the king said layosa EinodanaA Earabiy-ato kaEarabiy-atokumo [“Arabic like your Arabic is not current with us:”] and this, says ISd, is the right reading in my opinion: for the king did not mean to exclude himself from the Arabs. (MF.)

entry.sense: 2. wt-bh, inf. n. tawoviybN, He seated him upon a cushion: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) asserted to be of the dial. of Himyer. (MF.)
wv-bh wisaAdapF, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in some copies of the Ḳ wavabahu, (TA,) He threw to him a cushion (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) that he might sit upon it: (Ṣ:) [app. in the dial. of Himyer].
wav-abotuhu wivaAbFA I spread for him a bed, or the like. (TA.)
3. wAvbh He leaped, or sprang, upon him, or at him; he assaulted or assailed him; syn. saAwarahu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and vaAwarahu. (Ḳ, art. vwr) and SaAwalahu. (Ḳ, art. Swl.)
[Also, perhaps, He contended with him in leaping, jumping, springing, or bounding.]
[wAvbh is also mentioned in the TA as having a signification not explained in the Ḳ: app., He contended with him in hastening to a thing.]
4. Awvbh He made him to leap, jump, spring, or bound. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
Awvbh AlmawoDiEa [He made him to leap, or jump, upon, or over, the place]. (TA.)
5. twv-b fulaAnN fiI DayoEapK liI ‡ Such a one took possession unjustly of an estate belonging to me; he seized upon it unjustly. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
twv-b fiI OaroDihi EalaI Oaxiyhi ‡ He took possession of his land with injustice towards his brother. (A.)
twv-b EalaI manozilatihi ‡ He took possession unjustly of the place occupied by him. (A.)

6. humo yatawaAvabuwna EalaI kacaA They leap, or rush, together upon such a thing [in an evil, or injurious, or a contentious manner]. (Ṣ, art. klb.) Alt-awaAvubu is syn. with Alt-akaAlubu. (Ṣ, Ḳ, art. klb.)
wavobapN A single leap, jump, spring, a bound: (TA:) or a leap down, or downwards. (Mgh, Mṣb, art. Tfr.)
vubapN An assembly; a company; a troop; a congregated body. (Ḳ.) [But it seems rather to belong to the root vbI, as remarked by Freytag; or, accord. to some, to art. vwb. See arts. vbI and vwb.]
wavabaI: see wav-aAtN.
wivaAbN A throne, or couch; syn. sariyrN; (Ḳ;) accord. to some, that is always occupied by the king; or that the king does not cease to occupy: (TA:) [app. of the dial. of Himyer].

A bed; or what is spread to lie or recline upon: (Ḳ:) ex. wat-abotuhu wivaAbFA I spread for him a bed, or the like: (TA:) or places where persons sit; syn. maqaAEidu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) in which case it is a pl., as some have expressly affirmed it to be: (TA:) accord. to IF and others, of the dial. of Himyer. (MF.) Applied to heaven (Als-amaACu) as being the sittingplaces of the angels. (Ṣ.)
ZaboIN wat-aAbN An antelope that leaps, jumps, springs, or bounds, quickly. farasN wav-aAbapN A mare that leaps, &c., quickly. (TA.)
wavabaI↓ i. q. wav-aAbapN; (Ḳ;) i. e., That leaps, &c., quickly. (TA.)
mawovabaAnN A king who sits still, and does not undertake military expeditions: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) asserted to be of the dial. of Himyer. (MF.)
miyvabN A plain, or level, land, or tract of land. (Ḳ.)
A leaper, or jumper. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
Also, [contr.,] A sitter: (IAạr., Ḳ:) [app. in the dial. of Himyer].
What is elevated, of land. (Ḳ.)
A rivulet, stream, or streamlet: syn. jadowalN. (Ḳ.)
1. wavuja, aor. yawovuju, inf. n. wavaAjapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and Awvj↓, and Astwvj↓; (TA;) It (anything, Ṣ,) became dense; thick; compact. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

wavuja, aor. yawovuju, inf. n. wavaAjapN, He became abundant in flesh; or very fleshy: wavura, inf. n. wavaArapN signifying he became abundant in fat; or very fat: and both signify he became bulky, or big; or large in body, corpulent and fleshy. (AZ, Ṣ.)
wavuja Aln-abotu The herbage, or plants, became dense, thick, or compact, and tall.
4. Oawovijo lanaAmino hecaA AlT-aEaAmi Give us much of this food. (TA.) See 1.

10. Astwvj It became in a complete, or perfect, state: (TA:) or it became so in a certain way: (Ṣ:) one says Astwvj Aln-abotu ‡ the plants, herbs, or herbage, clung together, one part to another, and became in a complete, or perfect, state. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See 1.
Astwvj AlmaAlu The property [app. meaning camels or the like] became much, or abundant. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Astwvj mina AlmaAli He desired, wished for, or longed for, much of property [app. meaning camels or the like]; syn. Asotakovara: (Aṣ, Th, Ṣ, Ḳ *:) as also Astwvq. (TA.)
Astwvjt She (a woman) became large in body, or corpulent and fleshy, and perfect in make. (T.)
waviyjN Anything (Ṣ) dense; thick; compact. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
A horse, (Ṣ,) and a camel, (TA,) compact in flesh: (Ṣ:) or strong. (TA.)
Dense, thick, or compact, herbage. (TA.) [See also OaroDN muwtavijapN.]
vawobN waviyjN ‡ A garment, or piece of cloth, of firm texture. (A.) [See also viyaAbN mawovuwjapN.]
waAvijN, applied to herbage, Dense, thick, or compact, and tall. (TA.)

OaroDN muwtavijapN (in the CK muWotavijapN [which is evidently a mistake]) Land abounding with herbage, or pasture, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and with tangled trees; as also waviyjapN: (ISh:) land of which the herbage is dense, thick, or compact. (TA.) [See also waviyxN.]
viyaAbN mawovuwjapN Garments, or pieces of cloth, of which the threads and texture are slack, or loose. (Ḳ, from Sh, on the authority of a man of Bá- hileh: but see waviyjN. TA.)

hom.sense: 1. wavura, aor. _u {yawovuru}, inf. n. wavaArapN; [and app., watorN; (see the second signification;)] It (a thing, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, or a bed, A) was, or became, plain, level, smooth, soft, or easy to lie or ride or walk upon. (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
wavirati AlEajuzu; and wavurat, inf. n. as above, ‡ The buttocks became fat. (A.) See also wavaArapN, below.

wavarahu, (M, A, Ḳ,) aor. yaviruhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. wavorN (M, TA) and virapN; (TA;) and wv-rhu↓, inf. n. tawoviyrN; (M, A, Ḳ;) He made it plain, level, smooth, soft, or easy to lie or ride or walk upon. (M, A, Ḳ.) And wv-r marokabahu He made the thing on which he rode smooth, soft, or easy to ride upon. (A, Mṣb.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in two places.
4. maA Oawovara firaAXaka How smooth, soft, or easy to lie upon, is thy bed! (A, TA.)
10. Astwvr AlfiraAXa He found, or deemed, the bed smooth, soft, or easy to lie upon. (A,* TA.)
UicaA tazaw-ajota QmoraOapN faQsotawovirohaA ‡ [When thou takest a woman as thy wife, choose her fat, suitable for a bedfellow: see waviyrN]. (A, TA.)
wavorN: see waviyrN.
wivorN: see waviyrN, in three places.
See also miyvarapN, throughout.
wavirN: see waviyrN.
wavaArN: see wivaArN.

hom.sense: wivaArN, a subst., Plainness, levelness, smoothness, softness, or state of being easy to lie or ride or walk upon; as also wavaArN↓. (M, Ḳ.)
See also waviyrN, in two places.

waviyrN Plain, level, smooth, soft, or easy to lie or ride or walk upon; (T, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) as also wivorN↓ (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) and wavorN↓ and wavirN↓; (M, Ḳ;) applied to a bed, (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and anything upon which one sleeps, (T, TA,) or sits, (TA,) and finds it to be thus, (T, TA,) and to other things: (M, Ḳ;) and thick and soft; applied to a bed: (Mṣb:) [and wivaArN↓ seems to signify the same; or this and wavorN↓ are epithets in which the quality of a subst. predominates:] fem. waviyrapN. (M Ḳ.)
You say, maA taHotahu wivorN, and wivaArN, (Ṣ, TA,) There is not beneath him a smooth, or soft, bed. (TA.)

waviyrapN ‡ A woman having much flesh: (IDrd, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or fat; (T, A, Ḳ;) suitable for a bedfellow: (T, Ḳ:) and waviyrapu AlEajuzi ‡ large, (T,) or fat, (A,) or soft, (M,) in the buttocks: (T, M, A:) pl. wavaAYiru and wivaArN. (M, Ḳ.)
See also miyvarapa, throughout.

entry.sense: wavaArapN: see 1.
‡ Abundance of fat: (AZ, Ṣ:) or of flesh: (Ḳ:) or the latter is termed wavaAjapN. (AZ, Ṣ.)
Oawovaru More [and most] smooth, or soft; applied to a bed. (TA, from a trad.)

miyvarapN, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the measure mifoEalapN, from AlwavaArapu, (TA,) without hemz, (Ṣ, TA,) originally miwovarapN, (Mṣb,* TA,) the w being changed into I because of the kesreh before it, (TA,) and waviyrN↓ and wivorN↓, (Ḳ,) or [only] miyvarapN, (TA, &c.,) of a horse's saddle, (T, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and of a camel's saddle, (T,) A thing in the form of a pillow, made for the saddle, like the Suf-ap [q. v.], (M, Mgh, Ḳ,) to render it soft, or easy to ride upon: (T:) or the saddlecloth or housing (libodap) of a horse: (Ṣ:) pl. mawaAviru and mayaAviru, (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter agreeing with the sing., (Mṣb,) retaining the permuted letter, as is the case in OaEoyaAdN, pl. of EiydN. (IJ, M.)

Also, accord. to the Ḳ, [referring to the three words above,] or [correctly] the red mayaAvir, (AlmayaAviru AlHumoru,) which are forbidden to be used, (Ṣ, IAth, TA,) Certain things to ride upon, (maraAkibu, Ṣ, IAth, Ḳ, TA,) used by the OaEaAjim, (Ṣ,) or Eajam, (IAth, TA,) [meaning Persians or other foreigners,] made of diybaAj or Hariyr [silk brocade or other silk]: (Ṣ, IAth, Ḳ, TA:) or the red miyvarap, (miyvarapu AilOurojuwaAni,) forbidden, in a trad., to be used, is a stuffed thing to ride upon, which is put upon a camel's saddle: (TA:) and the red myvrp which is put upon a horse's saddle is included in the prohibition. (IAth, TA.)
Also, the first of the above three words, (M,) or all of them (Ḳ) A garment or piece of cloth which is put as a covering over other garments or pieces of cloth. (M, Ḳ.)
Also, (accord. to the Ḳ [referring to the three words above,] or [correctly] mayaAviru, TA,) The skins of beasts of prey. (Ḳ, TA.)

wj-N A kind of medicine; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) certain twigs, or rods, with which one fumigates; (TA;) or which are used medicinally or remedially; (T;) [acorum, (Golius,) or acorus; sweet-cane, or, as some say, galangal: see Diosc., I. i., c. 2., referred to by Golius:] thought by El-Jawáleekee to be not pure Arabic; i. e., an arabicized word, from the Persian [wajo]: (TA:) so says J. (Ṣ.)

1. wajaOa, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yawojaOu, and sometimes yajaOu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. wajoCN; (TA;) and twj-O↓; (Ḳ;) He beat, or struck, or smote, a person with his hand, (Ṣ *, Ḳ,) or with a knife, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or the like, on any part. (Mṣb.)
wajaOa Eunuqahu, inf. n. wajoCN, He beheaded him: syn. Daraba Eunuqahu. (Ṣ.)
wajaOa ‡ Inivit feminam. (Ḳ.)

wajaOa Alt-ayosa, inf. n. wajoCN and wijaMCN, (or the latter is a simple subst., TA,) He beat the veins of the testicles of the goat between two stones, without extracting the testicles themselves: or he bruised or beat the goat's testicles until they broke, (Ḳ,) and he became like one gelded. (TA.) You say also wajaOa AlkaboXa. (Ṣ.) [See wjaMCN.] wujiYa He (a goat) had the operation termed wajoCN performed upon him. (Ḳ.)
He was struck with a knife. (Ṣ.)
wajaOa ‡ He bruised, or pounded, dates until they cohered. Hence wajiyoYapN, q. v. (TA.)
2: see 1.
wj-O Alr-akiy-apa, inf. n. tawojiIoCN, He found the well to be what is termed wajoOapN, [fem. of wajoCN, q. v.: app. signifying without water]. (Ḳ.)
4. AwjO Eanohu He repelled from him; removed, or put away, from him. (Ḳ *, TA.)
AwjO He came in search of a thing that he wanted, or in pursuit of game, and did not attain it. (Ḳ.)
It (a well) failed; i. e., its water ceased: or it contained no water. (TA.) [See also OawojaI.]
8. Uit-ajaOa Alt-amoru ‡ The dates became closely packed, or pressed together: (Ḳ:) they were bruised, or pounded, until they cohered. (TA.)

maMCN wajoCN, and wajaON↓, and wajaMCN↓, A water where there is no good: (Ḳ:) [app., a source of water where there is no herbage, or pasture; or, more probably, a source without water; or a water that has failed: see 2 and 4.]
wajaON and wajaMCN: see maMCN wajoCN.
wijaMCN, a subst., A striking with a knife or the like, on any part. (Mṣb.) [See also 1.]
wijaMCN The bruising of the veins of the testicles until they break, so that it is like gelding. (Ṣ.) [See also 1.]
wajiIoCN and mawojuwoCN↓ A goat on which has been performed the operation called wajoCN. (Ḳ.) [See 1.]
The latter is said to be used in a trad. as signifying Gelded.
Also the latter, Struck with a knife. (Ṣ.)

wajiyoYapN † Dates, (Ḳ,) or locusts, (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ,) bruised, or pounded, and then stirred up with clarified butter (samon), or with oil, and so eaten: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or dates moistened with milk or with clarified butter, and then bruised, or pounded, until they are consolidated: (TA:) or dates bruised, or pounded, until the stones come forth, and then moistened with milk or with clarified butter so that they become macerated and cohering, in which state they are eaten. (ISk, Ṣ.)
Also, A cow. (IAạr., Ḳ.)
mawojuwoCN: see wajiIoCN.

hom.sense: 1. wajaba, aor. yajibu, inf. n. wajobapN (Lḥ, Ḳ) and wajobN (Lḥ) It (a wall, or the like, Mṣb, or a house, or anything, Lḥ,) fell down. (Lḥ, Ḳ, Mṣb.) See wajobapN.
wajaba, inf. n. wajobapN, It fell to the ground. (TA.)
wajobapN does not signify a single act; but is an inf. n. in an absolute sense, unrestricted to the signification of a single act: ex. wajobapu AlX-amosi The falling of the sun, in setting. (TA.)
faUicaA wajabato junuwbuhaA [Ḳur. xxii. 37,] is said to signify And when their sides fall down upon the ground: or and when their souls depart, and they fall down. (TA.)
wajabati AlX-amosu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. wajobN and wujuwbN (Ḳ) and wajobapN (see above), The sun set. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
wajabati AlEayonu ‡ The eye was, or became, sunk in the head. (Ḳ.)
wajaba, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yajibu, inf. n. wujuwbN and mawojibN, (TA,) He fell down and died: (Ṣ:) he died. (Ḳ.)

Hudbeh Ibn-Khashram says,
faqulotu lahu laA taboki Eayonuka Uin-ahu
bikaf-aI-a maA laA qayotu Uico HaAna mawojibiI
[And I said to him, Let not thine eye weep; for by my own hands is occasioned what I experience, now that my death has come to pass]. By mwjb he means mawotN. (TA.)
[See also wajobapN, which seems to be a third inf. n. of the verb in this sense.]

wajaba, (aor. yajibu, TA,) inf. n. wajiybN (Th, Ṣ,) and wajobN and wajabaAnN (Ḳ) and wujuwbN and wajobapN, (TA,) It (the heart) palpitated, beat, throbbed; (Ḳ;) was agitated, or in a state of commotion. (Ṣ.)
wajabati AlUibilu, and wj-bt↓, The camels could scarcely arise from the places where they lay down. (TA.)
waHuba, [aor. yawojubu,] inf. n. wujuwbapN, He was cowardly, or pusillanimous. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
wajabahu Eanohu He drove him back, or turned him back, from it, (Ḳ,) when he had long kept to it. (Nawádir el-Aaráb.)
wajaba and Awjb↓ and wjb↓ ‡ He (a man, TA,) ate once a day. (Th, Ḳ) See wajobapN.

wajaba, aor. yajibu, inf. n. wujuwbN (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and jibapN, (Ḳ,) It (a thing) was, or became, necessitated, necessary, requisite, or unavoidable: it was binding, obligatory, incumbent, or due: syn. lazima; (Ṣ, Ḳ, Mṣb;) [lit. accord. to some, it fell on a person: see 4;] and vabata, (Telweeh,) which means nearly the same as lazima. (TA.)

For a fuller explanation, see its syn. Haq-a. [In the science of the fundamentals of religion, It necessarily was or existed; was a thing of which the nonexistence could not be mentally conceived: as is the essence of God. (Ibr. D.)]

[wajaba Ealayohi kacaA, or Oano yafaEala kacaA, Such a thing, or the doing of such a thing, was binding, incumbent, or obligatory upon him; was unavoidable to him; lay on him; was his necessary, or indispensable duty: or was binding, incumbent, or obligatory upon him, by God's express appointment, so that he would be punished for neglecting it: and it was that which should be preferred and approved. See waAjibN.]
See also another explanation, afterwards.

wajaba AlbayoEu, aor. yajibu, inf. n. jibapN (Lḥ, Ṣ, Mṣb) and wujuwbN (Lḥ, Mṣb) The sale was, or became, binding, or obligatory; (Mṣb, TA;) ratified, fixed, settled, decided, or determined; (Mṣb;) completed, accomplished, or concluded; it had, or took, effect; it was extended, or performed; or it was, or became, effectual: (TA:) and wajabato yamiynuhu, i. q. bat-ato, q. v. (M, in art. bt.)

It is said in a trad., UicaA kaAna AlbayoEu Eano xiyaArK faqado wajaba [When the sale is optional, it is binding, or obligatory]: i. e., when one says, after the contract, “Take thy choice to reject the sale, or to make it effectual,” and the person so addressed chooses to do the latter, the sale is binding, even if the two parties have not yet separated. (TA.)
In like manner, wajaba AlHaq-u, inf. ns. as above, The right, due, or claim, was, or became, binding, or obligatory; or fixed, settled, decided, or determined. (Mṣb.)
wjb Alwjb, inf. n. wjb: (TA: [unexplained; but following wajobN as signifying “a bet, &c.:” app. meaning The bet, wager, or stake, became due, or incumbent]).

[wajaba Ealayoh It was, or became, necessitated, necessary, requisite, or unavoidable, for him to do, or suffer, such a thing; and hence, sometimes, it was, or became, binding, obligatory, or incumbent, on him.]
wajaba Ealayohi Alqawolu [The saying or sentence became necessitated to take effect upon him; or it became requisite that the saying or sentence should take effect upon him.] Jel, in xxxvi. 6, &c.
[wajaba lahu kacaA Such a thing was, or became, due to him; as, for instance, a reward, or a punishment.]
wajaba Ealayohi Alqatolu [Slaughter was, or became, his due.] (TA, in art. bqI, &c.)
2. wj-b bihi AlOaroDa, inf. n. tawojiybN, He threw him down upon the ground. (Ṣ.)
wj-b, inf. n. tawojiybN, The camel lay upon his breast with folded legs, falling down upon the ground. (TA.)
wj-bt, inf. n. tawojiybN She (a camel) became milkless: (TA:) or [her biestings coagulated in her udder: see wajobN].
wj-b, (inf. n. tawojiybN, Ḳ,) He was fatigued, tired, or weary: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) said of a camel. (Ṣ.)
wj-b All-ibaOu, inf. n. tawojiybN, The biestings coagulated in the udder. (Ḳ.)
wj-b, (inf. n. tawojiybN, TA,) He milked (a camel, Ḳ,) but once in the course of each day and night. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

wj-b, inf. n. tawojiybN, He accustomed himself, (Lḥ, Ṣ,) in which case you also say wj-b linafosihi, (Lḥ,) and his family, or household, and his horse, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) to eat but one meal (Ḳ) in the course of each day and night. (Lḥ, Ṣ.)
See 1.
wj-b He took, got, or won, a bet, wager, or stake, at a shooting-match or race. (L, in TA, voce nadabN.)
See 4.

entry.sense: 3: see 4.

hom.sense: 4. Awjbhu (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and wj-bhu↓ (Ḳ) but this latter is by some rejected, (TA,) He (God, Ṣ) made it, or rendered it necessary, requisite, or unavoidable; necessitated it; made it, or declared it to be, binding, incumbent, or obligatory: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [lit. accord. to some, he made it to fall on a person: see faraDa.]

Awjb AlbayoEa, (Lḥ, Ṣ,) inf. n. UiyjaAbN, (Lḥ,) He made, or rendered, or declared, the sale binding, or obligatory; (Mṣb, TA;) ratified it; made, or rendered, it fixed, settled, decided, or determined; (Mṣb;) completed, accomplished, or concluded; effectual. (TA.)
Awjb laka AlbayoEa He made the sale to thee to be binding, or obligatory;, &c. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)

In like manner, waAjabahu↓ AlbayoEa, inf. n. muwaAjabapN and wijaAbN; (Lḥ; in quoting whose words, the author of the Ḳ has made an omission, so as to cause it to appear that these two words are inf. ns. of Awjb; TA;) He, with his (another's) concurrence, made the sale to him to be binding, or obligatory;, &c. (TA.)
Awjb Ealayohi XayoYFA [He made a thing, or declared it to be, binding, obligatory, or incumbent, upon him; or unavoidable to him]. (TA.)
Awjb Ealayoh AlqaDaMCa He necessitated the sentence to take effect upon him; syn. Haq-ahu and OaHaq-ahu. (TA, in art. Hq.)

Awjb He did a great sin, or an act of great goodness, making [the punishment of] hell, or [the reward of] paradise, the consequence thereof [unless followed by different conduct, &c.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he committed sins for which he who should punish him would be excusable, because he deserved punishment. (IAạr, in TA, art. lwT.)

It is said, in a trad., that some persons came to Moḥammad, saying, Uin-a SaAHibFA lanaA Oawojaba, i. e., Verily a companion of our's hath committed a sin for which he has become deserving of hell: to which he replied, Command him to emancipate a slave [as an expiation]. (TA.)
In another trad. it is said, Oawojaba cuw Alt-alaAvapi waAlUivonayoni, meaning, He of whom three children, or two, have gone before him [to paradise] hath become entitled to paradise. (TA.)

Oawojaba lahu Aljan-apa Oawi Aln-aAra It (an action) procured for him as a necessary consequence thereof [the reward of] paradise, or [the punishment of] hell; or made such to be to him a necessary consequence thereof; [unless followed by repentance, &c.:] (Ṣ, Ḳ *:) [it required for him paradise or hell.]
[yuwjibu kacaA It necessitates, or renders necessary, such a thing.]
[It requires such a thing, as a necessary consequence.]
[It necessarily implies the coexistence of such a thing therewith. Used in physics, &c., and perhaps in classical writings.]

Oawojabotu lifulaAnK Haq-ahu means I regarded such a one's right or due: and you say faEalotu celika UiyjaAbFA liHaq-ihi [I did that from regard to his right or due] (Ḥar. p. 490); [and Awjbhu lahu He made it, or declared it to be due to him].
[Awjbhu also signifies He affirmed it, he averred it; i. q. Oavobatahu as contr. of nafaAhu.]
[And It necessarily occasioned it.]
Awjb Ealayohi He beat him, overcame him, in a case of laying a bet, wager, or stake, at a shooting-match or race. (TA.)
Awjb Qll-ehu qalobahu God made his heart to palpitate, beat, or throb; [to be agitated, or in a state of commotion]. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)
See 1.

entry.sense: 6. tawaAjabuwA They laid a bet, wager, or stake, one with another, at a shooting-match or race: as though one party of them made a thing binding, or obligatory, on another party of them. (TA.)
10. Astwjbhu He had a right or just title or claim, to it; deserved it; merited it: syn. UisotaHaq-ahu [q. v.] (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See the act. part. n. below.

Astwjb UvomFA i. q. AisotaHaq-ihu; (TA, in art. Hq;) which means He did what necessitated sin; (Ksh, Bḍ, Jel, in v. 106;) [was guilty of a sin;] and deserved its being said of him that he was a sinner. (Ksh.)
rakaba xaTiYapF Qsotawojaba bihaA Aln-aAra [He committed a sin for which he became deserving of hell]. (TA.)

hom.sense: wajobN and muwaj-ibN↓ A she-camel whose biestings coagulate in her udder. (Ḳ.)
wijaAbN Places in which water stagnates: (Ḳ:) pl. of wajobN. (TA.)
wajobN A large skin of the kind called siqaACN, made of the (complete, TA,) hide of a he-goat: pl. wijaAbN. (AḤn, Ḳ.)
wajobN Stupid; foolish; of little sense. (Ḳ.)

wajobN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and waj-aAbN↓ (Ḳ) and waj-aAbapN↓ (IAạr, Ḳ) and muwaj-ibN↓ (IAạr) A coward; cowardly; pusillanimous. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) [The second and third, and more especially the latter, are probably intensive epithets.]
wajobN A bet, wager, or stake, at a shooting-match (Lḥ, Ḳ) or a race. (IAạr; and L in TA, voce nadabN.)
wajobapN inf. n. of wajaba “it fell down, &c.,” q. v.

bijanobihi falotakuni Alwajobapu, a proverb, (Ṣ,) [(May a disease be) in his side, or (may God afflict him, or smite him, with a disease) in his side, and may falling down upon the ground, and dying, happen (or be the result thereof)! i. e. bjnbh dACN fltkn Alwjbh bh; or ramaAhu Qll-ehu bidaACK bjnbh Alx. (Freytag, Arab. Prov. i. 156)].

wajobapN A falling with a sound, or noise, such as that produced by the fall of a wall or the like: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [see 1, where it is given as an inf. n. unrestricted to the signification of a single act:] or the sound of a thing falling (Ḳ) and producing a sound such as above mentioned. (TA.)

wajabahN An eating but once in the course of a day and night: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or an eating but once in a day until the like eating in the following day: (Ḳ:) an inf. n. (Lḥ) [restricted to the signification of a single act]: you say, fulaAnN yaOokulu wajobapF Such a one eats but once (T) in the course of the day and night. (AZ, Ṣ.) [See also SayoramN.]
In a trad. respecting the expiation of an oath, it is said, yuToEimu EaXarapa masaAkiyna wajobapF waAHidapF [He shall feed ten poor men with a meal sufficient for a day and a night]. (TA.)

entry.sense: wujaAbN: see wuHaAbN.

wajiybapN A daily allowance of food; or daily maintenance: syn. waZiyfapN: (Ḳ:) i. e., what a man is accustomed to allow himself [each day] as that which is necessary, and fixed: but the word in the A is wajobapN, q. v. (TA.)

wajiybapN [A term employed in the case of] one's concluding a sale, and then taking it [meaning what is sold to him] by regular successive portions, one after another, (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or, as some say, on the condition of his taking a portion of it every day, (TA,) until he has taken the whole of his wajiybap: (Ḳ:) [which hence appears to signify both the act above described and also what is due to one of a thing purchased and taken in this manner; but more probably the latter is the only meaning intended]. When a person has finished doing this, one says to him qadi Qsotawofayota wajiybataka [Thou hast taken the whole of what was due to thee of the thing purchased and taken by thee in the manner above described]. (Ṣ.)
[wujuwbiI-N Obligatory, or incumbent: opposed to AimotinaAniI-N.]
waj-aAbN and waj-aAbapN: see wajobN.

hom.sense:
waAjibN Slain: (Ṣ:) dying; or dead. (TA.) So in the following verse of Keys Ibn-El-Khateem:
OaTaAEato banuw EawofK OamiyrFA nahaAhumu
Eani Als-ilomi Hat-aI kaAna Oaw-ala waAjibi
[The sons of 'Owf obeyed a commander who forbade them to make peace until he was the first who was slain, or who died]. (Ṣ, TA.)

waAjibN [act. part. n. of wajaba; Necessary; requisite; unavoidable: binding, incumbent, or obligatory. In the science of the fundamentals of religion, Necessarily being or existing; of which the nonexistence cannot be mentally conceived: as the essence of God. (IbrD.)]

Accord. to [the Imám] Aboo-Ḥaneefeh, waAjibN [in matters of religion] is not so strong a term as faroDN: [and so may be rendered incumbent, or obligatory; or that which is a necessary, or indispensable, duty; yet not so decisively or manifestly shown to be such as that which is termed frD:] or, accord. to Esh-Sháfiʼee, these two terms are syn., signifying [binding, incumbent, or obligatory, by God's express appointment, as] a thing for neglecting which one will be punished: and wAjb signifies that which should be preferred and approved; thus explained by El-Khattábee as occurring in the following trad.: gusolu AljumoEapi waAjibN EalaI kul-i muHotalimK The ablution prescribed to be performed on Friday is an act which every one who has experienced a nocturnal pollution should prefer and approve. (TA.)

fiEolN waAjibN [A verb expressing an event as a positive fact] is such, for instance, as in the phrase bayonamaA OanaA kacaA Uico jaMCa zayodN [while I was thus, or in this state, lo, or behold, Zeyd came]. (Ṣ, L, art. Ac.)
muwjabN An effect; that which is produced by an operating cause; a result; a consequence. (Mṣb.)
[kalaAmN muwjabN, lit. An affirmed sentence; i. q. muvobatN as contr. of manofiI-N; virtually the same as kalaAmN muwjibN↓, an affirmative sentence.]
[mawojibN A place where one falls down and dies; where one dies].

xaraja Alqawomu UilaI mawaAjibihimo, i. e. AlI maSaAriEihimo; The people went forth to the places where they should be prostrated; [or, as implied in the Ṣ, where they should full down and die; or where they should die]. (Ṣ.)
muwjibN [and muwjibapN↓] A cause; an efficient; that which produces, or effects, anything. (Mṣb.)
muwjibN A name of the month AlmuHar-amu (Ḳ) in ancient times. (TA.)

entry.sense: muwjibapN A great sin for which one deserves punishment [in the world to come]: (TA:) or a great sin, and also an act of great goodness, which makes [the punishment of] hell, or [the reward of] paradise, the consequence thereof [unless followed by repentance, &c.] (Ḳ.)
Oall-ehum-a Uin-iI OasoOaluka muwjibaAti raHomatika [O God, I ask of thee those things which will procure thy mercy!]. (TA, from a trad.)
See muwjibN.

hom.sense: muwaj-ibN One who eats but once in the course of a day and a night. (AZ, Ṣ.)
muwaj-ibN A beast of carriage that is frightened at everything. (ISd.) Not known to AM. (TA.)
See wajobN in two places.

entry.sense: Oall-ehu musotawojibN AlHamodi God is worthy, or deserving, of praise; has a right, or just title or claim, to it; deserves it; merits it: syn. huwa waliy-uhu, and musotaHiq-uhu. (TA.)
1. wajaHa, aor. yawojaHu, inf. n. wajoHN, He had recourse, or betook himself, to a thing or place, for protection or concealment. (L.) [As also waHija.] See 4.
2: see 4.

hom.sense: 4. AwjHhu Uilayohi He compelled or constrained or necessitated him to have recourse to, or to betake himself to, him or it for protection or concealment or the like. (Ḳ.)
AwjH Albayota He curtained the house, or chamber, or tent; (Ḳ, TA;) hung a curtain upon it. (TA.)
AwjH He held fast, and defended, a thing. (L.)
AwjH, (L, Ḳ,) and wj-H↓, (Ḳ, TA,) or wajaHa↓, (as in the L and CK,) It (a thing) appeared; became apparent. (L, Ḳ.)
AwjH lanaA AlT-ariyqu The road became apparent or conspicuous to us. (Ṣ.)
AwjHti Aln-aAru The fire became apparent or conspicuous. (Ṣ.)
AwjH He reached, in digging, smooth rock, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is called wajaAH. (Ḳ.)
AwjHhu Albawolu The urine oppressed him by his wanting to void it. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: wajaHN A place to which one has recourse for protection or concealment; a place of refuge; an asylum: (L:) [as also waHajN:] a place resembling a gAr [or cave in a mountain]. (L, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: wajaAHN and wujaAHN and wijaAHN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) of which three forms IAạr prefers the first, (L,) and sometimes the w is changed into A, and one says OajaAHN and OujaAHN and UijaAHN, (Ṣ,) and in one dial. wjAHi, indecl., with kesreh for its termination, (L,) and jAHN, (Ḳ, in art. jwH,) A thing by which a person or thing is veiled, concealed, or hidden; a veil; a covering; a curtain. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
jaMCa fulaAnN wamaA Ealayohi wjAHN Such a one came having upon him nothing to veil, or conceal, him. (L.)
