layosa duwnahu wjAHN There is nothing that veils, or conceals, before, or in the way to, him, or it. (L.)
layosa bayoniI wabayonahu wjaAHN There is nothing that veils, or conceals, between me and him, or it. (L.)
waHaAHN Water in a tank or cistern sufficient to cover its bottom. (Ṣ.)
wajaAHN The remains of a thing, such as property, &c. (Az.)
laqiytuhu OadonaI wajaAHK I met him, he being the first object that I saw. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Smooth rock. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: wujaAHN: see wajaAHN.
wijaAHN: see wajaAHN.
OaHaAHN: see wajaAHN.
OujaAHN: see wajaAHN.
UijaAHN: see wajaAHN.
wjAHi: see wajaAHN.
jaAHN: see wajaAHN.
wajiyHN: see muwjaHN.

hom.sense: muwjaHN A garment closely woven, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and firm: (Ṣ:) or of close texture, and thick: or strong: or narrow and firm: (TA:) as also wajiyHN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) from OawojaHahu Albawolu. (Ṣ.)
muwjaHN A smooth skin. (Ḳ.)

muwjaHN Constrained, compelled, or necessitated, to have recourse to, or to betake himself to, a thing or place, for protection or concealment or the like; syn. mulojaON. (L, Ḳ, TA [in the CK malojaON, which is the signification of wajaHN]) Az says, that the word which he retains in his memory is muloHajN, with the H before the j; and that the two words may be two dial. forms.
muwjaHN, or muwjiHN↓, accord. to two different relations of a trad. in which it occurs, Oppressed by the want to void his urine. (L.)
muwjiHN One who veils, or conceals, or hides, a thing. (L.)
See muwjaHN.

entry.sense: baAbN mawojuwHN A closed door: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a door before which is a curtain. (TA.)
TariyqN muwaj-aHN A conspicuous, open, wide road. (L.)

hom.sense: 1. wajadahu, aor. yajidu and yajudu, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter of the dial. of the tribe of 'Ámir (Ṣ, L, Mṣb) Ibn-Saasa'ah, (MF,) and without a parallel (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) in verbs of this class, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb,) the w in it being dropped because it falls out in the original form of the aor., (Mṣb,) both of which forms are said by several authors to apply to the verb in all its significations, though F seems to restrict the latter to two significations, (TA,) inf. n. wujuwdN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and wijodaAn (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and UijodaAnN, (IAạr, L, Ḳ,) in which the w is changed into C, (L,) and wajodN and wujodN and jidapN; (L, Ḳ;) and wajidahu, aor. yajidu; (Ḳ;) but this form of the verb is not found in the lexicons, [the Ḳ only accepted,] (MF,) in the sense here assigned to it; (TA;) He found it; lighted on it; attained it; obtained it by searching or seeking; discovered it; perceived it; saw it; experienced it, or became sensible of it; (F, in the Ḳ and in the Basáïr, on the authority of Abu-l-Kásim El-Iṣbahánee;) namely, a thing sought, sought for or after, or desired; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) and simply a thing. (L.) wujuwd is of several kinds. It is The finding, &c., by means of any one of the five senses: as when one says wajadotu zayodFA [I found, &c., Zeyd]: and wajadatu TaEomahu, and raAYiHatahu, and Sawotahu, and xuXuwnatahu, [I found, or perceived, &c., its taste, and its odour, and its sound, and its roughness]. Also, The finding, &c., by means of the faculty of appetite, [or rather of sensation, which is the cause of appetite:] as when one says wajadotu AlX-ibaEa [I found, experienced, or became sensible of, satiety]. Also, The finding, &c., by the intellect, or by means of the intellect: of which kind is one's knowing God: and here it should be observed, that wjwd attributed to God is simple knowledge: (Abu-l-Kásim El-Iṣbahánee, cited in the Basáïr:) wajada Qll-ehu, wherever it occurs, means God knew. (Er-Rághib, Z, &c.) i. e., in the Ḳur-án. (TA.)

wajada [He found, in the sense of] he knew [by experience]. (A, TA, &c.) [In this sense, it is a verb of the kind called OafoEaAlu Alquluwbi; having two objective complements; the first of which is called its noun, and the second its predicate.] Ex. wajadotu zayodFA caA AlHifaAZi I [found, or] knew Zeyd to possess the quality of defending those things which should be sacred, or inviolable. (A.) Used in this sense, as doubly trans., its inf. n. is wajodaAnN (Akh) and wujuwdN. (Seer.) It is also used as singly trans., as syn. with Ealima. (TA.)
When wajada signifies he found, or lighted on, a thing after it had gone away, its inf. n. is wijodaAnN. (IḲṭṭ.)
wajada AlD-aAl-apa, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) aor. yajid (Mṣb) and yajudu, (MF,) inf. n. wajodaAnN (Ṣ, Mṣb) and lamo Oajido mino celika bud-FA (Mṣb) [He found the stray beast].
lamo Oajido mino celika bud-FA, for which one also says lamo Ajdi, I found no means of avoiding, or escaping, that. (Ḳz, TA.)

wajada, (L,) and wajada fiI AlmaAli, (Fṣ, T, Ṣ, L, Mṣb,) and wajada AlmaAla wagayarahu, (Lḥ, M, Ḳ,) aor. yajidu, (Lḥ, M, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. wujod and wijd and wajodN- and jidahN (Lḥ, T, Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and wijodaAnN (T, L) and wujuwdN, (Yz,) He became possessed of wealth, or property: (T:) or he was, or became, rich; possessed of competence, or sufficiency; in no need; without wants, or with few wants; (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ;) so as not to be poor afterwards: (L:) and he gained, acquired, or earned wealth. (Exps. of the Fṣ.) Hence the saying of the Arabs, wijodaAnu Alr-aqiyni yugaT-iI Oafana AlOafiyni [The possession of money hides the weakness of judgment of the weak in judgment]. (T, L.)

wajada Ealayohi, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, &c.) aor. yajidu (Fṣ, M, L, Ḳ) and yajudu; (M, L, Ḳ;) and wajida, as heard by Fr from certain of the Arabs; (Kzz;) inf. n. mawojidapN, (Fṣ, Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) by some pronounced mawojadapN, (Fr,) and wajodN and jidapN (L, Ḳ) and wijodaAnN (Lḥ, Ṣ, M, L) and wujuwdN (Fr, Kzz) He was angry with him: (Fṣ, Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) or he was angry with him with the anger that proceeds from a friend. (TA, voce EatobN.)

wajada bihi, (aor. yajidu, L,) inf. n. wajodN, He loved him. (L, Ḳ.) wajada bihaA, (A, L,) and tw-jd↓, (A,) He loved her; (A, L;) he loved her passionately or fondly. (L.) lahu bihaA wajodN He has a love [or passionate or fond love] for her. (A.)

wajada, [aor. yajidu,] (ʼEyn, Fṣ, Ṣ, L, Mṣb, &c.,) and wajida, [aor. yawojadu,] (El-Hejeree, M, Ḳ,) the latter the only form mentioned in the Ḳ, but the former is the only form generally known, (MF, TA,) and wajuda, (Lḥ, M, L,) inf. n. wajodN, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) He grieved; mourned; sorrowed. (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) You say, wajadotu bihi, (Mṣb,) and twj-dt↓ lahu, (Ṣ, L,) I grieved, mourned, or sorrowed, for such a one. (Ṣ, L, Mṣb.) Ibn-Hishám El-Lakhmee says, that in this sense wjd is not transitive: (MF:) [i. e., without a prep.].
wujida, (inf. n. wujuwdN, A, Mṣb,) It existed; it became existent (A, Mṣb) from a state of nonexistence. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
4. Awjdhu Uiy-aAhu He (God, Ṣ, A, L) made him to find, attain, or obtain, it; (Lḥ, Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ;) namely, the thing that he sought, sought for or after, or desired; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) or a stray beast. (A.)

Awjdhu He (God, Ṣ, &c.) enriched him; made him to be possessed of wealth or property; to be possessed of competence or sufficiency; to be in no need, or without wants, or with few wants. (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.) Ex. AlHamodu lil-ehi Al-iciI OawojadaniI baEoda faqorK waMjadaniI baEoda DaEofK Praise be to God who enriched me after poverty and strengthened me after weakness. (Ṣ, L.)
He strengthened him after weakness; like Mjadahu. (Ḳ.) [But see what immediately precedes.]

Awjdhu, (inf. n. UiyjaAdN, TA,) He (God) made it; meaning, created it; originated it; caused it to be or exist, or to come to pass; brought it into existence (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) from a state of nonexistence, (Mṣb,) not after the similitude of anything preëxisting. (TA.) wajadahu in this sense is not allowable. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
5. twj-dhu He complained of it; namely, sleeplessness by night, (L, Ḳ,), &c., (Ḳ,) or a particular affair. (L.)
See 1, in two places.

entry.sense: 6. twAjd He feigned, or made a show of, love [or passionate love]. (A.)
wijodN and wajodN and jidapN: see wujodN; and see 1.

wujodN and wijodN↓ and wajodN↓ [and jidapN↓, &c., see 1,] (the first of which is the most chaste, IKh, MF) Richness, or competence, or sufficiency; state of being in no need, or of having no wants, or few wants: (M, L, Ḳ:) ability; capacity; power. (M, L.)
hecaA mino wujodiI This is a result of my power, or ability. (L.)

hom.sense: waAjidN, act. part. n of 1, Finding; or a finder;, &c. (L.)

Rich; possessing competence, or sufficiency; in no need; without wants, or with few wants; (L;) solvent; one who finds that wherewith to pay what he owes. (AʼObeyd, L.) Ex. laI-u AlwaAjidi yuHil-u Euquwbatahu The solvent man's putting off the payment of his debt with promises repeated time after time makes his punishment allowable. (L, from a trad. See Mgh art. lwI.) AlwaAjidu, as an epithet applied to God, He who has no wants. (IAth, L.)
huwa waAjidN EalaI SaAHibihi He is angry with his companion. (A.)
OanaA waAjidN lilX-aIoCi I am able to do the thing. (Mṣb.)
huwa waAjidN bifulaAnapa, and EalayohaA, and mutawaj-idN↓, He is in love [or passionately in love] with such a female. (A.)
wujudN is mentioned in the Towsheeh as a pl. of waAjidN; but this is strange. (TA.)

entry.sense: mawojuwdN, part. n. of wujida, Being, or existing; come to pass: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or, as an irreg. pass. part. n. of Oawojadahu, caused to be, or exist; or to come to pass; brought into existence: (MF:) pl. mawojuwdaAtN: which is a term applied to three kinds of things: namely, that which exists and has neither beginning nor end; and such is only God: that which exists and has a beginning and an end; as the substances of the present world: and that which exists and has a beginning but no end; as men in the world to come. (TA.)
[Present.]
mawojuwdN A thing within one's power; over which one has power. (Mṣb.)
mutawaj-idN: see waAjidN.

wajocN A small, or round, hollow, or cavity, in a mountain, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) in which water collects, (Ṣ,) or which retains water, (L, Ḳ,) and in which it stagnates: (L:) or a pool: (L:) and (some say, TA) a tank, or cistern: (Ḳ:) pl. wijaAcN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and wijocaAnN. (L, Ḳ.)
makaAnN wajicN A place abounding with wijaAc, pl. of wajocN. (Ḳ.)

1. wajarahu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and wajarahu dawaM, (AZ, A,) [or wajuwrFA,] aor. yajiruhu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. wajorN; (AZ, Ḳ;) and Oawojarahu↓, [which is the more common,] (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) and Awjrhu dawaMCN, or wajuwrFA, (TA,) inf. n. UiyjaArN; (Mṣb;) He put, or poured, medicine into his (a child's, Ṣ, or sick person's, Mṣb) mouth; (AZ, Ḳ;) into any part of his mouth: (ISk, ISd:) or into the middle of his mouth: (Ṣ, Mgh:) or into his fauces: (Mṣb:) with a miyjarap: (A:) and Awjrhu AlmaMCa [he poured the water into his mouth: or into the middle of his mouth: or into his fauces]. (AʼObeyd.)

wajarahu Alr-umoHa; (IḲṭṭ;) or Oawojarahu↓ Alr-umoHa, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) which latter only is allowable; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ;) or the latter is what is commonly known, but the former may be a dial. form thereof; (IAth;) and Oawojarahu biAlr-umoHi; (Lth;) ‡ He pierced him in his mouth with the spear: (A, Ḳ:) or in his breast, or chest: (Lth, Ṣ, IḲṭṭ;) and wajarahu biAls-ayofi, inf. n. wajorN, occurs in a trad., signifying, ‡ he pierced him with the sword. (IAth, TA.)
And in like manner you say, Oawojarahu↓ AlgayoZa ‡ [app. He infused into him wrath, or rage]. (AʼObeyd, TA.)
Also, wajarahu, aor. yajiruhu, inf. n. wajorN, ‡ He made him to hear what he disliked, or hated: (Ḳ, TA:) but the form commonly known is Oawojarahu↓, as AʼObeyd says. (TA.)
4: see 1, throughout.
5. twj-r He swallowed a medicine (Ḳ, TA) by little and little, or by degrees. (TA.)
He drank water against his will. (Aboo-Kheyreh, Ḳ.)
8. Uit-ajara, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) originally Uiwotajara, (Ṣ,) He physiced himself with the medicine termed wajuwrN. (Ṣ, TA.)

wijaArN and wajaArN The hole, or den, (juHor, A, Ḳ,) or subterranean habitation, (sarab, T, Ṣ,) of the hyena, (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,), &c., (A, Ḳ,) or, and the like, (T,) such as the lion, and the wolf, and the fox, and the like: (M, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OawojirapN and [of mult.] wujurN. (Ḳ.) A poet uses the expression kilaAbu wijaArK, applying wjAr metaphorically to the place of the dog: but it is not improbable that the correct relation may be DibaAEu wijaArK: though it may be allowable to call hyenas kalaAb, as her young ones are called jiraMC. (M.)

wajuwr (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and wujuwrN (Ḳ) Medicine which is put, or poured, into the mouth; (Ḳ;) into any part of the mouth: (ISk, ISd:) or into the middle of the mouth: (Ṣ, Mgh:) or into the fauces: (Mṣb:) or into the middle of the fauces: (TA:) of a child, Ṣ, TA, or sick person; (Mṣb;) with a miyjarap. (A.)
Also the former, ‡ [A thing which one is made to hear and which he dislikes, or hates:] a subst. from wajarahu in the last of the senses explained above. (Ḳ.)
miyjarN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and miyjarapN (A, Ḳ) A thing like the musoEuT, with which medicine is put, or poured, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) into the mouth, (Ḳ,) or into the middle of the mouth, (Ṣ,) [or into the fauces.]

hom.sense: 1. wajuza, _u, inf. n. wajaAzapN (A, Mṣb, TA) and wajozN, (M, TA,) [It (an expression, or speech, or language,) was brief, or concise: or] it [an expression] was brief, and quickly intelligible: (Mṣb:) or it (a man's speech) was of few words; (A;) as also Oawojaza↓, said of language: (A, Ḳ:) or both signify it (language) was of few words, with eloquence. (M, TA.)

wajuza fiI manoTiqihi, aor. _u {yawojuzu}; (A, Ḳ;) or fI kalaAmihi; (Mṣb;) and wajaza fiyhi, aor. yajizu; inf. n. wajaAzapN; (A, Ḳ;) of the former verb; (TA;) and [of the latter] wajozN and wujuwzN; (A, Ḳ;) and Awjz↓ fiyhi; (Mṣb;) [He was brief, or concise, in his speech, or language; contr. of OaTonaba: or] he was of few words in his speech: (A, Ḳ:*) or he was brief, and quickly intelligible, in his language: (Mṣb:) or Awjz↓ signifies he was quick and brief in speaking. (Nh, TA.) See this latter verb below.
wajaza All-afoZa: see 4.
4: see 1, in four places.

Awjz All-afoZa [He made the expression brief, or concise; and in like manner, the speech, or language: or] he made the expression brief, and quickly intelligible; as also wajazahu↓, aor. yajizuhu: (Mṣb:) or Awjz kalaAmahu, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiyjaAzN, (A,) he made his language to be of few words: (A, Ḳ:) or Awjz AlkalaAma he abridged the language; (Ṣ;) i. q. AixotaSarahu; though there is a logical distinction between the two, for the mention of which this is not the place: (M, TA:) the difference is said to be this; that the former signifies he expressed the correct meaning concisely, without regard to the original words; and the latter, “he curtailed the words, preserving the meaning.” (MF, in art. xSr.)
Awjz AlEaTiy-apa He made the gift prompt, or speedy: (A, Ḳ:) or he made the gift little, or small. (L, TA.)
Awjz EalaI Alqatiyli He hastened and completed, or made certain, the slaughter of the slain man; i. q. Oajohaza Ealayohi. (Abu-l-Mikdám Es-Sulamee, in TA, art. njz.)

entry.sense: 5. twj-z AlX-Ca He sought, asked, or demanded, the accomplishment of the thing; syn. tanaj-azahu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he sought, asked, or demanded, it; syn. Uilotamasahu; (Ḳ;) and asked for its accomplishment; tnj-zh meaning Uilotamasahu wasaOala najaAzahu. (TA.)
wajozN Quickness; speed; haste. (TA.) As an epithet, applied to a man, (TA,) Quick of motion (Ḳ, TA) in that which he begins: (TA:) fem. with p {wajozapN}: (Ḳ:) and quick, applied to a camel. (TA.)
Also, applied to a man, (TA,) Prompt, or quick, in giving. (Ḳ.)

Also, wajozN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and wajiyzN↓ (Ṣ, A, Mṣb) and waAjizN↓ (TA) and muwjazN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and muwjizN↓, (Ṣ,) applied to an expression, (Mṣb,) or language, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA,) [Brief, or concise:] or brief, or quickly intel-ligible: (Mṣb:) or consisting of few words: (A, TA:) or abridged: (Ṣ:) or light, or easy, (xafiyfN, Ḳ, TA,) and keeping within just, or moderate, bounds: (TA:) and all these epithets (all but the last accord. to the Ḳ, and the last also accord. to the TA,) are likewise applied to the thing, or an affair, [app. meaning, small, or slight, or the like:] (Ḳ, TA:) and the first is also applied to a gift, and to beneficence, meaning, little, or small. (TA.)
wajiyzN: see wajozN, in two places.
waAjizN: see wajozN, in two places.
muwjazN and muwjizN: see wajozN, in two places.

mwjz: [so in the L and TA: it may be either muwjazN or muwjizN:] One of the names of [the month of] Safar: [app. for one or other of the reasons mentioned voce SafarN:] thought by ISd, to be an appellation used in the time of the tribe of 'Ád [who are also said to have called this month naAjirN]. (L, TA.)
miyjaAzN [Brief, or concise, in speech;] a man who uses few words in speech and in reply,, &c. (IDrd, Ḳ,* TA.)

1. wajasa, aor. yajisu, inf. n. wajosN and wajasaAnN, He was frightened at some sound, or other thing, that fell into his mind, or ear. (TḲ.) [See also wajosN, below; and see 4, and 5.] This combination of letters generally denotes the perception of a thing of which one bears not any sound. (Ṣgh.)

wijasa AlX-aIoCu, [aor. app. as above,] inf. n. wjosN, i. q. xafiIa [app. meaning The thing was unperceived, or hardly perceived, by the eye, or ear, or mind; was hidden, or concealed; was low, faint, gentle, or soft, to the ear; or was obscure to the mind]. (IḲṭṭ.)
2: see 5, last signification but one.

4. Awjs He conceived a thing in his mind; syn. OaDomara. (A.) So in the Ḳur, [xx. 70,] faOawojasa fiI nafosihi xiyfapF And he conceived in his mind a fear: (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, Ṣ:) and tawaj-asa↓ signifies the same: (Ṣ:) or the above words of the Ḳur. signify he perceived, or felt, and conceived, in his mind a fear; (Ḳ;) and in like manner in the same book, [xi. 73, and] li. 28: or, as Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ says, in one place, Awjs signifies fear fell into his mind. (TA.) See also 1, and 5.

5. twj-s He listened to (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) a sound, (A,) or a low, faint, gentle, or soft, sound. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Ex. tw-js rikozFA [He listened to a low, sound], occurring in a poem of Dhu-r-Rummeh: or, as some say, it means he perceived a low sound, and listened to it, being in fear. (TA.) [See also 4, where another signification of the same verb is mentioned; and see 1.] And Uisotawojasato↓ McaAnuhaA Their ears (referring to camels) listened, or endeavoured to hear. (IB, [in a marg. note in my copy of the TA, art. Ons.])
[Hence,] twj-s Eani AlOaxobaAri He sought to learn the news, or tidings, without others knowing of him. (AZ, in TA, voce taHad-asa.)
Also, twj-st AlOacunu The ear heard a low, faint, gentle, or soft sound; as also waj-asat↓. (TA.)
Also, twj-s He tasted food, and beverage, time after time, little and little at a time. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: wajosN A fright of the heart: (Ṣ:) or fright that falls into the heart, or into the ear, from a sound or some other thing; (Lth, A, Ḳ;) as also wajasaAnN↓. (Ḳ.) [See 1, of which each is an inf. n.]

A low, faint, gentle, or soft, sound. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ.) [And particularly The sound denoted in the words here following, and explained in a former art., voce fahara.] It is said in a trad., nahaI Eani Alwajosi, meaning, He forbade a man's being with his slave-girl, or his wife, when another female would hear their low sound. (Ḳ,* TA.) And in another it is said, respecting the same case, that they used to dislike [what is termed] Alwajos. (Ṣ.)
See also Oawojasu.

entry.sense: wajasaAnN: see 1, and wajosN.

waj-aAsN is syn. with EaAlimN [Knowing,, &c.]; and therefore made trans. by means of bi in the saying of Aboo-Dhu-eyb,
cuw mir-apK bidiwaAri AlS-ayodi waj-aAsu
[An intelligent person, acquainted with the circumvention of game: see daAwarahu]: (M, art. dwr:) (ISd holds it to be a possessive epithet, since it has no known verb [of a suitable meaning that is unaugmented]): or [the meaning of these words is, a person possessing skill in circumventing game, a listener, or attentive, to their sounds and motions; for], accord. to Es-Sukkaree, rj-As means yatawaj-asu. (TA.)
waAjisN An opinion, idea, or object of thought, bestirring itself, or occurring, in the mind; syn. haAjisN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e., xaATirN. (TA.)

Oawojasu A little of food, and of beverage. (Ḳ.) One says, maA duqotu Einodahu Oawojasu I tasted not, at his abode, any food; (El-Umawee, Ṣ;) and [in like manner] wajosFA↓. (TA.) And maAfiI siqaAYihi Oawojasu There is not in his skin a drop: thus the phrase is given, without the mention of beverage: or a drop of water. (TA.) It is said that the word is not used except in negative phrases. (TA.)

Also, AlOawojasu and AlOawojusu (Ṣ, Ḳ) the latter on the authority of Yaạḳoob, (Ṣ, TA,) but the former is the more chaste, (TA,) Time; syn. Ald-ihora. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence the saying, (TA,) laAOafoEaluhu sajiysa AlOawojasi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AlOawojusi, (Ṣ,) I will not do it ever. (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ.) And OafoEaluhu sajiysa Eujayosa AlOawojasK I will not do it while time lasts. (El-Fárisee.)

R. Q. 1. waHowaHa, inf. n. waHowaHapN, He uttered a sound accompanied by a hoarseness, roughness, harshness, or gruffness, of the voice: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he made his breath to reciprocate in his throat, so as to be audible, by reason of cold; (TA:) he blew upon his hand by reason of intense cold. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
waHowaHN A strong man, (L, Ḳ,) who breathes hard at his work by reason of his briskness and vigour; (L;) as also waHowaAHN↓. (Ḳ.)
Also the former, (L, Ḳ,) and the latter, (L,) A quick, or prompt, and sharp-spirited, man. (L, Ḳ.)
Also the former, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and the latter, (Ṣ,) A light, or an active, or agile, man. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also both words, A lord, or chief: pl. waHaAwiHu and waHaAwiHapN. (L.)
Also both words, A barking, or howling, dog. (L, Ḳ.)
waHowaAHN: see what precedes.
wuHaAbN A disease that attacks camels. (Ḳ, TA.) By some written wajaAbN; [and so in the CK;] but the correctness of this is improbable. (TA.)
TaEaAmN waHotN Food in which is no good. (L.)

1. waHada, aor. yaHidu; (T, L, Mṣb;) and waHida, (Lḥ, M, L, Ḳ,) aor. yawoHadu (Lḥ) and yaHidu; (Ḳ;) with the latter aor., like wariva, aor. yarivu;
but waHida with this aor. is not mentioned by the lexicologists or grammarians [except F]; (MF;) [and its aor. is therefore probably yawoHadu, only, agreeably with analogy, for which reason it seems to be omitted in the M;] and waHuda, (Lḥ, M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. also yaHidu; (Ḳ;) but this is without a parallel, and without any authority [except F]; (MF;) or yawoHadu; (L;) [but this is also extr., and is probably a mistake for yawoHudu, which is the form agreeable with analogy;] inf. n. HidapN (T, M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and waHodN (M, L, Ḳ) and waHadN (L) and waHodapN, (L, Ḳ,) or wuHodapN, (as in some copies of the Ḳ and in the TA) and wuHuwdN (Ḳ) and waHaAdapN (M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and wuHuwdapN; (Ḳ;) He, or it, was, or became, alone, by himself or itself, apart from others; (T, L, Mṣb;) as also [Uit-aHada↓; and twH-d↓; and] AstwHd↓; (A:) he was, or became, alone, without anyone to cheer him by his society, company, or conversation: (L:) he remained alone, by himself, apart from others; (Lḥ, M, L, Ḳ;) as also twH-d↓. (M, L, Ḳ.) See also 5, below.

2. wH-dhu, (inf. n. tawoHiydN, Ḳ,) He made it one; or called it one: (Ḳ:) like as one says vanaAhu, and val-avahu: (Ṣ, L:) as also OaH-adahu. (TA.) Similar verbs are formed from the other nouns significant of numbers, to EaXarapN. (Esh-Sheybánee, Ḳ.)
wH-d liQmoraOatihi, or EinodahaA, He remained one night with his wife: and in like manner the verb is used in relation to any saying or action. (TA, voce sab-aEa.)
wH-d Qll-eha, inf. n. tawoHiydN, He asserted, or declared, God to be one: he asserted, declared, or preferred belief in, the unity of God: as also AH-dhu. (T, L.)
Alt-awoHiydu The belief in God alone; (L, Ḳ;) in his unity. (L.)
4. AwHd Qll-ehu jaAnibahu [God rendered him solitary]; i. e., he remained alone; (Ḳ;) or was made to remain alone. (L.)
AwHdhu liloOaEodaMCi He left him [alone] to the enemies. (L, Ḳ.)
AwHdhu He (God) made him the unequalled one of his time: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) made him to have no equal. (A.)
AwHdhu Aln-aAsu The people left him alone, or by himself. (L.)
OawoHadotuhu biruWoyatiI, inf. n. UiyHaAdN, [I singled him by my sight;] I saw none save him. (Ṣ, L.)
AwHdt She (a ewe) brought forth one only: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) like Oafac-ato. (Ṣ.)
AwHdt bihi She (a woman) brought him forth an unequalled one. (L, from a trad.)
5. twH-d Qll-ehu biEiSomatihi, (Ṣ,) or twH-dhu bESmth, (L, Ḳ,) God protected him himself, not committing him to the care of another. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
twH-d baAlOamori He was, or became, alone, without any to share or participate with him, in the affair. (L.)
twH-d biraOoyihi He was, or became, alone, without any to share, or participate with him, in his opinion. (Ṣ, L.)
See 1.
8. [Ait-aHada It was, or became, one. And hence, Ait-aHada maEahu He was, or became, one with him in interests, &c.]
At-Hd It (a number of things, or substances, two and more, KT,) became one. (KT, KL.) See 1.
10. UisotawoHada see 1.
HidapN: see waHodN.
faEalahu mino caAti Hidatihi, and EalaI cAt Hdth, and mn ciI Hdth, and mn cAt nafosihi, and mn cAt raOoyihi, He did it of himself; of his own accord; of his own judgment. (AZ, L, Ḳ.)
waHodN: see 1, and waHiydN.

raOayotuhu waHodahu (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) I saw him alone. (Ṣ, L.) wHd is here an inf. n., having no dual nor pl. (Ḳ.) The Koofees hold it to be in the acc. case as an adv. n. of place: the Basrees, as an inf. n., in every instance; as though thou saidst OawoHadotuhu biruWoyatiI UibHaAdFA, meaning “I saw none save him,” and then substituted wHdh: or, as Abu-l-ʼAbbás says, it may mean the man's being himself alone; as though thou saidst raOayotu rajulFA munofaridFA AinofiraAdFA, and then substituted wHdh. (Ṣ.) Or it is in the acc. case as a denotative of state accord. to the Basrees [and the grammarians in general]; not as an inf. n., J being in error in what he says on this matter: (IB, Ḳ:) the Basrees hold it to be a noun occupying the place of an inf. n. in the acc. case as a denotative of state; like jaMCa zayodN rakoDFA, meaning raAkiDFA: (IB:) excepting some of them, as Yoo, who holds it to be in the acc. case as an adv. n. of place, for EalaI waHodihi, (IB, Ḳ,) like Einodahu: (TA:) and there is a third opinion, that of Hishám; that it is in the acc. case as an inf. n. (L.) Or, (accord. to IAạr, L,) it is a noun used as a noun absolutely: (L, Ḳ:) so in the dial. of the Benoo-Temeem: (Mṣb:) you say jalasa waHodahu, and EalaI waHodihi, and jalasaA EalaI waHodi himaA, and waHodayohimaA, and jalasuwA EalaI waHodihimo, [He sat alone, and they two sat alone, and they sat alone]. (L, Ḳ.) When not preceded by a prefixed n. [or a prep.], it is always in the acc. case: (Lth, L:) you say, laA UilaAah Uil-aA Qll-ehu waHodahu [There is no deity but God alone]: and mararotu bizayodK waHodahu [I passed by Zeyd alone]: (L:) [excepting in a few cases, such as the phrases] qulonaA hecaA AlOamora waHodayonaA [We two alone said this thing], and qaAlataAhu waHodayohumaA [They two women alone said it]; mentioned by AZ. (L.) You say also, hecaA EalaI waHodihi, and EalaI Hidatihi↓, This is by itself; (L, Ḳ;) and humaA EalaI HidatihimaA They two are by themselves: and humo EalaI Hidatihimo They are by themselves: (L:) and OaEoTi kul-a waAHidK manohumo EalaI Hidatihi Give thou to every one of them by himself; syn. ElI HiyaAlihi. (Ṣ.) The p in HidapN is a substitute for the w (Ṣ, L) which is cut off from the beginning. (L.)
waHodN, (Ḳ,) or waHadN↓, (L,) A wild animal alone, by itself, or apart from others. (L, Ḳ.)
waHadN, (Ḳ,) or waHadN↓, (L,) A man whose lineage and origin are unknown. (Lth, L, Ḳ.)

waHod is used as the complement of a prefixed n. only in the following phrases: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, L:) huwa nasiyju waHodihi, which is an expression of praise; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) meaning, ‡ He is one unequalled; one who has no second: (L:) or he is a man of right judgment: you say also humaA nasiyjaA waHodihimaA, and humo nusajaMCu waHodihimo, and hiIa nasiyjapu waHodihaA, and hun-a nasaAYiju waHodihin-a: (Lth, L:) [see art. nsj:] it is as though you said nasiyju UiforaAdK: you put wHdh in the place of an inf. n. in the gen. case: (Ṣ:) and rajulu waHodihi, (IAạr, L,) and rujayolu waHodihi, (Ṣ, L,) [A man unequalled; who has no second, and a little man (probably meaning the contr.), &c.]: and qariyEu waHodihi A man with whom no one contends in excellence: (Lth, L:) and Euyayoru waHodihi, and juHayoXu waHodihi, which are expressions of dispraise; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) meaning, ‡ One who does not consult, nor mix with, any one, and who is contemptible and weak: (Sh, L:) waHod being used in the manner of an inf. n., not being an epithet nor an enunciative so as to be in concordance with the preceding noun, would be more properly in the acc. case; but the Arabs use it in these instances as the complement of a prefixed n.: (Lth, L:) these expressions are indeterminate: for the Arabs say, rub-a nasiyji waHodihi qado raOayotu ‡ [Few unequalled men have I seen]. (Hishám, Fr., L.)
waHadN: see waHodN and waHiydN.
waHidN: see waHiydN.
waHodapN The state of being alone, or apart from others; solitariness; solitude. (Sb, Ṣ.) See 1.
waHodapu Alqabori [The solitude of the grave]. (A.)

[layolapu AlwaHodapi The night of solitude; the first night after burial: so called because the soul is believed to remain in the grave during this night, and then to depart to the place appointed for the residence of good souls until the last day, or to the appointed prison in which wicked souls await their final doom. See also layolapu AlwaHoXapi.]
waHodaAniy-apN The unity of God: (L, Ḳ:*) as also OaHodiy-apN. (Mṣb.)

waHodaAniy-N One who is singular in his religious opinions; who separates himself from the general body of believers: a rel. n. from AlwaHodapu; the A and n being added to give intensiveness to the signification. (L.)
wuHaAda: see mawoHada.

waHiydN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and mutawaH-idN↓ (L, Ḳ) and waHadN↓ and waHidN↓ (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and waHodN↓ (M, L) and waAHidN↓ (L) A man alone; by himself; apart from others; solitary; lonely: (Ṣ, M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also OaHadN: (M, L, Ḳ:) or, accord. to Az, one should not say rajulN OaHadN, nor dirohamN OaHadN, nor XaIoCN OaHadN, though some of the lexicologists assert that OaHadN is originally waHadN: for OaHadN is an epithet applied to God alone: (L:) the fem. epithet used in this sense is waHidapN: (Ḳ:) and waAHidN↓ in this sense receives the dual form: and the pl. is wuHodaAnN and OaHodaAnN and wiHaAdN. (L.) rajulN waHiydN A man who has no one to cheer him by his society, conversation, or company. And rajulN mutawaH-idN↓ A man who remains alone, by himself, apart from others, or solitary, not mixing with other people, not sitting with them. (L.) See also waHodN.

waAHidN One; the first of the numbers: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) syn. [in many cases, which will be shown below,] with OaHadN: (Ḳ:) [and one alone: a single person or thing:] fem. waAHidapN: (L, Mṣb:) it sometimes receives the dual form; (L, Ḳ;) as in the expression UilotaqayonaA waAHidayoni [We met, we being each of us one alone]; cited from a poet by IAạr: or the dual form pertains to it in another sense, explained below, namely “alone:” (L:) pl. waAHiduwna (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and wuHodaAnN and OuHodaAnN; (Ṣ, L;) in the last of which, O is substituted for w because of the ḍammeh: (L:) one says, Oanotumo HaI-N waAHidN, and HaI-N waAHiduwna, (Ye are one tribe, L) like as one says XirocimapN qaliyluwna: (Fr, Ṣ, L:) MHaAdN may also be a pl. of waAHidN [and therefore originally OawoHaAdN,] like as OaXohaAdN is pl. of XaAhidN. (Th, Mṣb.) Its proper signification is A thing having no subdivision: and it is secondarily applied to any existing thing; so that there is no number to which it may not be applied as an epithet; wherefore one says, EaXarapN waAHidapN [One ten], and miAYapN waAHidapN [One hundred]. (Er-Rághib.) It is interchangeable for OaHadN when used as an epithet applied to God; and in certain nouns of number. [See art. OHd.] In most cases differing from these two, there is a difference in usage. The latter is used in affirmative phrases as a prefixed noun only, governing the noun which follows it in the gen. case; and is used absolutely in negative phrases: whereas the former is used in affirmative phrases as a prefixed n. and otherwise. (Mṣb.) [See, again, art. OaHd.]
lasotu fiI hecaA AlOamori biOawoHada↓ I am not alone, without a parallel, or watch, in this affair: (Ṣ,* L, Ḳ:*) or simply, I am not alone in it. (T, L.) The fem. waHodaMCu is not used. (Ṣ, L.)
OuHodaAnN, the pl. of AwHd↓, is applied by a poet to dogs having no equals or matches. (Ṣ, L.)
fulaAnN laA waAHida lahu Such a one has no equal, like, parallel, or match. (Ṣ, M, L.)
Also, One that has no equal; one unequalled. (L.)

fulaAnN waAHidu dahorihi Such a person is the unequalled one of his age. (Ṣ, L.) And in like manner, (TA,) fulaAnN OawoHadu↓ Oaholi zamaAnihi (Ṣ, L) Such a person is the unequalled one of the people of his time. (TA.) The pl. of AwHd↓ [as well as of wAHd in the same sense] is OuHodaAnN, (originally wuHodaAnN, Ṣ) like as suwdaAnN is pl. Oasowadu. (Ṣ, L.)
waAHidu Oum-ihi [An unequalled son of his mother], is an indeterminate expression, like nasiyju waHodihi, q. v. (Hishám, Fr. L.)

Also, A man pre-eminent in knowledge or science, or in valour in war, (L, Ḳ [in the CK, for baOos is put nAs]) or in other qualities; as though having no equal, and thus being alone: (L:) pl. wuHodaAnN and OuHodAnN. (L, Ḳ.)

AlwaAHidu and AlOaHadu (T, L) and AlOawoHadu↓ and AlmutawaH-idu↓, (M, L, Ḳ,) epithets applied to God, The One, the Sole; He whose attribute is unity: (M, L, Ḳ:) or the first signifies the One in essence, who has no like nor equal; and the second, the One in attributes, beside whom there is no other: or the first, the One who is not susceptible of division into parts or portions, nor of duplication, and who has no equal nor like: (TL:) or the One who has ever been alone, without companion: (IAth, L:) and there is no being but God to whom the first and second of these epithets are applicable together, or to whom the second is applicable alone. (T, L.) See also OaHadN, in art. OHd.
AlUinosaAnu waAlfarasu waAHidN fiI Aljinosi The human being and the horse are one in genus. And zayod waEamrowN waAHidN fiI Aln-awoEi Zeyd and ʼAmr are one in species. (Er-Rághib.)
waAHidN Singular, as opposed to plural: pl. wuHodaAnN. (The lexicons, passim.)
OaSoHaAbiI waOaSoHaAbuka waAHidN [Thy companions and my companions are one and the same]. And Aljuluwsu waAlquEuwd waAHidN [Aljlws and AlqEwd are one and the same]. (L.)
See waHiydN.

HaAdiIa EaXara, masc., and HaAdiyapa EaXorapa, fem., Eleventh. In this case, [and in similar instances, as HaAdiI waEiXoruwna Twentyfirst,, &c.,] HAdI and HAdyp are formed by transposition from waAHidN and waAHidapN, by putting the first radical letter after the second. [When without the article, it is indecl.: but when rendered determinate by the article, the first word is decl.] You say, huwa HaAdiIa EaXarahumo [He is the eleventh of them]: and Alyawomu AlHaAdiI EaXara [The eleventh day]: and All-ayolapu AlHaAdiyapu EaXorapa [The eleventh night]. (ISd, L.) [The rules respecting HaAdiIa EaXara and its fem. are the same as those respecting vaAliva EaXara and its fem., explained in art. vlv, q. v.]
biwaAHidapK signifies i. q. faqaTo: and is often used in the sense of Albat-apa. (MF, voce cur-uwHN.)
UiHodaI: see art. OHd.
OuHaAda: see muwoHada.
OawoHadu: see waAHidN.
muwHidN A ewe bringing forth, or that brings forth, one ewe only. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See mugoridN.]

mawoHada and wuHaAda↓ and OuHaAda [used adverbially] are imperfectly decl. because of their having the quality of an epithet and deviating from their original form, (Ṣ, L,) which is waAHidFA: (L, Ḳ:) or because they differ from their original both as to the letter and the meaning; the original word being changed as above stated, and the meaning being changed to waAHidFA waAHidFA: (Ṣ, L:) you say daxaluwA mawoHada mawoHada, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) [and wuHaAda wuHaAda,] and OuHaAda OuHaAda, (L, Ḳ,) They entered one [and] one, [one and one]; or one [by] one, [one by one]; (Ḳ;) or one at a time; one after another. (Ṣ, L.)

[muwaH-adapN, (not muwHadapN,) conv. term in lexicology, Having one diacritical point; one-pointed: an epithet added to bAC to prevent its being mistaken for tAC, vAC, or yAC. (The lexicons, passim.)]

miyHaAdN One of several hills, such as are called OakamaAt, separate or remote, one from another: pl. mawaAHiydu. (L, Ḳ.) F remarks, that J is in error in saying, AlmiyHaAdu mina AlwaAHidi kaAlmiEoXaAri mina AlEaXarapi: (TA:) but the meaning of this is, that it denotes one part or portion; like as miEoXaArN signifies one of ten: (L:) [i. e., the former signifies one of several things whereof each is alone, or by itself:] and the same explanation is given by [several] old authors. (TA.) [In one copy of the Ṣ, instead of AlEaXarap, I find AlEuXor; which affords a good sense, i. e., that myHAd, is syn. with waAHidN; and may be the true reading.]
mutawaH-idN: see waHiydN and waAHidN.

hom.sense: 1. waHuXa, aor. _u {yawoHuXu}, [inf. n., probably, wuHuwXapN or waHaAXapN or both,] It (a place) abounded with wild animals. (IḲṭṭ.) [The meaning assigned to this verb in Freytag's Lex. belongs not to it, but to waxuXa.]

waHaXa bihi, [or bihaA,] aor. yaHiXu, (IAạr, Ḳ,) inf. n. waHoXN; (TḲ;) and wH-X↓ bihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or bihaA, (Ṣ, A,) which latter form of the verb is disapproved by IAạr, but both are correct; (TA;) and twH-X↓ [app. used alone, the objective complement being understood]; (TA;) He threw it, or them, away, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or to a distance, (A,) namely, his garment, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or his garments, (A,) and his sword, (TA,) and his spear, (Ṣ, TA,) and his weapon, or weapons, (Ṣ, A,) or anything, (TA,) to lighten himself, (A,) or his beast of carriage, (TA,) in fear of his being overtaken: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [or in any case; for] it is said in a trad. of El-Ows and El-Khazraj, fawaHaXuwA biOasoliHatihimo wQEotanaqa baEoDuhumo baEoDFA [Then they threw away their weapons, and embraced one another]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.

hom.sense: 4. AwHX It (a place, A, Mṣb, or a place of alighting or abode, Ṣ, Ḳ) was, or became, desolate, deserted, or destitute of human beings; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the people having gone from it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also twH-X↓. (A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And [in like manner you say of a land,] twH-Xt↓ AlOaroDu, [and AstwHXt↓, (see OaroDN waHoXapN, voce waHoXN,)] The land was, or became waHoXap (Ṣ, TA) [i. e. desolate, deserted,, &c.]

He (a man) was, or became, hungry; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA;) not having eaten anything, so that his inside was empty; (TA;) as also twH-X↓: (A:) or the latter signifies his belly became empty by reason of hunger. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Also the former, His provisions became spent, or exhausted. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, qado OawoHaXonaA munocu layolatayoni Our provisions have been spent for two nights. (Ṣ.) You say also, twH-X↓ lild-awaMCi (Ṣ, A, Ḳ *) He made himself hungry; (A;) or made his inside, (Ṣ,) or his stomach, (Ḳ,) empty of food (Ṣ, Ḳ) and beverage; (Ḳ;) for the purpose of drinking medicine. (Ṣ,* A,* Ḳ.)
AwHX AlOaroDa He found the land to be waHoXap (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ) [i. e. desolate, deserted, or destitute of human beings].

AwHX Alr-ajula (Ṣ, A) He made the man lonely, or solitary; and sad, sorrowful, or disquieted or troubled in mind; [by his absence, or withdrawal of himself; and afraid;] or he made him to feel, or experience, waHoXap [i. e. loneliness, or solitude,, &c.]; (Ṣ;) contr. of Mnasahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, in art. Ons,) inf. n. UiynaAsN. (Ṣ, in that art.) Hence the saying of the people of Mekkeh, [and of Egypt,] OawoHaXotanaA [Thou hast made us lonely,, &c., by thine absence]. (TA.) [See also an ex. from a poet, voce OunosN: And see its quasi-pass., 10.]

entry.sense: 5. twH-X He (a beast) became wild, or shy; syn. Oabada, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, &c., in art. Obd,) and taOab-ada. (A, L, in that art.) And He (a man) became unsocial, unsociable, unfamiliar, or shy; like a wild animal; syn. Oabida, (Ṣ, Ḳ, ubi supra,) and taOab-ada: (A, Ḳ, ubi supra;) and AstwHX↓ signifies the same; (see this verb below;) or he became, or made himself, as though on a par with the wild animals; expl. by laHiqa baAlowaHoXi. (TA.) [See exs. of both voce Oanisa.]
See also 4, in five places.
And see 1.

hom.sense: 10. AstwHX: see 5.

It is also quasi-pass. of OawoHaXa Alr-ajula, (Ṣ, TA,) and [thus] signifies He felt, or experienced, waHoXap [i. e. loneliness, or solitude,, &c.; and sadness, grief, sorrow, or disquietude or trouble of mind,, &c.; and fear,, &c.]. (Ṣ,* Ḳ, TA.) And AstwHX UilaI AlX-aIoCi [He felt a want of the thing]. (Ḳ, voce EuriIa, q. v.) You say also AstwHX minohu, (A, TA,) or Eanohu, (Mṣb,) [meaning He was afraid of, or feared, him, or it; agreeably with an explanation of the inf. n. in Ḥar, p. 331: see also an instance below, voce waHoXN: or] meaning he was shy of him; averse from him; unsocial, unsociable, or unfamiliar, with him; and like a wild animal. (TA.)
AstwHXt AlOaroDu: see 4.
[He deemed a word, or sound, &c., strange, or uncouth.]

entry.sense: HiXapN: pl. HiXuwna: see waHoXN.

waHoXN, applied to a country, or region, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and a place, (TA,) and a house (dAarN), (A,) and [its fem.] waHoXapN, applied to a land (OaroDN), (Ṣ, TA,) to a house (dAr); (A;) Desolate, deserted, or destitute of human beings or inhabitants; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as also muwHiXN↓ and mutawaH-iXN↓: (A:) and OaroDN waHoXapN and musotawoHiXapN↓ signify the same. (Ḳ, TA.) You say also, bilaAdN HiXuwna Countries, or regions, desolate, deserted,, &c.; after the manner of sinuwna; and in the accus. and gen., HiXiyna: pl., as Az says, of HiXapN↓, originally waHoXN, [So I read instead of waHoXap, which is evidently a mistranscription,] the w being wanting, as it is in zinapN and SilapN and EidapN. (TA.) You also say, laqiytuhu biwaHoXi UiSomita, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and UiSomitapa, (TA,) i. e., I found him, or met him, in a desolate, or deserted, country, or region. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See remarks on the last word in the former phrase in art. Smt.] And in like manner, tarakotuhu biwaHoXi Almatoni I left him in the desert part of the elevated plain, where one could not reach him. (L, TA.*) And [hence] HimaAru waHoXK An ass of a desert; [i. e. a wild ass;] as also HimaArN waHoXiI-N. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [And baqaru AlwaHoXi The bull and cow, or bulls and cows, collectively, of the desert; i. e., the wild bull and cow, or bulls and cows.]

[Hence also] Animals (HayawaAn [which is used as a sing. and a pl., but is here meant to be understood collectively, as appears from what follows,]) of the desert, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA,) such as are not tame; (TA;) [i. e. wild animals;] of the fem. gender; (TA;) as also wuHuwXN (Ṣ) and waHiyXN↓: (Ḳ:) these three words are all used in a collective sense: (ISh:) and waHoXiI-N↓ signifies a single one of such animals; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like zanojiI-N in relation to zanojN, and ruwmiI-N to ruwmN: (TA:) or waHoXN signifies such as is not tame, of beasts of the desert; and everything that is afraid of human beings (kul-u XaIoCK yasotawoHiXu Eani Aln-aAsi); as also waHoXiI-N↓, as though the I were a corroborative, as in dw-aAriI-N: or, accord. to El-Fárábee, waHoXN in the pl. [lexicologically, but not in the language of the grammarians] of waHoXiI-N↓, like as ruwmN is of ruwmiI-N: (Mṣb:) or it is used as a sing., as well as collectively; for you say, hecaA waHoXN DaxomN [this is a bulky wild animal], and hecihi XaApN waHoXN [this is a wild sheep or goat,, &c.]: (ISh:) wuHuwXN is a pl. of waHoXN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and so is wuHoXaAnN, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) and so is waHiyXN, [lexicologically, but grammarians term it a quasi-pl. n.,] like as DaYiynN is of DaOonN: (Ṣgh, TA:) or wuHuwXN is its only broken pl. (TA.)
[Hence also, Wild, or shy; applied to girls or women: see an ex. of the word in this sense voce taw-N, where it has a redundant n affixed to it.]
[Hence also] Lone; solitary; without company. You say. maXaI fiI AlOaroDi waHoXFA He walked, or went, in the land alone, having no other with him. (TA.)

[Hence also] Hungry; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also muwHiXN↓, (AZ, A,) and mutawaH-iXN↓, (A,) and waHiXN↓: (TA:) pl. of the first, OawoHaAXN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) [and waHoXuwna]. You say, baAta fulaAnN waHoXFA, (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ,*) and muwHiXFA, and mutawaH-iXFA, (A,) Such a one passed the night hungry, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) not having eaten anything, so that his inside was empty. (TA.) And bitonaA waHoXiyna We passed the night without food. (TA.) [In another place in the TA, we find laqado bitonaA layolatanaA hecihi waHoXiI, and so in the L; the last word being evidently a mistranscription, for waHoXiyna: and it is added, as though the speaker meant, jamaAEapa waHoXaI; doubtless a mistake for jamaAEapa waHoXK so that the saying seems to mean, We have passed this our night like a company of wild animals.]
waHiXN: see waHoXN, last signification.

waHoXapN Loneliness; solitude; lonesomeness; solitariness; desolateness; syn. xalowapN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) sadness; grief; sorrow; disquietude, or trouble, of mind: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or sadness,, &c., arising from loneliness or solitude: (TA:) fear: (Ḳ, TA:) or fear, or fright, arising from loneliness or solitude: (TA:)
a state of disunion between men, and remoteness of hearts from feelings of love or affection; from waHoXN signifying “a wild beast,” or “wild beasts, of the desert:” (Mṣb:) unsociableness; unfriendliness; unsocialness; unfamiliarity; shyness; wildness: [in all the above senses] contr. of OunosN. (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, in art. Ons.) [Hence, layolapu AlwaHoXapi The night of loneliness,, &c.; the first night after burial: also called layolapu AlwaHodapi, q. v.] You say, tarakotuhu fiI waHoXapK I left him in loneliness, or solitude. (TḲ.) And Oaxacatohu AlwaHoXapu Sadness, grief, sorrow, or disquietude or trouble of mind, or sadness,, &c., arising from loneliness or solitude, laid hold upon him. (TA.)

waHoXiI-N [Of, or belonging to, or relating to, the desert: and hence, wild; untamed; undomesticated; uncivilized; unfamiliar: and often used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant]: see waHoXN, in three places: i. q. HuwXiI-N; (Ṣ, Mṣb, art. HwX;) contr. of OaholiI-N. (TA, in art. Ahl.)
kalaAmN waHoXiI-N ‡ i. q. HuwXiI-N, q. v. (Ṣ, A, art. HwX:) and in like manner, lafoZapN waHoXiy-apN↓ ‡ i. q. HuwXiy-apN. (Mz, 13th nwE.)

The right side of anything: (AZ, AA, Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.:) or the left side (Aṣ, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) of anything. (Aṣ, Ṣ.) [For more full explanations of this term, and its contr. UinosiI-N, in relation to a beast and to a man, see the latter term: of a beast, accord. to most authorities, it is The right, far or off, side. See an ex. in a verse cited voce daf-N.] Of the arm or hand, and of the leg or foot, The back; UinosiI-N signifying the side that is towards the man: (Ṣ:) or of the foot, the former means [the outer side, or] the side that is the more remote from the other foot; the latter being the contr., or that which is towards the other foot. (TA.) Of a bow, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or of a Persian bow, (TA,) The back; and UinosiI-N, the side that is towards thee: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or of a bow, whether Persian or not is not said, the former means the side against which the arrow does not lie. (TA.) And AljaAnibu AlwaHiyXu↓ signifies the same as AlwaHoXiI-u. (IAạr.)

A sort of fig, that grows in the mountains and in the remote parts of valleys, of every colour, black and red and white; it is the smallest of figs, [in the TA, smaller than the tbn,] and when eaten newly plucked it burns the mouth; but it is dried. (AḤn, L.)
waHoXiy-apN [or riyHN waHoXiy-apN] A wind that enters one's clothes, by reason of its vehemence. (Ḳ.)
waHoXaAnu, applied to a man, Sad; sorrowful: pl. waHaAXaI. (Ḳ.)
waHiyXN: see waHoXN, (of which it is a quasi-pl. n.,) in two places:
and see waHoXiI-N.
muwHiXN: see waHoXN, first sentence, and near the end.

OaroDN mawoHuwXapN A land having, (Fr, Ṣ, A,) or abounding with, (Ḳ,) wild animals, or animals of the desert. (Fr, Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) [See OaroDN majoruwadpN, in art. jrd.] In [some of] the copies of the Ḳ, muwHiXapN, which is a mistake. (TA.)
mutawaH-iXN: see waHoXN, first sentence, and near the end:
OaroDN musotawoHiXapN: see waHoXN, first sentence.
R. Q. 1. waxowaxa His belly was, or became, flabby. (TA, voce xaboxaba.)

waxowaAxN A fat and fleshy man, whose flesh shakes: (L:) having a flaccid belly, and dilated skin; (L, Ḳ;) as also baxobaAxN: (L:) lazy; (L, Ḳ;) unwilling to work: (L:) lazy or heavy: (L:) weak: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a weak coward: (L:) ad venerum impotens; (L, Ḳ;) as also baxobaAxN and cawocaxN: (L:) qui se polluit, aut concacat, tempore coitus; as also nxbAx and cwcx. (IAạr.)
Anything flaccid: (L:) and particularly a flaccid date: (Ḳ:) or a date having a flaccid skin: (L:) or a date having no sweetness nor taste. (IAạr.)

1. waxada, aor. yaxidu, inf. n. waxodN and waxadaAnN (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ) and waxiydN, (Ḳ,) He (a camel) went along throwing out his legs like the ostrich: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or went quickly: or went with wide steps: (L, Ḳ:) as also xadaI: (L:) also said of a horse, (Kr, L,) and of an ostrtch. (TA.) See naSaba Als-ayora.
wxuwdN: see waAxidN.
wax-aAdN: see waAxidN.

waAxidN and wax-aAdN↓ (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and waxuwdN↓ (L, Ḳ) A camel going along, or that goes along, throwing out his legs like the ostrich: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or, quickly: or, with wide steps. (L, Ḳ.) The second [which is an intensive or frequentative epithet] is also applied to an ostrich: and the third [which is intensive] to a she-camel. (L.)
1. waxaca, &c.: see art. Oaxc.

1. waxazahu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) aor. yaxizohu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. waxozN (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) He pierced, stabbed, or pricked him, with a spear, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or other thing, (Ḳ,) or with the like of a spear, as a dagger, (Ṣ,) and a needle, (A, Mṣb,), &c., (Mṣb,) not making the instrument to pass through: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or, as some say, he did so making the instrument to pass through: in a trad., the plague (AlT-aAEuwn) is said to be a waxoz inflicted by jinn, or genii; and the word in this instance is explained by some agreeably with the former rendering, and by some agreeably with the latter: or waxozN signifies a slight piercing, and is like a goading: so accord. to Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, who uses the expression waxaza fiI sanaAmihaA bimiboDaEihi [He made a slight stab in her hump with his scarifier]. (TA.) waxozN also signifies The act of scarifying; syn. taboziygN. (Ḳ. [So in a MṢ copy of the Ḳ, and this is the right reading: in the TA, taboziyE, written with E, unpointed: in the CK, tanoziyE, with n and E instead of b and g.]) You say of a farrier, waxazahu bimiboDaEK waxozFA xafiyfFA laA yabolugu AlEaSaba [He scarified it with a scarifier slightly, not penetrating to the sinews]; the pronoun referring to the hoof of a horse or the like, and the place of the operation being the part called the OaXaAEir. (Aboo-ʼAdnán, TA.)
waxozN The plague; syn. TaAEuwnN. (TA.) See above.
Pain: [or, app., a piercing, or pricking, pain:] as in the following ex.: Uin-iI laOajidu fiI yadiI wxozFA [Verily I feel, in my arm, or hand, a pain, or a piercing, or pricking, pain]. (IAạr, TA.)
1. waxuXa, aor. _u {yawoxuXu}, inf. n. waxaAXapN and wuxuwXapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and wuxuwXN, (TA,) It (a thing, Ṣ, TA,) became bad, vile, or base. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)

waxoXN Bad, vile, or base; applied to anything: (Ḳ:) low, ignoble, vile, base, or mean; the refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, of mankind; (Lth, Az, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) the abject, contemptible, or despicable, thereof; (Lth, Az, Mṣb;) used as a pl., (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and dual, (Mṣb,) and sing., and masc. and fem., without variation: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) but sometimes it is made fem. by the addition of p: (IAạr, ISd:) and has the dual form: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and has for its pl. OawoxaAXN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and wixaAXN; (Ḳ;) or the latter is pl. of waxoXapN. (TA.) You say, rajulN waxoXN and UimoraOapN waxoXN and qawomN waxoXN [A man, and a woman, and a company of men, low, ignoble,, &c.]. (TA.) And celika rajulN mino waxoXi Aln-aAsi That is a man of the low, ignoble, vile, base, or mean, of mankind. (Ṣ.) And jaMCaniI OawoxaAXN mina Aln-aAsi Some of the refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, of mankind came to me. (Ṣ.) And waxoXan-N↓ is the same as waxoXN: (TA:) the rájiz (Dahlab, TA) says,
jaAriyapN layosato mina AlwaxoXan-i
[A girl who is not of the low, or ignoble,, &c.]; meaning AlwaxoXi; adding a double n. (Ṣ, TA.)
waxoXan-N: see waxoXN.

dictScrap.label: See art. wxTh in two places.

entry.sense: 1. waxaTahu, aor. yaxiTu, (TA,) inf. n. waxoTN, (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) He pierced him through: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or he pierced him slightly; (Ḳ, TA;) not through: (TA:) or he pierced him so as to penetrate into his inside; not piercing him through; (Aṣ, TA;) baAlr-umoHi with the spear; as also waxaDahu. (TA.) [See also waxazahu.]

[And hence,] waxaTahu AlX-ayobu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ḳ,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) ‡ Hoariness, or whiteness, became intermixed in his hair; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as also waxaDahu: (TA:) or appeared or spread upon him: or his blackness and whiteness [of hair] became equal: (Ḳ:) and you say of the man, wuxiTa: (Ḳ,* TA:) or this signifies his head became hoary, or white. (TA.)
5. twx-T: see 2, in art. xyT.
waxoTN [originally an inf. n. (see above)] is said to signify ‡ A little, somewhat, or a small degree, of hoariness, or whiteness of the hair. (TA.)
You say also, bahaA waxoTN mino waHoXK ‡ In it [meaning a land (OaroD)] is a small number of wild animals. (TA.)
TaEonN wax-aATN [A piercing, of one or another of the kinds described above, that is much, or frequent]: and in like manner rumoHN wax-aATN [a spear so piercing, much, or frequently]. (TA.)

mawoxuwTN A man (TA) having hoariness, or whiteness, intermixed in his hair: or upon whom hoariness, or whiteness, has appeared and spread: or whose blackness and whiteness [of hair] have become equal: (Ḳ:) or whose head has become hoary, or white. (TA.)

1. wad-ahu, first pers. wadidotu, (Ṣ, M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and wadadotu, (Ks, Z, Ḳ,) [but most disallow this] aor. yawad-u, inf. n. wud-N and wid-N and wad-N, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) of which three forms the first is the most common, (MF,) and mawad-apN, (Ṣ, M, L, Ḳ,) or this last is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) and miwad-apN (CK and some MṢ. copies of the Ḳ) and mawid-apN, (accord. to some other copies of the Ḳ, this and the next preceding deviating from the common forms of inf. ns., TA,) and mawodidapN (M, Ḳz, Ḳ) and mawodadapN, (TA,) but these last two are allowable only in poetry, and deviate from constant rule, the former doubly, (Ḳz, MF, TA,) and widaAdN and wadaAdN and wudaAdN, (M, L, Ḳ,) the first of which last three forms is the most common, (MF,) and wadaAdapN (M, L, Ḳ) and, accord. to some, widaAdapN and wudaAdapN, (MF, TA,) and, as in a copy of the Ḳ esteemed of good authority, mawoduwdapN, (TA,) He loved, or affected, him, or it, (Ṣ, M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) i. e. any means of attaining or doing good. (AZ, M, L.) The form wadadotu is disallowed by the Basrees who hold it to be erroneous: and Zj says, We know that Ks did not mention wadadotu without having heard it; but he heard it from him who was no authority. (T, L.)
Oawodidohu, an imp. form [of Oawad-ahu↓], without idghám, accord. to the dial. of El-Ḥijáz, occurs in a trad., meaning Love thou it, or affect it. (L.)

wadidotu lawo tafoEalu celika. and wadadotu lawo Oan-aka tafoEalu celika, (Ṣ, L,) aor. as above, inf. n. wud-N and wad-N and wadaAdapN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb) and wadaAdN (Ṣ, L) or widaAdN, (T, in TT,) I wished that thou wouldest do that. (Ṣ, L.)
wadidotu lawo kaAna kacaA I wished that it had been so. (Mṣb.)

wadidotu AlX-aIoCa I wished for the thing. Fr says, This is the more approved form; but some say wadadotu: in both cases the aor. is yawad-a only. (L.) [Respecting the latter form of the pret., see above.] This is a secondary signification of the verb. (TA.)
3. wAd-hu, inf. n. muwaAd-apN and widaAdN, He loved, or affected him, being loved, or affected, by him. (Mṣb.)
4: see 1.
5. twd-dhu He attracted to himself his love, or affection. (IAạr, L, Ḳ.)
twd-d Uilayohi He manifested, or showed, love, or affection, to him. (L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
6. humaA yatawaAd-aAni, (Ṣ, L,) inf. n. tawaAd-N, (Ḳ,) They two love, or affect, each other. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

wid-N (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and wud-N↓ (L, Ḳ) and wad-N↓ (IJ, L, Ḳ) and wadiydN↓ (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) A person loved, or beloved; an object of love; a friend; syn. xib-N and HabiybN and SadiyqN (L) and muHab-N. (Ḳ: in the CK muHib-N.)

Also, wudN↓ (TA) and waduwdN↓ (Ṣ, L, Mṣb) and wadiydN↓ (TA) and waAd-N↓ (Ḳz) A person who loves; loving; affectionate: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, TA:) the first also used in a pl. sense, (L, Ḳ,) being [originally] an inf. n. (TA) and the second used alike as masc. and fem. (Ṣ, L, Mṣb.)
Also, wud-N↓ and wuduwdN↓ and miwad-N↓, (Ḳ,) also written mawad-N↓, (MF,) A man (TA) loving much; having much love or affection; very loving or affectionate. (Ḳ, MF.)

Pl. OawodaAdN, (L, Ḳ,) pl. of wid-N, (TA,) and also a pl. [of wud-N] in the second of the above senses; (Ḳ;) and wadaAdN, [pl. of wad-N or wadiydN] in the first of the above senses; (L;) and Oawud-N, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) pl. of wud-N (TA) in the second of the above senses; (Ḳ;) or of wid-N; (Ṣ, TA;) and Oawod-N, (L, Ḳ,) [an irreg. pl., or quasi-pl. n., upon which I find no remark,] in the first of the above senses, (L,) or the second; (Ḳ;) and wud-aAdN, pl. of waAd-N; (Ḳz;) and Oawid-aMCu, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) pl. of wadiydN (TA) in the first of the above senses, (L,) or in the second; (L;) and Oawid-apN, (Ḳ,) also pl. of wadiydN (TA) in the second of the above senses; (Ḳ;) and wudadaMCu, pl. of waduwdN (Ṣ) in the second of the above senses, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [and the third]; and wadiydN is also mentioned as a pl. in the second of the above senses in the Ḳ; but this is probably a mistake for widaAdN. (TA.)
IAth says, that wud-N↓, used as an epithet, is for cuw wud-K; but wid-N does not require cw to be understood, being syn. with SadiyqN. (L.)

hom.sense: wad-N: see 1, and wid-N.

wad-N and wud-N↓ (the former is the more common, L) A certain idol (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) which pertained to the people of Noah, and then to Kelb, and was at Doomet-el-Jendel: (Ṣ, L:) or a certain good man, who lived between Adam and Noah, and of whom, after his death, was made an image, which, after a long time, became an object of worship; like suwaAEN and yaguwvu and yaEuwqu and nasorN, mentioned therewith in the Ḳur, lxxi. 22 and 23: (Bḍ:) and the former, a certain idol belonging to Kureysh, also called Oud-N. (L.)
biwad-iki By thy Wedd! meaning the idol so named. (L.)
wad-N A wooden pin, peg, or stake; i. q. watidN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) of the dial. of Temeem; (IDrd;) or of Nejd: as though they made the t quiescent and incorporated it into the d. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: wud-N: see 1, and wid-N, and wad-N.

biwud-iI Oano yakuwna kacaA I wish that such a thing may be. In the following saying of the poet,
Oay-uhaA AlEaAYidu AlmusaAYilu Ean-aA
wabiwud-iyka lawo varaI OakofaAniI
[O thou visitor of the sick, inquiring respecting us, wishing that thou mayest see my graveclothes], the kesreh of the d is lengthened for sake of the measure. (Ṣ, L.)
waduwdN: see wid-N.

Alwaduwdu, as an epithet applied to God, The loving towards his servants, (IAmb, L,) or, towards those who obey: (Beyd, lxxxv. 14:) or He who regards with approbation his righteous servants: or He who is beloved in the hearts of his saints. (IAth, L.)
waduwdN also, A mare that puts forth all her power of running. (ISd, L.)
wadiydN: see wid-N.
waAd-N: see wid-N.
Oawad-u More or most, loving or affectionate. Said to be also used as a pl., for Oawad-uwna. (L.)
mawad-N and miwad-N: see wid-N.
mawad-apN Love; affection. (Mṣb.) See also 1.

Also, A letter; an epistle: and letters, or epistles: syn. kitaAbN and kutubN. (IAạr, L, Ḳ.) Said to have the latter meaning in the Ḳur, lx. 1, in the first of the instances of its occurrence there: (L, Ḳ:) but this is a strange interpretation. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. wadaOahu, aor. yadaOu, He made it even or plain. (Ḳ.)
See 5.
wdO (aor. yadaOu, T) Veretrum exseruit equus: (T, Ḳ:) but AHeyth says that this is an error, and that the correct word is without C: [i. e., wadaI, q.v.]. (TA.)
daOoniI [imp.], i. q. daEoniI, Let me, &c. (Ḳ.) Said by some to be of weak authority. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. wd-O Elyh AlOaroDa, inf. n. tawodiIoCN, He made the earth even, or plain, over him. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
wad-aOatohu AlOaroDu The earth, or the land, hid, or concealed, him. (TA.) [See also 5.]
wd-O, He, or it, buried. (IAạr.)
wd-O bihimo, inf. n. tawodiYapN; (Ṣ, L;) accord. to the Ḳ, wadaOa; but this is incorrect; (TA;) He covered, or overwhelmed, them with evil, or with ill treatment. (L, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 5. twd-Atu Ealayohi AlOaroDu The earth became even, or plain, over him, (Ḳ,) as over a dead body in the grave: (TA:) or enclosed him: or was overturned over him: or was broken in pieces over him. (Ḳ.)

The earth, or the land, hid, or concealed, him. (TA.) [See also 2.] This phrase is used when a person has gone away to the more distant parts of the earth, or land, so that it is not known what he has done: also, when a man has died; even if among his family. (ISh.)

twd-Ot Eanohu AlOaxobaAru News, or tidings, of him were cut off, or ceased to come; like wadiYato↓, and were hid. (Ḳ.) [In the Ḳ we read, Enh AlAxbAru AnqTEt (twd-Ot) Elyh w (twd-Ot) w Alx: whence it seems that twd-Ot Elyh AlAxbAr also has the above signification. But in the TA, after Elyh, in the passage above quoted from the Ḳ, is inserted AlArD. This word, however, has, I think, been inserted through inadvertence: if not, twd-Ot Elyh AlArDu signifies The land was interrupted to him, and hid: as also wadiYat↓.]
twd-O EalaI maAlihi He took his property or wealth, and kept it carefully. (Ḳ.)
twd-O Ealayohi He, or it, destroyed him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: wadaON Perdition; destruction. (Ḳ.)
muwad-aON [Earth made even, or plain, over a person: or earth hiding, or concealing, him;] like muHoSanN for muHoSinN, &c. (TA.)
A grave. (See below.)

Zuheyr Ibn-Mes-ood Ed-Ḍabbee says, in an elegy on his brother Ubeí,
Oa OubaI-u Uino tuSobiHo rahiyna muwad-aOK
zaloji AljawaAnibi qaEoruhu maloHuwdu
[O Ubeí! if thou become a deposit in a place over which the earth is made even, or plain, (or in a place that hideth thee, or in a grave,) with smooth, or slippery, sides, and having its bottom hollowed out laterally,]
(Ṣ, TA. See Ḥam, p. 466.)
muwad-aOapN A place of destruction, or perdition; or a desert in which is no water. (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also, accord. to IAạr, or without p, as in an example which he quotes, A grave. (TA.)
wadobN An evil state, or condition. (L, Ḳ.)

1. wadaja, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yadiju}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. wadojN (L, Ḳ) and widaAjN; (L;) and wd-j↓, inf. n. tawodiyjN; (Ḳ;) but the latter has an intensive signification; (Mṣb;) He cut the vein called Alwadaj: (Ḳ:) he bled a beast by cutting the vein so called; wdj with reference to a beast, as the object of the act, being the same as faSada with reference to a man. (Ṣ.)

wadaja, inf. n. wadojN ‡ He put to rights; put into a right or proper state; adjusted. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) wadaja AlmaAla He put the property into a right or proper state. (Mṣb.) wadaja bayona Alqawomi He adjusted differences between the people, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and put an end to evil. (TA.)
2: see 1.
3. wAdjhu, inf. n. muwaAdajapN, ‡ He acted towards him with gentleness and good nature. (ISh, A.)

hom.sense: wadajN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) also written with kesreh, [app. widojN, but perhaps wadijN,] (Mṣb,) and widaAjN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [A name given to each of the external jugular veins;] a certain vein in the neck; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) one of two veins, which are called the wadajaAni: (T, Ṣ, &c.:) these are two veins extending from the head to the lungs; and the pl. is OawodaAjN: (M:) or two great veins on the right and left of the pit between the clavicles: (Mṣb, TA:) they are by the side of the wariydaAni, [here app. meaning the two carotid arteries,] and are of the number of the veins in which the blood [merely] runs, whereas the wrydAn are for pulsation and for [the diffusion of] the soul, Alnfs [i. e Aln-afos, not Aln-afas; for, accord. to the Arabs, the animal soul (Alr-uwHu AlHayowaAniI-u, as is said in the KT,) diffuses itself throughout the body, from the heart, by means of the pulsing veins, or arteries]: (T, Mṣb, TA:) accord. to some, the wdj and wryd are the same; [meaning, that each of these names is applied to the external jugular vein:] (Mṣb:) or the AwdAj are the veins which surround the windpipe: (TA:) or the wdj is the vein called the OaxodaE, [elsewhere said to be a branch from the wryd, in the place where one is cupped,] which the slaughterer [of an animal] cuts through, thereby putting an end to life. (Mṣb.)
wadajaAni ‡ Two brothers: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) two persons mutually attached; likened to the two veins so called. (A.) biYosa wadajaA HarobK humaA Two evil brothers of war are they two. (Ṣ.)

wadajN ‡ A cause; a means whereby one attains to a thing; syn. sababN and wasiylapN; (Ḳ;) or, as in some lexicons, wuSolapN. (TA.) Ex. kaAna fulaAnN wadajiI UilaI kacaA Such a one was my means of attaining to such a thing. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. AwdH He confessed; syn. Oaqar-a: (L, Ḳ:) or he confessed a falsehood, or what was false: (ISk, T, Ḳ:) or he confessed himself submissive to him who would lead, guide, or govern, him: (AZ, T, Ḳ:) he was submissive, or prompt in obedience, and humble. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
He (a ram) held back, and would not mount the female. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
AwdHt AlUibilu The camels became fat and in good condition. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. wacaOahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yacaOu, (TA,) inf. n. wacoCN, (Ṣ,) He imputed to him a vice, fault, or the like; despised him; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) chid him; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and blamed, or reproached him. (AʼObeyd.)
wacaOato Eanohu Eayonuhu His eye recoiled from him, or it: syn. nabato Enh. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 8. Uit-acaOa, quasi-pass. of wacaOa, He was charged with a vice, fault, or the like;, &c. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
wacoCN Disapproved, or hateful, language; (Ḳ;) whether it be reviling or of another description.
maA bihi wacoOapN (like wacoyahN) There is no fault, or defect, (Eil-ap,) in him or it. (Aboo-Málik, Ḳ.*)

wicaAbN The stomach of a ruminant beast, (or, as in some lexicons, the stomachs of such beasts, TA,) with the intestines, or guts, into which milk is put, and which are then cut in pieces, [and eaten]: a pl. which has no sing. (ISd, Ḳ.)

Also The perforations, or punctures, made in sewing, or the loops, (the word in the original is xurabN, pl. of xurabopN: in some of the lexicons, xurazN: but both these words relate to the same things: TA: [whence it appears that, accord. to the author of the TA, &c., the former of the above two meanings is the one intended:]) of a mazaAdap. (Ḳ.)
1. waciHati AlX-aAtu, aor. tawocaHu and tayocaHu (Ṣ, Ḳ) or tiycaH, (TA,) inf. n. wacaHN, (Ṣ,) The sheep was, or became, foul with wacaH [q. v. infrà.] (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
waciHa, inf. n. as above, He suffered from an inflammation and excoriation of the inner sides of his thighs; (En-Naḍr, L, Ḳ;*) as also maciHa. (En-Naḍr, L.)

wacaHN The dung and urine that have clung to the wool of sheep, (Ḳ,) or to their tails and the inner sides of the roots of their thighs (OarofaAghA), and dry [thereon]: (Ṣ:) or the filth that clings to the rump, or buttocks, of the ram: (Th:) n. un. with p {wacaHapN}: pl. wucoHN; like budonN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) pl. of badanapN. (Ṣ.)

1. wacirahu, of the same measure as wasiEahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) or wacarahu, (Lth, ISk, T, TA,) is the original pret. of which the aor. is yacaruhu (Lth, ISk, T, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) signifying, He leaves, lets alone, or ceases or desists from, it, or him; he leaves it undone; syn. yadaEuhu, (ISk, T, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and yatorukuhu; (Mṣb;) imp. carohu, syn. daEohu: (ISk, T, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) but the pret. is not used, (Lth, Sb, ISk, T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) tarakahu being used in its stead; (Lth, T, Ṣ, TA;) and because its pret. is not used, the aor. is of the measure yafoEalu; for if there were a pret., [it would most probably be of the measure faEala, as this is the regular measure of trans. unaugmented triliteral verbs, and] the aor. would be of the measure yafoEulu or yafoEilu: (Sb, M, TA:) nor is the inf. n. used, (Lth, T, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) tarokN being used in its stead, (Lth, T, M, TA,) i. e., instead of wacorN: (Ḳ:) nor is the act. part. n., (ISk, T, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) namely waAcirN, instead of which taArikN is used: (ISk, T, Ṣ:) or the pret. is sometimes used, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) though rarely, (Mṣb,) or by the deviation from the constant course of speech: (Ḳ:) so in the Ḳ; but in the M it is said, that the phrase lamo Oaciro waraMYiI XayoYFA [I left not behind me anything, with kesr to the c, and so in the original copy of the TT,] is related on the authority of some of the Arabs. (TA.) You say, caro caA and daEo caA [Leave thou, or let alone, or cease or desist from, this]. (ISk, T.) It is said in the Ḳur, [lxxiii. 11,] wacaroniI waQlomukac-ibiyna And leave me, or let me alone, with the beliers, or descrediters; (Bḍ;) commit their case to me, (Bḍ, TA,) and busy not thy heart respecting them; (TA;) for I will stand thee in stead to recompense them. (Bḍ.)

hom.sense: 1. waraOa, aor. yaraOu, He repelled, pushed, or thrust. (Ḳ.)
waraOa mina AlT-aEaAmi He was, or became, filled with food. (Ḳ.)
maA wuriYotu, and mA wur-iYotu↓, I knew not. (Ḳ.) mA OuwriYotu↓ biAlX-aIoCi I knew not the thing, or of the thing. (L.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1.
4: see 1.
5. twr-Ot Ealayohi AlOaroDu i. q. twd-Ot, The earth became even, or plain, over him: or enclosed him:, &c. (IJ, Ḳ.)

10. AstwrOti AlUibilu The camels took fright and ran away, in a body, one after another: (Aṣ:) accord. to AZ, this is said when they have taken fright and ascended a mountain; but if they have taken fright and run away in a plain, one says AstOwrt: so in the dial. of the tribe of 'Okeyl. [Thus in the TA in this art.: but see UisotaWarto.]

waraMCa and waraMCu and waraMCi, indecl., (Ḳ,) an adverbial noun of place or time: (Bḍ, &c.:) J mentions it in art. wrI, regarding the _u as substituted for I; and this is the opinion of the Koofees, and of all writers on inflexion, though disapproved by F, who, however, mentions it again in art. wrI as though belonging to that art.: (TA:) Behind: and, contr., before. (Ḳ.) In like manner, AlwaraMCu [The location that is behind, or beyond; and the time past: and, contr. that is before, or preceding]. (Ḳ.) Or it does not bear contr. meanings; but one meaning; namely, what is concealed from one. (Ḳ, art. wrI.) Or it is a homonym; [but not a word of contr. meanings; as it signifies what is behind, or beyond, in respect of place, and what is before in respect of time]. Fr. says, It is not allowable to say, of a man behind thee, that he is bayona yadayoka; nor of a man before thee, that he is waraMCak; these expressions being only allowable [as synonymous] in cases relating to particular times of events or actions: thus one may say, waraMCaka barodN XadiydN and bayona yadayoka brd Xdyd [meaning Before thee is intense cold]: each of these expressions is allowable because the intense cold is a thing that is coming; so, as it will overtake thee, it is, as it were, behind thee; and as thou wilt attain to the period thereof, it is, as it were, before thee. It is said in the Ḳur, [xviii. 78,] kaAna waraMCahumo malikN There was before them a king: [because it has reference to a certain period, which might be said to be before them as they would attain to it, and behind them as it would overtake them: this passage Jelál-ed-Deen explains by saying, “there was behind them when they returned, and before them now, a king.”] Of the same kind also is the phrase min waraAYihi jahan-amu [Ḳur, xiv. 19,] Before him is hell: [for the same reason]. (TA.)
wayakofuruwna bimA waraMCahu, [Ḳur, ii. 85,] signifies And they disbelieve in what [hath been revealed] beside that: syn. siwaAhu: (IAạr:) or it may mean after that. (Jel.)

wrAC is masc. and fem. (TA.) Its dim. is wuray-iYapN, (Ḳ,) accord. to those who hold the _u to be a radical letter, not substituted for I; namely, the Basrees: accord. to others, wuray-apN and wuraI-N. (TA.)
[See also art. wrI.]
rajulN maAniEN maA waraMCa Zhorihi: see zab-uwnapN.
waraMCN A son's son, or son's offspring. (Ḳ.)
waraMCN Bulky, and thick in the OalowaAH, or shoulder-blades. (AAF.)
1. wariba, aor. yaworabu, inf. n. warabN, It, or he, (a root, origin, or stock, Ṣ, or a man, TA,) was, or became, corrupt. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

2. wr-b, inf. n. taworiybN, [app., He expressed himself respecting a thing equivocally, or ambiguously, by words objectionable in one sense, and allowable in another: so thinks IbrD:] the inf. n. is thus explained: Oano tuwar-iIa Eani AlX-aIoCi biAlmuEaAraDaAti waAlmubaAHaAti. (T, Ḳ, but in the latter, the w before the last word is omitted.)

3. wArb, inf. n. muwaArabapN He strove to outwit, deceive, beguile, or circumvent [another]: syn. daAhaI and xaAtala. (Ḳ.) Accord. to IAth, it is from Alwarabu “the being corrupt:” or it may be from AlArb “intelligence, &c.;” the O being changed into w. The latter is the opinion of AM. (L.)

One of the sages says, muwaArabapu AlOariybi jaholN waEanaACN [The striving to outwit the cunning, or intelligent, or sagacious, is ignorance and labour without profit]. (TA.) [See art. Orb, where this saying, but with mWArbp in the place of mwArbp, is given as a trad.]
It is said in a trad., Uino baAyaEotahumo waArabuwka, i. e., xaAdaEuwka, If thou buy and sell with them, they will deceive thee, or endeavour to deceive the. (IAth.)

hom.sense: warobN The hole of a wild beast: pl. OaworaAbN. (Ḳ, TA.)

warobN The space between two ribs; maA bayona AlD-ilaEayoni: (Ḳ:) but this (says SM) I find not in any other book than the Ḳ; and probably it should be mA byn UiSobaEayoni the space between two fingers; for we read in the L that wrb is said to signify mAbyn AlOaSaAbiEi: (TA:) pl. OaworaAbN. (Ḳ, TA.) [See also OarobN.]
warobN The space measured by the extension of the thumb and forefinger; syn. fitorN: pl. OaworaAbN. (Ḳ, TA.)

warobN A member; a limb: pl. OaworaAbN. (Ḳ, TA.) wirobN↓ [also] is a dial. from of UirobN, (Ḳ,) as signifying “a member, or limb.” (TA.) The form of word commonly known, says AM, is UirobN; but I do not deny that wrb may be a dial. form, like as wirovN and UirovN are two words whereof one is a dial. form of the other. (TA.)
warobN and warobapN↓ The podex: syn. UisotN: pl. of the former OaworaAbN. (Ḳ, TA.)
warobapN↓ The pit, or hollow, that is in the lower part of the side, i. e., the hypochondre, or flank. (TA.)
warobN The mouth of the hole of a rat, or mouse, (faOorap,) and of a scorpion: pl. OaworaAbN. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: wirobN: see warobN.
warobapN: see warobN.
waribN Corrupt. (Ḳ.)

EiroqN warib A corrupt root, origin, or stock. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Aboo-Dharrah El-Hudhalee says,
Uino tanotasito tunosabo UilaI EiroqK waribo
[If thou mention thy lineage, thy lineage is traced up to a corrupt origin, or stock]. (Ṣ.)
rajulN waribN A corrupt man. (TA.)
waribN A cloud that is loose (Ḳ) and much broken. (TA.)
muwar-abN [i. q. muWar-abN] A member, or limb, cut off entire. (TA.)

1. wariva, aor. yarivu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) an instance of deviation from a constant rule, there being only the following verbs of the measure faEila which have the aorists of the measure yafoEilu only, namely, waviqa, wariva, wariEa, warima, wariIa, wafiqa, waliIa, and wamiqa, (Ibn-Málik and others,) and waSiba: (TA, art. waSb:) the w falls out in yarivu [&c.] because it occurs between I and kesreh; and in those persons of the aor. which begin with A and t and n because these letters are changed from I, which is the original: (Ṣ:) inf. n. wirovN and UirovN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in which the w is changed into O, (Ṣ,) and rivapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in which the p is a substitute for the [elided] w, (Ṣ,) and wiraAvapN (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [the most common form] and UiraAvapN, (TA,) and accord. to some miyraAvN, but this is an error, for mifoEaAlN is not one of the measure of inf. ns., (ISd,) [but it is used by some of the professors of practical law as an inf. n.,] and turAvN: (Mṣb [but see wirovN below]:) He inherited. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) You say wariva OabaAhu He inherited [the property of] his father: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) but the original phrase is wariva maAla Oabiyhi He inherited the property of his father. (Mṣb.) Also wariva mino Oabiyhi (and Eanohu, A,) He inherited of his father: (Ḳ:) or he inherited part of the property of his father. (Mṣb.) And wariva AlX-aIoCa mino Oabiyhi He inherited the thing of, or from, his father. (Ṣ.) When you say wariva zayodN OabaAhu maAlFA [Zeyd inherited of his father property], the word mAlA is a second objective complement, if the verb be doubly trans.; or it is a substitute of implication (badalu QXotimaAlK) for zyd. (MF.) You say warivotuhu maAlahu, and majodahu, I inherited his property, and, ‡ his glory: and warivotuhu Eanohu I inherited it from him. (TA.)

hom.sense: 2. wrv-hu, inf. n. taworiyvN, He included him among the heirs of his property: (Ṣ:) or made him to be one of his heirs: (TA:) [see also 4:] or wrv-hu maAlFA he included him among his heirs, he not being one of them, and assigned him a portion: (AZ, Mṣb:) [in like manner,] wr-v fiI maAlihi he included among his heirs of his property one or more not of them. (TA.)
war-avotu fulaAnFA mino fulaAnK I made such a one to be the heir of such a one. (TA.) See 4.
wr-v He stirred a fire, in order that it might burn up, or blaze: (Ḳ:) a dial. form of Oar-ava, q. v. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4. Awrvhu AlX-aIoCa He (his father) made him to inherit the thing. (Ṣ.)
Awrvhu UiyraAvFA HasanFA He made him to have a goodly inheritance. (TA.) Awrvhu AlUirova, and AlmiyraAva, and wr-vhu↓ Uiy-aAho, He made him to inherit the heritage. (A.)
Awrvhu and wrv-hu↓ He (his father) made him to be one of his heirs. (Ḳ.) [See also 2.]
Awrv waladahu He made his son sole heir. (AZ.)
Awrvhu XayoYFA ‡ It occasioned him, as its result, a thing. Ex. Awrvh AlmaraDu DaEofFA ‡ The disease occasioned him, as its result, weakness. (TA.)
6. tawaAravwuhu kaAbirFA Eano kaAbirK ‡ [They inherited it by degrees, one great in dignity and nobility from another great in dignity and nobility]. (Ṣ.) [See art. kbr.]
tawaAravaniI AlHawaAdivu (Bedr Ibn-'Ámir El-Hudhalee) ‡ Misfortune took me by turns, as though they inherited me, one from another. (TA.)
warovN ‡ What is fresh, juicy, or moist, of things. (Ḳ.)

wirovN and UirovN↓ [see 1] and turaAvN↓ (in which the t is originally w, Ṣ,) and miyraAvN (originally miworaAvN, the w being changed to I because of the kesreh immediately preceding it, Ṣ.) What is inherited; an inheritance, or a heritage: or, accord. to some, wrv and myrAv are used with reference to property, or wealth; and Arv with reference to rank or quality, nobility or eminence, reputation, or the like, in Arabic, Hasab: (M:) [the pl. of myrAv is mawaAriyvu.] [See also art. Oriv.]

OuvobutuwAEalaI maXaAEirikumo hecihi faUin-akumo EalaI UirovK mino Uirovi Uiborehiyma ‡ Remain ye steadfast in the observance of these your rites, or ceremonies; for ye act [therein] according to usage inherited from Abraham. (TA, [app. from AʼObeyd].) [See also UirovN in art Orv.]
lahumo Uirovu majodK ‡ They have an inheritance of glory. (TA.)
warovapN Fire. (L.)
waArivN An heir: pl. wur-aAv and waravapN. (Mṣb.)

It is said in a prayer (of Moḥammad, TA) Oall-ehum-a OamotiEoniI bisamoEiI wabaSariI waQjoEalohu AlwaAriva mn-iI [O God, cause me to enjoy my hearing and my sight, and make it (i. e. the enjoyment that I pray for, TA) survive me: or,] make it to continue with me until I die. (Ḳ.) Or, accord. to another relation, which substitutes waQjoEalohumaA for wAjElh, make them both to continue with me, sound, until I die. Or, as some say, what is meant is the continuance and strength of those two faculties in old age, so that they may survive all the other powers: so says ISh. Some say, that by samoE is meant the remembering of what is heard, and the acting according thereto; and by baSar, the being admonished by what is seen, and the light of the heart, whereby one escapes from perplexity and darkness to the right course. (TA.)

AlwaArivu (as an epithet applied to God, TA.) He who remains after the creatures have perished. (Ḳ.) He remains after everything beside Him has perished; and thus, what was the property of mankind, his servants, returns to Him. (TA.)
UirovN: see wirovN, and 1.
miyraAvN: see wirovN, and 1.
turaAvN: see wirovN, and 1.
maworuwvN Property inherited. (Mṣb.)
Almajodu mutawaAravN bayonahumo ‡ Glory is inherited among them. (A.)
