1. warixN, aor. yaworaxu, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. waraxN; (Ṣ, L;) and twr-x↓; (L;) It (dough) was, or became, thin, or flaccid, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) by reason of the abundance of water in it. (Ṣ, L.)
2. wr-x AlkitaAba biyawomi kacaA He inscribed the writing, or letter, with the date of such a day; i. q. Oar-axahu; (Ṣ, Ḳ *;) of which it is a dial. form. (Yaạḳoob.)
4. Awrx He made dough thin, or flaccid, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) by putting much water to it. (L.)
5: see 1:
and 10.
10. Astwrxt AlOaroDu, and twr-xt↓, The land, or ground, became wet, or moist. (Ḳ.)
waroxN A kind of tree resembling the marox in its growth, (L, Ḳ,) except that it is dust-coloured, having slender leaves, like the leaves of the Taroxuwn, or larger. (L.)
OaroDN warixapN Land having tangled and luxuriant herbage. (Ḳ.)
wariyxapN Dough that is thin, or flaccid, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) by reason of the abundance of water in it. (Ṣ.)
Wet, or moist, land, or ground. (Ḳ.)
tawaAriyxu, pl. of taworiyxN: see taOoriyxN.

hom.sense: 1. waradahu, (Ṣ, M, L, Mṣb,) aor. yaridu, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb,) inf. n. wuruwdN (M, L, Mṣb) and maworidN (L) and wirodN, (M, L, Ḳ,) or the last is a simple subst., (L, Mṣb,) He (a man, and a camel, &c., Mṣb) came to it, or arrived at it, (M, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [and repaired to it,] namely a water (Ṣ, M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ), &c., (M, L, Ḳ,) whether he entered it or did not enter it; (M, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also warada Ealayohi, (M, L,) and twr-dhu↓, (M, L, Ḳ,) and Astwrdhu↓: (M, A, Mgh, L, Ḳ:) he came to it (namely a water) to drink: (L:) ‡ he arrived at it (namely a town or country or the like), whether he entered it or did not enter it: (Mgh, L:) it is allowed by common consent not necessarily to imply entering. (L.) [Hence, waradati AlUibilu, the objective complement maMCF or AlmaMCa being understood, The camels came to water.]
warada, inf. n. wuruwdN, He came; he was, or became, present. (Ṣ, L.)
warada EalayonaA, inf. n. wuruwdN † He (a man) came to us. (Mṣb.)
wirada AlkitaAbu (A, Mṣb,) inf. n. [wuruwdN and] maworidN (A,) ‡ The letter came, (A, Mṣb,) EalaI-a to me: you say, warada EalaI-a AlkitaAbu. (A.)
huwa yatawar-adu↓ AlmahaAlika ‡ [He ventures upon, or goes into, places of destruction]. (A.)
Astwrd↓ AlD-alaAlapa, and waradahaA, ‡ [He ran into error]. (A.)
warad Ealayohi OamorN lamo yuTiqohu ‡ [A thing befell him which he was unable to master]. (A.)
warada Ealayohi [It contravened it; presented itself as an objection to it; opposed it.]
[warada, said of a word or phrase or the like, It occurred.]
waradatohu AlHum-aI, (aor. taridu, Mṣb, inf. n. wuruwdN, A) ‡ The fever attacked him periodically. (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb.)
wurida ‡ He suffered a periodical attack of fever. (A, L, Mṣb.)

waruda, aor. _u {yaworudu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. wuruwdapN; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb;) and UiyraAd-a↓, originally UiworaAd-a, the w becoming I because of the kesreh before it; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) ‡ He (a horse) was, or became, [of a bright, or yel-lowish bay colour;] of a colour between that called kumayot and OaXoqar: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or, of a red colour inclining to yellow. (M, L, Mṣb.)
wuruwdu AlOaronabapi see Xamama and OaronabapN.

entry.sense: 2. wr-d vawobahu ‡ [He dyed his garment, or piece of cloth, red, or of a rose-colour]. (A.)
wr-dti AlX-ajarapu, (AḤn, L, Ḳ,) inf. n. taworiydN; (Ḳ;) and waradato, aor. tardu; (Mṣb;) The tree flowered, or blossomed. (AḤn, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
wr-dt ‡ She (a woman) reddened her cheek with the dye of dyed cotton. (L.)
3. wArdhu, (inf. n. muwaAradapN, A,) He came to water with him. (L, Ḳ.)

bayona AlX-aAEirayoni muwaAradapN, and tawaArudN, ‡ [Between the two poets is an agreement, or a coincidence, in ideas and expressions; as though they both drew from the same source]. (A.) Similar to this is the phrase tawaArudu AlxaATiri ‡ [Agreement, or coincidence, of thought, or idea]. (TA.)
4. Awrdhu, and Astwrdhu↓, (Ḳ,) and twr-dhu↓, (ISd,) He brought him to the watering-place. (Ḳ.)
Also, the first and second of these verbs, He brought him; made him to come, or to be present. (Ṣ, L.)
[And the first, He adduced it, or cited it; namely, an evidence, a speech or saying, a word, &c.]
[He set it forth, or expressed it; namely, a meaning.]
Awrdhu AlmaMCa, (inf. n. UiyraAdN, A.) He made him to come to the water. (L, Mṣb.) [See an ex. voce HamoDN.]
Awrdhu AlD-alaAlapa ‡ [He made him to run into error.] (A.)
Oaworada Ealayohi xayorFA [He brought to him wealth, property, or what was good.] (Mugh, in art. HTb.)
Awrd Ealayohi Alxabara ‡ He related to him the news. (L.)
Awrd AlX-aIoCa ‡ He mentioned the thing. (TA.)
Oworada wOaSodara ‡ He began and compelled. (TA, art. Sdr)
Awrdh wASdrh He brought it and he took it away. (Ḥar. p. 361.)

hom.sense: 5: see 1, and 4, and 10.
tawr-dti Alxayolu Albalodapa ‡ The horses entered the town by little and little. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.*)
twr-d ‡ [It became red, roseate, or rose-coloured]: said of a woman's cheek. (A.)

entry.sense: 6. twArdnA We came to water together. (A.)
10. Astwrd (ISd) and twr-d↓ (Ḳ) He desired to come to water. (ISd, Ḳ.) [See an ex. of the part. n. voce HamoDN.]
See 1 and 4.

warodN [coll. gen. n.] The flower, or blossom, of any tree (AḤn, L, Ḳ) or plant: (AḤn, L:) but its predominant application is to the rose Hawojam, (L, Ḳ,) the well-known red flower (TA) which one smells: (Ṣ, L, TA:) its colour varies in winter and summer: (L:) and it is of different kinds in the cultivated soil and in the desert and in the mountains: (AḤn, L:) n. un. with p {warodapN}. (Ṣ, L.) Said to be an arabicized word. (Mṣb.)

warodN ‡ A horse [of a bright, or yellowish, bay colour;] of a colour between that called kumayot and OaXoqar: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) a horse, (M, L, Mṣb,) or other thing. (M, L,) of a red colour inclining to yellow, (M, L, Mṣb,) beautiful in everything: (M, L:) fem. with p {warodapN}: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb:) applied in the above sense to the sky, in the Ḳur, lv. 37: (L:) or it there means roseates, or of a rosecolour: (Zj, L:) pl. wurodN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) like as juwnN is pl. of jawonN, (Ṣ,) and wiraAdN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OaworaAdN: (Ḳ:) but this last is unknown, and app. a mistake. (M, F, TA.)
EaXiy-apN warodapN ‡ An evening when the horizon is red (L, Ḳ) at sunset; which is a sign of drought: and in like manner the morning at sunrise. (L.)
layolapN warodapN ‡ A night of which the beginning and end are red; which is the case in a time of drought. (A.)
warodN Bold, or daring; (Ḳ;) an epithet applied to a man; (TA;) as also waAridN↓. (Ḳ.)
warodN Saffron. (Ḳ.)
Alwarodu AljabaliI-u: see EabaAlN.
Oabuw Alwarodi ‡ The penis: (Ḳ:) so called because of its redness. (TA.)
wirodN A coming to, or arriving at, water, &c., whether one enters it or does not enter it; (Ṣ,* L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) contr. of SadarN. (Ṣ, L, Mṣb.) See also 1.
wirodN Water to which one comes to drink. (L.)
wirodN The time of the day of coming to water, between the two periods of abstaining from water: (L:) a time, or turn, of coming to water. (TA in art. Hzb.)
wirodN The arrival of the day of coming to water. (L.)
waradati AlUibilu AlmaMCa wirodFA, and OaworaAdF, and in like manner, AlT-ayoru, The camels, and the birds, came to the water in a herd, or in a flock, and in herds, or in flocks. (L.)

wir-dN A company of men, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and a number of camels, and of birds, &c., (L,) coming to, or arriving at, water; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also waAridapN↓: (L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) the former originally an inf. n.: (Mṣb:) its pl. is OaworaAdN. (L.) See also waAridN.
wirodN A herd of camels. (L.)
A flock of birds. (L, Ḳ.)
‡ An army, (L, Ḳ,) so called as being likened to a herd of camels, or to a flock of birds. (L.)
A portion, or share, of water. (L, Ḳ.)
Thirst. (L.)
nasuwqu Almujorimiyna UilaI jahay-ama wirodFA [Ḳur, xix, 89,] † We will drive the sinners to hell like beasts that come to water: or, thirsty: (Beyd:) or, walking and thirsty. (Zj, L.)
wirodN ‡ The day of a fever, when it attacks the patient periodically: (Aṣ, Ṣ, L, Mṣb,* Ḳ *:) or one of the names of fever: (L, Ḳ:) but the former explanation is the more correct. (TA.)
wirodN † A portion of the night when a man has to pray. (L.)

wirodN ‡ A section, or division, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) of the Ḳur-án: (L, Ḳ:) a set portion of recitation or the like: (Mṣb:) a certain portion of the Ḳur-án, as a seventh, or half a seventh, or the like, (Mgh, L,) which a person recites at a particular time: (L:) a set portion of the Ḳur-án, or of prayer;, &c., of which a man imposes upon himself the recital on a particular occasion, or at a particular time; i. q. HizobN q. v.: (Mgh, L:) pl. OaworaAdN. (L, Mṣb.) Ex. qaraOotu wirodiI [I recited my set portion of the Ḳur-án, &c.]: (Ṣ, L:) and lifulaAnK kul-a layolapK wirodN mina AlquroMni yaqoraOuhu Such a one has every night a set portion of the Ḳur-án which he recites. (L.)
warodapN [A bright, or yellowish, bay colour;] a colour between that of a horse that is termed kumayotN and that of one termed OaXoqaru: (Ṣ, L:) or a red colour inclining to yellow. (L.)
binotu warodaAna, (Mṣb,) pl. banaAtu warodaAna, (Ḳ,) A certain insect, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) well known, (Ḳ,) like the beetle, of a red colour, mostly found in baths and in privies. (Mṣb.)

Alwariydu, and Habolu Alwariydi, [Each of the two carotid arteries: and sometimes applied to each of the two external jugular veins:] each of two veins asserted by the Arabs to be from the watiyn [or aorta], on the right and left of the two sides of the neck, next the fore part, and thick: (Ṣ, L:) or the wryd is a certain vein, said to be the wadaj [or external jugular vein]: or, by the side of the wdj: or, accord. to Fr, a certain vein between the windpipe and [the two sinews called] the EilobaAwaAni, always pulsing; being one of the veins in which is the life; the blood not flowing in it, but only the soul, Alnfs [i. e., Aln-afosu, not Aln-afasu; for, accord. to the Arabs, the animal soul (Alr-uwHu AlHayowaAniI-u, as is said in the KT,) diffuses itself throughout the body, from the heart, by means of the pulsing veins, or arteries: see also wadajN]: (Mṣb:) or the wariydaAni are two veins in the neck, (AZ, L, Ḳ,) between the OawodaAj [or external jugular veins] and [the two parts of the neck called] the liytaAni: in the camel, the wadajaAni [or two external jugular veins]: (AZ, T:) or, accord. to AHeyth, and his is the correct explanation, two veins beneath the wadajaAni, [see above,] which latter are two thick veins on the right and left of the pit between the clavicles; they (the former) are always pulsing, in man: the wryd is a vein in which the soul (Alnfs [see above]) flows, and in which the blood does not flow: and every pulsing vein, in which the life flows, is of those thus called: (T:) or the wryd is the vein in each side of the neck which swells out on an occasion of anger: (L:) or four veins in the head; of which two descend before the ears, and of which are the wrydAn in the neck: or a certain vein beneath the tongue: and, in the upper half of the arm, the faliyq [or cephalic]: and, in the fore arm, the OakoHal [or median]: and, among those which separate in the outer side of the hand, the OaXaAjiE: and, in the belly of the fore arm, the rawaAhiX: (T:) pl. OaworidapN [a pl. of pauc.] (M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and warudN, (M, Mṣb,) like as burudN is pl. of bariydN, (Mṣb,) [and wutunN of watiynN, &c.,] or waruwdN, (Ḳ,) [but this I think a mistake].
rajulN munotafixu Alwariydi [A man whose external jugular vein swells out;] a man of bad disposition or temper, prone to anger. (TA.)
war-aAdN: see waAridN.

hom.sense: waAridN A man, and a camel, or other animal, (L,) coming to, or arriving at water,, &c., whether he enter it or do not enter it; (L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also war-aAdN↓: (L, CK:) pl. of the former, wur-aAdN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and waAriduwna: (L:) and of the latter, war-aAduwna. (L.) See also wirodN.

Uino manokumo Uil-aA waAriduhaA [Ḳur, xix. 72, There is not any of you that shall not come to it,] means, accord. to Th, that the Muslims shall come to hell with the unbelievers, but not enter it with them. (L.)
TariyqN waAridu ‡ A road, or way, by which people come to water: opposed to SaAdirN. (M, A, art. Sdr.) See also maworidN
maA lhu SaAdirN walaA waAridN: see art. Sdr.
waAridN A preceder. (L, Ḳ.) So (accord. to some, TA) in the Ḳur, xii. 19. (L.)
waAridN Courageous; (Ḳ;) bold; forward in affairs. (TA.) See also warodN.
XaEorN waAridN ‡ Long and lank hair: (L, Ḳ:) or hair so long as to reach the buttocks, (A,) of a woman. (L.)
waAridN ‡ Anything long. (L.)

OaronabapN waAridapN ‡ The end, or tip, of a nose advancing over the middle of the mustaches: (A, L:) because the nose, when it is long, reaches to the water when the person drinks: and in like manner, a lip, and a gum. (L.)
fulaAnN waAridu AlOaronabapi ‡ Such a one has a long end, or tip, to his nose. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) XajarapN waAridapu AlOagoSaAni ‡ A tree having pendulous branches. (L.)
See wirodN.

entry.sense: waAridapN: see waAridN, wirodN and maworidN.
[UiyraAdN † Income; revenue: pl. UiyaraAdaAtN.]

hom.sense: maworidN A place of coming to water: (Mṣb:) a watering-place: (L:) and maworidapN↓ a road, or way, by which one comes to water; (L, Ḳ;) as also waAridapN↓: (A, Ḳ:) pl. of the first (L) and second, (TA,) mawaAridu; (L, TA;) and of the third, waAridaAtN. (TA.)

Hence, (A, TA,) maworidN and waAridN↓ ‡ A road, or way; (Ṣ, L;) as also waAridapN↓: (TA:) or the last, the middle and main part of a road; or a main road; or simply, a road; syn. jaAd-apN; (Ḳ;) as also maworidapN↓: (L, Ḳ:) pls. as above. (A, TA.)
mawaAridu OamorK ‡ [The ways leading to a thing: or the ways of commencing a thing]: (TA, art. rHb.) [See an ex., voce taraAHaba; and see its opposite, maSaAdiru OamorK, voce maSodarN.]
[maworidN also signifies, agreeably with analogy, The time of coming to water: pl. mawaAridu: see the last signification of val-apN in this lexicon: see also wirudN.]
maworidu mavalK ‡ [The primary idea, or thing, signified by a parable or proverb: correlative of maDoribu mavalK: pl. mawaAridu]. (TA, &c., passim.)

entry.sense: maworidapN: see maworidN.
maworuwdN ‡ Attacked by a fever periodically: (Ṣ, L:) or suffering a periodical attack of fever. (Mṣb.)

An Arab of the desert said to another, maA OamaAru UiforaAqi Almaworuwdi [What is the sign of the convalescence of him who is attacked by a periodical fever?] and he answered, Alr-uHaDaMCu [The sweat which follows it; or copious sweat]. (Ṣ.)
muwar-adN ‡ A shirt dyed of a rose-colour; of a less deep dye than that which is termed muDar-ajN: (Ṣ, L;) or dyed with saffron. (TA.)
xad-N muwar-adN ‡ A reddened cheek. (TA.)
rajaEa muwar-ada AlqacaAli ‡ He returned [with the back of his head] slapped, or thumped with the fist, [and rendered red]. (A.)
mutawar-idN: see warodN.
1. warasa, inf. n. wuruwsN, It (a plant) became green. (AA, A, Hn, M.)
See also 4.
warisa, (M, Ḳ,) aor. yaworasu, (Ḳ,) It (a rock, M, Ḳ, in water, Ḳ) became overspread with [the green substance called] TuHolub, so that it became green and smooth. (IDrd, M, Ḳ.)
See also 4.
2. wr-shu, inf. n. taworiysN, He dyed it (a garment, or piece of cloth,) with waros, q. v. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
4. Awrs AlmakaAnu The place produced the plant called waros. (Ṣ.)

Awrs Alr-imovu The [trees called] rmv produced waros, a thing yellow like the [garments termed] mulaMC; as also warasa↓: so it is asserted, on trustworthy authority: (M:) or became yellow in their leaves, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) after attaining to maturity, (Ṣ,) and had upon them what was like yellow mulaMC; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and in like manner one says of a place, Awrs AlmakaAnu: (TA:) or became yellow in its fruit: (A:)
Awrs AlX-ajaru The trees put forth leaves; (Ḳ;) as also warisa↓. (IḲṭṭ.)

warosN A certain plant, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of a yellow colour, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) resembling sesame, (A, Ḳ,) with which one dyes, (A, Mṣb,) and of which is made the [liniment called] gumorap for the face, (Ṣ,) existing in El-Yemen, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and nowhere else, (Ḳ,) being there sown; (Mṣb;) it is not wild, but is sown one year, and remains ten years, (AḤn, M,) or twenty years, (Ḳ,) without ceasing to be profitable, resembling sesame in its manner of growth; and when it dries, on its attaining to maturity, its pericarps (xaraAYiT) burst, and it is shaken, and the waros shakes out from it: (AḤn, M,) it is useful for the [discolouration of the face termed] kalaf, used as a liniment; and for the [leprous-like discolouration of the skin termed] bahaq, [prepared] as a drink; and the wearing of a garment dyed with it strengthens the venereal faculty: (Ḳ:) or a certain yellow dye: or, as some say, a certain plant, of sweet odour:
or, as is said in the qaAnuwn [of Ibn-Seenà, or Avicenna,] a certain thing of an intensely red colour, resembling powdered saffron, brought from El-Yemen, and said to be scraped or rubbed off, or to fall off, from its trees: (Mgh:) or, as some say, a species of kurokum, q. v.: or, as some say, resembling kurokum: (Mṣb:) or a certain thing, yellow, like the [garments of the kind called] mulaMC, that comes forth upon the [trees called] rimov, between the last part of summer and the first part of winter, (M, TA,) which, when it touches a garment, soils it: (TA:) or it also, sometimes, [accord. to certain persons who seems to misapply the word, is a substance which] pertains to the [trees called] EaroEar and rimov, and to other trees, above all in Abyssinia; but this is inferior to that first mentioned (Ḳ, TA) in virtue and properties: as to that of the ErEr, it is found between its rind and the main substance, when it dries up; and when it is rubbed, it rubs off; and there is no good in it; but wrs [properly so called] is adulterated with it: and as to that of the rmv, when it is the end of summer, and it has attained its utmost state, it becomes intensely yellow, so that what envelops it becomes yellow, and with this also one adulterates: so says AḤn: (TA:) wrs is called in Persian AsPrk [UisoPariko]; and in Turkish, MlAjhrh. (TḲ.) [Freytag adds to what he has given on this word from the Ḳ, Ṣ, TḲ. as follows: “Memecylon tinctorium. Sprengel. hist. med., t. ii., p. 444, ed. tert. (ubi wrz scriptum est). Spreng. hist. rei herb., t. i., p. 258. Avicenn. p. 165”]
warisN: see wariysN.
warosiI-N A yellow bowl: (A:) or a bowl made of nuDaAr, (M,) which is a yellow wood: (TA:) or of the best kind of those made of nuDaAr. (Lth, Ḳ.)
A pigeon that is red inclining to yellowness: (M:) or a pigeon inclining to redness and yellowness. (Ḳ.)
See also wariysN.

wariysN A garment dyed with waros; as also warisN↓ and waArisN↓ (M) and muwar-asN↓. (M, A.) You say, maloHafapN wiriysapN, (so in some copies of the Ṣ and Ḳ) or warosiy-apN↓, (as in other copies of the Ṣ and Ḳ, and thus in a copy of the Mṣb,) [An outer wrapping garment] dyed with ws; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) i. q. muwar-asapN↓; (Ḳ;) which latter epithet is sometimes used. (Mṣb.)
See also waArisN.
waArisN applied to a place [Producing the plant called waros]. (TA.)

Applied to a tree of the kind called rimov, Producing waros, a thing yellow like the [garments termed] mulaMC: (M:) or becoming yellow in the leaves, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) after attaining to maturity, (Ṣ,) and having upon it what is like yellow mulaMCu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or becoming yellow in its fruit: (A:) or, app., having waros, like as taAmirN signifies “possessing dates;” (AḤn;) and wariysN↓ likewise has the last of these significations: (TA:) muwrisN↓ also signifies the same as waArisN, applied to a tree of the kind abovementioned; (A, Ḳ;) but is very rare, though agreeable with analogy: (Ḳ:) it is said (M) one should not say muworisN; (Ṣ, M;) but it occurs in a poem of Ibn-Harmeh. (M.)
Applied to a tree [of any other kind], Putting forth leaves. (TA.)
Applied to a plant, Becoming green. (M.) You say also, SaxorapN waArisapN biAlT-uHolubi, A rock overspread with the green substance called THlb, so that it is green and smooth: [see 1]. (A.)

It also denotes intenseness of colour, in the phrase OaSofaru waArisN Yellow intensely bright. (M.) And [in like manner] you say, jamalN waArisu AlHumorapi A camel intensely red. (Ṣgh.) And zaEofaraAnN waArisN [app., Bright-coloured saffron]. (A.) See also wariysN.
muwrisN: see waArisN.
muwar-asN: see wariysN, in two places.

hom.sense: 1. waraXa, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. yariXu, inf. n. wuruwXN (Ḳ) and waroXN, (TA,) He took, or reached, or took or reached with the hand, or with the extended hand, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) food, (A, Ḳ,) or somewhat thereof, (Ṣ,) or a little thereof. (AZ.)

Also, (Ḳ,) inf. n. waroXN and wuruwXN, (TA,) He ate vehemently and greedily: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, A, Ḳ:) but accord. to IAạr, rawoXN, with the rá first, signifies the “eating much;” and waroXN, with the wáw first, the eating little. (TA.)
Also, (Ḳ,) inf. n. waroXN, (TA,) He coveted; longed; yearned; eagerly desired; strove to acquire; obtain, or attain. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) You say, waraXa Uilyhi He coveted it;, &c. (TḲ.)

waraXa Ealayohimo, (A, Ḳ,) inf. n. waroXN, (TA,) He came in to them uninvited when they were eating, (A, Ḳ, TA,) to get some of their food: and when one has gone in to others while they were drinking, you say, wagala Ealyohimo: but see waAriXN. (TA.)
waraXa fulaAnFA bifulAanK He incited such a one against such a one: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA:) in the Ḳ, erroneously, waraXa fulaAnN bifulaAnK. (TA.) See also 2.

entry.sense: 2. war-aXa bayona Alqawomi, (Ṣ,) inf. n. taworyiXN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He excited discord, dissension, disorder, strife, quarrelling, or animosity, between, or among, the people; syn. Har-aXa; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Oar-aXa (Ṣ) [and har-aXa]. See also 1, last signification.

waraXaAnN A certain bird, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) of the pigeon-kind, (AḤát, Mgh, Mṣb,) or resembling the pigeon, (TA,) also called saAqu Hur-K, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) which is the male of the qamaAriI- [or kind of collared turtle-doves of which a single female is called qumoriy-apN (see qumoriI-N)], (Mṣb,) of the birds of the desert, (TA,) the flesh of which is lighter than that of the [common] pigeon: (Ḳ:) fem. with p {waraXaAnapN}: (Ḳ:) pl. waraAXiynu (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and wiroXaAnN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) like as kiruwaAnN is a pl. of karawaAnN, contr. to rule. (Ṣ.) It is said in a proverb, biEil-api AlwaraXaAni taOokulu ruTaba AlmuXaAni [With the pretext of the warashán, thou eatest the fresh ripe dates of the excellent kind called mXAn]: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) said to him who pretends one thing and means another: (A, Ḳ:) originating from the fact that some people employed a slave belonging to them to guard the fresh ripe dates of their palm-trees, and he used to eat them, and, when reproved for his evil conduct, laid the blame upon the warashán; wherefore this was said to him. (Ṣgh.)

waAriXN One who comes in to a people uninvited, when they are eating; like waAgilN in the case of beverage: (Ṣ:) and, accord. to some, i. q. waAgilN but others say, that wArX has the first signification only, relating to food: and that of a sponger desiring food. (TA.) See raAXinN and TufayoliI-N.

2. wr-Thu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. taworiyTN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He made him to fall into what is termed waroTap [properly and also tropically, or in its primary sense and also in any of its subordinate senses]; as also AwrThu↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiyraATN: (Mṣb:) both signify † he made him to fall into that from which he could not extricate himself: (TA:) or into that from which he could not easily extricate himself. (Mṣb.)

wr-T Uibilahu fI UibilK OaxoraI † He hid, or concealed, his camels among other camels [in order that they might escape the notice of the collector of the poor-rates]; as also AwrT↓. (Ḳ.) [See also 1, and 3.]

hom.sense: 3. wiraATN (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) and muwaAraTapN (TA) [The act of mutually making to fall into what is termed waroTap.]

[And hence,] † The act of mutually deceiving, beguiling, or circumventing; or endeavouring to deceive, beguile, or circumvent; (TA;) or the act of deceiving, beguiling, or circumventing; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) and the acting, or advising, or counselling, dishonestly, or insincerely; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) and waroTN↓ and wiraATapN↓, the latter on the authority of J, [accord. to some copies of the Ṣ, but in other copies wiraATN,] signify the same [as substs.] (TA.)
You say, laA tuwaAriTo jaAraka faUin-a AlwiraATa yuwridu AlOaworAaTa † [Do not thou practise mutual deceit with thy neighbour, or endeavour to deceiving him,, &c., for the doing so brings upon its author things, or affairs, from which it is difficult to escape]. (Z, TA.) And it is said in trad, laA xilaATa walaA wiraATa, which is like his [Moḥammad's] saying, † There shall be no putting together what is separate, nor separating what is put together, from fear of the poor-rate: (Ṣ:) xlAT has been explained in its place: (TA:) wrAT [has also been variously explained in that place, and, it is said,] signifies the putting together what is separate: and the reverse: (Ḳ:) or the dispersing camels (Ḳ, TA) among other camels: (TA:) or the hiding camels among other camels; (Th, Ḳ;) or in a low, or depressed, piece of ground; in order that the collector of the poor-rate may not see them: (Ḳ:) or the making one another to fall into a waroTap, (TA,) one saying to the collector of the poor-rate, “Such a one has that for which a poor-rate is due,” when he has not; (Ḳ, TA;) so accord. to IAạr: accord. to Ibn-Háni, it is from OaworaTa Aljariyra fiI Eunuqi AlbaEiyiri. (TA.) See 4.

entry.sense: 4: see 2, in two places; and 1.
AwrT Aljariyra fiI Eunuqi AlbaEiyr † He put the end of the jryr [q. v.] of the camel into its ring, and then pulled it so as to throttle him. (Ibn-Háni. Ḳ.)

5. twr-T fiI waroTapK He fell into what is termed waroTap [properly and also tropically, or in its primary sense, and also in any of its subordinate senses]. (Ṣ.) You say, twr-Tti Alganamu wagayoruhaA The sheep, or goats, &c., fell into mud from which they could not extricate themselves; or into a depressed piece of ground in which was no way directing to escape: and hence the verb is used in relation to any straitness or difficulty. (Mṣb.) Thus you say, twr-T fulaAnN fiI AlOamori † Such a one undertook, or embarked in, the affair, and could not easily extricate himself; and so AstwrT↓ fiyhi: (Mṣb:) or the former signifies † he fell into the affair, or case: (Ḳ:) or † he became entangled in the affair, and could not easily extricate himself from it; (TA;) and so ↓the latter: (Sh, Ḳ, TA:) and twr-T and AstwrT↓ both signify he stuck fast: or † he perished; or died. (TA.)
10: see 5, in three places.
AstwrT maEa fulaAnK † He behaved proudly, haughtily, or insolently, in speech, with such a one. (TA.)
waroTN: see 3.

waroTahN Slime, or thin mud, [in the CK, Alr-aHolu is erroneously put for AlwaHolu,] into which sheep or goats fall, and from which they cannot extricate themselves: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) this, or, as some say, what here next follows, is the primary signification: (Mṣb:) a low, or depressed, piece of ground or land, in which is no way, or road, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) directing to escape: (Mṣb:) this is said by AʼObeyd to be the primary signification: (Ṣ:) a deep hollow, cavity, or pit, in the ground: (TA:) a deep hollow, cavity, or pit, formed for the purpose of a stratagem, such as may be in a mountain, occasioning difficulty to him who falls into it: (Aṣ:) and hence, (TA,) a well: (Ḳ, TA:) and anything that is gaAmiD [app. here meaning low, or depressed]: (Ḳ:) also, by derivation from the first of these significations, (Mṣb,) or from the second, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) [or some other,] † perdition; or destruction; or death: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and † [any embarrassing, or difficult, case, or affair;] any case, or affair, from which escape is difficult: (Ḳ:) pl. [of pauc.] OaworaATN, (Ṣ, IS,) the p in the sing. being app. regarded as elided; (IS;) and [of mult.] wiraATN, (Ḳ,) and waraTaAtN. (TA.)
Also, ‡ The podex: or the anus: syn. UisotN. (Ḳ, TA.)
wiraATapN: see 3.

waz-N a dial. var. of Uiwaz-N, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) A kind of water-fowl; (Ṣ;) [the goose, or geese; and the duck, or ducks; but generally the former of these birds;] as also waz-iynN↓: (Ḳ:) n. un. of the former, waz-apN; (Mṣb, art. wz;) and of the latter, waz-iynapN. (Ṣgh, TA.) See kurokI-.
waz-iynN and waz-iynapN: see waz-N.
OaroDN mawaz-apN A land abounding with the birds called waz-; (Ḳ;) like maOowazapN from Uiwaz-N. (TA.)
1. wazaOa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yazaOu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. wazoCN, (Ṣ,) He dried flesh-meat: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he roasted and so dried it. (TA.)
wazaOa Alqawoma He repelled one part of the people from another. (Ḳ.)
wazaOa Alqawomu One part of the people repelled another part. (TA.)

hom.sense: 2. wz-O AlwiEaMCa, inf. n. tawoziYapN and tawoziIoCN, He made tight the contents of the bag; or other repository: syn. Xad-a kanozahu. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
wz-O, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tawoziIoCN, (Ṣ,) He filled a water-skin (Ṣ, Ḳ) or other vessel. (TA.)
wz-Ot bihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tawoziYapN, (Ṣ,) She (a mare, TA) or a camel, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) threw him (i. e. her rider, TA,) down prostrate. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
wz-Oh He made him bind himself by every oath: (Ḳ:) or by a hard, or severe, oath. (L.)

entry.sense: 5. twz-O It (a water-skin, Ḳ, or other vessel, TA) was filled, or became full. (Ḳ.)
He was, or became, filled with drink to satiety. (Aṣ, Ṣ.)
wazaOa Strong-made: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a short, fat, strong-made, man. (TA.)
1. wazaba, aor. yazibu, inf. n. wuzuwbN, It (water, Ḳ, or a thing, T,) flowed. (T, Ḳ.)
4. Awzb fiI AlOaroDi ‡ He went, or went away, or pursued his course, through the land, (Ḳ,) like as does water. (TA.)
waz-aAbN ‡ A clever thief: (Ḳ:) so called because quick in his motions, like running water. (TA.)

miyzaAbN A water-spout; a pipe or other channel that spouts forth water; (TA, art. Ozb;) that by which water pours down from a high place; (Towsheeh;) a water-spout of wood, or the like, to convey away the water from the roof of a house: (MF, art. zwb:) from wazaba AlmaMCu “the water flowed:” (Ḳ:) or a Persian term, arabicized; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e., composed of the Persian words, (TA,) signifying “make water:” (Ḳ:) also written miYozaAbN; and in this case its pl. is maMziybu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) but if without C, its pl. is mayaAziybu, (Ṣ,) or mawaAziybu; the latter agreeable with analogy, like mawaAEiydu and mawaAziynu. (TA.) [See also arts. Ozb and zwb. It has also two other forms, mizoraAbN and mirozaAbN.]

1. wazara, (A, Mgh, Ḳ,) aor. yaziru, inf. n. wizorN, with kesr, (Ḳ,) He bore, or carried, a heavy load, or burden. (A, Mgh, Ḳ.) It is said in the Ḳur, [vi. 164, &c.,] walaA taziru waAzirapN wizora OuxoraI Nor shall any [soul] bearing [a heavy burden] bear the [heavy] burden of another soul; (Ṣ;) i. e., its burden of sin: (Mgh, Mṣb:) meaning, that no one shall be punished for the sin of another; nor shall any sinning soul bear the heavy burden of another soul; every one shall be requited for his [own] deeds: (TA:) or nor shall any sinning [soul] sin by the sin of another. (Akh, Ṣ, TA.)

Hence, (Akh, Ṣ,) wazara, (Akh, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaziru; and wazira, aor. yawozaru; (Akh, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and wuzira (the same and A,) aor. yuwzaru; (Akh, Ṣ, Ḳ;) inf. n. wizorN and wazorN and zirapN, (Ḳ,) or wizorapN, accord. to Zj, as I have seen it [says IM] pointed and well written; (L;) ‡ He sinned: (Akh, Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or he bore [a burden of] sin- (Mṣb.) See also 8.
wuzira also signifies ‡ He was charged with, or accused of, a sin. (Ḳ,* TA.)

wazara liloOamiyri, (A,) and lilos-uloTaAni, (Mṣb, [this I believe to be the right reading; but in the only copy of the Mṣb, that I have, I find it written AlslTAn;]) aor. yaziru; (A, Mṣb;) inf. n. wazaArapN; (A;) and twz-r↓ liloOamiyri, (Ṣ.) or lalomaliki; (Ḳ;) and waAzrhu↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) ‡ He was, or became, waziyr [or vicegerent] (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) to the governor, (Ṣ, A,) or sultán, (Mṣb,) or king. (Ḳ.)
3. [waAzrhu He bore a burden with him.]
[Hence,] wAzr Almalika OaEobaMCa Almuloki ‡ He bore with the king (HaAmalahu) the burden of the regal office. (A.) See also 1, last signification.

wAzrhu EalaI AlOamori, (TA,) inf. n. muwaAzarapN, (A, TA,) He aided, assisted, or helped, him, and strengthened him, to do the thing: originally Mzarahu: (A,* TA:) the former of these, wAzrh, is the more chaste. (TA.)
4. Awzrhu He appointed him a wazar, (Ḳ, TA,) i. e., a place of refuge to which to betake himself. (TA.)
5. tawaz-ara see 1, last signification.
8. Uit-azara, of the measure UifotaEala, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) [originally Uiwotazara,] ‡ He committed a wizor, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e., a sin. (Mṣb, TA.)
10. Uistwzrhu ‡ He took him, or chose him, as a waziyr [or vicegerent]. (Ḳ.) You say, Ousotuwzira fulaAnN ‡ Such a one was taken, or chosen, as a wzyr. (Ṣ, A.*)

wizorN A heavy load or burden, (A, Mgh, Ḳ,) a bundle, (Ṣ,) or great bundle, (Ḳ,) that is carried on the back: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a weight; syn. vql: (Ṣ, [in which the syn. is written viqol: so in two copies; and so app. accord. to AʼObeyd, who makes its pl. OavoqaAl:] and Mṣb [in which, in my copy, the syn. is written without syll. signs:] and Ḳ [in which it is written viqal:]) pl. OawozaArN. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)

‡ A weapon; an instrument of war: or weapons; arms: syn. silaAHN: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) because heavy upon the wearer: (Mgh, Mṣb:) or OawozaArN signifies the burdens and instruments of war, &c.; and the sing. is wizorN; (AʼObeyd, TA;) or it has no sing., accord. to some. (TA.) A poet says, (Ṣ,) namely El-Aạshà, (Mgh, TA.)
waOaEodadotu liloHarobi OawozaArahaA
rimaAHFA TiwaAlFA waxayolFA cukuwraA
[And I prepared for the war its weapons and other apparatus; long lances and male horses]. (Ṣ, Mgh, TA.) And it is said in the Ḳur, [xlvii. 5,] Hay-aI taDaEa QloHarobu OawozaArahaA, meaning, ‡ Until the war terminates: (Mgh, Mṣb:) because then the people thereof lay down their arms: (Mgh:) properly, until the people of the war lay down their burdens: (Mṣb:) their weapons and burdens: or, as some say, their sins. (Bḍ.)
‡ A sin: (Ṣ, Bḍ, ubi supra, and Mṣb, Ḳ:) and [especially] polytheism: (Fr, Bḍ, TA:) pl. as above. (Bḍ, Mṣb, &c.) This is the sense in which it is most frequently used in the traditions. (IAth.)

wazarN A mountain: this is the primary signification: (Ṣ:) or a mountain difficult of access, or strong: (Ḳ, TḲ:) or a mountain to which one betakes himself for refuge: this is the primary signification. (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ.)
A place of refuge: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) any such place. (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, Ḳ.) So in the Ḳur, lxxv. 11. (TA.)
See also waziyrN.

waziyrN i. q. muwaAzirN [One who bears a burden or burdens with another: or one who aids, assists or helps, and strengthens, another: see 3:] (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) like as OakiylN signifies i. q. muWaAkilN, (Ṣ,) and jaliysN i. q. mujaAlisN. (A.)

‡ [A vicegerent of a king or the like: or a confidential minister of state: in English commonly written vizier, in imitation of the Turkish pronunciation; but properly, wezeer:] the familiar of the king, who bears his master's burden, and aids him by his counsel: (Ḳ:) or the wzyr of the king is the person who bears with him (yuwaAziruhu, i. e. yuHaAmiluhu,) the burdens of the regal office: not from muwaAzarapN, signifying the “act of aiding or the like,” because the w in this latter word is substituted for C, and the derivative from it of the measure faEiylN is OaziyrN: (A:) ISd says, some hold that the w in wzyr is substituted for C; but Abu-l-ʼAbbás says, that this is not agreeable with analogy; for the substitution of C for w in a word of this measure is rare, and that of w for C is more strange: (TA:) the wzyr is so called because he bears for the king the burden of administration: (Ṣ,* Mṣb:) or it is from wazarN↓, signifying “a mountain to which one has recourse to save himself from destruction:” so the wzyr of the khaleefeh is one upon whose counsel the khaleefeh relies in his affairs, and to whom he betakes himself for refuge or safety: (Aboo-Is-ḥáḳ, TA:) pl. wuzaraMCu (A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and OawozaArN; (A, Ḳ;) the latter like OaXoraAfN and OayotaAmN, (A, TA,) pls. of XariyfN and yatiymN. (TA.)
wizaArapN and wazaArapN The condition, or office, of a waziyr: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) the former word is the more approved. (ISk, Mṣb.)
waAzirN Bearing, or carrying, a heavy load, or burden. (A.)

[Hence,] also, (A,) and mawozuwrN↓, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) ‡ Sinning: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or bearing [a burden of] sin. (Mṣb.) maOozuwraAtK occurs in a trad., for mawozuwraAtK, the regular form, because it is there coupled with maOojuwraAtK, to which it is opposed. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
mawozuwrN: see waAzirN.
mawozuwraAtK: see waAzirN.

R. Q. 1. wasowasa, [inf. n. wasowasapN and wisowaAsN, and simple subst. wsowaAsN, but see ZOoZaOa,] He spoke, or talked, indistinctly: (TA:) [or in a low, faint, gentle, or soft manner, with confusedness: for] Aboo-Turáb is related to have said, that he heard Khaleefeh say, wasowasapN signifies the speaking in a low, faint, gentle, or soft, manner, with confusedness: or, accord. to one relation, it is [waXowaXapN,] with X. (TA.) [It is generally intrans., agreeable with the above explanations: but sometimes trans.; for you say,] wasowasa Alr-ajula He spoke to the man with low, faint, gentle, or soft, speech. (M.)

[Hence,] wasowasatN Uilayohi nafosuhu, (Ṣ, M,* A,* Mṣb, Ḳ,*) and wasowasa Uilayohi AlX-ayoTaAnu, (Ṣ, A,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) and lahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and fiyhi, (TA,) or fiI Sadorihi, (M,) inf. n. wasowsapN (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ) and wisowaAsN, with kesr, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and wasowaAsN, with fet-ḥ, is also allowable in the case of this and similar reduplicative verbs, (MF, voce ZaOoZaOa,) or this last is a simple subst., (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) His mind, or soul, (Ṣ, M, A, &c.,) and the devil, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) prompted, or suggested to him [something], or talked to him, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) and [in him, or] in his bosom: (M:) or suggested to him, or talked to him of, (A,* Ḳ,) and suggested in him, or talked in him of, (TA,) what was vain, or unprofitable, and destitute of good: (A, Ḳ, TA:) and in like manner one says of the thoughts. (TA.) By the prep. l by which it is made trans. in the Ḳur, in vii. 19, is meant UilaI. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) You say also, wusowisa bihi [as though signifying properly He had vain things suggested in him by the devil, so that his mind was disturbed thereby, and] his speech became confused, and he became stupified, or deprived of his reason. (TA.)

[Hence also,] wasowasa AlHaloIu, (M, A, Bḍ, in vii. 19,) inf. n. wasowasapN and wisowaAsN, (M,) ‡ The woman's ornament sounded, or made a sound or sounds: (M:) or made a low, or gentle, sound; or a chinking. (Bḍ, [who holds this to be a primary signification: but it is said in the A to be tropical.]) And wasowasa AlqaSabu ‡ [The reeds made a low sound; or rustling]. (A.) And samiEotu wisowaAsahu ‡ [I heard its low sounding, or its chinking; or its rustling]. (A.) See also wasowaAsN.

hom.sense: wasowaAsN a subst. from wasowasa; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) signifying, [Speech, or talk, that is indistinct: or low, faint, gentle, or soft: or low,, &c., and confused: see 1.]

[And hence,] The soul's, or mind's, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and the devil's, (Ḳ,) prompting, or suggestion, or talk, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of what is vain, or unprofitable, and destitute of good; (Ḳ;) as also wasowasapN↓ [used as subst., in which case its pl. is wasaAwisu, occurring below]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
[And hence,] † An evil, or unprofitable, idea, imagination, or thought, which bestirs itself in, or occurs to, the mind. (Mṣb.)

And [by a metonymy,] † A certain disease, [i. e. melancholia, in which is a doting in the imagination and judgment, a sort of delirium, vulgarly attributed to diabolical prompting or suggestion, but, it is said,] arising from a predominance of the black bile, attended with confusion of the intellect. (Mṣb.)
[And from the primary signification seem to be derived those which here follow.] † The low, or faintly heard, sound of the hunter and the dogs. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
† A low or faint sound [or rustling] of wind; as also wasowasapN↓. (M.)
‡ The sounds, (Ṣ,) or sound, (M, Ḳ,) of women's ornaments: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) [the chinking thereof: see 1.]

Also, AlwasowaAsu The devil; (M, Ḳ;) a name of the devil: (Ṣ:) it occurs in verse 4 of the last chap. of the Ḳur; and is said to mean there cuw AlwasowaAsi [the prompter, or suggester, of what is vain, or unprofitable, and destitute of good.] (M.)

entry.sense: maraDN wasowaAsiI-N [A disease of the nature of melancholia]. (Ḳ in art. EXq.)
muwasowasN: see muwasowisN.

muwasowisN, with kesr, A man subject to wasaAwis [or diabolical promptings, or suggestions, of vain, or unprofitable, things, and thereby confused in his intellect, or disordered in his mind]: (M:) an act. part. n., applied as an epithet to a man, because he to whom it is applied talks to himself: and one also says muwasowasN, [or muwasowasN Uilayohi,] like AlmagoDuwbu Ealayohimo: (Mṣb.) or, accord. to IAạr, one should not say muwasowasN. (TA.)
1. wasabati AlOaroDu, aor. tasibu, (inf. n. wasobN, TA;) and Awsbt↓; The land became abundant in fresh herbage, such as is called EuXob, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and in dry herbage. (TA.)
wasiba, aor. yawosabu, inf. n. wasabN, He, or it, was dirty: (IAạr, Ḳ:) syn. with wakiba and HaXina. (TA.)
4: see 1.

wasubN Wood that is put in the lower part of a well, when its earth is such as would pour in, (Ḳ,) and that prevents the earth from doing so: called by the people of Egypt xinoziyrap, and only of the wood of the sycamore fig-tree: (TA:) [the xnzyrp is a lining of planks, resembling a barrel; and the wood above mentioned is used in its construction because water does not rot it so quickly as it rots other kinds of wood:] pl. wusuwbN. (Ḳ.) [Accord. to IDrd, of the dial. of El-Yemen. (Freytag.)]
wisobN Plants; herbs; herbage: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or abundance of herbage. (M, in art. Asb.)
muwsibN ‡ A ram abounding with wool: (Ḳ:) likened to a land abounding with herbage. (TA.)
miysaAbN Dates such as are termed mujaz-aEN, [i. e., half, or two-thirds, ripe]: (Ḳ:) i. e., as applied to ruTab, vile, or bad. (TA.)

1. wasaja, (aor. yasiju, Ḳ,) inf. n. wasiyjN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and wasojN and wasajaAnN; (L;) He (a camel) went a certain pace; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) [more quick than that called EasojN: the contr. is said in the TA, app. by a mistranscription: but see naSaba, and camala:] the first pace, accord. to En-Naḍr and Aṣ, is called Ald-abiybu; the next, AlEanaqu; the next, Alt-azay-udu; the next, Alc-amiylu; the next, AlEasoju; and the next, Alwasoju: or he went quickly, or swiftly. (TA, L.)
4. Awsj He incited, urged, or made, a camel, to go at the pace called Alwasiyj. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
jamalN was-aAjN Eas-aAjN A quick, or swift, camels. (Ḳ.) UiblN wasuwjN EasuwjN Quick, or swift, camels. (Ḳ.)

1. wasixa, aor. yawosaxu (Ṣ, Ḳ) and yaAsaxu and yayosaxu, (Ḳ,) [the last two of which are irregular forms,] inf. n. wasaxN; (L;) and Uit-asaxa↓ and tws-x↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and Astwsx↓; (Ḳ;) It (a garment, Ṣ, L, Ḳ, and the skin, L, or some other thing, Mṣb) was, or became, dirty, filthy, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) in consequence of its being seldom washed, (L,) or from want of care. (Mṣb.)
2: see 4.
4. Awsx (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and ws-x↓ (L, Ḳ) He, or it, made a garment, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and the skin, (L,) or some other thing, (Mṣb,) dirty, or filthy. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
5: see 1.
8: see 1.

wasoxN Dirt, filth, or soil; (Ṣ, L;) what collects upon a garment, or the skin, (L,) or some other thing, (Mṣb,) in consequence of its being seldom washed, (L,) or from want of care: (Mṣb:) pl. OawosaAxN. (Mṣb.)
laA taOokulo OwosaAxa Aln-aAsi ‡ [Live not thou upon the alms of men]. (A.)
wasixN Dirty, or filthy, [in consequence of being seldom washed, or] from want of care: an epithet applied to a garment, &c. (Mṣb.)

2. ws-dhu wisaAdFA, or wisaAdapF, (L, Ḳ,) and XayoYFA, (Ṣ,) He put a pillow, (L, Ḳ,) and a thing, (Ṣ,) beneath his (another's) head. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ *.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce canuwbN: and another voce sawaAdN.]
4. Awsd fiI Als-ayori He hastened, or was quick, in his pace. (L, Ḳ.)
Awsdhu, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) or Awsdhu biAlS-ayodi, (Mṣb,) He incited him (a dog) to the chase: as also Msadahu. (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
5. tws-d, (L, Ḳ,) and tws-d wisaAdFA, or wisaAdapF (L,) and XayoYFA, (Ṣ,) He put for himself a pillow, (L, Ḳ,) and a thing, (Ṣ,) beneath his head; (Ṣ, L,) he rested his head upon a pillow. (L.)
tws-d ciraAEahu He made his fore arm his pillow; i. e., lay upon his fore arm, putting it as a pillow. (L.)

wisaAdN (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and wisaAdapN↓ (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and wasaAdapN and wusaAdapN, (Ḳ,) but some disallow the last two forms, (TA,) and UisaAdapN, (L,) and OusaAdapN, (Ḳ, art. Osd,) A pillow, or cushion, upon which one rests his cheek (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) or head: (L:) and the first, a thing upon which one reclines, or rests: (M, L, Ḳ:) or the first, only, signifies, anything that is used as a pillow, (A, Mṣb,) or put beneath the head, (L,) whether of household-furniture, (Mṣb,) or stones, (L,) or earth (A, L, Mṣb) &c: (Mṣb:) pl. of the first, wusudN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and wusodN; (L, TA;) and of the second, wasaAYidu (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and wasaAdaAtN. (Mṣb.)

Uin-a wisaAdaka laEariyDN ‡ [lit., Verily thy pillow is wide:] said by Moḥammad (L, Ḳ) to 'Adee Ibn-Ḥátim: (L:) alluding to his sleeping much; (L, Ḳ;) because he whose pillow is wide sleeps pleasantly: (Ḳ:) or to his sleeping night and day: (L:) or to his having a wide back to his neck, and a great head, indicating want of understanding. (L, Ḳ.) You say, huwa EariyDu AlwisaAdi, meaning, He is stupid, dull, or wanting in intelligence: (Mṣb:) or sleepy. (TA, art. ErD.)
wisaAdapN and wasaAdapN and wusaAdapN: see wisaAdN.

1. wasaTa Alqawoma, aor. yasiTu, inf. n. wasoTN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) [and wusuwTN (as shown below)] and siTapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He sat, [or was, or became,] in the middle, or midst, of the people, or company of men; (Ḳ;) or among them: (TA;) i. q. tws-Thumo↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or tws-T↓ bayonahumo: (Mṣb:) and in like manner, wasaTa AlmakaAna [he was, or became, or sat, in the middle, or midst, of the place]: (Mṣb:) and wasaTa AlX-aIoCa, and ws-Thu↓, and tws-Thu↓, he was, or became, in the middle, or midst, of the thing: and [in like manner] wusuwTu AlX-amosi signifies tawas-uTuhaA↓ Als-amaMCa [The sun's being, or becoming, in the middle, or midst, of the sky]. (M.)

wasaTa AlX-aIoCa also signifies He, or it, was, or became, in the best part of the thing, most remote from the two extremes. (TA.) And wasaTahu He alighted, or took up his abode, in, or among, the best, or most generous, thereof. (M.) And wasaTa Alr-ajulu qawomahu, and fiI qawomihi, inf. n. wasaATapN, The man occupied, or held, a middle place, [meaning the best place, or one of the best places,] among his people, in respect of truth and equity. (Mṣb.) And wasaTa qawomahu fiI AlHasabi, aor. yasiTu, inf. n. siTapN, [He held a middle, or good, or the best, rank among his people in regard of grounds of pretension to respect.] (M.) And wasuTa fiI Hasabihi, [aor. yawosuTu,] inf. n. wasaATapN and siTapN, [He held a middle, or good, or the best, rank in regard of his grounds of pretension to respect;] (M, TA;) and wasaTa signifies the same; (M;) and so does ws-T↓, (M, TA,) inf. n. tawosiyTN. (TA.) [See wasaTN, below.]
2. ws-Thu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tawosiyTN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He put it in the middle, or midst. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And [so in the Ṣ, but in the Ḳ “or,”] He cut it [in the middle, or midst, i. e.] in two halves. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See the pass. part. n., below.]

[In the Ḳur, c. 5,] some read, fawas-aTona bihi jamoEFA [which may mean And have put in the midst, thereby, a company of the enemy: or have divided in two halves, thereby,, &c.: or have thereby become in the midst of a company of the enemy]: (Ṣ, TA:) others read fawasaTona. (TA.) See 1, first sentence.
ws-T fI Hasabihi: see 1, last sentence.
5: see 1, first sentence, in four places.

tws-T bayona Aln-aAsi He mediated, or interceded, between the men, or people, for the purpose of accommodation; from wasaTa Alr-ajulu qawomahu and fiI qawomihi, explained above; (Mṣb;) or from wasaATapN; (Ṣ;) he made mediation, or intercession, (Eamila AlwasaATapa,) between them. (Ḳ.)
tws-T also signifies He took what was of a middle sort, between the good and the bad. (Ḳ.)

wasoT, with the s quiescent, is an adv. n.; [as such written wasoTa, meaning In the middle of: in the midst of; or among;] (Ṣ, M, IB, Mgh, Ḳ;) and it is for this reason that it has its middle letter quiescent, (Ṣ, IB,) like bayona (IB) with which it is syn.; (IB, Mṣb;) [for] it may be used in any case in which bayona may be substituted for it; (Ṣ, IAth, Ḳ;) and, like bayona, it does not denote a part of the thing denoted by the noun to which it is prefixed, wherein differing from wasaT↓. (Ṣ, IB, Ḳ.) You say, jalasotu wasoTa Alqawomi (Ṣ, IB, Mṣb) I sat [in the middle of, or in the midst of,] or among, the people, or company of men, (IB, Mṣb;) not being one of them. (IB.) And wasoTa raOosihi duhonN [In the middle of his head is oil]; not meaning a component part of the head. (IB.) And it is said in a trad. AljaAlisu wasoTa AlHaloqapi maloEuwnN [The sitter in the midst of the ring is cursed]: for he must of necessity turn his back towards some of those who surround him, and so displease them; wherefore they curse him and revile him. (IAth.)

It may not [properly] be used as a decl. n., (IB,) i. e. as an inchoative, (Mgh,) nor as an agent, nor as an objective complement; (IB, Mgh), &c.; thus, also, differing from wasaT↓; unless it have the adverbial particle [fiI] prefixed to it; in which case it has the sense of wasaT, and you say, jalasotu fiI wasoTi Alqawomi and fI wasoTi raOosihi duhonN [like as you say jalasotu wasoTa Alqawomi and wasoTa raOosihi duhnN, explained above]: and sometimes it is used as a subst., preserving the quiescence [and the adverbial form], like as bayona is used as a subst. though virtually an adv. n., in cases like that where it is said in the Ḳur, [vi. 94,] laqado taqaT-aEa bayonakumo [meaning maA bayonakumo, or, as explained in the Expos. of the Jel., waSolukumo bayonakumo]: (IB:) or wasoT is sometimes used for wasaT↓, improperly; (Ṣ;) or it may be so used; (Mṣb;) or it is so used by poetic license; (M;) or, as some say, each of them may take the place of the other; and this seems the most likely: (IAth:) or one says wasoT, with sukoon, only, of that whereof the component parts are separate, or distinct, (IAth, Ḳ *,) such as a number of men, and beasts of carriage, &c.; (IAth;) and wasaT↓, (IAth,) or both, (Ḳ,) of that whereof the component parts are united, (IAth, Ḳ *,) such as a house, and the head, (IAth,) or such as a ring: (Ḳ:) it is related, as on the authority of Th, that wasaTu↓ AlX-aIoCi and wsoTuhu [both meaning The middle, or midst, of the thing] are said when the thing is solid; but when its component parts are separate, or distinct, the word is wasoTN, with sukoon, exclusively. (M.)

wasaTN [The middle, midst, or middle part, of a thing; i. e.,] properly, the part of which several lateral, or outer, portions are equal; as, for instance, the middle finger: but also meaning the part which is surrounded, or enclosed, on its several sides, although unequally: (Mṣb:) or the part that is between the two sides or extremities of a thing; (M, IB, Mgh, Ḳ;) [or the part, or point, that is between every two opposite extremities of a thing; and properly when equidistant;] as, for instance, the centre of a circle: (Mgh:) as also OawosaTu↓, (M, Ḳ,) which is [likewise] a subst., like OafokalN and OazomalN [but imperfectly decl. because originally an epithet]: (M:) wasaTN has its middle letter with fet-ḥ in order that it may agree in measure with its contr., which is TarafN; the like agreement being frequent: (IB:) and it is only used in cases in which bayona may not be substituted for it, herein [and in other respects, mentioned in the next preceding paragraph,] differing from wasoT: (Ṣ, IB, Ḳ:) [respecting the similar and dissimilar usages of wasaT and was-T, sufficient observations have been made in the next preceding paragraph, which see throughout, and more especially in its latter part:] the pl. of wasaTN is OawosaATN; and that of its syn. OawosaTu↓ is OawaAsiTu; or this may be a pl. of waAsiTN↓, and originally wawaAsiTu. (M.) You say, jalasotu fiI wasaTi Ald-aAri [I sat in the middle, or middle part, of the house]; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb;) because wasaT is a subst. (Ṣ.) And Uit-asaEa wasaTuhu [The middle, or middle part, thereof, became wide]. (Mgh, Mṣb.) And Darabotu wasaTa raOosihi [I smote the middle, or middle part, of his head]. (Mgh,* Mṣb.) And kasarotu wasaTa Alr-umoHi [I broke the middle, or middle part, of the spear]. (IB.) And wasaTuhu xayorN mino Tarafihi [The middle, or middle part, thereof is better than the extremity]. (Mgh, Mṣb.) And xayaru AlOumuwri OawosaATuhaA The best of affairs, or actions, or cases, are such of them as are between two extremes. (M. [See R. Q. 1, in art. Hq.]) It is sometimes put in the accus. case as an adv. n.; as in the saying, jalasotu wasaTa Ald-aAri; but this is an instance of departure from the original usage; and [the meaning is jalasotu fiI wasaTi Ald-aAri signifying as explained above; so that] it is not here syn. with bayona, like as wasoTa is. (IB.)

It is also used as an epithet: (IB, Mgh:) [as such signifying Middle; intermediate; midway, or equidistant, between the two extremities or extremes; in place, or position: but in this sense superseded in usage by OawosaTu↓ and waAsiTN↓ and mutawas-iTN↓: and in time; but in this sense also superseded in usage by OawosaTu↓:] middling; of middle sort, kind, or rate; (Mṣb;) as also OawosaTu↓ (Ṣ,* M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and mutawas-iTN↓ (M, Mgh, Mṣb) and wasuwTN↓ (M, TA) [and wasiyTN↓]; between good and bad; (Mṣb, TA;) as also OawosaTu↓: (Mṣb:) conforming, or conformable, to the just mean; just; equitable: (Zj, Ṣ, Ḳ:) good; (Zj, M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also wasiyTN↓: (M:) most conforming, or conformable, to the just mean; most just; most equitable; applied to what is so of a thing; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) whatever it be; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also OawosaTa↓: (M:) best; (Mṣb;) as also OawosaTu↓: (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ *:) most generous: (M:) and when used as an epithet, it is applied alike to a masc., fem., sing., dual, and pl., subst.: (Mgh:) the fem. of OawosaTu↓ is wusoTaI; (Mgh, Mṣb;) and the pl. masc. OawaAsiTu; and pl. fem. wusaTN. (Mṣb.) Hence, (Mṣb,) AlUiSobaEu AlwusoTaI↓ (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) The middle finger. (Mṣb.) And Alyawomu AlOawosaTu↓ [The middle day]. (Mṣb.) And All-ayolapu AlwusoTaI↓ [The middle night]. (Mṣb.) And AlEaXarapu AlOawaAsiTu↓, meaning The [ten middle] days. (Mṣb.) And AlEaXoru AlwusaTu↓, meaning The [ten middle] nights:
not AlEaXoru AlOawosaTu↓; for this is a vulgar mistake, into which relaters of traditions have fallen; or it may be a mistake of transcription. (Mṣb.) And AlS-alewpu AlwusoTaI↓, (M, Mgh, &c.,) mentioned in the Ḳur, [ii. 239,] (M, Ḳ,) meaning The middle prayer (Bḍ, TA) between the other prayers, (Bḍ,) or between the prayers of the night and the day; (TA;) or the most excellent of them in particular: (Bḍ:) i. e. the prayer of the afternoon; (ʼAlee Ibn-Abee-Tálib, I’Ab, and others, Mgh, Bḍ, Ḳ;) because the prophet said, on the day of the Ahzáb, “they have diverted us from AlSlwp AlwsTI, the prayer of the afternoon:” (Bḍ:) or the prayer of daybreak; (also said to be on the authority of ʼAlee, Mgh, Bḍ, Ḳ;) because it is between the prayers of the night and the day; (Bḍ;) for the saying of the prophet mentioned above does not contravene this and other assertions, since what is meant in the trad. is not what is meant in the Ḳur: (Ḳ:) or, (M, Ḳ,) accord. to Abu-l-Ḥasan, (M,) the prayer of Friday; (M, Ḳ;) because it is the most excellent of the prayers; (M;) and he who says otherwise errs, unless he trace up the assertion to the prophet: (M, Ḳ:) these three opinions are of the strongest authority; (B;) and the first is that which commonly obtains: (Mgh:) or the prayer of noon; (Mgh, Bḍ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) because it is in the middle of the day: (Bḍ:) or the prayer of Friday on the day thereof; but on other days the prayer of noon: (Ḳ, and also said to be on the authority of 'Alec:) or the prayer of sunset: (Mgh, Bḍ, Ḳ:) or the prayer of nightfall: (Bḍ, Ḳ:) or [the night-prayer called] Alwitor: (Ḳ:) or the prayer of the breaking of the fast: (Ḳ:) or the prayer of sacrifices: (Ḳ:) or the prayer of the period called the DuHaI: (Ḳ:) or the prayer of the congregation: (Ḳ:) or the prayer of fear: (Ḳ:) or the prayers of nightfall and daybreak together: (Ḳ, and said to be on the authorities of ʼOmar and ʼOthmán:) or the prayers of daybreak and the afternoon together: (Ḳ:) or any of the five prayers; because before it are two prayers and after it are two prayers: (Ḳ:) or all the divinely-appointed prayers: (Ḳ:) or certain prayers not particularized: (Ḳ:) or prayer of middling length, between long and short. (Ḳ.) Hence also, XaIoCN wasaTN A middling thing; a thing of middle sort or kind; (Mṣb;) between good and bad; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also OawosaTu↓: (Mṣb:) and in like manner it is applied to a male slave, and a female slave, (Mṣb,) and two male slaves, and two sheep or goats. (Mgh.) And mino OawosaTi↓ maA tuToEimuwna Oaholiykumo, in the Ḳur, [v. 91,] Of the middle sort of that which ye give for food to your families, (Mgh, Mṣb,) between what is prodigal and what is niggardly. (Mgh.) And Aln-amaTu AlOawosaTu↓ The middle class of men: occurring in a saying of ʼAlee, cited in full in art. gT. (M.) And Eal-imoniI diynFA wasuwTA↓ Teach thou to me a religion of the middle sort: occurring in a saying of an Arab of the desert to El-Ḥasan, cited in full voce faraTa. (M, TA.) And jaEalonaAkumo Oam-apF wasaTFA, in the Ḳur, [ii. 137,] (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) [We have made you to be a nation] conforming, or conformable, to the just mean; just; equitable: (Zj, Ṣ, IB, Bḍ, Ḳ:) or good. (Zj, Bḍ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And maroEFI wasaTN Choice pasturage. (M.) And rajulN wasaTN A good man; as also wasiyTN↓: (M:) or a man having good grounds of pretension to respect. (TA.) And fulaAnN wasiyTN↓ fiI qawomihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ *,) or bayonahumo, (as in some copies of the Ḳ,) Such a one is the best of his people (OawosaTuhumo↓) in race, and the highest of them in station. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And fulaAnN wasiyTu↓ Ald-aAri waAlHasabi [Such a one is of good quality, or of the best quality, in respect of tribe, and of grounds of pretension to honour]. (Lth.) And huwa mino wasaTi qawomihi, and mn OawosaTihimo↓, He is of the best of his people. (Mṣb.) And in like manner, huwa mino wasaTi AlX-aIoCi, and mn OawosaTihi↓, It is of the best of the thing. (Mṣb.) And qaAla OawosaTuhumo↓ in the Ḳur, lxviii. 28, The best of them said: (Jel:) or the most rightly directed, of them, to the truth: (Mṣb:) or it means OawosaTuhumo↓ raOoyFA [the most remote, of them, from either extreme, in judgment]; or sin-FA [in age]. (Bḍ.)
wasuwTN: see wasaTN, as an epithet, in two places.
wasiyTN: see wasaTN, as an epithet, in five places.
A mediator, or an intercessor, for the purpose of accommodation, (O, Ḳ,) between people, (O,) or between two persons engaged in mutual altercation or litigation. (Ḳ.)
wasaATapN [originally an inf. n.: (see 1:)]
[and hence, as a subst., Mediation, or intercession]. (Ṣ, Ḳ: see 5.)
wasaATapu Ald-anaAniyri The best of deenárs. (TA.)
[wasiyTapN A mean, or means: pl. wasaAYiTu.]
waAsiTN: see wasaTN, as a subst., and also as an epithet.

waAsiTu Alkuwri, (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ,) or Alr-aHoli, (ISh, Az, M,) and waAsiTatuhu↓, (Lth, M, Ḳ,) and mawosiTatuhu↓, (Lḥ, M, [or perhaps muwsiTatuhu↓, corresponding to muWoxiratuhu↓,]) The fore-part of the camel's saddle: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) accord. to Lth, (Az, TA,) the part, of the camel's saddle, which is between the taAdimap and the Mxirap; (Az, M, L;) but this is a mistake; (Az, L;) for the wAsT of the camel's saddle is one of the XaroxaAni, (ISh, Az, L,) which are its two extremities, [or upright pieces of wood,] like the qarabuwsuAni of the horse's saddle, (Az, L,) between which the rider sits; (ISh, Az, L;) it is the extremity which is next to the head of the camel; (Az, L;) the tall forepart next to the breast of the rider, (ISh, Az, L,) against which the breast of the rider sometimes strikes; (TA, in art. nHz;) the Mxirpa being the extremity which is next to the tail of the camel; (Az, L;) the hinder part of the saddle, which is its tall and broad piece of wood that is against (tuHaAciI) the head of the rider: (ISh, Az, L:) the former of these is not called wAsT as being a middle part between the Mxrp and the qAdmp, as Lth says; nor has the camel's saddle any [part called] qAdmp. (Az, L.)

AlwaAsiTu also signifies The piece of wood that is in the middle, between the two pieces called the EiDaAdataAni, in the yoke that is upon the neck of a bull which draws a cart or the like. (L in art. EDc.)

waAsiTapN The jewel that is in the middle of a qilaAdap [or necklace], which is the best thereof; (Ṣ;) the large pearl (dur-ap) that is in the middle thereof, which is the most precious of the beads thereof. (L.)
[In modern Arabic, A means of doing a thing. You say, biwaAsiTapi kacaA By means of such a thing.]
[Also, An intermediary, interposer, or agent between parties; a go-between.]
See also waAsiTN.
huwa fiI waAsiTapK mina AlEayoXi † He is in a good condition of life. (Er-Rághib, TA, in art. Hf.)
OawosaTu; fem. wusoTaI; pl. masc. OawaAsiTu; pl. fem. wusaTN: see wasaTN, as a subst., in two places; and as an epithet, throughout.
muwsaTN What is in the middle of a bayot [i. e. house, or tent, &c.], particularly. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
mawosiTapN, or muwsiTapN: see waAsiTN.

qatala fulaAnFA muwas-aTFA He slew such a one cut [in the middle, or midst,] in two halves. (TA.) [This mode of slaughter, termed tawosiyTN, was often practised under the rule of the Egyptian Sultáns; many instances thereof being mentioned by El-Makreezee and other historians. See De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., 2nd ed., vol. i. p. 468.]
mutawas-iTN: see wasaTN, as an epithet, in two places.

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. [waXowaXa, inf. n. waXowaXapN, He spoke in a low, faint, gentle, or soft, manner, with confusedness; accord. to an explanation, given by Khaleefeh, of the inf. n.; or the word of which he gave that explanation was wasowasapN, with s: (see wasowasa:) or he spoke confusedly, so as to be hardly intelligible: or he spoke in a low, faint, gentle, or soft, manner: (see waXowaXapN below: and see R. Q. 2:) in the present day it signifies he whispered: and waXowaXahu, he whispered to him.]
waXowaXotuhu, [or rather, app., waXowaXotuhu Uiy-aAhu,] I gave or handed, it to him in a small quantity. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 2. tawaXowaXuwA They were in a state of commotion, and spoke together one to another, or some of them to others, in a low, faint, gentle, or soft, manner. (IDrd, Ḳ.)
waXowaXN: see waXowaAXN.

hom.sense: waXowaXapN Speech with confusedness, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) so as to be hardly intelligible: (TA:) or confused speech: or low, faint, gentle, or soft, speech: or such a word or saying. (TA.) See R. Q. 1.
Lightness, activity, or agility. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: waXowaXiI-N: see waXowaAXN.

waXowaAXN Light, active, or agile; (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ;) applied to a man; (Ṣ;) and to an ostrich; (AA, Ḳ;) and so waXowaAXapN↓ applied to a she-camel; (Ḳ;) or this last, so applied, signifies quick, and light or active or agile; and so waXowaAXN applied to a he-camel; and waXowaXN↓ applied to a he-camel and to a man. (TA.) You say also, rajulN waXowaXiI-u↓ Alc-iraAEi, meaning, nXanaXiyy-uhu, (Ḳ,) i. e., A man slender in the [fore] arm, and light, or active, in work. (AO, TA.)
waXobN [app. meaning Fleshy] is from the expression tamorapN waXobapN, (in one copy of the Ḳ, waXobaACu, TA,) A date having a thick liHaMC [i. e. pulp, or flesh]. (Ḳ.) Of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

wiXobN sing. of OawoXaAbN, (Ḳ,) which is the same as OawobaAXN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and OaXowaAbN, (TA,) [but see this last word, in art. Xwb,] and signifies, A medley, or mixed multitude; (Ḳ;) or sundry, or separate sorts of people; (Ṣ;) and young men of the baser sort. (TA.) A term of dispraise only. (Marg. note in a copy of the Ṣ.)
1. The roots and branches became entangled together. (Ṣ.)
waXaja, aor. yaXiju, inf. n. waXojN and waXiyjN, It (anything) became entangled, intermixed, confused, or intricate. (TA.)
waXajato fiI qalobihi OumuwrN wahumuwmN ‡ Affairs, and griefs, or solicitudes, became perplexing in his heart. (TA.)
qado waXajato bika qaraAbapu fulaAnK, aor. taXiju, (Ḳ,) ‡ The relationship of such a one to thee has become intricate; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) like as the roots and branches of trees become intricate. (TA.)
2. waX-j AlqaraAbapa, inf. n. tawoXiyjN, ‡ He (God) made the relationship intricate. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
wX-j Qll-ehu bayonahumo ‡ God joined and mixed them together. (TA.)
wX-j He laced together a maHomil [or basket in which grapes are carried to the dryingplace] with a leather thong, or the like, (such as a XariyT, TA,) lest anything should fall from it. (Ḳ.)

waXiyjN Trees of which spears are made: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or canes growing obliquely, or, as in the M, in an intricate manner: or the hardest of canes: or, as a coll. gen. n., ‡ spears; n. un. with p {waXiyjapN}: (TA:) [See also EijolapN:] or, originally, the roots of canes: and afterwards applied to signify spears, themselves; so called because of their intermingling when meeting together. (Ḥam, p. 165.)
taTaAEanuwA biAlwaXiyji ‡ They thrust one another with the spears. (A.)
Oafonati Als-anapu AlwaXiyja Drought destroyed the tangled trees, or their roots; no moisture remaining in the earth. (TA, from a trad.)
waXiyjN The roots of the sinews. (TA.)
waXiyjN ‡ Intricacy of relationship: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. waXaAYiju. (TA.) Ex. bayonahumo waXaAYiju Aln-asabi There is an intricacy of relationship between them. (TA.)
waXiyjapN The root (Eiroq) of a tree. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See waAXijapN.

waXiyjapN [An implement made of] fibres of the palm tree (lyf) twisted, and then tied (or, as in some lexicons, attached in the manner of a net, TA,) between two pieces of wood, (or a net between two pieces of wood, TA,) upon which reaped wheat, &c. are carried. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
waAXijN Anything entangled, intermixed, confused, or intricate. (TA.)

waAXijapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and waXiyjapN↓ (TA) ‡ Intricate relationship; or intricate uterine relationship; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and close. (TA.) Ex. bayonahumo waAXijapu raHimK Between them is an intricate and close relationship. (TA.)
OamorN muwaX-ajN An intricate, or a confused, affair. (TA.)
2. wX-H AlmaroOapa, inf. n. tawoXiyjN, He put on the woman a wiXaAH, q. v. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See 5.
wX-Hhu wiXaAHFA ‡ He struck him a blow upon the place of the wiXaAH. (TA.)
5. twX-Ht, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and At-XHt↓, (Ḳ,) She (a woman) put on, or decked herself with, a wiXaAH q. v. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

t-wXH bivawobihi, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) and At-XH↓ bihi, (Mṣb,) ‡ i. q. taqal-ada: (Ḳ:) but MF disapproves of this explanation: (TA:) or He put his garment under his right arm-pit, and threw it [meaning a portion of it] over his left shoulder, like as the muHorim does; (T, Mṣb;) like taOab-aTa and AiDoTabaEa: (T:) or he threw a portion of his garment over his left shoulder, and drew its extremity under his right arm, and tied the two extremities together in a knot upon his bosom. (M.) Also, He wrapped himself up in his garment. (L.)
wX-Hhu↓ Alv-awoba, as also OaX-aHahu ‡ He put on him the garment in the manner described in the explanation of the phrase twX-H bivawobihi. (M, L.)

twX-H bisayofihi (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) ‡ i. q. taqal-adahu: (Ḳ:) [or i. q.] twX-H biHamaAYili sayofihi He put the suspensories of his sword over his left shoulder, leaving the right bare: (T:) and twX-H binijaAdihi [signifies the same]. (A.)

twXH bilijaAmihi (L) ‡ He threw the bit and bridle of his horse upon his shoulder, and put his arm through it, so that it became like a wiXaAH. (Expos. of the Moʼallaḳát printed at Calcutta, p. 171.) [See the verse of Lebeed quoted below.]
twX-H QmoraOapF ‡ Inivit feminam: (A, TA:) or he embraced a woman round the neck, and turned her over. (TA.)
8: see 5, in two places.
UiOuXaAHN: see wiXaAHN.

wiXaAHN and wuXaAHN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) also written UiXaAHN↓ and OuXaAHN, and by poetic licence wiXoHan-N↓, (Ṣ.) An ornament worn by women, (L,) [consisting of] two series (kirosaAni) of pearls and jewels strung or put together in regular order, which two series are disposed, or placed, contrariwise, (yuxaAlafu bayonahumaA,) one of them being turned (maEoTuwf) over the other [so that they cross each other]: (L, Ḳ:) or a thing woven of leather, and adorned with jewels, like a qilaAdap, worn by a woman: (Mṣb:) or a wide [piece, or thing, of] leather, (Ḳ,) or a thing woven of leather, in a wide, or broad, form, (Ṣ,) and adorned with jewels, which a woman binds (taXud-uhu) between her shoulders and her flanks: (Lth, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) or a qilaAdap of the belly, which is sometimes long, so that the redundant portions of its two extremities are thrown over the shoulders: (Mgh:) or one of a pair of necklaces which a woman makes to hang down upon her sides; one upon her right side, and the other upon her left: (W. 144:) [hence it seems to be of different kinds; one kind consisting of two ornaments resembling necklaces, one of which rests upon the right shoulder and against the left flank, the other resting upon the left shoulder and against the right flank; another kind seems, from an expression in the A, “a woman bearing a wiXaAH, and wiXaAHayoni,” to be one such ornament; another, an ornament resembling a necklace, thrown over the head, so as to rest upon the shoulders, crossing in front, and passing round the loins, and is tied or crossed in front, and of which the redundant portions are thrown over the shoulders: see also kaXoHN:] pl. wuXuHN and OawoXiHapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and waXaAYiHu: (M, Ḳ:) the last thought by ISd to be formed as though from wXAHp. (L.)

Lebeed says:
walaqado Hamayotu AlHaI-a taHomilu Xik-itiI
furuTN wiXaAHiI Uico gadawotu lijaAmuhaA
[And I have protected the tribe; a swift, outstripping, horse, whose bit and bridle were my wiXaAH when I went away, bearing my arms: see twX-H bljAmh]:
he relates his having gone forth as a scout for his people, mounted on his camel, with his horse by his side, and bearing its bit and bridle like a wXAH, so that he might bit the horse if he perceived the enemy. (L.)
wiXaAHN † A bow: (L:) [so called because of the manner in which it is worn].
wiXaAHN (M) and wiXaAHapN↓ (M, Ḳ) † A sword: (M, Ḳ:) so called because of the manner in which it is worn: see 5. (M.)
hiIa garovaI AlwiXaAHi, [and EaToXaI AlwiXaAHi, or EaTiXapu AlwiXaAHi, and jaAYiEapu AlwXAH,] ‡ She is slender in the belly and flanks. (Ḳ.) [See also art. grv.]
wiXaAHapN: see wiXaAHN.
waXoH-MCu A she-goat (Ṣ, Ḳ) that is black, (L,) with a white mark, or with two white marks, like a wiXaAH; expl. by muwaX-aHapN bibayaADK. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
muwaX-aHN ‡ A garment, and a cock, having two marks like a wiXaAH. (L.)
muwaX-aHapN ‡ A gazelle, and a sheep, and a bird, having two streaks, or strips, one on each side. (L.) [See SuloSulN.]
1. waXara, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. waXorN, (TA,) He sawed a piece of wood with a miyXaAr; a dial. form of OaXar; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. q. naXara. (Ḳ.)

wXarato, aor. taXiru, (Mṣb,) inf. n. waXorN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) She (a woman) sharpened (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) her teeth, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or her canine teeth, (Mṣb.) and made them thin [and serrated], (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) meaning their edges: (TA:) [as also OaXarato.] See waAXirapN.
10. AstwXrt She (a woman) asked for her [teeth or] canine teeth to be sharpened and made thin [and serrated]. (Mṣb.)
wuXurN a dial. form of OuXurN [A serration and a sharpness of the extremities of the teeth]. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

waAXirapN A woman who sharpens and makes thin [and serrated] the [teeth, or] canine teeth. (Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., laEan Qll-ehu AlwaAXirapa waAlmuwtaXirap [May God curse her who sharpens and makes thin and serrated the teeth, or the canine teeth, and her who orders one to do this, or who asks for it to be done]. (Ṣ, TA.) An old woman does this in order to make herself like the young. (TA.)
muWaX-aru AlEaDudayoni, applied to the beetle, [meaning, Having the fore-shanks formed thin, and serrated;] as also without C. (Ḳ.)
miyXaAr, without C, A saw; a dial. form of miYoXaArN. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.)

muwtaXirapN A woman who orders one to sharpen teeth and to make them thin [and serrated]: (L:) or who asks for this to be done; as also musotawoXirapN↓: (Ḳ:) if with C, it is from OaXorN, not waXorN; and if without C, accord. to the regular way it should be mut-aXirapN. (Ḳ.)
musotawoXrapN: see muwtaXirapN.

2. wS-St, (AZ, TA,) or waSowaSato↓, (M,) She (a girl, M,) put on, or wore, her niqaAb [a kind of fare-veil], (AZ, TA,) or her qinaAE [a kind of head-covering], (M,) in such a manner that nothing was seen but her eyes: (AZ, M, TA:) tawoSiySN and taroSiySN signify the same: (AZ, Ṣ, CK:) the former is of the dial. of Temeem: (AZ, TA:) or both the above verbs signify she (a woman) contracted her nqAb (Ḳ, TA) so that it shewed nothing but her eyes: (TA:) or wSwSt signifies she (a woman) put her nqAb near to her eyes. (Fr. TA.)

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. waSowaSato: see 2, throughout.
waSowaSa He looked through a hole such as is termed waSowaSN. (Ḳ.)
He (a whelp) opened his eyes. (Ḳ.)
waSowaSa Eayonahu He (a man) contracted his eye in order to obtain a sure view. (IDrd, M.)

entry.sense: waSaAYiSN: see waSowaSN.

waSowaSN, (Ṣ,) or waSowaASN↓, (M,) or both, (Ḳ,) the latter on the authority of Lth, (TA,) A hole in a veil or the like, of the size of the eye, through which one looks. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) And waSaAwiSu, [the pl. of the former, or of either,] The narrow parts of the apertures for the eyes of a buroquE [a kind of woman's face-veil]; (M, TA;) as also waSaAYiSu. (TA.)
waSowaASN: see waSowaSN.
A small buroquE [a kind of face-veil]: (Ṣ, M:) pl waSaAwiSu (Ṣ,) signifying small baraAqiE worn by a girl. (Ḳ.)
buroquEN waSowaASN A buroquE that is contracted [so as to show nothing but the eyes]. (M, TA.)
1. waSiYa, as also SaYiYa, (mentioned by Lb, TA,) It (a garment) was, or became, dirty. (Ḳ.)
1. waSaba, aor. yaSibu, inf. n. wuSuwbN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and AwSb↓; (Ḳ;) It continued; was constant; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) was fixed, settled, or firm. (Ḳ.)
waSaba labanu Aln-aAqapi † The milk of the camel continued, or was constant. (A.)

waSiba, aor. yawoSabu, inf. n. waSabN; (Ṣ, Ḳ, Mṣb;) and wS-b↓ and AwSb↓ and twS-b↓; (Ḳ;) He (a man, Ṣ,) was, or became, diseased, ill, or sick: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or in pain: (Mṣb:) [or in violent pain: or in continual, or constant, pain: or emaciated in body by reason of fatigue or disease: or in a state of excessive fatigue: and, sometimes, he suffered fatigue, or weariness, and languor: see waSabN:] tawoSiyobN is also explained as signifying the being languid: (TA:) and twS-b↓, as signifying he felt, or experienced, pain in his body. (A.)
waSaba AlX-aHomu ‡ The fat [in an animal] continued. (TA.)

waSaba EalaI AlOamori, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yaSibu, [inf. n. wuSuwbN;] and waSiba, aor. yaSibu; the latter aor. extr. [with respect to analogy]; (Kr;) like waviqa, aor. yaviqu, and wamiqa, aor. yamiqu, &c.; but not mentioned by the lexicographers with these verbs; (TA;) [and AwSb↓; see below;] and wASb↓; (TA;) i. q. waAZaba; He kept. attended, or applied himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to the thing; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and managed it, or conducted it, well. (Ḳ.)
waSaba fiI maAlihi, and EalaI mAlh; and wiSiba; aors. as above; He kept, attended, or applied himself, constantly to his property, [meaning his camels, &c.,] and managed it well. (Kr.)
AwSb↓ Alqawomu EalaI AlX-aIoCi The people kept, attended. or applied themselves, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to the thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
2. wS-bhu He took care of him, tended him, or nursed him, in his sickness: like mr-Dh. (TA, from a trad.)
See 1.
3: see 1, and 4.

hom.sense: 4. AwSbhu It (a disease) rendered him ill, or sick. (TA.) See waSabN.
AwSbhu He (God) afflicted him with a disease, sickness, or malady. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See waSabN.
AwSb He (a man) had diseased children born to him. (Ḳ.) Accord. to IḲṭṭ, AwSb Alqawomu The people had their children wearied by disease. (TA.)

AwSbti Aln-aAqapu AlX-aHoma ‡ The she-camel grew fat, (Ḳ,) and continued so: (TA:) [explained in the Ḳ by nabata XaHomuhaA, which is probably a mistake for vabata; and if so, I prefer another reading of the phrase in the Ḳ, mentioned in the TA; namely, AwSb Aln-aAqapa AlX-aHomu; i. e., the she-camel was constantly fat].
AwSbt Aln-aAqapu, and wASbt↓, † The she-camel yielded milk continually, or constantly. (A.)
See 1.

entry.sense: 5: see 1, in two places.
waSobN The space between the third finger and the first finger; or, lit., what is between those two fingers. (Ḳ.)

waSabN A disease, sickness, or malady: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or pain: (Mṣb:) or violent pain: or continual, or constant, pain: or continuance of pain: (TA:) or emaciation of the body by reason of fatigue or disease: (IDrd:) or excessive fatigue: (Zj:) and, sometimes, fatigue, or weariness, and languor: (TA:) pl. OawoSaAbN. (Ḳ.)
waSibN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and waASibN↓ (TA) Diseased; ill; sick: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or in pain: (Mṣb:) [or in violent pain: or in continual, or constant pain:, &c.: see waSabN]: pl. of the former waSaAbaI and waSaAbN. (Ḳ.)
waASibN: see waSibN.
EacaAbN waASibN [Ḳur. xxxvii. 9,] A continual, perpetual, constant, or fixed, punishment. (Fr, TA.)

lahu Ald-iynu waASibFA, [Ḳur, xvi. 54,] as Zj observes, is said to mean To Him shall be rendered obedience perpetually, or constantly: (Fr, Ṣ:) or it may mean To Him shall be rendered obedience, whether man be content with that which he is commanded to do, or not; or whether it be easy to him, or not: to Him shall be rendered obedience, even if it be attended by excessive fatigue. (TA.)
mafaAzapN waASibapN A desert far-extending, [as though] without end; (Ṣ;) that extends so far as scarcely to have an end; (A;) very far-extending. (Ḳ.)
muwaSabN Afflicted by God with a disease, sickness, or malady. (Ṣ.)
naAqapN muwSibapN, and muwaS-ibapN↓ [perhaps a mistake for muwaASibapN: see 4:] † A she-camel that yields milk continually, or constantly. (A.)
muwaS-abN Having many pains [or diseases]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
muwaS-ibapN: see naAqapN muwSibapN.
4. AwSd He closed, a door, or an entrance; syn. Oagolaqa; (Ṣ, M, A, L, Ḳ;) and OaTobaqa: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) as also MSada. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
See 10.
OuwiSida It (a door, or entrance) became closed. (Ṣ.)
AwSd He covered, or covered over, a cooking-pot. (M, A, L.)
waqaEa Aljabalu EalaI baAbi Alkahofi faOawoSadahu The mountain fell upon the entrance of the cavern, and stopped it up. (L, from a trad.) See also OawoTada.
AwSdwA Ealayohi ‡ They straitened him, and imposed on him a difficulty which he was unable to bear. (A.)
10. AstwSd (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ) and AwSd↓ (A, Ḳ) He made a fold, such as is called waSiydap, (Ṣ, L,) or waSiyd, (Ḳ,) or a HaZiyrap, for his sheep or goats, (A,) in a mountain. (Ṣ, L.)

wiSaAdN (M, L,) as also UiSaAdN, (L,) and waSiydN↓ [see the Ḳur, xviii. 17,] (Ḳ,) i. q. mTbq: (M, L, Ḳ.: [in a copy of the M written maTobaqN: in the L, without any syll. signs: in the CK, muTobaq: and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, muTobiq: see the remarks on these words in art. OaSd:]) or wiSaAdN and UiSaAdN are like TibaAqN. (O.)
waSiydN A court, or an open or a wide space in front of a house or dwelling, or extending from its sides: (Ṣ, M, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) as also OaSiydN; q. v.: (L:) pl. wuSudN and waSaAYidu. (TA.)
A threshold (Mṣb, Ḳ) of a door or entrance. (Mṣb.)
A door, or entrance. (A.) See wiSaAdN.
It has the first of these meanings in the Ḳur, xviii. 17; (A, L, TA;) or the second: (TA:) or the third: (A, TA:) or it there means The cavern of the Asháb el-Kahf. (Ḳ *, TA.)

Also, waSiydN, (Ḳ,) or waSiydapN↓, (Ṣ, A, L,) [as also OaSiydapN,] A fold (HaZiyrap) for sheep or goats: (A:) or a house like a HZyrp, of stones, made in the mountains, for flocks or herds; (L, Ḳ;) i. e., for sheep or goats, &c.: (TA:) an enclosure like a HZyrp, made for flocks or herds, excepting that it is of stones, and a HZyrp [is] of branches of trees: (Ṣ, L:) F, misunderstanding this explanation, has erroneously said in the Ḳ, that waSiydN also signifies a HZyrp of branches of trees: (TA:) pl. waSaAYidu. (A.)
[Snares, or traps, for catching beasts of prey: see raSaAYidu in art. rSd.]
waSiydN Herbage having the roots near together. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
waSiydN ‡ Strait; straitened; (Ḳ, TA;) as also muwSadN↓ Ealayohi. (A, TA.)
waSiydapN: see waSiydN.
muwSadN A door, or entrance, closed: (L:) or become closed. (Ṣ.)
In the Ḳur, eiv. 8, [and xc. 20,] muwSadapN (as some read instead of muWoSadapN, L) signifies Closed over. (Ṣ, L.)
See waSiydN.
wiSorN A covenant, compact, or contract: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a dial. form of UiSorN; like as they said UirovN and wirovN, and UisaAdapN and wisaAdapN. (Ṣ.)
