Also, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and waSar-apN↓ (Lth, A, Ḳ) and waSiyrapN↓ (Ḳ) and OawoSarN↓, (Lth, TṢ, L,) A written statement of a purchase or sale, transfer, bargain, or contract: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA:) the first is from UiSorN, and is generally used in this sense: pl. of the first, OawoSaArN; and of the second, waSar-aAtN: Lth says, that the second is an arabicized word; and others say, that the first and second are Persian words, arabicized. (TA.) One says, OaqoTaEahu AlOaroDa wakataba lahu AlwiSora, and AlwaSar-apa↓, [He made him a grant of the land to be held in fee, and wrote for him the statement of the transfer.] (A.) And it is said in a trad., hecaA QXotaraI min-iI OaroDFA waqabaDa min-iI wiSorahaA falaA huwa yarud-u EalaI-a AlwiSora walaA yuEoTiyniI Alv-amana [This man purchased of me some land (or daArFA a house, as in the TA) and received of me the written statement of its sale, but he will not restore to me the written statement of the sale, nor will he give me the price]. (Ṣ.)
waSar-apN: see wiSorN.
waSiyrapN: see wiSorN.
OawoSarN: see wiSorN.
1. waDuWa (Ṣ, Ḳ) aor. yawoDuWu, inf. n. waDaMCapN; (TA;) and waDiYa, aor. yawoDaOu; (IO, &c.;) He was, or became, fair, beautiful, neat, or clean. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

waADaOahu↓ fawaDaOahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. of the latter yaDaOu, (Ṣ,) dev. from rule, by which, as a verb of the class called AfEAl AlmgAlbp, it should be like yanoSuru, (TA,) He vied with him for the honour of surpassing in fairness, or comeliness, and prevailed over him therein. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
2. wD-Ohu [He made him, or assisted him, to perform the ablution termed wuDuwoCF, or waDuwoC.] (M, TA.) [See an ex. voce qisoTN.]
3: see 1.
It sometimes signifies He washed some one or more of his members: he purified his hand, or hands, and mouth, by washing, from the foul smell of fat, or greasy, food: he washed his hand.
Some say tawaD-ayotu [for tawaD-aOotu]; but this should not be said: (Ṣ:) it is of weak authority, or is viciously so pronounced: (Ḳ:) it is said to be of the dial, of Hudheyl. (TA.)
twD-O, and twD-Ot, He (a youth), and she (a girl), arrived at the age of puberty. (Ḳ.)
UiDaACN: see waDiIoCN.
waDuwoCN: see wuDuwoCN.

wuDuwoCN signifies The act of ablution, &c. (Ṣ, Ḳ) (see 5); and waDuwoCN↓, the water with which that act is performed, or the water that is prepared for that act, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and is said to be also an inf. n., [or rather a quasi-inf. n., signifying the act itself]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or they are syn. words of two different dialects, each sometimes used as an inf. n., signifying the act, (though inf. ns. of the measure faEuwlN deviate from constant rule, TA,) and each sometimes as signifying the water. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) AA says, that waDuwoCN↓ signifies “the water with which one performs the ablution above mentioned;” and he knew not wuDuwoCN [though it occurs in many traditions]: and AʼObeyd disallows waDuwoCN, and allows only waDuwoCN↓. (TA.)

waDiIoCN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) pl. OawoDiyaMCu and wiDaMCN; (Ḳ;) and wuD-aMCN↓, [Ṣ, Ḳ; in the CK, erroneously, wuD-aMCK;] pl. wuD-aAWuwna and waDaADiYu; (Ḳ;)
and waADiYN↓, (Ḳ,) which is used in the future sense, accord. to Lḥ, [like an act. part. n., though from a neut. verb,] as in the ex. [mentioned in the Ḳ] maAhw biwaADiYK; waDiIoCN being used in the present sense; (TA;) Fair, beautiful, neat, or clean. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

In the following of En-Nábighah,
fahun-a UiDaMCN SaAfiyaAtu AlgalaAYili
[And they are fair, beautiful, neat, or clean; unsullied as to their inner garments], UiDaMCN↓ may be put for wiDaMCN. (TA.)
waDaMCap Fairness, beauty, neatness, or cleanness. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
wuD-aMCN and waADiYN: see waDYCN.
OawoDaOu Fairer, neater, or cleaner. (TA, from a trad.)

miyDaOapN, and, sometimes, miyDaMCapN↓, A place in which, and from which, one performs the ablution termed wDwC; (Ḳ;) [as also mutuwaD-aON↓:] a miToharap (Ḳ: in the CK, maToharap), meaning that from which, or in which, one performs the said ablution: (TA:) [a tank for ablution, accord. to present usage].
miyDaMCapN: see what precedes.
mutawaD-aON: see miyDaOapN. A privy; or place where one performs ablution. (Ḳ, TA, voce macohab, &c.)

hom.sense: 1. waDaHa, aor. yaDiHu, inf. n. wuDuwHN (Ṣ, Mṣb, L, Ḳ) and DiHapN and DaHapN, (L, Ḳ,) the last with fet-ḥah because the guttural letter; (TA;) and At-DH↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and AwDH↓, and twD-H↓; (L, Ḳ;) It (an affair, OamorN, Ṣ, Ḳ, and a thing, XaIoCN, L,) appeared; became apparent, or plainly apparent, overt, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, plain, obvious, or evident; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) became clear, unobscured, exposed to view, displayed, laid open, disclosed, or uncovered. (Mṣb.)
‡ It (language) was perspicuous. (The Lexicons, passim.)
twD-H↓ miloku AlT-ar-iyqi The middle of the road became plainly apparent, obvious, or conspicuous. (Ṣ.)

mano Oayona waDaHa Alr-aAkibu, as AZ says, or, as others say, mn Ayn AwDH↓, Whence did the rider make his appearance? (L.) Or waDaHa Alr-aAkibu signifies the rider came forth: (ISd:) and mn Ayn OawoDaHta↓ whence hast thou come forth? (IAạr, Ṣ,) and [in like manner one says] mn Ayn badaA waDaHuka. (Ṣ.)
waDaHati AlUibilu biAll-abani ‡ i. q. OalomaEat. (Ḳ.)

waDiHa, aor. _a {yawoDaHu}, inf. n. waDaHN, [a verb of which the inf. n. is explained in the Mṣb by the word drn: if this be not a mistake of a copyist, it app. signifies He, or it, was dirty; or was dirtied, soiled, or besmeared].

entry.sense: 2: see 4.

4. AwDHhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and AwDH Eanohu, (L,) inf. n. UiyDaAHN: (TA,) and wD-Hhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. tawoDiyHN; (TA;) He rendered it apparent or plainly apparent, overt, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, plain, obvious, or evident; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) rendered it clear, or unobscured; exposed it to view; displayed it; laid it open; disclosed or uncovered it. (Mṣb.)
He rendered language perspicuous. (The lexicons, passim.)
AwDHt AlX-aj-apu fiI Alr-aOosi The wound upon the head laid bare the bone. (Mṣb,) [See muwDiHapN.]
AwDH lahu AlOamora, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AlkalaAma, (Ṣ,) He made the affair, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and the language, (Ṣ,) plain, or clear, to him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See 1.
AwDH qawomFA He saw a people. (L.)
AwDH He (a man) had white children born to him: (Ṣ, L:) and in like manner one says [AwDHt] of a woman. (L.)
5: See 1.
twD-H [app., He (a sheep or goat) had a whiteness predominant over other colours, overspreading generally his whole body: or in his breast and back and face]. (L.)
8: see 1.

10. AstwDH XayoYFA He put his hand over his eyes (in the sun, L) to try if he could see a thing, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) guarding his eyes with his hand from the rays of the sun: as also Aisotakaf-ahu, and AisotaXorafahu. (L.) One says AisotawoDiHo Eanohu yaA fulaAnu [Try if thou canst see him, or it, by putting thy hand over thine eyes, O such a one]. (Ṣ.)
AstwDH Als-abiyla He sought or endeavoured to see plainly or clearly the way: syn. AistabaAnahu (Beyd, vi. 55.)
AstwDH AlX-amosa He blinked at the sun; syn. taHaAwaSa UilayohaA. (A.)
AstwDHhu AlOamora, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AlkalaAma, (Ṣ,) He asked him to make the affair, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and the language, (Ṣ,) plain, or clear, to him. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
AstwDH Eani AlOamori He inquired respecting the thing or affair; sought for information respecting it; inquired into it; investigated it. (L.)
waDaHN Light, and whiteness, (Ṣ,) of anything: (TA:) the whiteness of daybreak, or dawn: and of the moon; (Ḳ;) and its light. (TA.)
SuwmuwA mina AlwaDaHi UilaI AlwaDaHi Fast ye from new moon to new moon. (IAth, from a trad.)
waDaHN ‡ Leprosy; syn. baraSN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) It is sometimes used in this sense, metonymically. (Ṣ.)
waDaHN A mark in a horse differing in colour from the generality of his coat. You say biAlfarasi waDaHN In the horse is such a mark. (Ṣ.)
waDaHN A blaze, or white mark on a horse's forehead or face. (Ḳ.)
What is termed taHojiylN in the legs of a horse. (L, Ḳ.) And also applied to other varieties of colour. (L.)
frasN cuw OawoDaAHK A horse having a blaze and what is termed tHjyl. (A.)
waDaHN Whiteness of the hair, or hoariness; or white, or hoary, hair. (Ḳ.)

‡ Milk: (L, Ḳ:) thought by ISd to be so called because of its whiteness: or milk that has not been mixed with water: (L:) or that is just drawn. (TA, art. zhr.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
Eaq-awoA bisahomK falamo yaXoEuro bihi OaHadN
vum-a QsotafaWuwA waqaAluwAHab-acaA AlwaDaHu
[They shot an arrow towards the sky, and no one knew of it: then they returned, and said, An excellent thing is milk]: meaning, we would rather have milk than the blood of him who has killed our companion: they preferred that camels should be given them in compensation. (L.) [See also 2, in art. EqI.]
waDaHN A sound, whole or perfect, [silver coin, of the kind called] diroham. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) dirohamN waDaHN A clean, white dirhem: pl. OawoDaAHN. (TA.)
waDaHN The middle, or main part and middle, of a road; the part of a road along which one travels. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

waDaHN A woman's ornament (HaloIN) of silver: (AʼObeyd, Ḳ:) or, of stones; (El-Mesháriḳ;) i. e. of silverstones: (Towsheeh:) so called because of its whiteness: (TA:) pl. OawoDaAHN: (Ḳ:) or OawoDaAHN signifies a kind of woman's ornament (HaloIN) made of whole [silver coins such as are called] daraAhim: (Ṣ:) and (according to some, TA,) waDaHN signifies an anklet; syn. xaloxaAlN (Ḳ)

waDaHN (Ḳ) or waDaHN AlT-ariyfapi, (L, but the latter word is there written; Tryqp,) Small portions, or parts, of herbage; (L, Ḳ;) what he has become white thereof: (AḤn:) pl. OawoDaAHN: (L:) or OawoDaAHN mino kalaUK signifies somewhat of herbage that has become white: (Aṣ:) Az says, I have mostly heard the term waDaHN, with respect to herbage, applied to the naSiI- and Sil-iyaAn SayofiI- which is not a year old and has not become black: and on another occasion he says, that it is the remains of the HaliI- and Sil-iyaAn only. (L.)

waDaHN Whiteness predominating over other colours in sheep or goats, overspreading generally the whole body: pl. OawoDaAHN: (L:) or, in the breast and back and face: (T:) you say also lahu tawoDyHN↓. (L.)
mino Oayona badaA waDaHuka: see 1.
waDaHu Alqadami Whiteness of the hollow of the sole of the foot. (L.)
waDaHapN A she-ass. (Ḳ.)
waDiyHapN, Camels, or camels and sheep; syn. naEamN: pl. waDaAYiHu. (L, Ḳ.)
waD-aAHN: see waADiHN.

waADiHN and waD-aAHN↓ [but the latter has an intensive signification] Apparent, or plainly apparent; overt; conspicuous; manifest; notorious; plain; obvious; or evident; (L, Ḳ;) clear, or unobscured; exposed to view; displayed; laid open; disclosed, or uncovered. (So accord. to the explanation of the verb in the Mṣb.)
Perspicuous language. (The Lexicons passim.)
Also ↓the latter, A man of white, or fair, and beautiful, complexion: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) of beautiful and smiling countenance. (L.)
See mutawaD-iHN.
Also ↓the latter, ‡ Leprous. Hence Jedheemeh El-Abrash was called AlwaD-aAHu. (Ṣ.)
AlwaD-aAHu↓ The day. (L, Ḳ.) The night is called Ald-ahomaAnu. (L.)
bikoru AlwaD-aAHi↓ The prayer of morning, or daybreak. The prayer of nightfall is called vinoIu dahomaAna. (L, Ḳ [but in the CK and a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, for dahomaAna, we find duhomaAna].)

EaZomu waD-aAHK↓, (L, Ḳ,) and EuZayomu waD-aAHK, (L,) A certain game (of the children of the Arabs of the desert, L,) in which children take a white bone and throw it in the darkness of night, and then disperse themselves in search of it: (L, Ḳ:) he who finds it wins. (L.) [See more in art. EZm.]
huwa minoka OadonaI waADiHapK↓ He is plainly apparent to thee, as though he had become white. (Th.)
rajulN waADHu AlHasabi, and waD-aAHuhu↓, ‡ A man as though he were conspicuous, clean, or pure, and white, with respect to rank or quality, nobility, reputation, or the like. (L.)
In like manner one says, lahu Aln-asabu AlwaD-aAHu↓ ‡ He is of conspicuous and pure race, or lineage. (TA.)
waADiHN † An illustrious man. (EsSaadee.)
[And so] OawoDaAHN↓ min Aln-aAsi waOawobaAXN [Illustrious people, and mixed people of the baser sort;] companies of people of various tribes. No sing. of AwDAH in this sense has been heard. (L.)
AlwuD-axu [pl. of waADiHN] The stars called AlkawaAkibu Alxun-asu [namely, Saturn, Jupiter, Mars, Venus, and Mercury,] when in conjunction with the bright stars of the Mansions of the Moon. (L.)
waADiHapN: see waADiHN.

SiyaAmu AlOawaADiHi, originally wawaADiH, (Hr, Ḳ,) pl. of waADiHapN, (TA,) or SiyaAmu AlOawoDaAHi, (IAth,) The fasting during the days of the white nights: (Ḳ *, TA:) which was commanded by Moḥammad: (Ḳ:) these are the 13th, 14th, and 15th, [of the lunar month]. (TA.)
AlwaADiHapN The teeth that appear when one laughs: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) an epithet in which the quality of subst. predominates: pl. DawaAHiku. (TA.)
See muwDiHap.
OawoDAaHN: see waDaHN and waADiHN.
tawoDiyHN inf. n. of 2, q.v.
And see waDaHN at the end.

muwDiHapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and waADiHapN↓ (TA) A wound by which the head or face is broken, that shows the whiteness of the bone: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or, that removes the skin which is between the flesh and the bone: the only kind of Xaj-ap for which retaliation is allowed: for [some] other kinds there are assigned mulets: and for this too is assigned a mulct, consisting of five camels: but a mwDHp may also be in other parts than the head or face; and respecting this, a judge must give his sentence: pl. mawAaDiHu. (TA.) [See Xaj-apN.]
mawaADiHu AlHaq-i i. q. mabaAyinuhu, q.v. (TA, in art. byn.)
muwDiHapN A woman who brings forth white children. (O, in TA, art. byD.)

mutawaD-iHN and waADiHN↓ A camel that is white, but not intensely so; (En-Naḍr, L, Ḳ;) more white than such as is termed OaEoyaS [app. a mistake for OaEoyas] and OaSohab: (En-Naḍr, L:) also (the former accord. to the Ḳ, and the latter also accord. to the L) of such a colour in the OaqoraAb [or flanks]. (L, Ḳ.)
mutawa D-iHN One who is apparent, or plainly apparent. (Ḳ.)

One who shows himself openly in the road, (Ṣ,) or who goes along the middle, or main part and middle of the road, (Ḳ,) and does not enter a woody place or the like where he would be concealed. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
1. waDaxa Ald-alowa, and AwDxhA↓, He nearly half-filled the bucket, so that it resembled one half-full. (L, Ḳ.) [See also 4.]

3. wADxhu, inf. n. muwaADaxapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and wiDaAxN, (Ḳ,) He emulated, or imitated, him (that is his companion) in drawing water, doing as he did. (Aṣ, Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ.) This is the original signification: afterwards used with reference to any two persons emulating each other. (Ks, Ṣ.) [Hence,]

‡ He emulated him, or imitated him, in running; (L, Ḳ;) and exerted himself excessively, or exceeded the usual bounds or degree, therein: (L:) or [so in the L; in the Ḳ, and] went, journeyed, or marched, like him; or kept pace with him in going, journeying, or marching; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) not a vehement rate; (Ṣ, L;) as also wADxhu Als-ayora. (L.) Az says, that mwADxp, as used by the Arabs, signifies emulation, although not with unusual exertion, or an exceeding of the usual bounds or degree, in running. (L.) [See also 6.]
4. AwDx biAld-alowi He drew water with the bucket and shook it about vehemently [app. so that it did not become, or remain full]: or he drew with it little water. (L.) [See also 1.]
AwDx lahu He drew for him little, or a little, water. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
Also, AwDxt AlbiYoru The well contained little water; its water became little; (Ḳ;) water having been taken from it for irrigation. (TA.)
6. twADxA They (two men standing together over a well, L) emulated each other [in drawing water and] in watering, or irrigating. (L, Ḳ.)
‡ They (two horses) emulated each other [in running]; (L:) and twADxt AlUibilu the camels emulated one another in going, journeying, or marching. (L, Ḳ *.) [See also 3.]
wuDuwxN Water in a bucket resembling half [of the quantity that would fill it]: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or what is less than the quantity that would fill it. (L.)

1. waDira, (M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) said of a vessel, (TA,) and waDirato, said of a bowl, (qaSoEapN, Ṣ,) aor. yawoDaru (Mṣb) and tawoDaru, (Ṣ,) inf. n. waDarN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) It was, or became, dirty, or filthy, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with grease or gravy, or the dripping that exudes from flesh-meat, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) or otherwise, with what is termed waDarN. (M, Ḳ.)
2. wD-rhu [He made it (a vessel) dirty, or filthy, with waDar, i. e., grease, or the like].
kaAna naqiI-a AlEiroDi fawaD-arahu biAld-anaMCapi [He was unsullied in honour, and he sullied it by baseness]. (A.)

waDarN Dirt, or filth: (Ṣ, Mṣb): and grease, gravy, or dripping that exudes from flesh-meat or from fat; (Ṣ:) or the dirt of grease or gravy, or of what exudes from flesh-meat, and of milk: (M, A, Ḳ:) and (so in the M; but in the Ḳ, or) the washings of a skin that is used for milk or for water, and of a bowl and the like: (M, Ḳ:) [see xaDoraMCu AlwaDari voce :] and remains of hinaMC [or tar] (AO, Ṣ, Ḳ), &c.: (AO, Ṣ:) [and feculence of clarified butter, adhering to the interior of a skin: see EabakapN and EabaqapN:] and the soil, or stain, of saffron and the like; (Ḳ;) or of [the perfume called] xaluwq, or of [other] perfume having a colour: and a mark that remains from what is not perfume: (TA:) pl. OawoDaAr. (Ḳ.)
Also, The odour, (A,) or what a man smells of the odour, (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ,) of food in a corrupt state. (AA, Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
You say also of a man, fiI OaxolaAqihi waDarN ‡ In his dispositions is foulness. And huwa cuw OawoDaArK ‡ He possesses foul qualities. (A.)

waDirN Dirty, or filthy, (M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) with grease, or gravy, or what exudes from flesh-meat, or otherwise, with what is termed waDarN; (M, A, Ḳ;) applied to a vessel: (A:)
fem. waDirapN (M, A, Ḳ) and waDoraI↓; (M, Ḳ;) both applied to a woman; (M;) and the former, to a hand. (A.) See sahikN.

[Hence] AlwaDoraI (IAạr, Ḳ) and AlwaDoraMCu↓ (A, Ṣgh, Ḳ) The anus; syn. AlUisotu, (A, TA,) and Alfunoduwrapa, (Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, Alfinodiyrapu, which is a mistranscription,]) both of which signify the same. (TA.)
[Hence also,] fulaAnN waDiru AlOaxolaAqi ‡ Such a one is foul in dispositions. (A.)
waDoraI and waDoraMCu: see waDirN; the former in two places.
1. waT-N, [an inf. n., of which the verb is waT-a, aor., accord. to rule, _i, but accord. to the TḲ, _u,] The crying of the waTowaAT. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
The creaking of the [kind of vehicle called] maHomil. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
R. Q. 1. waTowaTapN, [inf. n. of waTowaTa,] The uttering speech, or words rapidly, or near together. (Ḳ.) [See waTowaATN.]
† The being weak. (Ḳ.)
R. Q. 2. tawaTowaTa He (a child) cried out. (Ibn ʼAbbád, Ṣgh, Ḳ.)
wuTuTN: see the last sentence of the next paragraph.

waTowaATN The bat; syn. xuf-aAXN: (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the large xuf-aAX: (Mṣb:) or the swallow; syn. xuT-aAfN; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) this is thought by AʼObeyd to be, more probably than the first, the correct meaning; (Ṣ;) or the last may be right, but the first is that which is commonly known: (IB:) or it has the first signification, and also signifies a species of the swallows (xaTaATiyf) of the mountains, (Ḳ, TA,) black and likened to a species of the xaXaAXiyf [or bats], because of its [frequent] receding and turning aside [in its flight]: (TA:) [Golius says, as on the authority of the Ḳ, “pec. genus montanum et vocale, quod ἄπους dicitur; i. e. the swift:] pl. waTaAwiyTu, (Mṣb,) or waTaAwiTu, (Ṣ,) or both, (Kr, Ḳ,) but the latter, which is irreg., only allowable in poetry, in cases of necessity. (Kr.) It is used in the first of these senses in the proverb, OaboSaru fiI All-ayoli mina AlwaTowaATi [More clear-sighted in the night than the bat]. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

Clamorous; (Lḥ, Ḳ;) applied to a man: (Lḥ:) and one who utters his speech, or words, rapidly, or near together; (Lḥ, Ḳ;) as though his voice were the voice of bats: so they assert it to mean: (Lḥ:) fem. with p {waTowaATapN}: (Ḳ:) and [in like manner] waTowaATiI-N↓ signifies loquacious; a great talker; a babbler. (Ḳ *, TA.)

† A man weak in intellect and judgment: (ISh:) or weak and cowardly; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ Ḳ;) in the opinion of AʼObeyd, as being likened to the flying thing so called; (Ṣ;) as also waTowaATiI-N↓: (Ḳ:) and wuTuTN↓, (IAạr, Ḳ,) of which waTowaATN is the sing., (TA,) men (IAạr) weak in intellects and bodies. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
waTowaATiI-N: see waTowaATN, in two places.

hom.sense: 1. waTiYa, aor. yaTaOu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the w, falls out from the aor. of this verb, and from that of wasiEa, because they are transitive; for other verbs of the class faEila, having the aor. of the measure yafoEalu, and the first radical letter infirm, are intransitive; and as these two differ from their class in being transitive, they are also made to differ in the aor.; (Ṣ;) or yaTaOu was originally yaTiYu, and therefore the w, falls out from it; (TA;) inf. n. waToCN, (TA) [and TiYapN, q.v. infra]; and wT-O↓, (Ḳ, but this has an intensive signification, MF;) and twT-O↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) He trod; trod upon; (birijolihi with his foot; Ṣ) trod under foot; trampled upon: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or waTiYahu signifies he pressed, or bore, upon him, or it, with his hand or his foot. (TA, in art. vTO.) [See also waToOapN.]

Th, at the commencement of the 20th ch. of the Ḳur, is read by some Taho, and said to be for TaOo, (the h being substituted for C,) and to signify Tread upon the ground with the soles of both thy fect; because Moḥammad raised one of his feet in prayer. (TA.)

humo yaTaWuhumu AlT-ariyqu ‡ They (i. e. the sons of such a one) sojourn, or encamp, near the road, so that its passengers tread upon them [i. e., became their guests]: (Sb, Ḳ:) a tropical phrase, in which AlTryq is put for Oaholu AlT-ariyqi; this being done to give greater force to the phrase, as it is one expressive of praise; for the road is a thing that is constant; whereas its passengers are sometimes upon it, and sometimes absent. (L.) [It means They are a people who take up their abode near the road in order that many passengers may enjoy their hospitality.]
[See also TariyqN.]

Of the same kind is the phrase OaxaconaA EalaI AlT-ariyqi AlwaATiYi libaniI fulaAnK ‡ [We look to the road whose passengers tread on (i. e., make themselves the guests of,) the sons of such a one]. (IJ.)
So too, mararonaA biqawomK mawoTuwYiyna biAlT-ariyqi ‡ [We passed by a people trod on (i. e., resorted to for their hospitality,) by the passengers of the road]. (IJ.)
Also, yaA Tariyqu TaOo binaA baniI fulaAnK ‡ O road, bring us near to [or, lit., make us to tread on, i. e., make us the guests of,] the sons of such a one! (IJ.)
waTiYa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor, as above, (Ṣ,) Inivit feminam. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

waTaOa, inf. n. TiYapN, † He trod under foot, and despised. Ex. naEuwcu biQll-ehi mino TiYapi Alc-aliyli We put our trust in God for protection from the vile person's treading us under foot, and despising us. (Lḥ.)
waTaOa and wT-O↓ (in MF's copy of the Ḳ wATO) He prepared, and made plain, smooth, or soft. (Ḳ.)
waTayotu; for waTaOotu, is disallowed. (TA.)
waTuWa, aor. yawoTuWu, inf. n. wTO, [so in the TA: probably a mistake for waTaMCapN: see TiYapN below:] He (a horse, &c.) was, or became, easy to ride upon. (TA.)

waTuWa, aor. yawoTuWu, inf. n. waTaMCapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and wuTuwoCapN (TA) and TaOapN (TA, as from the Ḳ) [and, app., TiYapN, q.v. infra], It (a place, Ṣ) was plain, level, smooth, soft, or easy to be travelled, or to walk, or ride or lie upon. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
kunotu OaTaOu cikorahu † I used to conceal the mention of him, or it. (TA, from a trad.)
2: See 1, in two places.

wT-O, inf. n. tuwoTiYapN, He made plain, level, smooth, soft, or easy to be, travelled, or to walk or ride or lie upon. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) He made a beast of carriage easy to ride upon; trained, or broke, it (M, voce raADa.)
Also, (TA,) and twT-O↓, (L,) He prepared (L, ubi supra, and TA,) a bed, or a chamber. (TA.)
He arranged, or facilitated, an affair. (TA.) waT-ayotu [for waT-aOotu] is disallowed. (Ṣ.)
wT-O He (i. e. God) rendered a land plain, level, smooth, soft, or easy to walk or ride or lie upon. (TA.)
Also, He (God,) rendered a land depressed. (Ḳ.)
See 4.

entry.sense: 3. waATaOahu EalaI OamorK, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. muwaATaOapN (Ṣ) and wiTaMCN; (TA;) and twATOhu↓ and twT-Ohu↓; (Ḳ;) ‡ He agreed, or concurred, with him respecting a thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) The radical signification of wATO is said to be He trod in the footsteps of another: and the signification of agreement is therefore figurative. (MF.)
fulaAnN yuwaATiYu Qsomuhu QsomiI ‡ [Such a one's name agrees, or is the same, with mine]. (Ṣ.)
liyuwaATiYuwA Eid-apa maA Har-ama Qll-eh ‡ [That they may agree in the number of (the mouths) which God hath made sacred: Ḳur, ix. 37]. (Ṣ.)

OaXad-u wiTaMCN, as some read, [in the Ḳur, lxxiii. 6,] signifies ‡ More, or most, suitable; (Ṣ;) [i. e., prayer, and the recitation of the Ḳur-án]: but some read waToOF, in the sense of qiyaAmFA: see naAXiYapN. (Ṣ, L.) See 4.
4. AwTOhu gayorahu He made another to tread, or trample, upon him. (TA.)
AwTOh farasahu He made his horse to tread, or trample, upon him. (Ḳ, TA.)
AwTOhu AlOrDa He made him to tread upon the ground. (Mṣb.)
OawoTaWuwhumo † They overcame them, or prevailed over them, in a contention, or dispute. (TA.)

In a trad. it is said, that the pastors of the camels, and the shepherds, boasted, one party over the other, and the former overcame the latter (AwTWwhm). (TA.) The verb is used in this sense because it originally signifies, with the annexed pronoun, they made (others) to tread, or trample, upon them: (Ḳ, TA:) for him with whom you wrestle or fight, and whom you throw down, you trample upon, and make to be trampled upon by others. (TA.)
AwTOhu AlEaXowapa, (Ḳ,) and EaXowapF, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He made him to pursue a course without being rightly directed. (Ḳ *, TA.) See art. EXw.

AwTO fiI AlX-iEori, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiyT-MCN; (TA;) and AwTO AlX-iEora, and wATO↓ fiyhi, and wT-Ohu↓, and OaT-aOahu, and MTaOahu, (Ḳ,) in which last the w is changed into A; (TA;) He repeated a rhyme in a poem, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) using the same word in the same sense: (Akh, Ḳ:) when the word is the same, but the meaning different, the repetition is not called AyTAC [but jinaAsN taAm-N]. (TA.) This repetition (AyTAC) is deemed by Arabs a fault: or it is only deemed a fault if it occur two, or three, or more, times. (TA.)
tawaT-ayotu for tawaT-aOotu is incorrect. (Ṣ.)
twT-O He, or it, was, or became, prepared. (Ḳ.) [See also 8.]
6. tawaATaWuwA † They agreed together. (Ṣ.)
twATWwA Ealayh † They agreed together, or concurred, respecting it. (TA.) [See 3.]
8. Uit-aTaOa It was prepared, and became plain, smooth, or soft. (Ḳ.) [See also 5.]

Uit-aTaOa AlEiXaMCu (in a trad.) The evening became completely dark: [or the period of nightfall fully came:] also read UiytaTaI, accord. to the dial. of the tribe of Keys, and explained as signifying the period of nightfall came. The latter verb also signifies “concurrence, or concord, and agreement, with another.” (TA.)
UiytaTaOa AlX-ahoru [About half the month has elapsed]. This is said a day before the half, and a day after the half. (AZ.)

Uit-aTaOa, (as in the CK,) or UiytaTaOa, (as in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,) measure UifotaEala [in the TA written UisotaTaOa, which is doubtless a mistake,] It was right, and attained its full period; was perfect, or complete. (Ḳ.)
10. AstwTO He found, or deemed, a thing plain, level, smooth, soft, or easy to walk or ride or lie upon. (Ḳ, TA.)
He found, or deemed, the thing on which he rode smooth, soft, or easy to ride upon. (Ṣ.)

waToCN and waTaMCN↓ and miyTaON↓ (measure mifoEalN, as shown in the TA; but in the CK, myTaMCN;) Depressed land, or low ground, between eminences niXaAz [in the CK naXAz] and OaXoraAf [in the CK UiXorAf]: (Ḳ:) nXAz, is pl. of naXazN, and AXrAf is pl. of XarafN; and both signify “eminences.” (TA.)
TaOapN: see TiYapN.

TiYapN and TaOapN↓ (in both of which the final p is a substitute for the incipient w, Ṣ) and waTaMCapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and wuTuwCapN↓ (Ḳ) Plainness, levelness, smoothness, softness, or state of being easy to walk or ride or lie upon. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
waToOapN [A tread, or a treading.]

[And hence,] ‡ A pressure; oppression; affliction; violence: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a vehement assault, or punishment; syn. OaxocapN XadiydapN: (Ḳ:) also, a hostile expedition or engagement; battle, fight, or slaughter. (TA.)
Qll-ehum-a QXodudo waToOataka EalaI muDara, in a trad., O God, make thy punishment of Mudar severe. (Ṣ, TA.)

waTiYanaA AlEaduw-u waToOapF XadiydF ‡ [The enemy assaulted, or punished, us with a very vehement assault, or punishment]. (TA.) Mxiru waToOapK waTiYahaA Qll-ehu biwaj-K, in a trad., ‡ The last assault, or conflict, which God caused to befall (the unbelievers was) in Wejj [a valley of Et-Táïf]. (TA.)
waToOapN and mawoTaON↓ (Ḳ) and mawoTiYN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) A place on which the sole of the foot is placed; a footstep, or footprint. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
waTaMCN: see wiTaMCN, and waToCN.

wiTaMCN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and waTaMCN↓, (Ḳ,) the former is the word commonly known and approved; the latter disapproved by many; (TA;) The contr. of giTaMCN (a covering); [what is placed, or spread, beneath one, to sit or lie upon]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. AwoTiYapN. (TA, in art. xwr.)
waTiIoCN Plain, level, smooth, soft, or easy to be travelled, or to walk or ride or lie upon. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
daAb-apN waTiIoCN (IAạr) A beast easy to ride upon. (TA.)
EayoXN waTiIoCN [An easy life]. (TA.)
waTiIoCu Alxuluqi Easy in nature, or dispositon. (TA.)
waTaMCapN: see TiYapN.
wuTuwoCapN: see TiYapN.

waTiyoYapN A certain kind of food, (Ṣ,) i. q. HayosapN: (IAạr:) or dates of which the stones are taken out, and which are kneaded with milk: or what is called OaqiT, with sugar: (Ḳ:) or a food of the Arabs, prepared with dates, which are put into a stone cooking-pot; then water is poured upon them, and clarified butter if there be any; (but no AqT is mixed up with them;) and then it is drunk, like Hysp: (T:) or it is like jayos; dates and AqT kneaded together with clarified butter: (ISh:) or a certain kind of food, also called waTiIoCN; a thin EaSiydap: when it is thickened, it is called nafiytap; when a little more thick, nafiyvap; when a little thicker, lafiytap; and when so thick that it may be chewed, ESydp. (El-Muffaddal.)
Also, (as some say, TA,) A thing like [the kind of sack called] a giraArap: (Ṣ:) or a grArp containing dried meat (qadiyd) and kaEok (Ḳ) and other things: (TA:)
Oaxorijo UilayonaA valaAva OukalK mino wTyYpK Take forth and give us three cakes of bread from a grArp. (Ṣ, TA, from a trad.)
[See also waATiYap and muwaT-aON.]

waATiYapN Fallen dates. (Ḳ.) An act. part. n. in the sense of a pass.: (Ḳ:) [such dates being so called] because they are trodden under foot. (TA.) Or [it is changed] from waTaAyaA, pl. of waTiyoYapN, [which is] from waTaOa; [and such dates are] so called because their owner has despised them, or trampled upon them, (cll-hA,) and spread them about, for those who may take them; wherefore they are not included in the conjectural estimate of the produce of the tree [made by the collector of the legal alms]. (TA.)
waTaOapN (Ḳ) [pl. of wATiYN] and wATiYapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) Travellers; wayfarers: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) so called from their treading the road. (Ṣ.)

laA yutawaD-aOu mino mawoTaUK One is not to perform wDwC (i. e., to repeat it,) on account of treading on filth in the road: but this does not mean that one is not to wash off the filth. (TA, from a trad.)
See waToOapN.
mawoTiYN: see waToOapN.
miyTaON: see waToCN.
MvaArN mawoTuwoCapN (in a trad. respecting destiny) Tracks trodden [as it were] by past predestined events, good and evil. (TA, from a trad.)

muwaT-aOu AlOakonaAfi, (Ḳ,) and waTiIoCu↓ AlAknAf, (TA,) A man of easy nature, or disposition, generous, and very hospitable: or one in whose vicinity his companion is possessed of power, authority, or dignity; not harmed, nor inconveniently situated. (Ḳ.)

Qll-ehum-a QjoEalohu muwaT-aOa AlEaqibi † O God, make him to be (a Sultán, followed by many dependants, and) one whose heels shall be trod upon: (Ḳ *, TA:) an imprecation, occurring in a trad. respecting a man who had been secretly informed against to ʼOmar, who said this with reference to the informer if a liar. (TA.)

waTobN A skin (siqaACN) in which milk is put, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) specially used for that purpose: (Ṣ:) or a skin in which are put clarified butter and milk: (Mejma' el-Bihár, &c.:) it is made of the skin of an animal such as is termed jacaEN, [meaning a goat in its second year,] or what is above that [in age]: (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ:) the skin of a sucking kid, in which milk is put, is called XakowapN;
and that of one that is weaned, badorapN; and the like of a Xkwp, in which clarified butter is put, Euk-apN; and the like of a bdrp, misoOadN: (ISk, Ṣ:) see also badorapN: pl. of pauc. OawoTubN, and of mult. wiTaAbN (Ṣ) and OawoTaAbN, (dev. with respect to analogy, TA,) [accord. to most grammarians; but not so accord. to Fr, because its first radical letter is w;] and pl. pl. (i. e. pl. of AwTb, TA,) OawaATibu. (Ḳ.)
waTobN ‡ A hard, rough, rude, or coarse, man: syn. rajulN jaAfK. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
waTobN ‡ A large breast: (Ḳ:) likened to the skin so called. (TA.)

Safiratu wiTaAbuhu ‡ He died: or he was slain: (Ḳ:) the body's becoming empty of the soul is compared to the skin's becoming empty of the milk: or the meaning is his blood issued forth from his body: or, as some say, his skins became empty of their milk; a hostile attack having been made upon his camels, and no milch camel remaining in his possession. (TA.) [See similar sayings voce rfodN; and see Ḥam., p. 34.]

Tbp, without teshdeed, [but whether TabupN or Tibap is meant is not said,] A piece of skin, or hide: thought by ISd to be perhaps from AlwaTobu: but the word commonly known is Tb-p, with teshdeed, mentioned in art. Tb. (TA.)

waTobapN, occurring in a trad., accord. to one relation, and explained by En-Naḍr as signifying The kind of food called HayosN, made of dates and OaqiT and clarified butter: but said to be erroneous: accord. to another relation, rTbp, which is erroneous: accord. to another, waTiyYapN [q. v., app. the right reading]. (TA.) See HayosN.
waTobaACu ‡ A woman having large breasts: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as though having a waTob; (Ṣ;) i. e., carrying a wTb of milk. (TA.)

1. waTava, (aor. yaTivu, Ḳ,) inf. n. waTovu, He struck the ground vehemently with his foot: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he (a camel) struck vehemently with his foot: (TA:) a dial. form of waTasa, or viciously pronounced for the latter word: (Ṣ:) or the v of wTv is a substitute for the s of wTs; and the meaning is he broke: (Yaạḳoob:) or waTavahu, aor. yaTivuhu, inf. n. waTovN, signifies he trod, or trampled, upon it so that he broke it. (T.)
1. waTaHahu, aor. yaTiHu, (inf. n. TiHapN, TA,) He pushed him, or thrust him, with his hands, ungently, harshly, or violently. (Ḳ.)
6. twATH Alqawomu The people did evil, or mischief, one to another, by turns: or fought together. (El-Umawee, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
twATHt AlUibilu EalaI AlHawoDi, (TA,) or twATHt AlHawoDa, (Ḳ,) The camels crowded, or pressed together, to the tank or cistern. (Ḳ.)

waTaHN [so in the Ṣ] and so written by Aboo-Sahl, but in the copies of the Ḳ waToHN, (TA,) Dung (Ear-ap) or mud that adheres to cloven hoofs, and to the claws, or talons of birds: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) n. un. with p {waTaHapN}. (TA.)
1. waTada, aor. yaTidu. inf. n. waTodN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and TidapN; (L, Ḳ;) and wT-d↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tawoTiydN; (Ṣ, L;) He made a thing constant, firm, steady, steadfast, fast, or established. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
waTada, aor. yaTidu, inf. n. waTodN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and TidapN; (L, Ḳ;) and wT-d↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tawoTiydN; (Ṣ, L;) He, or it, pressed upon a thing heavily; syn. vaq-ala. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
waTadahu Uilayohi He drew and pressed him to him; hugged him. (L, Ḳ *.)
waTada, inf. n. waTodN, He pressed a thing to another thing, and made it fast. (AA, L.)

waTadahu UilaI AlOaroDi He pressed him to the ground [with his hand, or hands, or foot, or feet,] and kept him fixed upon it, preventing his moving: (IAth, L:) he trod upon him vehemently: (Ṣ, L:) occurring in a trad. (L.)
waTada lahu manozilapF ‡ He prepared, or established, (mah-ada,) for him a station; (L, Ḳ;) as also wT-d↓. (TA.)
waTada AlOaroDa He closed up, (Ḳ,) and trod, (TA,) the ground, in order that it might become hard. (Ḳ, TA.)
See 5.
waTada He trod; trod upon; trod under foot; trampled upon; a dial. form of waTiYa. (Ḳ.)
waTadotu EalaI baAbi AlgaAri AlS-axora I piled up the rocks at the entrance of the cave so as to stop it up with them. (Ṣ, L.) See also 4.
2: see 1.
wT-d Qll-ehu lls-uloTaAni mulokahu, as also AT-dhu, ‡ God established, or confirmed, to the Sultán his dominion. (L.)
waT-adahu He beat it with the implement called miyTadap. (A.)

4. waqaEa Aljabalu EalaI baAbi Alkahofi faOawoTadahu The mountain fell upon the entrance of the cavern, and stopped it up with its ruins. Occurring in a trad. IAth says, One should only say waTadahu; or perhaps wTdh is a dial. form. Another relation gives OawoSadahu. (L.) See also 1.
5. twT-d, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and At-Td↓; (L;) and waTada↓, (L, Ḳ,) inf. n. waTodN; (L;) It became constant, firm, steady, steadfast, fast, or established. (Ṣ,*, L, Ḳ.)
8: see 5.
waTodapN i. q. waToOapN: so in the following words [of a trad.]; Qll-ehum-a QXodudo waTodatako EalaIa muDara [O God, make thy punishment of Mudar severe!] (Ḳ *, TA.) [See also waToOapN.]
waTiydN and mawoTuwdN↓ Rendered constant, firm, steady, steadfast, fast, or established. (L, Ḳ.) See also waATidN.
waTiydN and mawoTuwbN Pressed upon heavily; syn. muvaq-alN. (L, Ḳ.)
waTiydapN † An established station which a man holds. (Yaạḳoob, L.)
waTaAYidu ‡ The foundations, or bases, or the columns, (qawaAEid,) of a building: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) the columns (OasaATiyn) of a mosque. (A.)
fulaAnN mino waTaAYidi AlUisolaAmi ‡ [Such a person is one of the columns of el-Islám.] (A.)
waTaAYidu ‡ The supports called OavaAfiI- of a cooking-pot: (A, Ḳ:) app. pl. of waTiydapN. (TA.)
waATidN Constant, firm, steady, steadfast, fast, settled, or established; as also, by transposition, TaAdK [q. v. in art. Tdw]. (Ṣ, L.) See also waTiydN, and mutawaATdN, and muwaT-adN.
mawoTuwdN: see waTiydN, and muwaT-adN.
miyTadapN A wooden implement with which the foundations of a building, &c. are compressed, in order that they may become hard. (A, L, Ḳ.)
A piece of wood with which a boring-instrument, or drill, is held: [i. e., a wooden socket which fits upon the top]. (Ṣ, L.)
Eiz-N muwaT-adN, and mawoTuwdN↓, and waATidN↓, ‡ Established, or confirmed, might, or glory. (A.)
mutawaATidN Continuous; or constant and uninterrupted; (Ḳ;) as also waATidN↓ and TaAdK. (TA.)
‡ Strong; vehement; hard. (Ḳ, TA.)

waTarN A want; an object of want or need: (Zj, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or one which one purposes to accomplish: (Lth:) or for which one is anxious, (A, Ḳ,) or desirous: (Mṣb:) pl. OawoTaArN. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) It has no verb. (Kh, Ṣ, Mṣb.) You say, qaDayotu waTariI I accomplished, or obtained, my want,, &c. (A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) And qaDayotu mino kacaA waTariI I accomplished my want of such a thing [so as to have no further need of it: see Ḳur, xxxiii. 37, in two places]. (Lth.)

hom.sense:
1. waZaba EalaI XaIoCK, (aor. yaZibu, Ḳ,) inf. n. wuZuwbN, (and waZobN, Mṣb,) He continued, to do a thing; persevered in it: (Lth, Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, (as also waZabahu, aor. and inf. n. as above, TA,) i. q. waAZaba↓, [which is the more common,] inf. n. muwaAZabahN, he kept, attended, or applied himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to a thing; he was, or became, intent upon it; (AZ, Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ;)
wAZb↓ is said to be sometimes trans. without a preposition, like laAzama; but Es-Saạd denies this. (TA.)
wuZibati Alr-awoDapu The meadow was incessantly pastured on, [so that it became destitute of herbage]. (TA.) See the pass. part. n.

fulaAnN yuwZabu Ealayohi, and yuwaAZabu↓ Ealayohi, [Such a one is deprived of his property (his camels, &c.) by successive misfortunes]. (TA, [but for ywZb is there written yZb.]) See the pass. part. n.
waZaba, inf. n. waZobN, He trod; trod upon; trod under foot; trampled upon. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 3: see 1.
wAZbhu EalaI xidomapi fulaAn He incited him, or urged him, to keep to, or continue in, the service of such a one. (TA, from a trad.)
waZobapN The vulva (HayaAC, L, or jahaAz, Ḳ,) of a solid-hoofed animal. (L, Ḳ.)
waAZibN ElI kacaA, and muwaAZibN Ealayohi↓, Keeping, attending, or applying himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to such a thing; intent upon it. (Lḥ.)
miyZabN i. q. ZurarN, (Ḳ,) which is a kind of stone. (TA.)
rajulN mawoZuwbN A man deprived of his property (mAl [app. meaning his camels, &c.]) by successive misfortunes. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

OaroDN mawoZuwbapN A land that has been pastured on by turns, so that there remains in it no herbage, or pasture. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) In like manner, rawoDapN mwZwbp: or a meadow that has been incessantly pastured on. And waAdK mwZwb A valley of which the herbage has been eaten by cattle, &c., so that it has become barren, or bare. (TA.)
muwaAZibN: see waAZbN.

1. waEabahu, aor. yaEibu, (inf. n. waEobN, Mṣb;) and AwEbhu↓, (inf. n. UiyEaAbN; Mṣb;) and AstwEbhu↓; (and twE-bhu↓; TA, voce taEaboEaba;) He took it altogether; took the whole of it. (Ḳ, Mṣb.) See 4.
4: see 1.
AwEbhu (TA) and AstwEbhu↓ (Ṣ, TA) He extirpated it; eradicated it. (Ṣ, TA.)
AwEb and AstwEb↓ He went to, or attained, the utmost limit in anything. (TA.)

AwEb AljicoEa ‡ He extirpated the trunk of a palmtree. (Ḳ.) But this is a mistake: the right reading is AwEb AljadoEa He made the mutilation (of a nose, ear, hand, or lip) to be radical, or total. (TA.) See muwEabN.
AwEb Oanofahu He cut off the whole of his nose. (Ṣ, TA.)
AwEbhu He cut off the whole of his tongue. (TA.)
AsotaraTa mawozapF faOawoEabahaA He swallowed a banana-fruit, and left nothing of it. (Lḥ.)
AwEb AlX-aIoCa fiI AlX-aIoCi, (Ḳ,) and waEabahu↓ fiyhi, (Az,) He put, inserted, or introduced, the whole of the thing into the [other] thing. (Ḳ, Az, Mṣb.)

AwEb fiI maAlihi He lent, or paid in advance, of his property, syn. Oaslf: (IM:) or he was prodigal of his property; syn. Oasorafa: (IḲṭṭ:) or, as some say, he expended his property in every way. (TA.)
AwEb Alqawomu ‡ The people collected themselves together; congregated: (Ṣ, TA:) they came all together. (TA.)
AwEb He collected; gathered together; congregated. (Ḳ.)
AwEb banuw fulaAnK jalaACF falamo yaboqa bibaladihimo minohumo OaHadN ‡ [The sons of such a one came all together, emigrating, so that there remained not in their country one of them]. (ISk, Ṣ.)
AwEb banuw fulaAnK libaniI fulaAnK The sons of such a one collected together a company for the sons of such a one. (Lḥ.)
AwEb Alqawomu ‡ The people went forth all together on a military expedition. (TA.)
AwEbwA Alnafara They [collected together the men, and] went forth all together on a military expedition. (TA, from a trad.)
5: see 1.
AstwEb AlX-ayoCa ‡ It (a place, or a vessel,) was large enough to contain the thing; it held the thing, or received it into its capacity. (TA.)
Aln-iEomapu AlwaAHidapu tasotawoEibu jamiyEa Eamali AlEabodi yawoma AlqiyaAmapi ‡ One favour [of God] will be equivalent to all the works of a man on the day of resurrection. A trad. (TA.)

AXtwEb [generally signifies He, or it, took, took in or comprised or comprehended or included, or took up or occupied, altogether, wholly, or universally; or took in the gross; engrossed: like Aisotagoraqa]. See 1: and 4, in two places. AicaA QsotuwEiba jadoEuhu Ald-iyapu, said in a trad. respecting the nose, If the mutilation thereof be total, so that nothing be left of it, the [whole] price of blood [shall be paid]: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to another relation, OuwEiba kul-uhu [If] the whole of it be cut off. (TA.)
waEobN A wide road. (Ḳ.) You say, TariyqN waEobN: and the pl. is wiEaAbN. (TA.)
wiEaAbN Wide places in a land. (Ḳ.) Correctly, it is pl. of waEobN; but in the Moajam [el-Buldán] it is made a proper name of certain places. (TA.)
waEiybN An ample house, or tent. (Ḳ.) An ample vessel, that takes in the whole of what is put into it. (TA.)
jaACa Alfarasu birakoDK waEiybK The horse came at his utmost rate. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
waEiybN Pudendum mulieris amplum. (TA.)

hecaA OawoEabu likacaA This is most proper, or fit, for the full giving, or receiving, or the like, of such a thing: syn. OaHoraI liAsotiyfaAYihi. (Ḳ.) This is taken from the following words of a trad.
nawomapN baEoda AljimaAEK OawoEabu lilomaACi A sleep after coitus is most proper for the complete evacuation of the semen remaining in the penis. (TA.)

jadoEN muwEabN, (also written muwEibN, TA,) A mutilation of the nose, ear, hand, or lip, by which it is extirpated. One says, in reviling, jadaEahu Qll-eh jadoEFA mwEbFA May God mutilate him by an utter mutilation of the nose, &c.! (Ṣ.)
jaAWuwA muwEibiyna ‡ They came having collected together all that they could: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) they came all together, not one of them remaining behind. (Mṣb.)
1. waEiva, aor. _a {yawoEavu}, (inf. n. waEovN, TA,) and waEuva, aor. _u {yawoEuvu}, (inf. n. wuEuwvapN and waEaAvapN, TA,) It (a road) was difficult to travel, (Ḳ,) and arduous to ascend. (TA.)
waEiva, aor. _a {yawoEavu}, inf. n. waEovN and waEavN; and waEuva, aor. _u {yawoEuvu}, inf. n. wuEuwvapN; it (a road) was soft, and like what is termed waEovN. (ISd.)
waEiva It (dust) was fine, and it (land) was soft, and loose, so that the feet of beasts of carriage sank in it. (TA.)
waEivato yaduhu His hand broke. (Ḳ.)

2. wE-v, inf. n. tawoEiyvN, He withheld, or restrained, and turned, or diverted, [another from a thing]. (Ḳ.) wE-vhu Eano kacaA He turned him, or diverted him, from such a thing; as also Ew-vhu. (Az.)

hom.sense: 4. AwEv He came upon a tract such as is called waEovN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he came upon an even and soft tract: (A:) he walked along a tract such as is called waEovN. (Mṣb.)
AwEv fiI maAlihi He was prodigal of his wealth, (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
AwEv, inf. n. UiyEaAvN, He confounded, or confused. (TA.)

entry.sense: waEovN A place that is even and soft, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) such as is termed dahosN, (Ḳ,) or kaviyru Ald-ahasi, (Ṣ,) in which the feet sink, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and upon which it is troublesome to walk: (Ṣ:) or sand in which the feet of camels, &c., sink: (ISd:) and [in like manner] waEovaACu↓ signifies that in which the hoofs of horses and the like, and the feet of camels, sink, consisting of fine sand, and what is termed dahaAs, of small pebbles: (Az, from Khálid Ibn-Kulthoom:) or waEovN signifies whatever is soft and even: (Aṣ:) or sand that is not much in quantity: or a soft place: pl. wuEovN and wuEuwvN: and [in like manner] naqFA muwaE-avN↓ an extended and gibbous tract of sand, which is soft, and in which the feet sink. (TA.)
Also waEovN and waEivN↓ and muwaE-avN↓ A difficult road. (Ḳ.)
huwa yamoXiI fiI AlwaEovi, and fiI AlwuEuwvi, He walks along a tract such as is called dahaAs, (and along tracts of that kind,) in which walking is laborious. (TA.)
waEovN ‡ A bone broken, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and chipped, or notched. (Ṣ.)
waEovN Leanness: (Ḳ:) soft leanness. (TA.)
waEovN A corrupt and confused state of an affair: pl. wuEuwvN. (L.)
waEovN ‡ Anything inconvenient, troublesome, difficult, or toilsome. (Mṣb.)

UimoraOapN waEovapN A woman who is fat, (Ḳ,) or fleshy; (Ṣ;) as though the fingers would sink into her, by reason of her softness and fleshiness. (TA.) AmrAp waEovahu AlOarodaAfi ‡ A woman having soft buttocks. (ISd.) Ru-beh says,
tumiyluhaA OaEojaAzuhaA AlOawaAEivu
[Her soft buttocks make her to bend]. Here AwAEv may be pl. of waEovN, contr. to analogy; or it may be pl. of OawoEuvN, which may be pl. of waEovN. (ISd.) waEovaACu↓ also signifies the same as waEovN. (ISd.)

[For the prov.]
EalaI maA xuy-ilato waEovu AlqaSiymi , (TA,) [see 2, in art. xyl.]
waEivN: see waEovN.
wuEuwvN Adversity; difficulty; distress; affliction; evil. (TA.)
See waEovN.
waEovaACu ‡ Inconvenience, trouble, difficulty, or toil, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of travel: (Ṣ:) or severity of trouble, difficulty, or toil, thereof. (AʼObeyd.)
Also the like with respect to crimes, sins, or the like: you say, rakiba AlwaEovaACa meaning ‡ He committed a crime, sin, fault, or act of disobedience. (AʼObeyd.)
See waEovN.
muwoEuwvN A man deficient in rank or quality, nobility, or eminence, reputation or note or consideration, or what is termed Hasab. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
muwaE-avN: see waEovN.

1. waEada, aor. yaEidu, inf. n. waEodN and EidapN, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [in which the p is a substitute for the elided w,] or the latter is a quasi-inf. n., (L,) and mawoEidN and mawoEidapN, (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or the last is a quasi-inf. n., (L,) and mawoEuwdN and mawoEuwdapN, (L, Ḳ,) the last two being instances of inf. ns. of the measures mafoEuwlN and mafoEwulapN, (L,) He promised. (TA.) It is trans. immediately, and by means of the prep. b; (L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) but some say that the b is redundant in this case; and most of the lexicologists disallow it with this form of the verb, allowing it only with OawoEada. (TA.) It is also used with reference to good and evil: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) you say waEadahu xayorFA [He promised him good]: and waEadahu Xar-FA ‡ [He threatened him with evil]: (Fr, Fṣ, Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.:) and, [accord. to some,] wEdh bixayorK, and biXar-. (IḲooṭ, Mṣb.) When neither good nor evil is mentioned, if you mean the former, you say waEada [He promised good]: and if you mean the latter, OawoEada↓, (Fr, T, Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiyEaAdN, with which waEiydN is syn., (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) being one irregular inf. n., [or quasi-inf. n.,] (Mṣb,) [He threatened, or threatened with, evil]; and OawoEadahu↓ [He threatened him, menaced him, or threatened him with evil]; (Mṣb;) as also twE-dhu↓, (L, Mṣb,) inf. n. tawaE-udN; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) and At-Edhu↓. (L.) You also say AwEd↓ xayorFA [He promised good]; (IAạr, T, ISd, Mṣb, Ḳ;) but this is extr.: (L:) and AwEd↓ biXar-K [He threatened, or threatened with, evil]: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) when b is introduced after this form of the verb, it relates only to evil: (Fṣ, Mṣb:) but you also say AwEdh↓ Xar-FA. (Mṣb.)

Failure of performance, with respect to a promise, the Arabs regard as a lie; but with regard to a threat, as generosity. A poet says,
waUin-iI waUino OawoEadotuhu Oawo waEadotuhu
lamuxolifu UiyEaAdiI wamunojizu mawoEidiI
[And verily I, if I threaten him or promise him, fail to perform my threat, but fulfil my promise]. (Mṣb.) Nay, they do not apply the term xulofN to the failure of performing a threat. (TA.)
yawomunaA yaEidu barodFA ‡ Our day promises cold. (L.)
waEadati AlOarD ‡ The land promised good produce. (A.)
waAEadahu fawaEadahu: see 3.
3. wAEdhu, inf. n. muwaAEadapN, He promised him, the latter doing the same to him. (Aboo-Mo'ádh, L.)
waAEadahu fawaEadahu He vied with him in promising, and surpassed him therein, by promising more. (L, Ḳ.*)
waAEadhu Alwqota, and AlmawoDiEa, [He appointed with him the time, and the place]. (L, Ḳ.) OawoEadaniI mawoEidFA is a vulgar mistake. (Aboo-Bekr, L.)

hom.sense: 4: see 1 throughout.

AwEd, (A, L,) inf. n. UiyEaAdN, (L,) in the sense of which waEiydN is also used [as a quasi-inf. n.], (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ) ‡ He (a stallion-camel) brayed, (hadara, Ṣ, A, &c.) on his being about to attack and fight with other camels. (Ṣ, A, L.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1.

6. twAEdwA and At-EdwA↓ signify the same, [They promised one another]: (Ḳ *, TA:) or the former relates to good, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) signifying they promised one another something good: (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and the latter, to evil, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) signifying they threatened one another: (L:) and this distinction is commonly admitted and observed. (TA.)
tawAaEadonaA AlmawoDiEa, [and Alwaqota, We appointed mutually the place, and the time]. (Mṣb.)

8. At-Ed, (A,) [aor. yat-aEidu,] inf. n. Uit-iEaAdN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) He accepted a promise: (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ:) originally UiwotaEada; the w being changed into t and then incorporated [into the augmentative t]: some persons say QYotaEada, aor. yaOotaEidu, (inf. n. QYotiEaAdN, TA) and pronounce the act. part. n. muWotaEidN, with C; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) like as they say yaOotasiru: (Ṣ, L:) but [if they do not change the w into t] they should say UiytaEada, and yaAtaEidu, and muwtaEidN, without _u. (IB, L.)
Also, He confided in the promise of another. (L.)
See also 1:
and 6.

waEodN and EidapN↓ (in which latter the p is a substitute for the [elided] w, Ṣ, L) and mawoEidN↓ and mawoEidapN↓ and mawoEuwdN↓ (A) and mawoEuwdapN↓: (L:) see 1: A promising; a promise; (A, L;) meaning, of something good: (Ṣ, L, &c.:) pl. of the first, wuEuwdN; (IJ, L;) or this has no pl.: (T, Ṣ, L, Mṣb:) and of the second, EidaAtN: (T, Ṣ, L, Mṣb:) [and of the ↓third, mawaAEidu:] and of mwEwd↓, mawaAEiydu. (L.) When Eidap is used as a prefixed n., [in a case of wasl,] the p is elided, (Fr, Ṣ, L,) and I is substituted for it: (Fr, L:) a poet says,
waOaxolafuwka EidaI QloOamori Ql-aciI waEaduwA
[And they have broken to thee the promise of the thing which they promised]. (Fr, Ṣ, L.)
AlEidapu↓ EaTiy-apN [A promise is equivalent to a gift]: i. e., it is base to break it as it is to take back a gift. A proverb. (TA.)

waEadahu Eidapa↓ Alvry-aA biAlqamari [He promised him as the moon promises the Pleiades]: for the moon and the Pleiades are in conjunction once in every month. Another proverb. (TA.) [Perhaps we may also read Eid-apa Alv-uzay-aA Alqamara: see mdaAd, in art. Ed.]
UixolaAfu AlwaEodi mino OaxolaAqi Alwagodi [The breaking of a promise is one of the natural habits of the mean and base]. A saying of the Arabs. (MF.)
waEodN also signifies The fulfilment of a promise. Ex. mataI hecaA AlwaEodu, in the Ḳur, [x. 49, &c.] means, When shall be the fulfilment of this promise? (L.)
Also, a thing promised. (TḲ, art. njz.)
EidapN: see waEodN, and 1.

EidiI-N Of, or relating or belonging to, a promise: rel. n. of EidapN, like ziniI-N of zinapN, formed without restoring the w like as it is restored in [the rel. n. of] XiyapN: [see art. Xyw:] but Fr says EidawiI-N and zinawiI-N, like XiyawiI-N. (Ṣ, L.)
waEiydN: see 1: A threatening; a threat: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) also written wiEiydN. (TA.) See also 4.
AlwaEiydiy-apu A certain sect of the xawaArij, who are extravagant in threatening; asserting that transgressors [who have been true believers] shall remain in hell for ever. (TA.)
waAEidN ‡ A horse that promises run after run. (L, Ḳ.)
‡ A beast that promises to be productive of good, and fortunate. (L.) ‡ See an ex. in a verse cited voce maSodaq.
‡ A tree, or herbage, promising good produce. (A.)
‡ A cloud, which, as it were, promises rain. (L, Ḳ.)
‡ A day which promises heat; (L;) as also a year: (TA:) or of which the commencement promises heat; or cold. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
OaroDN waAEidapN ‡ Land of which the herbage is hoped to prove good and productive, (Aṣ, Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) by reason of its first appearance. (Aṣ, L.)
mawoEidN signifies A covenant, or compact. So, accord. to Mujáhid, in ch. xx. vv. 89 and 90, of the Ḳur-án. (L.)
mawoEidN and mawoEidapN: see 1, and waEodN.
See also miyEaAdN.
miyEaAdN (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and mawoEidN↓ (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb) A time, and a place, of promise: (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [and, of appointment; an appointed time, and place].
miyEaAdN A mutual promising, or promise. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
mawoEuwdN and mawoEuwdapN: see 1, and waEodN
Alyawomu AlmwEwd [The promised day; meaning] the day of resurrection. (TA.)
maEohuwdN wamaXohuwdN wamawoEuwdN Past and present and future: the tenses of a verb. (Kh, in L, art. Ehd.)

mawoEuwdN is one of the inf. ns. which have pls. governing as verbs; its pl. being mawaAEiydu. Ex. mawaAEiyda Euroqwb OaxaAhu biyavoriba [As 'Orkoob's promisings of his brother in Yethrib.] (IJ, ISd.) See EuroquwbN.

1. waEura, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yawoEuru; (TA;) and waEara, aor. yaEiru; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and waEira, (Lḥ, A, Ḳ,) aor. yawoEaru (Ḳ, TA) and yaEiru; (Lḥ, TA;) inf. n. wuEuwrapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and waEAarapN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the first (Mṣb, TA) and second; (TA;) and waEorN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the first (TA) and second; (Mṣb, TA;) and wuEuwrN, (Ḳ,) of the second only; (TA;) and waEarN, (Ḳ,) of the third: (TA:) It (a place, A, Ḳ, and a mountain, Ṣ, Mṣb,) was, or became, rugged; (A, Ḳ;) as also twE-r↓: (Ṣ,* A, Ḳ:) or difficult. (Mṣb.)

[Hence,] twE-r↓ ‡ It (an affair), and he, (a man,) was, or became difficult, or hard. (Ḳ,* TA.) You say, saOalonaA fulaAnFA HaAjapF fatawa E-ara EalayonaA ‡ We asked of such a one a thing wanted, and he was hard, or difficult, to us. (Ṣgh, TA.)
[Hence also,] waEura, inf. n. waEaArapN and wuEuwarpN, ‡ It (a thing) was, or became, little, or scanty. (Ḳ, TA.)
2. wE-rhu, inf. n. tawoEiyrN, He made it (a place, Ḳ, and a mountain, Ṣ,) rugged: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) [or difficult.]
4. AwEr bihi AlT-riyqu The road became rugged to him: or brought him to a rugged land. (Ḳ,* TA.)
AwEr He came, or lighted, upon a rugged place. (A, Ḳ.)
See also 10.
‡ His (a man's) property became little, or scanty. (Ḳ,* TA.) The man is thus likened to a rugged place without plants or herbage. (TA.)
AwErhu ‡ He made it (a thing, A, Ḳ,) little, or scanty. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)
5: see 1, in two places.
10. AstwErhu He found it, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or deemed it, (Ḳ,) namely a place, (Mṣb,) or a road, (A, Ḳ,) or a thing, (Ṣ, Ṣgh,) rugged, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) or difficult; (Mṣb;) as also AwErhu↓. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

waEorN Rugged; contr. of saholN: (A, Ḳ:) or difficult: (Mṣb:) applied to a place, (TA,) and a road, (A,) and a mountain: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) as also waEirN↓, (A, Ḳ, or, accord. to Aṣ, this latter is not allowable, (Ṣ,) and F's assertion, that this which is said in the Ṣ is nothing, being a negation of a negation without evidence, is a thing unheard of, MF,) and waAEirN↓ and waEiyrN and OawoEaru↓: (Ḳ:) and plain with ruggedness: and a mountain rugged, and difficult of ascent: and a place inspiring fear, and desolate: (TA:) pl. OawoEurN, (Ḳ,) a pl. [of pauc.] of waEorN, (TA,) and wuEuwrN, (A, Ḳ,) a pl. of mult. [of the same], (TA,) and wuEuwrapN, (A,) [of the same,] and OawoEaArN, (A, Ḳ,) a pl. [of pauc.] of waEirN and wiEiyrN. (TA.)
Applied to a place where a thing is sought, (maTolabN, Ṣ, and Mṣb) † Difficult [of access]. (Mṣb.)
Also, applied to a thing, ‡ Little, or scanty. (A, TA.) And you say, fulaAnN waEoru AlmaEoruwfi, meaning, ‡ Such a one has little goodness, beneficence, or kindness. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

It is also an imitative sequent to qaliylN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [but in this case it is only a corroborative;] and to watoHN: (Ṣ:) and so is waEirN↓ to maEirN, in the phrase XaEarN maEirN waEirN, (Ḳ,) meaning, † Little, scanty, hair. (TA.)
waEirN: see waEorN, in two places.
waEiyrN: see waEorN.
waAEirN: see waEorN.
OawoEaru: see waEorN.
1. waEaza: see 4.
2: see 4.

4. AwEz Uilayohi fiI kacaA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or bikacaA, (Mgh,) inf. n. UiyEaAzN, (Mgh, TA,) He commanded, ordered, or enjoined, him, respecting such a thing, syn. tqd-m, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) and Oamara, (Mgh, Ḳ,) Oano yafoEala Oawo yatoruka that he should do [it] or not do [it]; (Ḳ;) as also wE-z↓ Alyh, (Ṣ, Ḳ *) inf.n tawoEiyzN; (Ṣ;) and (sometimes Ṣ) waEaza↓ Alyh, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) inf. n. waEozN; (Ṣ;) which are also explained by qad-ama [signifying the same as taqad-ama and Oamara]: or the first and second are correct, accord. to ISk, but the last (waEaza) is not allowable, accord. to him, nor is it, as related by AḤát, accord. to Aṣ. (TA.)

1. waEaZahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. yaEiZu, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. waEoZN and EiZapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in which the p is a substitute for the elided w, (TA,) and EaZapN, (TA,) and mawoEiZapN, (Ḳ,) in which the p is not to denote the fem. gender, because this is not real, (TA,) or this last is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) He exhorted him, admonished him, or warned him; he put him in fear: (IF:) he exhorted him to obedience; commanded him to obey: (Mṣb:) he gave him good advice, or counsel; and reminded him of the results of affairs: (Ṣ:) he reminded him by informing him of that which should make the heart tender: (Kh:) he reminded him of that which should soften his heart, by the mention of reward and punishment. (Ḳ.) It is said in the Ḳur, [xxxiv. 45,] Uin-amaA OaEiZkumo biwaAHidapK I only exhort you, or command you, to do one thing. (Mṣb.) And you say, wuEiZa bigayorihi [He was exhorted, admonished, or warned, by the example of another: see 8]. (Ṣ.) [And wEaZa, alone, He preached a sermon or sermons.]

8. Uit-aEaZa [He became exhorted, admonished, warned, or put in fear:] he obeyed, or conformed to, [an exhortation to obedience, or] a command, and restrained himself: (Mṣb:) he accepted good advice, and the being reminded of the results of affairs: (Ṣ:) he became reminded of that which should soften his heart, by the mention of reward and punishment. (Ḳ.) It is said, Als-aEiydu mano wuEiZa yigayorihi waAlX-aqiI-u mano Qt-aEaZa bihi gayoruhu [The happy is he who is exhorted, or admonished, or warned, by the example of another, and the unhappy is he by the example of whom another becomes exhorted, or admonished, or warned]. (Ṣ, L.)
EiZapN: see 1.

[As a simple subst.,] it has for its pl. EiZaAtN: and is syn. with mawoEiZapN↓: (TA:) [the pl. of the latter is mawaAEiZu.] It is said in trad., laOajoEalan-aka EiZapF I will assuredly make thee a warning, or an example, to others. (TA.) And in the Ḳur, [ii. 276,] famano jaMCahu mawoEiZapN↓ mino rab-ihi [But he to whom cometh an exhortation, or an admonition, or warning, from his Lord]. (TA.)
And AlqatoluwbiAlmawoEiZapi↓ [The slaying by way of warning], mentioned in a trad., is when the innocent is slain in order that he who gives reason for suspicion may become warned. (TA.)
waE-aAZN: see waAEiZN.

waAEiZN [One who exhorts, admonishes, warns, or puts in fear:] one who exhorts to obedience; who commands to obey: (Mṣb:) one who gives good advice, or counsel; [who reminds of the results of affairs;, &c.: and a preacher of a sermon or sermons: see 1:] and in like manner waE-aAZN↓ [one who exhorts,, &c., much, or frequently]: (TA:) pl. of the former wuE-aAZN. (Mṣb, TA.)
mawoEiZapN: see 1:
and EiZapN, in three places.
1. waguba, aor. yawogubu, inf. n. wuguwbapN (and wagaAbapN, IM and others), He (a camel) was, or became, large, big, or bulky. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

wagobN What is of a mean sort, of the utensils and furniture of a house, or tent: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. OawogaAbN and wigaAbN: (Ḳ:) the former, of pauc.; the latter, of mult. (TA.) The Awgb of a house, or tent, are the wooden bowl and the stone cooking-pot and the like: (Ṣ:) [as also OawoqaAb].

A sack, such as is called giraArap: (Ḳ:) but this is included among the meaner sort of the utensils of a house, or tent; and is therefore not particularly mentioned by any of the lexicographers except T. (TA.)
wagobN (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ) and wagabapN (Th, Ḳ) Stupid: foolish; of little sense: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) i. q. lagobN, a weak, stupid, man: (TA, voce lgb:) pl. as above. (Ḳ, TA.) See also waqobN.
wagobN Weak in body: (as also wagodN: TA:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.)
Base; mean; vile.: (as also wagodN: TA:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.)
wagobN A large, big, or bulky, camel: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. as above: fem. with p {wagobapN}. (Ḳ.)

1. waguda, aor. _u {yawogudu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. wugaAdapN, (L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) He was, or became, a low, or ignoble, mean, or sordid, and weak person, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) who served for the food of his belly: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb:) or light, (L,) stupid, and weak (L, Ḳ) in intellect, (L,) low, or ignoble, and mean, or sordid; (L, Ḳ;) or weak in body: (L, Ḳ:) or light in intellect: or weak as is a slave. (Mṣb.)
wagada Alqawoma, aor. yagidu, (Ṣ, L,) inf. n. wagodN, (L,) He served the people; acted as a servant to them. (Ṣ, L.)

3. wAgdhu, (L,) inf. n. muwaAgadapN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) He (a man) did like as he (another man) did: (L, Ḳ:) accord. to some, specially in pace, or in going, or marching; (L;) he went like him; or kept pace with him: (Ṣ *, L:) and he ran with him; or vied with him in running: (Ḳ:) you say waAgadati Aln-aAqapu AlOuxoraI the she-camel went like, or kept pace with, the other: (L:) and sometimes the term muwaAgadapN is used in relation to a single she-camel, because one of her fore legs, and her hind legs, moves with (tuwaAgidu) the other. (Aṣ, Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

wagodN A low, or ignoble, mean, or sordid, and weak person, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb:) who serves for the food of his belly: (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb:) or light, (L,) stupid, weak (L, Ḳ) in intellect, (L,) low, or ignoble, and mean, or sordid: (L, Ḳ:) or weak in body: (L, Ḳ:) or light in intellect: (Mṣb:) or weak; as is a slave: (Umm-El-Heythem, Mṣb:) or who eats and carries away. (Expos. of the Lámeeyeh of Et-Tughráee.)
A servant of a people. (L, Ḳ.)
A slave. (L, Ḳ.)
A boy. (L, Ḳ.)
Pl. OawogaAdN (A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and wugodaAnN and wagodaAnN. (L, Ḳ.)
A certain arrow, (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ,) of those used in the game called Almayosir, (Ṣ, L,) to which no portion, or share, pertains. (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.) Accord. to the A, this is the original signification. (TA.)
The fruit of the baAcinojaAn. (L, Ḳ.)
AlmuwaAgadapu A certain game (Ḳ) of the Arabs, in which one player does like as the other does. (TA.)
See also 3.

hom.sense: 1. wagaratohu AlX-amosu The sun fell vehemently upon him. (A.)
wagarati AlhaAjirapu, (Ḳ,) aor. tagiru, (Ḳ,* TA,) inf. n. wagorN, (TA,) The summer-midday was, or became, intensely, or vehemently, hot. (Ḳ,* TA.)

[Hence, (see wagorN,)] wagira Sadoruhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yawogaru (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ,*) and yiyogaru, with kesr to the first letter, (Fr, Ḳ,) [an irreg. form,] like yiyjalu; (TA;) and wagara, aor yagiru; (Ḳ, TA;) but yawogaru is more common than yagiru; (Az, TA;) inf. n. wagarN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the former, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and wagorN, (Ḳ,) [of the latter,] or wagorN is a simple subst., and the inf. n. is wagarN; (Ṣ,* Mṣb, [but perhaps this is said because only the former of the two verbs is mentioned in the Ṣ and Mṣb];) His bosom was, or became, affected with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, and enmity; and burned with wrath, or rage; (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) EalaI fulaAnK against such a one: (Ṣ, A:*) or became filled with wrath, or rage, (Mṣb, TA,) and rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite: (TA:) or burned by reason of intense, or violent, wrath, or rage: (TA:) and twg-r↓ he (a man, TA,) burned, and was, or became, hot, with wrath, or rage. (Ḳ, TA.) You say also, wagira EalaI-a fulaAnN, aor. yygaru, [see above, Such a one became affected with rancour,, &c.; or burned with wrath, or rage; against me]. (Fr, TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 4, in two places.

hom.sense: 4. AwgrwA They entered upon the summer-midday when the heat was intense, or vehement. (Ḳ, TA.)
Awgr AlmaMCa He heated the water, (Ḳ, TA,) by putting into it heated stones: (TA:) or i. q. OaHoraqahu: (TA:)

He made the water to boil. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Sometimes, a live pig has its hair scalded off in it, and is then slaughtered: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, accord. to some lexicons, is then roasted. (TA.) This is done by certain Christians. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say Oawogara Aln-aSaAraI Alxinoziyra The Christians boiled some water, and scalded off the hair of a live pig in it, and then slaughtered it. (A.)
Awgr All-abana, He made the milk what is termed wagiyr and wagiyrap; as also, wg-rhu↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tawogiyrN. (Ṣ.)

Awgrhu He made him to be affected with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, and enmity, and to burn with wrath; or rage: (Ḳ:) or he made him to be affected with wrath, or rage: (A:) [in like maner,] wg-rhu↓ Ealayohi, (TḲ,) inf. n. tawogiyrN, (Ḳ,) he incited him to rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, against him. (Ḳ,* TḲ.) You say also, Oawogarotu Sadorahu EalaI fulaAnK I made his bosom hot with wrath, or rage, against such a one. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1.

wagorN Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, and enmity; and a burning with wrath, or rage; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also wagarN↓; (A, Ḳ;) or the latter is an inf. n., (Ṣ, TA,) but the former is a simple subst.: (TA:) or the state of being filled with wrath, or rage: (Mṣb:) from wagorapN, explained below. (Ṣ.) You say, fiI Sadorihi EalaI-a wagorN In his bosom is rancour,, &c., against me. (Ṣ,) And cahaba wagoru Sadorihi The rancour,, &c., of his bosom departed. And Alhadiy-apu tucohibu wagora AS-adori The gift dispelleth the rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, and the heat, of the bosom. (TA.)
wagarN: see wagorN.

wagorapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and wagorapu Har-K, (Mṣb,) Intenseness, or vehemence, of heat: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) or of the burning thereof, (Ṣ, TA,) when the sun is in the meridian. (TA.) You say, nazalonaA fiI wagorapi AlqayoTi EalaI maMCi kacaA We alighted during the intense midday heat at such a water. (TA.)
Also, Flesh-meat roasted upon heated stones: (Lth, TA:) or upon stones heated by the sun. (L, Ḳ.)
wagiyrapN: see wagiyrN.

huwa waAgiru AlS-adori He has the bosom [affected with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite, and enmity, and] burning with wrath, or rage; EalaI-a against me: (TA:) or filled with wrath, or rage. (Mṣb.)
karihati AlxanaAziyru AlHamiyma Almuwgara The pigs hated the boiled hot water. A proverb. (TA.) See 4.

1. wafada Ealayohi, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) [in the Mṣb, wafida, but this appears to be a mistake,] and Uilayohi, (M, Ḳ,) aor. yafidu, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. wufuwdN (M, A, Ḳ) and wafodN (M, Ḳ) and wifaAdapN, (M, A, Ḳ,) or this last is a simple subst., (Ṣ,) and UifaAdapN, (M, Ḳ,) in which the w is changed into U, (M,) He came to him, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) namely, to a king, (A,) or governor, (Ṣ, A,) or great man, ('Ináyeh,) as an ambassador, envoy, or messenger; (Ṣ, A;) or to convey gifts, and to ask aid, or assistance: ('Ináyeh:) or he went forth to him, namely, to a king, or governor. (Aṣ, L.)
2: see 4.

hom.sense: 4. Awfdhu Ealayohi, (M, A, Ḳ,) and Uilayohi, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiyfaAdN; (Ḳ;) and wf-dhu↓ Uilayohi, (L,) inf. n. tawofiydN; (Ḳ;) He sent him to him, (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ,) namely, to a king, (A,) or governor, (Ṣ,) [or great man, as an ambassador, envoy, or messenger; or to convey gifts, and to ask aid, or assistance: see 1].
wf-dhu↓ AlOamiyru UilaI AlOamiyri Al-aciI fawotahu [The governor, sent him as an envoy to the governor who was above him]. (L.)
maA Oawofadaka EalayonaA † [What hath caused thee to come to us?]. (TA.)
bayonamaA OanaA fiIDiyqK Uico Oawofada Qll-ehu EalaI-a birajulK faOaxorajaniI manohu ‡ While I was in difficulty, lo, God brought to me a man, and extricated me from it. (A.)

Awfd EalaI AlX-aIoCi, inf. n. UiyfaAdN, ‡ It rose up, or stood up, so as to be higher than the thing; overtopped it; overpeered it; overhung it; overlooked it. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ *.) A poet (Homeyd Ibn-Thór El-Hilálee, TA) says,
taraI AlEilaAfiI-a EalayohaA muwfidaA
kaOan-a barojFA fawoqahaA muXay-adaA
[Thou seest the 'Iláfee saddle overtopping her, as though a high-raised tower were upon her.] (Ṣ, L.) And one says of a horse, maA OaHosana maA Oawofada HaArkuhu How beautiful is the prominence of his withers! (Ṣ, L.) twf-d↓ is also syn. with Awfd in the above sense. (Ḳ, TA.)
Awfd inf. n. UiyfaAdN, ‡ It (a white antelope) raised its head and erected its ears. (L, Ḳ.)
Awfd, inf. n. UiyfaAdN, He hastened, or went, quickly: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) occurring in the poetry of Ibn-Aḥmar. (Ṣ, L.)
Awfd, inf. n. UiyfaAdN, ‡ It rose, or became elevated. (A, L, Ḳ.)
Awfd, ‡ He raised, or elevated, a thing. (L.)

entry.sense: 5. twf-dt AlUibilu, and AlT-ayoru, † The camels, and the birds, strove to outgo, or outstrip, one another. (L.)
twf-dt AlOawoEaAlu fawoqa Aljabali ‡ The mountain-goats ascended upon the mountain. (A.)
See 4.
6. twAfdnA Ealayohi [We came together as ambassadors, or envoys, &c., to him: see 1]. (A.)

hom.sense: 10. UisotawofadaniI † [app. He asked, or desired, me to come]. (TA.)
Astwfd ‡ He elevated himself, and made himself erect, in his manner of sitting; (A;) a dial. form of Astwfz [q. v.] (Ṣ.)
wafodN: see waAfidN.
AlHaAj-u wafodu Qll-ehi ‡ [The pilgrims of Mekkeh are the ambassadors of God]. (A.)

wafodu Qll-ehi valaAavapN AlgaAziI waAHaAj-u waAlmuEotamiru ‡ [The ambassadors of God are three; the warrior, and the pilgrim of Mekkeh, and the performer of the ceremonies of the Eumorap]. A tradition. (L *, El-Jámiʼ eṣ-Ṣagheer.)
wafodN The upper part of an elevated long tract (Habol: in some copies of the Ḳ, jabal:) of sand. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: wafaAdapN, subst. from wafada Ealayohi, (Ṣ,) A coming to a king, (A,) or governor, (Ṣ, A,) [or the like,] as an ambassador, envoy, or messenger, [&c.: see 1]. (Ṣ, A.)
lahu wifaAdapN [a phrase of frequent occurrence in notices of companions of Moḥammad, meaning, He had the honour of coming as an envoy to the Prophet]. (TA, passim; and other works.)

waAfidN A man coming to a king, (A,) or governor, (Ṣ, A,) [or great man,] as an ambassador, or envoy, or messenger; (Ṣ, A;) [or to convey gifts, and to ask aid, or assistance: See 1:] pl., (Ṣ, L,) or [rather] this first is a quasi-pl. n., (L,) wafodN↓ (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ) and wuf-adN (Ḳ) and wuf-aAdN; (A, Mṣb;) and pl. of wafodN, OawoqaAdN and wufuwdN: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) wafodN is also explained as signifying a party that assembles together and comes to a country or town: and a party that repairs to princes, or governors, to visit, and to ask aid, or assistance, or some benefit, &c.: (L:) and a party that comes to a king respecting an affair of conquest, or for congratulation, or the like: (Mgh:) and a company chosen to go forth for the purpose of having an interview with great men: (En-Nawawee:) and a company of riders: (Jel, xix. 88:) and a company riding and honoured: (Zj, in explanation of the same verse of the Kur-an:) but from the explanations in the Ḳ, and other lexicons, it seems to signify a party coming, whether walking or riding, chosen for the purpose of having an interview with great men, or not: the explanations of En-Nawawee and some others may be in accordance with general or conventional acceptations, and those of the rest may be proper, or literal. (TA.)
waAfidN ‡ A camel, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or bird, (A,) or bird of the kind called AlqaTaA, (Ḳ,) that precedes the others (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) in pace, and in coming to water. (A.)

AlwaAfidaAni (in the poetry of El-Aasha, Ṣ, L) ‡ The parts of the two cheeks which project when one chews, and which become depressed when one grows old. (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ.) One says of a very old man, gaAba waAfidaAhu ‡ [The middles of his cheeks have become depressed]. (A.)
humo EalaI OawofaAdK They are upon a journey: (L, Ḳ:) as also OawofaAzK. (TA.)
muwfidN ‡ Prominent, or elevated: (A, L:) applied to a camel's hump, (A,) and to the pubes. (L.)
musotawofidN ‡ Erecting himself, and not placing himself at his case, in his manner of sitting; (L;) i. q. musotawofizN. (L, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. wafara, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yafiru; (T, Mṣb, Ḳ;*) and wafura, [aor. yawofuru;] (A, Ḳ;) inf. n. wufuwrN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and waforN and firapN, (M, Ḳ,) [all of the former,] or waforN is inf. n. of the trans. v.; (Mṣb;) and wafaArapN, (Ḳ,) [which is of the latter;] It (a thing) was, or became, full, complete, perfect, whole, or entire: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or it (a thing, TA, or property, M, Ḳ, and herbage, M, [and a collection of goods, or commodities, or household furniture and utensils,]) was, or became, much, abundant, ample, or copious; (T, M, A, Ḳ;) not deficient: (T:) or it (anything) was, or became, generally, or universally, comprehensive: [syn., in the last sense, Eam-a, as is implied by an explanation of the epithet waforN, by which this sense of the verb is indicated in the lexicons whence this signification is taken:] (M, A, Ḳ:) as also At-fr↓, (Ḳ,) [and twf-r↓: see waAfirN.] You say also of a branch, Aisotawofara↓ waraqFA [It was full of, or abounded with, leaves]. (L, Ḳ, art. gmd.) wafara EiroDuhu, and wafira, (M, L,) inf. n. [of the former] wufuwrN, (M,) ‡ [His honour, dignity, or estimation, was unimpaired;] he was honourable, or generous, not careless of his honour, or dignity, or estimation. (M, L.)

wafarahu, (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) aor. yafiruhu, (T, Mṣb,) inf. n. wafurN (T, Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and firapN, (T, M,) and waforapN, (TA, as from the Ḳ, but wanting in the CK and in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,) He made it full, without lack or defect, complete, perfect, whole, or entire; (Ṣ, Mṣb;) as also wf-rhu↓, inf. n. tawofyrN; (Ḳ;)
and Awfrhu↓, inf. n. UiyfaArN; and Astwfrhu↓: (Ṣ,* TA:) or, as also wfr-hu↓, (T, M, A, Ḳ,) which latter is the usual form, (Lth, T,) he made it much, abundant, ample, or copious; (Lth, T, M, A, Ḳ;) not deficient. (Lth, T.) You say, wafara lahu maAlahu He made his property much, abundant, ample, or copious. (Ḳ,* TA.) And it is said in a trad., AlHamodu lil-ehi Ql-aciI laA yafiruhu QlomanoEu Praise be to God, whom withholding doth not make to abound. (TA.) You say also, wf-r↓ Alv-awoba He cut out the garment whole. (M, Ḳ.) And wf-r↓ Als-iqaMCa He made the skin whole, without cutting off any redundance. (M.) And waf-arotu↓ lahu TaEaAmaho, inf. n. tawofiyrN, I made his food full, or complete, in quantity; not deficient. (Mṣb.) And waf-arotu Ealayohi Haq-ahu faQsotawofarahu↓ I gave him the whole of his right, or due, and so he received the whole of it; syn. of the former verb with its objective complement and the prep., waf-ayotuhu, (A, Mgh,) or OaEoTayotuhu AljmiyEa; (Mṣb;) and of the latter verb with its objective complement, AisotawofaAhu↓: (A, Mgh, Ḳ:) or both these verbs, thus used, signify the same, i. e., AstwfAh, (Ṣ, Ḳ) [in the former of which we read, waf-ara Ealayohi Haq-ahu tawofyrFA waQsotawofarahu OaIi QsotawofaAhu; and in the latter, Aisotawofara Ealayohi Haq-ahu UisotawofaAhu kawaf-arahu.] You also say, wafarahu EaTaMCaha, (M, Ḳ,) inf. n. waforN, (TA,) He restored, or returned to him his gift, being content with it, (M, Ḳ.) or deeming it little. (M, TA.) And waf-ara Qll-ehu HaZ-ahu mino kacaA God made his lot, or share, of such a thing, full, or complete. (T.) And wf-r↓ XaEarahu ‡ He left his hair to become abundant and long. (A, TA.) And wafarotu AlEiroDa, aor. Oafiruhu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. waforN (Mṣb, TA) and firapN; (TA [in my copy of the Mṣb, Afr, which is probably a mistranscription;]) and waf-arotuhu, in an intensive sense; (Mṣb;) He preserved, or guarded, honour, dignity, or estimation. (Mṣb.) And wafarahu EiroDahu; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) and wf-rhu EiroDahu; (A;) and wafarahu lahu; (M;) or wf-arhu↓ lahu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tawofiyrN; (TA;) ‡ [He preserved his honour,, &c., unimpaired;] he spoke well of him, and did not find fault with him; (A;) he did not revile him; (M, Ḳ;) as though he preserved it [namely his honour, &c.] to him abundant and good, not diminishing it by reviling. (M.) It is said in a proverb, tuwfaru watuHomadu EalaI kacaA (Ṣ,* A,) ‡ Thy honour, or dignity, or estimation, will be preserved, or guarded, and thou wilt be spoken well of, for such a thing: (A:) from wafarotuhu EiroDahu; and maAlahu: (Ṣ:) said by him to whom a thing is offered: and applied to a man who, when thou hast given to him a thing, returneth it to thee without discontent, or without esteeming it little. (Fr, Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 2: see wafarahu, and what follows it in the same paragraph {1}.
4: see wafarahu {1}.
5: see wafara {1}.

twf-r Ealayohi ‡ He was regardful of those things pertaining to him (namely his companion, A) which one is under an obligation to respect or honour; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and held loving communion, commerce, or intercourse, with him. (TA.)
twf-r EalaI kacaA ‡ He turned his purpose, or intention, or strong determination or resolution, (him-atahu,) toward such a thing. (A, Mgh, Mṣb.)
8: see wafara {1}.

hom.sense: 10: see wafara {1}:
and see wafarahu {1}, in two places.

entry.sense: waforN: see wufuwrN.

Also, [an inf. n. used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predodominates] Much, or abundant, property, (Lth, T, Ṣ,) of which nothing is deficient: (Lth, T:) what is much, abundant, ample, or copious, of property, and of goods, or commodities, or household furniture and utensils; (M, A, Ḳ;) whereof nothing is deficient: (TA:) or what is generally, or universally, comprehensive, (EaAm-N,) of anything: (M, A, Ḳ:) pl. wufuwrN. (M, Ḳ.) See also waAfrN.
firapN: see wufuwrN.
waforapN: see wufuwrN.

Also, Hair collected together upon the head: or hair hanging down upon the ears: or hair extending beyond the lobe of the ear: (M, Ḳ:) or hair extending to the lobe of the ear: (Ṣ:) or hair (T, Mgh, Mṣb) such as is termed jum-ap, (T, A, Mgh,) extending to the ears: (T, A, Mgh, Mṣb:) it is said to be larger than what is termed jum-ap; but this is a mistake: (M:) the order is this: first, the waforap; then, the jum-ap; then, the lim-ap: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) the second of these three is what extends beyond the ears; (M;) and the third is what descends upon the shoulder-joints: (Ṣ, M:) pl. wifaArN. (M, Ḳ.)

wufuwrN and waforN↓ and waforapN↓ and firapN↓ [are inf. ns., (see 1,) used as simple substs.,] all signify the same: (Ṣ, TA:) Fulness, completeness, perfectness, wholeness, or entireness: (Ṣ:) or muchness, abundance, ampleness, or copiousness: (TA:) and the second also, richness; or competence. (A, Ḳ.)
