You say, hecihi OaroDN fiI nabotihaA waforN, (Ṣ,) and waforapN↓, (Ṣ, A,) and firapN↓, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) i. e., wufuwrN, (Ṣ, A, TA,) This is land in the herbage of which is fulness,, &c., (Ṣ,) or abundance; (TA;) the herbage of which has not been pastured upon. (Ṣ, A, TA.) And huwa fiI waforapK mina AlmaAl [He is in possession of abundance of property]. (A.)

waAfirN and mawofuwrN↓ and muwaf-arN↓ and mutawaf-irN↓ [and Oawofaru↓ and waforN↓] all signify the same: [i. e., Full, without lack or defect, full-sized, complete, perfect, whole, or entire: or much, abundant, ample, or copious.] (A, TA.) You say, maAlN waAfirN and nabaAtN waAfirN, &c., [Full, or complete,, &c., or] much, or abundant, property, and herbage,, &c., (TA.) And XaIoCN mawofuwrN↓ A thing that is full, complete,, &c. (Ṣ.) And jazaMCN muwaf-arN↓ A recompense of which nothing is deficient. (TA.) And fulaAnN muwaf-aru↓ AlX-aEari ‡ Such a one has his hair left to become abundant and long. (TA.) And siqaMCN Oawofaru↓, (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and waforN↓, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) A skin for milk, or water, made of hide of which nothing is deficient. (T, Ṣ, A, Ḳ.) And in like manner, mazaAdapN waforaMCu A leather water-bag made of a complete skin; (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ;) nothing thereof being deficient: (Ṣ, TA:) also signifying a leather water-bag filled (M, Ḳ,* TA) completely. (M, TA.) And OaroDN waforaMCu↓ Land in the herbage of which is abundance: (M, Ḳ,* TA:) and land of which the herbage has not been diminished. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And OucunN waforaMCu↓ An ear having a large lobe: (M:) or a large ear, (Ḳ, TA,) large in the lobe. (TA.) You say also, humo mutawaAfiruwna↓ They are numerous. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

AlwaAfiru The fourth metre (baHor) in prosody; (M,* Ḳ;) the measure of which consists of mufaAEalatuno six times [in its original state]: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) or, [in practice,] mufaAEalatuno mufaAEalatuno faEuwluno, twice: or mufaAEalatuno mufaAEalatuno, twice: (M, L:) so called because its feet are made full like those of the kaAmil, except that there is [in practice] an elision in their letters, so that it is not complete. (M, L.)
Oawofaru, fem. waforaMCu, [pl. wuforN:] see faAfirN.
muwaf-arN: see waAfirN, in three places.
tarakotuhu EalaI OaHosani muwaf-arK ‡ I left him in the best state, or condition. (TA.)
mawofuwrN: see waAfirN.
mutawaf-rN: see waAfirN.
mutawAfirN: see waAfirN.
3. wAfzhu He hastened with him; vied, or strove, with him in hastening; or made haste to be, or get, before him; syn. EaAjalahu. (A, TA.)
4. Awfzhu He hastened him. (Ḳ.)
5. twf-z He prepared himself (A, Ḳ) likacaA for such a thing, (A,) or lilX-ar-i for evil, or mischief. (Ḳ.)
Also, He turned over and over upon his bed. (A.) See also 10.

10. Astwfz fiI qiEodatihi He put himself in an upright posture, not at his ease, in his manner of sitting; he sat erect, not at his ease: (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ:) or he put down his knees [upon the ground] and raised his buttocks: (Aboo-Mo'ádh, Ḳ:) or he raised himself upon his legs, or feet, without having yet set himself firmly in a standing posture, but having prepared himself to leap, or spring, (Lth, Ḳ, TA,) or to go away: (Lth, TA:) or he sat in a posture as though he desired to rise and stand up; whether in the manner termed UiqoEaMC [i. e. sitting upon the ground with the shanks erect], or otherwise. (MF.)

wafozN and wafazN↓ Haste: pl. (of the latter, TA,) OawofaAzN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, naHonu EalaI OawofaAzK, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and EalaI wafazK, (Ḳ,) We are in haste: (Ḳ:) or we are on a journey; [like EalaI OawofaAdK;] the time of our journeying has come. (Ṣ, TA.) And laqiytuhu EalaI OawofaAzK, and EalaI wafazK, I found him in a state of haste: (Az, TA:) or preparing [his apparatus for travel]. (M, TA.)
wafazN: see wafozN.
wafazapN An upright posture in sitting, so that one is not at his ease. (Lth, TA.) See 10.
mutawaf-izN Turning over and over upon the bed, scarcely sleeping: (Ḳ,* TA:) mentioned by Z, and by Ṣgh in the O, on the authority of Ibn-ʼAbbád. (TA.)
musotawofizN act. part. n. of 10, q. v. One says, UiTomaYin- faUin-iI OaraAka musotawofizFA [Be thou at ease, for I see thee to be sitting in an upright and uneasy posture]. (TA.)

1. wafaDa, (A, Mgh, Ḳ.) aor. yafiDu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. wafoDN (A, Ḳ) and wafaDN; (IDrd, Ḳ;) and AwfD↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) and AstwfD↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He ran: (A, Mgh, Ḳ:) he hastened, or went quickly. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ.) Hence, in the Ḳur. [lxx. 43,] kaOan-ahumo UilaI nuSubK yuwfiDuwna↓, or naSobK, As though they were hastening, or going quickly, to a thing set up for worship. (Fr, Ṣ, TA.) You say also wafaDati AlUibalu The camels hastened, or went quickly: (M:) or went the pace termed xabab. (Khaleefeh El-Hoseynee.) And The camels became dispersed: (AA:) and AstwfDt↓ they became dispersed (Ḳ, TA) in their pasturing. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. AwfD: see 1, in two places.
Also, He made a she-camel to go the pace termed xabab; as also AwDf. (Khaleefeh El-Hoseynee.) And He dispersed camels. (The same, and Ḳ.) See also 10.
AwfD lahu He spread for him a carpet, or the like, by which to preserve himself from the ground; (Ḳ, TA;) as also AwDm. (TA)
10. AstwfD: see 1, in two places.
Also, He required, or commanded, another to hasten, or be quick, or he hastened, hurried, or urged, him. (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ, [but in the M; it seems to relate to camels, or an ostrich.])
He drove away (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) camels, or an ostrich; as also AwfD↓: (M:) he drove away, or expelled, another from his country: (M:) he banished him. (Mgh, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: wafoDN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and wafaDN↓ (M, Ḳ) Haste: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) [like wafozN and wafazN:] pl. OawofaADN. (Ḳ.) You say, jaMCa EalaI wafoDK, and wafaDK↓, and OawofaADK, He came in haste. (M.) And laqiytuhu EalaI OawofaADK I found him in a state of haste: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) like OawofaAzK. (Ṣ.)
wafaDN: see wafoDN, in two places.
wafoDapN A pastor's [bag of the kind called] xariyTap, for his implements and provisions, (M, Ḳ,) which he carries therein. (M.)

And hence, as being likened thereto, (M,) A [quiver of the kind called] jaEobap, (M, Ḳ,) or a thing like the jaEobap. (Ṣ,) for arrows, (M,) of skins, or hides, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) in which is no wood: (Ṣ, M:) or [a quiver] smaller than the jEbp, having its upper and lower parts of equal size: the jEbp is round and wide, and has a cover on the top, over its mouth: [see the latter word:] (ISh:) pl. wifaADN (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and wafaDaAtN. (A, TA.)
Also, A thing like a quiver (kinaAnap), (Fr, M,) of small size, (Fr,) in which a man of the class called OawofaAD puts his food. (Fr, M.)
Also, The small depression between the two mustaches, beneath the nose, (Ḳ, TA,) of a man. (TA.)

OawofaADN Parties of men: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ:) a mixed multitude: (AʼObeyd, M, Ḳ:) from wafaDati AlUibalu meaning “the camels became dispersed:” (AA:) or poor, weak, defenceless people: (L:) or an assemblage, (Ḳ,) or a mixed multitude or collection, (Ṣ,) from various tribes, such as the OaSoHaAbu AlS-uf-api: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a company of whom every one has a wafoDap for his food, (Fr, M, Ḳ,) i. e. a thing resembling a kinaAnap, (Fr, M,) of small size, (Fr,) in which he puts his food; (Fr, M;) but this explanation is disapproved by AʼObeyd (TA) [and by ISd]: or AlOawofaADu applies to the persons called Oaholu AlS-uf-api, (M,) who were a mixed multitude (AʼObeyd, M) from various tribes, (AʼObeyd,) consisting of ninety-three men. (TA.) [See Suf-apN.]
miyfaADN Going quickly, or swiftly; applied to a she-camel, (Ṣ, M, Ḳ,) and to an ostrich. (Ṣ, M.)
musotawufiDN Going quickly, or hastening, by reason of fright; (Aṣ;) or running away by reason of fright; as though desiring his wafoD, or running: (Ṣgh:) or frightened. (TA.)
1. waqaba AlZ-alaAmu The darkness came in upon the people. (Ṣ, Ḳ *.)
So in the verse of the Ḳur. [cxiii. 3,] wamino Xar-i gaAsiqK UicaA waqaba And from the mischief of night when it cometh in upon men; (Ṣ;) [for other explanations see gaAsiqN in art. gsq.]
waqabati AlX-amosu, (inf. n. waqobN and wuquwbN, Ḳ,) ‡ The sun set: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) entered its place [of setting.] (Ṣ.)
waqaba Alqamaru, (inf. n. wuquwbN, TA,) The moon entered upon a state of eclipse; (Ḳ;) entered into the cone-shaped shade of the earth. (TA.)
waqabato EayonaAhu (and simply waqaba, TA,) His eyes became sunk, or depressed, in his head. (Ṣ.)

waqaba, aor. yaqibu, inf. n. waqobN and waqiybN, He (a horse) made a sound with his prepuce: [in the Ṣ and Ḳ, the verb is not mentioned, but only the latter of the two inf. ns., which is explained as signifying “the sounding of a horse's prepuce:”] or made a sound by the motion of his penis in its prepuce. (TA.)

waqaba, aor. yaqibu, inf. n. waqobN It (a thing) entered: (Ṣ:) but it is said in a marginal note in a copy of the Ṣ, that the inf. n. is correctly wuquwbN, because the verb is intrans.: accord. to some, it signifies he, or it, entered into a waqobN, q. v.; and in the Ḳ, waqobN is given as the inf. n. of the verb in this sense. (TA.) [In the CK, waqot is put by mistake for waqob.]
waqaba, [aor. yuqibu,] inf. n. waqobN and wuquwbN, He, or it, became absent, hidden, or concealed. (Ḳ.)
waqaba [aor. yaqibu,] inf. n. waqobN, He, or it, came; approached; advanced. (Ḳ.)
4. Awqb Aln-axolu The palm-tree became rotten in the fruit-bearing stalks of its racemes. (TA.)
Awqb He (Ḳ), or it, (a people, Ṣ,) hungered; suffered hunger. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Awqb XayoYFA, (inf. n. UiyqaAbN, TA,) He put a thing into a waqobap, q. v.: (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, as in some Lexicons, into a waqob. (TA.)

hom.sense: waqobN A small hollow, or cavity, (nuqorapN,) in which water collects, in a mountain: (Ṣ:) or in a rock: as also waqobapN↓: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to some, wqb is a coll. gen. n., of which wqbp is the n. un.: (MF:) pl. OawoqaAbN: (TA:) or waqobN, accord. to the Ḳ, (but accord. to the TA waqobapN↓,) signifies what is like a well, in a tract of hard and large stones that produce no plants, a fathom, or two fathoms, in depth, (Ḳ,) in which the rain-water stagnates. (TA.)
The cavity, or socket, of the eye: (Ṣ:) any cavity, or socket, in the body; as that of the eye, and that of the shoulder-blade: (Ḳ:) pl. wuquwbN and wiqaAbN. (TA.)
The pit, or cavity, above the eye of a horse: (Ḳ:) pl. wuquwbN and wiqaAbN. (TA.)
The hole into which enters the axle of a pulley. (Ḳ.)
See also waqobapN.
Stupid; foolish; of little sense: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) like wagobN: (Ṣ:) an epithet of a man: pl. OawoqaAbN: (Ḳ, TA:) fem. with p {waqobapN}. (TA.)

So in the following trad. of El-Ahnaf: Uiy-aAkumo waHamiy-apa AlOawoqaAbi [Beware of the care with which stupid people defend their rights: a proverb]. (TA.) For AlAwqAb, another relation substitutes AlOawgoAb, meaning the same, or weak persons. (TA, art. wgb, on the authority of AA.)
A despised, or contemptible, low, base, or ignoble, man. (Th, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: qibapN The thing that is in the belly, resembling the faHiv: (TA:) the UinofaH-ap [a name given to the stomach of a sucking kid, &c.] when it has grown large, of a XAp, [i. e., a sheep or goat or the like]: (Ḳ:) not in any animals but those termed XAC: (IAạr:) mentioned before, in art. qb, [q. v., where it is also written qib-apN]. (TA.)
waqobapN A large aperture, or hole, in a wall, in which is shade: (Ḳ:) pl. OawoqaAbN.
See waqobN.

waqobapu Alv-ariydi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and Ald-uhoni, (Ḳ,) but the latter is a mistake, and the correct word is Almudohuni, [a vase for ointment], (TA,) i. q. OanoquwEatuhu, [i. e., its cavity or hollow]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Lth says, that waqobN↓ signifies any cavity, hollow, or pit; as that in a [stone of the kind called] fihorN, and in a mudohun, or mudohunap, q. v. (TA.)
wuqobiI-N Fond of, or given to, the company of OawoqAb, i. e., stupid, or foolish, persons. (Ḳ.)
OawoqaAbN [pl. of waqobN?] The utensils and furniture, of the meaner sort, of a house, or tent: (Ḳ, TA:) as also OawogaAbN. (TA.)
cakarN Oawoqabu Multum penetrans in vulvam penis. (Ḳ.)
rakiy-apN waqobaACu, A well of which the water sinks into the earth. (TA.)
miyqabN i. q. wadaEapN [The shell called cowry]. (Ḳ.)
miyqaAbN A man who drinks much of water: (Ḳ:) or of the beverage called nabiyc. (L.)

miyqaAbN A stupid, or foolish, woman: or one who gives birth to stupid, or foolish, children; syn. muHomiqapN. (Ḳ: [so in the CK: in a MṢ. copy, muHam-aqapN, one to whom stupidity, or folly, is imputed: but the former is evidently the right reading; myqAb being an epithet similar to micokaArN and miYonaAvN, &c.])
Also Latam vulvam habens mulier. (Ḳ.)
banuw AlmiyqaAbi a reproachful appellation, (Ḳ,) referring to the mother of the persons to whom it is applied. (TA.)
sayoru AlmiyqaAbi A journeying continued during a day and a night together. (Ḳ.)

1. waqata, aor. yaqitu, inf. n. waqtN; and wq-t↓, inf. n. tawoqiytN; He determined, defined, or limited, a thing as to time; (IAth, L, Mṣb;) and otherwise: (L, Mṣb:) he determined, or defined, times. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) waqatahu He declared [or appointed] a time in which it should be done. (Ṣ.) waqata Qll-ehu AlSlaApa, aor. yaqitu; and waq-atahaA↓, God hath determined, or defined, a time for prayer. (Mṣb.) wq-t↓, as also Oaq-ata, He assigned, or appointed, for a thing, a particular time; he assigned, or appointed, a particular time for doing a thing. (IAth, L.) waq-at-uhu↓ liyawomi kacaA [I appointed him, or it, for such a day]; like Oaj-alotuhu. (Ṣ.)

In the following words of the Ḳur. [lxxvii. 11,] waUicaA Alr-usulu Ouq-itato, Aqtt↓ is a dial. form of wuq-itato, like as OujuwhN is of wujuwhN; (Ṣ;) and the meaning is And when the Apostles shall have one [particular] time assigned to them to decide between the people [to whom they have been sent to preach]: (Zj:) or, shall be collected at their appointed time, on the day of resurrection. (Fr.) This is the general reading: but there are other reading; namely, wuq-itato, and wuqitato, (Ṣ, TA,) and wuwqitato, which last is of the measure fuwEilato, from AlmuwaAqatapu. (Ḳ.)
lamo yaqito fI Alxamori Had-FA He (Moḥammad) did not determine, or define, for [drinking wine,] a castigation consisting of a certain number [of blows, or stripes]. (TA, from a trad.)
waqata sometimes signifies He [i. e. God] made the entering upon the state of UiHoraAm in pilgrimage, and prayer at the commencement of its appointed time, obligatory, or incumbent, upon men. (TA.)
waq-ata↓ liOaholi Almadiynapi caA AlHulayofapi He appointed, for the people of El-Medeeneh, Dhu-l-Huleyfeh as the place where they should enter upon the state of UiHoraAm. (TA, from a trad.)
2: see 1 throughout.
3. wAqthu, inf. n. muwaAqatahN, [He made an appointment with him for a particular time]. (Ḳ.)

waqotN (Ṣ, Ḳ) A time; or space, or measure, of time, (M, L, Ḳ, Mṣb,) appointed for any affair; a season: (Mṣb:) mostly used with respect to what is past: (M, Ḳ:) sometimes with respect to the future: (TA:) as also miyqaAtN↓, (Ḳ, Mṣb:) or, accord. to some, there is a difference between these two words; the former having an absolute signification, and the latter signifying a time appointed for the performance of some action: [as in the Ṣ:] (TA:) pl. of the former OawoqaAtN, and of the latter mawaAqiytu. (Mṣb.) [Hence, waqotaYicK Then; at that time.]
waqotN ‡ A space, or measure, of local extension; as a mile, &c. (Sb.)

mawoqitN, [of the measure] mafoEilN from Alwaqotu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [it may therefore be an inf. n., or a noun of place, or a noun of time]. El-ʼAjjáj says,
waAljaAmiEu Aln-aAsa liyawomi Almawoqiti
[And He who congregateth mankind for the day of the appointment of a particular time, or, of the place of a certain event, or, of the time of a certain event; i. e., for the day of resurrection]. (Ṣ.)
miyqaAtN: see waqotN.

Also, A place in which a certain action is appointed to be performed. (Ṣ.) Ex. miyqaAtu AlHaj-i The place where the pilgrims enter upon the state of UiHoraAm: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) you say, hecaA myqAtu Oaholi AlX-aOomi This is the place where the people of Syria enter upon the state of AHrAm. (Ṣ.)

[Also, A place in which a meeting is appointed to take place at a particular time. Ex.] AlMxirapu miyqaAtu Alxaloqi [The world to come is the place in which mankind are appointed to meet after the resurrection]. (L.)
[Also, That which determines the commencement, or the like, of a period, &c. Ex.] AlhilaAlu myqAtu AlX-ahori [The crescent is that which determines the commencement of the month]. (L.)
See also mawoqitN.
mawoquwtN and muwaq-atN↓ Determined, defined, definite, or limited, as to time. (L.)
waqotN mawoquwtN, and muwaq-atN↓, A determined, defined, definite, or limited, time. (Ḳ.)

Uin-a AlS-alaApa kaAnato EalaI AlmuWominiyna kitaAbFA mawoquwtFA [Ḳur. iv. 104,] For prayer is to the believers a prescript, or an appointment, or ordinance, ordained [to be performed] in the times [thereof]. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.)
Also [mawoquwvN (see 1) and] muwaq-atN↓ Determined, defined, or definite, as to its extreme limit, extent, or amount: (L:) both signify anything defined, definite, or limited. (Mṣb.)
muwaq-atN: see mawoquwtN.

1. waquHa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yawoquHu; (Ṣ;) and waqiHa, (Ḳ,) aor. yawoqaHu; (TA;) and waqaHa, (Ḳ,) aor. yaqiHu; (TA;) inf. n. waqaAHapN and wuquwHapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. ns. of the first, (TA,) and wuqoHN and wuquHN, (Ṣ,) [also of the first,] and waqaHN, so in [most of] the copies of the Ḳ, [but in the CK wuqoHN.], inf. n. of the second, (TA,) and qiHapN and qaHapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) in both of which the p is a substitute for the [elided] w, (Ṣ,) and in the latter of which the fet-ḥah is put in the place of kesreh because of the guttural letter, both inf. ns. of the second and third; (TA;) and AwqH↓, and AstwqH↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) It (a solid hoot, Ṣ, Ḳ, and a camel's foot, and the back, TA) was, or became, hard. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

waquHa,(Ṣ, Ḳ,) and waqiHa, and waqaHa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. waqaAHapN and qiHapN and qaHapN (Ṣ) and wuqoHN and wuquwHN; (Lḥ;) and twq-H↓; (A;) He (a man) had little shame: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he was hard-faced, having little shame: he was bold to do bad, foul, or abominable, things, and cared not for them, accord. to Bḍ and Z. (TA.)
2. wq-H, inf. n. tawoqiyHN, He repaired a tank, or cistern, with pieces of dry clay, or tough clay in which was no sand, and (or, as is sometimes done, TA) with broad and thin stones. (Ḳ.)

wq-H, inf. n. tawoqiyHN, He rendered a solid hoof hard by means of melted fat, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) burning with the melted fat the places where the hoof was worn by treading, and the hairs next to the hoof. (TA.)
4: see 1.
5: see 1.
waqiHN and waqaAHN↓ ‡ A man having little shame. (Ṣ, A.)

waqaAHu Alwajohi, an epithet applied to a woman, (Ṣ,) without p, as well as to a man, and waqiyHu↓ Alwajohi, applied to a man, ‡ Hard-faced, having little shame; (TA;) as also waqoHaI↓ applied to woman. (Mṣb.)
waqaAHu Alc-anabi † A man patient in riding. (IAạr, Ḳ.) [See canabN.]

waqaAHN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and waAqiHN↓ (Ḳ,) A hard solid hoof, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and camel's foot, and the back; the former an epithet both masc. and fem.: (TA:) pl. of the former wuquHN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and wuq-aHN. (TA.) farasN waqaAHN † A hard and strong horse. (Mṣb.)
See waqiHN.
waqiyHN and waqoHaI: see waqiHN.
waAqiHN: see waqaAHN.
rajulN muwaq-aHN ‡ A man who has been tried or proved, or rendered experienced or expert (Lḥ. Ṣ, Ḳ) by trials which have befallen him; as also muwaq-aE. (Lḥ, Ṣ.)
baEiyrN muwaq-aHN ‡ A camel jaded by work. (TA.)

1. waqadati Aln-aAru, aor. taqidu, inf. n. wuquwdN (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and waquwdN, (Sb, Zj, L, Ḳ,) but this is a deviation [as to form] from the constant course of speech, and most hold that the former is an inf. n. and the latter a subst. signifying “fire-wood” [or “fuel”], though there are some instances of inf. ns. of the measure faEuwlN, whereof qabuwlN is one, (El-Basáïr, TA,) and waqodN (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and waqadN and qidapN and waqadaAnN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and waqiydN; (Ṣ, L;) and twq-dt↓, and At-qdt↓, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Astwqdt↓; (L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) The fire burned; burned up; burned brightly or fiercely; blazed; or flamed; syn. AiXotaEalat; (Mṣb, art. XEl;) and haAjat; (L;) and saTaEato waQrotafaEa lahabuhaA. (Bḍ, ii. 16.)
waqadato bika zinaAdiI † [May my znd emit fire by thy means!] a prayer, like wariyato bk znAdI: (L:) [meaning, do thou aid, or help, me].
waqada and twq-d↓ It (anything) shone, or glistened. (L.)
twq-d↓ qalobuhu ‡ His heart became excited with ardour, or eagerness. (L.)
[And twq-d↓ ‡ He (a man) was, or became, clever, ingenious, acute, sharp, or penetrating. (See waq-aAdN.)]
2. waq-ada see 4.

4. Awqd Aln-aAra, (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiyqaAdN; (L, Mṣb;) and wq-dhA↓, (L,) and twq-dhA↓, (Ḳ,) and AstwqdhA↓; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) He lighted, or kindled, the fire; made it to burn, to burn up, to burn brightly or fiercely, to blaze, or to flame; syn. OaDoramahaA; (Ḳ, art. Drm;) and OaXoEalahaA; (TḲ;) he raised the fire, or made it to burn up, with fire-wood, or fuel: (A:) or the ↓last signifies he desired, or endeavoured, to kindle the fire. and to make it burn up, or burn brightly or fiercely, and blaze, or flame. (Bḍ, ii. 16.)

kul-amaA OawoqaduwA naArFA liloHarobi OaTofaOahaA Qll-ehu ‡ [Whenever they kindle a fire for war, God extinguisheth it; Ḳur. v. 69,] meaning, whenever they contrive a mischievous and deceitful plot, God annulleth it. (Mṣb.)

Oawoqadotu lilS-ibaA naArFA [in some copies of the Ḳ, lilS-abiI-i,] † I relinquished silly and youthful conduct. (L, Ḳ.) A poet says,
SaHawotu waOawoqadotu lil-ahowi naAraA
warad-a EalaI-a QlS-ibaA maA QsotaEaAraA
† [I recovered from intoxication, and relinquished vain and frivolous diversion; and youthfulness restored to me what it had borrowed]. (L.)

OaboEada Qll-ehu daArahu waOawoqada naAraA Oavarahu ‡ [May God remove his dwelling far away, and] may He not bring him back, or restore him! (L, Ḳ.) It was a custom of Arabs, when a man whose evil or mischief they feared removed from them, to light a fire behind him, that his evil or mischief might go with him. (L.)
5: See 1 and 4.
twq-d is also said of the odour of perfume, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, in art. whj,) meaning † It was, or became, hot [or strong]. (TḲ.)
8: see 1.
At-qdt AlX-amosu [The sun was, or became, burning, or fiercely burning]. (M, Ḳ, in art. Sqr, conj. 4, &c.)
10: see 1 and 4 .
waqadN Fire itself. (A, L, Ḳ.) Ex. maA OaEoZama hecaA Alwaqada How great is this fire! (A.)
See also 1.
Alwaqodapu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or waqodapu AlHar-i, (L,) ‡ The greatest heat; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) which is a period of ten days, or of half a month. (Ṣ, L.)
Tabaxatohumo waqodapu AlS-ayofi ‡ [The greatest heat of the summer affected them with a hot, or burning, fever]. (A.)
waqadaAtu suhayolK: see the last paragraph of art. Edl.
waqadaI, fem. Shining, or glistening. (L.)
See also miyqaAdN.

waquwdN Fire-wood; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) but it is only so called when kindled; (El-Ḥareeree, in De Sacy's Anthol. Gramm. Ar., p. 31 of the Arabic text;) as also wiqaAdN and waqiydN: (Ḳ:) or any fuel; anything with which fire is kindled, or made to burn, burn up, burn brightly or fiercely, blaze, or flame: (L:) or the blaze, or flame, of fire, which one sees. (Lth, L.)
waquwduhaA Aln-aAsu waQloHijaArapu [Ḳur. ii. 22; and lxvi. 6; The fuel whereof shall be men and stones]. (L.)
See also 1. In the Ḳur. lxxxv. 5, it is most properly rendered as an inf. n.; (Az, L;) and some in this case read Alwuquwd. (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ, L.)
waq-aAdN Shining, or shining brightly; (L, Ḳ;) applied to a star. (L.)
waq-aAdN (L, Ḳ) and mutawaq-idN↓ (L) ‡ A heart, or mind. quickly excited with ardour, or eagerness, in liveliness and acuteness or penetration. (L, Ḳ.)
Also, both words, ‡ A man (L) clever, ingenious, acute, sharp, or penetrating. (L, Ḳ.)

gaAYiru AlwaAqidayoni ‡ Blind: (A:) by AlwAqdyn are meant the two eyes: El-Aạshà says, accord. to one reading,
raOato rajulFA gaAYira AlwaAqidayoni
but the reading commonly known is AlwaAfidayoni. (JK.)
mawoqidN (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb) and musotawoqadN↓ (A, L) and muwqadN↓ (JK) A fire-place; a place in which fire is lighted. (Ṣ, A,* L, Mṣb.) [See an ex. voce HasaAsN.]
muwqadN: see muwoqidN.
zanodN miyqaAdN A znd that quickly produces fire. (A, L, Ḳ.) You also say znd waqadaI, i. e., mutawaq-idapN. (JK.)
mutawaq-idN: see waq-aAdN.
musotawoqidN: see mawoqidN.

1. waqacahu, aor. yaqicu, (Ṣ, L, &c.,) inf. n. waqocN, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ, &c.,) He beat him, or struck him, violently: (L, Ḳ:) he beat him until he became relaxed, or languid, and at the point of death: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb:) or he beat him so that he became at the point of death: (A:) he broke his skull, wounding the brain: (L:) he beat or struck, him upon the small protuberance above the back of the neck, so that the sound of the blow or blows reached the brain, and deprived him of reason: (Aboo-Saʼeed, L:) he beat him (a man) until he died. (L.)
waqacahu biAlD-arobi [He killed him with beating]. (ISk, L.)
waqaca AlX-aApa He beat the ewe, or she-goat, to death with pieces of wood [&c.: see waqiycN]. (L.)
waqacahu He prostrated him. (Ḳ.)
Darabotu AlHay-apa Hat-aI waqacotuhaA I beat the serpent until I killed it. (A.)

waqacahu † It (clemency, forbearance, or gravity,) rendered him still, quiet, or tranquil: (L, Ḳ:) it (the fear of God) rendered him still, quiet, or tranquil, and had such an effect upon him as to prevent his committing an unlawful action. (L.)
waqacahu ‡ It (drowsiness, Ṣ, L, Mṣb) overcame him: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or made him to fall down. (Mṣb.)
waqacahu AlmaraDu, and Algam-u, † [Disease, and grief, overcame him, or rendered him infirm, or caused him to be at the point of death]. (L.)
waqacatohu AlEibaAdapu ‡ [Religious service rendered him infirm, or caused him to be at the point of death]. (A)
waqacatoniI kalimapN samiEotuhaA ‡ [A word, or sentence, that I heard, distressed me.] (A.)
wuqicato ‡ She (a camel) was milked against her wish, so that her milk became little. (A.)
fiI qalobiI waqocahN mino celika ‡ In my heart is some distress remaining in consequence of that. (A.)
4: see 1.
waqiycN Beaten [violently: or] until he has become relaxed, or languid, and at the point of death: [&c.: see 1:] as also mawoquwcN↓. (Mṣb.)

waqiycN (ISk, L, Ḳ) and mawoquwcapN↓ (Fr, ISk, Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) A ewe, or she-goat, beaten to death; (Fr, ISk, L;) after which it is eaten: (ISk, L:) killed with pieces of wood (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ), &c.; (Mṣb;) not legally slaughtered: (Fr, L, Mṣb:) beaten to death with a staff, or stick; (A, El-Basáïr;) or with blunt stones: (El-Basáïr:) the Arabs in the time of paganism killed beasts thus. (A.)
waqiycN Prostrated. (Ḳ.) [In the TA, AlsryE is erroneously put for AlS-ariyEu.]
waqiycN † A man in whom is no fat or strength; maA bihi TiroqN. (Ṣ, L.)
waqiycN † A slow, heavy man: (L, Ḳ *:) as though his heaviness and weakness overcame him, or prostrated him, waqacahu. (L.)
waqaAYicF Stones spread about: (L, Ḳ:) sing. waqiycapN. (L.)
waqiycu AljawAaniHi † Grieved in the heart; as though it were broken and weakened by grief. The jwAnH [are the ribs that] enclose the heart. (L.)
muwqacN: see waqiycN.

mawqicN An extremity of the person, (Ḳ,) or place upon which a blow is severe, (A,) as, (Ḳ,) or namely, (A,) the elbow, (A, L, Ḳ,) and shoulder-joint, (Ḳ,) or extremity of the shoulderjoint, (A, L,) and knee, and ankle-bone: pl. mawaAqicu. (A, L, Ḳ.)
mawoquwcN and mawoqawcapN: see waqiycN.

muwaq-acapN A she-camel suffering in her dugs from the effect of the rag with which they have been bound to prevent their being sucked, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) by reason of its tightness: (L:) or that has been sucked by her young one without its drawing her milk otherwise than scantily, by reason of the largeness of her udder, in consequence of which she suffers disease, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) and has a tumour (Ṣ, L) in her udder. (L.)

hom.sense: 1. waqara as syn. with Oawoqara: and wuqirati Aln-axolapu as syn. with Oawoqarat: see 4.

[Hence,] waqara Qll-ehu Oucunahu, aor. yaqiruhaA, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. waqorN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) ‡ God made his ear heavy, or dull of hearing: (Mṣb, Ḳ:*) or deaf. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, Oall-ehum-a qiro Oacuhahu ‡ O God, make his ear heavy, or dull of hearing: (A:) or deaf. (Ṣ.)

[Hence also,] waqirato Oucunuhu, (ISk, Ṣ, TA,) aor. tuwqaru, inf. n. waqorN; (ISk, TA;) and waqirato, aor. tawoqaru; (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA;) and waqarato, aor. taqiru; (Mṣb, TA;) inf. n. waqorN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) which by rule should be waqarN, as inf. n. of waqirato, (Ṣ, TA,) but which is regular as inf. n. of waqarato; (TA;) ‡ His ear was, or became, heavy, or dull of hearing: (Mṣb, TA:*) or deaf: (Ṣ, TA:) but in the Ḳ we find, less properly, waqara and waqira, [as though signifying he (a man) was, or became, dull of hearing: or deaf:] inf. n. waqorN, which by rule should be waqarN; and wuqira, like EuniIa. (TA.) You say also, waqarato OucuniI Eanohu ‡ [My ear was dull of hearing, or deaf, to (lit. from) him]: (A:) and wuqirato Eani QsotimaAEi kalaAmihi ‡ [it was dull of hearing, or deaf, to (lit. from) the hearing of, or listening to, his speech]. (A, TA: but in the latter, waqirato.)

[Hence also,] waqara, aor. yaqiru, inf. n. waqArN, † He, or it, was, or became, still, or motionless; rested; syn. sakana. (TA.) So in the phrase waqara fiI Alqalobi † It (a thing) rested in the heart, or mind: and waqarafiI Sadorihi † it (a secret) rested in his bosom: occurring in a trad., accord. to different relations. (TA.) You say also, kal-amotuhu kalimapF waqarato fiI Oucunihi ‡ I spoke to him a speech which rested (vabatato) in his ear. (Aṣ, A.) And waqara fiI Als-amoEi wawaEaAhu Alqalobu ‡ [It rested in the ear; and the heart, or mind, kept it in memory]. (A.) And waqara fiI qalobihi kacaA ‡ Such a thing came into his mind and left its impression remaining. (A.)

[And hence,] waqara, aor. yaqiru; (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) and waqira, aor. yawoqaru; (TA;) inf. n. waqorN, (Ḳ, TA,) of the former, (TA,) and wuquwrapN, (Ḳ, TA,) of the latter; (TA;) ‡ He (a man, TA) sat: (Ḳ, TA:) or he sat with waqaAr [i. e. gravity,, &c.]. (Mṣb.)

[Hence also,] waqara, aor. yaqiru; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and waqura, aor. yawaquru; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) inf. n. waqaArN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) of the former, (Ṣ,) or of the latter, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and qirapN, of the former, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and waqaArapN, of the latter; (Ḳ;) He was, or became, grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [see waqaArN, below;] as also Uit-aqara↓ and tawaq-ara↓: (Ḳ:) or this last, signifies he showed, exhibited, or manifested, gravity, staidness, steadiness, sedateness, or calmness: (KL:) [and also, agreeably with analogy, he endeavoured, or he constrained himself, to be grave,, &c.] It is said in the Ḳur. [xxxiii. 33,] waqirona fiI buyuwtikun-a [meaning, accord. to some, And be ye grave,, &c., in your houses, or chambers]: (Ṣ, A:) or the meaning is, and sit ye,, &c.: (TA:) and so another reading, waqazona: (TA:) or this latter, (Ṣ,) or each of these two readings, (TA,) is from AlqaraAru, (Ṣ,) [i. e.,] from qar-a, aor. yaqar-u and yaqir-u; (TA;) and is a contraction of Uiqorarona [or Uiqorirona]. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: 2. wq-rhu, inf. n. tawoqiyrN, † He made him (a beast of carriage) to be still, or quiet. (Ḳ, TA.)
‡ He pronounced him, or held, or reckoned him, to be grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm; syn. of the inf. n. taroziynN. (Ṣ.)
‡ He treated him, with honour, reverence, veneration, or respect; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA;) did not hold him in light estimation. (A, TA.)

4. Awqrhu (inf. n. UiyqaArN and qirapN, Ḳ, which latter is anomalous, TA,) He loaded him: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or loaded him heavily: (A, Ḳ:) namely a camel, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) or a beast (Ḳ) or a mule, and an ass: (A:) [see wiqorN, below: and waqarahu↓, aor. yaqiruhu, signifies the same; and its inf. n. seems to be waqoraI, q. v., as also, probably, waqorN: waqara, aor. yaqiru, is explained by Golius, as on the authority of Ibn-Maạroof, as signifying “gravavit, aggravavit.”] You say, Oawoqara Ald-aAb-apaqirapF XadiydapF [He loaded the beast of carriage severely]. (TA.) And Oawoqara raAHilatahu cahabFA He loaded his riding-camel with a load, or heavy load, of gold. (TA.)
Awqrhu Ald-ayonu ‡ Debt burdened him, or burdened him heavily. (Ṣ, A.*)
Oawoqarati Aln-axolapu, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) and wuqirato↓, (A,) The palm-tree became laden, or heavily laden, with fruit; (A;) became abundant in fruit. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)

And Oawoqara, or Ouwqira, (accord. to different copies of the Ṣ, in art. dm,) [or Awqr XaHomFA or biAlX-aHomi,] said of a camel, &c., i. q. dum-a biAlX-aHomi [He was, or became, loaded, or overspread, with fat: see dum-a]. (Ṣ, in that art.)
5: see 1, last signification.
8: see 1, last signification.
10. Astwqr wiqorahu TaEaAmFA He took, or received, his load, or heavy load, of wheat or other food. (Ḳ.)
Astwqrt AlUibilu, (Ḳ, TA,) or Astwqrt AlUibilu XaHomFA (A,) The camels became fat; (Ḳ;) [lit.] carried fat: (TA:) or became heavy with fatness. (A.)
waqorN A heaviness in the ear; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) a heaviness, or dulness, of hearing: (Mṣb, TA:) or deafness; entire loss of hearing. (Ḳ, TA.) See 1.

wiqorN A load, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in a general sense, (A, Ḳ, TA,) whether heavy or light or moderate, (TA,) of a mule and of an ass and of a camel; (Mṣb;) or mostly of a mule and of an ass; that of a camel being mostly termed wasoqN: (Ṣ, TA:) or a heavy load: (A, Ḳ:) or a weight that is carried upon the back or head: (TA:) pl. OawoqaArN. (A, Ḳ.) You say, jaMCa yaHomilu wiqorahu He came carrying his load [&c.]. (Ṣ.)
waqarN, or waqurN: see waquwrN.
OucunN waqirapN: see mawoquwrN.
waqoraI: see muwqarN.

waqaArN Gravity, staidness, steadiness, calmness; syn. razaAnapN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and HilomN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) and sakiynapN, and wadaAEapN; (L, TA;) and tayoquwrN↓ is syn. with waqaArN [in this sense], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of the measure fayoEuwlN, (Ḳ,) originally wayoquwrN, (Ṣ,) the w being changed into t: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [see 1:] or, accord. to some, it is syn. with tawoqiyrN. (TA.) El-ʼAjjáj says,
faUino yakuno OamosaI AlbilaI tayoquwriI
i. e. AmsI waqaAriI. [And if wear, or waste, hath become the cause of my gravity,, &c.: or, if it be syn. with tawoqiyriI, the cause of making me still, or quiet]. (Ṣ, TA.) Some make it to be of the measure tafoEuwlN, like taconuwbN, &c. (TA.)
Also, The greatness, or majesty, of God: as in the Ḳur. lxxi. 12. (Ṣ. [See 1, in art. rjw.])
See also waquwrN.

waquwrN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and waqaArN↓, and waqurN↓, (Ḳ,) or waqarN↓, (L,) and mutawaq-irN↓, (TA,) Grave; staid; sedate; calm: applied to a man: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA:) and the first applied also to a woman: (Ḳ:) pl. of the first, wuqurN, (A, TA,) applied to men, (A,) and to women. (TA.)
waqiyrN ‡ Heavily burdened with debt. (TA.)
OucunN waqiyrapN: see mawoquwrN.
janaAnN waAqirN ‡ A heart which fright does not make to flutter. (A.)
tayoquwrN: see waqaArN.

muwqarN [Laden;] having a load: or [heavily laden;] having a heavy load: [as also mawoquwrN↓:] applied to a man: (Ḳ:) and also [the former] applied to a woman, in the same sense: (TA:) or you apply to a woman the epithet muwqarapN, meaning, bearing a heavy burden. (Fr, Ṣ, TA.) You say also daAb-apN waqoraI↓, meaning mawoquwrapN↓ [A beast of carriage laden: or heavily laden]: (Ḳ:) but ISd holds that waqoraI↓ is used elliptically, for caAtu waqoraI, and is an inf. n., of the measure faEolaI, like HaloqaI and EaqoraI. (TA.) [mawoquwrN↓, in the same sense, is also applied to a ship; as in the Expos. of the Jel, ii. 159.]

naxolapN muwqarapN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) and muwqirapN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and muwqirN↓, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) like as one says, UimoraOapN HaAmilN, (Ṣ,) and muwqarN, which is anomalous, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and miyqaArN↓, (Ḳ,) and mawoquwrapN↓, (A,) and muwaq-arapN↓, (Ḳ,) A palm-tree laden, or heavily laden, with fruit; (A, Ḳ;) abounding in fruit: (Ṣ:) pl. [of the first, second, third, and fourth,] mawaAqiru, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and [of myqAr and mwqwrp,] mawaAqiyru. (A.)
See also waqiyrN.
muwqirN, and with p {muwqirapN}: see muwqarN.

sense.ref: pass. part. n. of 2, q. v.

entry.sense: naxolapN muwaq-arapN: see muwoqarN.

hom.sense: mawoquwrN and with p {mawoquwrapN}: see muwqarN.
‡ [A man] dull of hearing: or deaf. (Ṣ.) And OucunN mawoquwarpN ‡ An ear dull of hearing: or deaf: (ISk, A, TA:) as also waqirapN↓, (A,) or waqiyrapN↓. (TA.)

entry.sense: miyqaArN: see muwqarN.
mutawaq-irN: see waquwrN.

hom.sense: 1. waqaSa Eunuqaha, (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AlX-aIoCa, (AʼObeyd, TA,) aor. yaqiSu, (Ks, Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. waqoSN, (Ks, Ṣ, Mgh,) He broke his neck, (Ks, Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) and the thing. (AʼObeyd, TA.) You say also, waqaSato bihi raAHilatuhu [His riding-camel, or she-camel, broke its neck]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) like as you say, xuci AlxiTaAma and xuco biAlxiTaAm: (Ṣ:) and waqaSati Aln-aAqapu biraAkibihaA The she-camel threw her rider and broke his neck. (Mṣb.) And wuqiSa He had his neck broken; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) said of a man; (Ṣ:) [and also] said of a camel, signifying, he became diseased in his back, and without motion: and in like manner said of the neck, and of the back. (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh.) And waqaSotu raOosahu I pressed, or squeezed, his head; sometimes meaning, so as to break the neck. (TA.)
[Hence,] waqaSa Ald-ayonu Eunuqahu ‡ Debt [oppressed him as though it] broke his neck. (TA.)
[Hence also,] Alfarasu yaqiSu AlUikaAma ‡ The horse bruises the hills, or rising grounds: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or breaks the summits thereof: (A:) and in like manner one says of a she-camel. (TA.)
You say also, Ald-aAb-apu tacub-u bicanabihaA fataqiSu EanohaA Alc-ubaAba ‡ The beast of carriage beats off from her with her tail, and kills, the flies. (TA.)

waqaSati AlEunuqu The neck broke: thus the verb is intrans. as well as trans.: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to Ks, one does not say this: (Ṣ:) i. e., one only says of the neck wuqiSat, using the pass. form. (TA.)
waqiSa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yawoqaSu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. waqaSN, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) He (a man, Ṣ) was short in the neck. (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. wq-S EalaI naArihi, (Ṣ, A,) inf. n. tawoqiySN, (TA,) He threw fragments, or broken pieces, of sticks upon his fire: (Ṣ,* A:) or he broke in pieces sticks upon his fire. (TA.)
4. AwqShu He (God) made him to be short in the neck. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

5. twq-S ‡ He went a pace between that called AlEanaq and that called Alxabab; (Ḳ;) falling short of the latter, but exceeding the former, and removing his legs as in the pace called Alxbb, excepting that they were nearer to the ground, and throwing himself [forward]: (AO:) or he trod vehemently in going, (Ḳ, TA,) with short steps, (TA,) as though breaking what was beneath him: (Ḳ, TA:) or he (a horse) bounded (Aṣ, Ṣ, A) in his running, (Aṣ,) making short steps, (Aṣ, Ṣ, A,) as though breaking his steps. (A.) You say, mar-a fulaAnN yatawaq-aSu bihi farasuhu Such a one passed along, his horse bounding, and making short steps, with him. (Ṣ.)

6. twAqS He made himself like, or imitated, him who is short in the neck: (Ḳ:) said of a man. (TA.) Hence, tawaAqaSa EalaI burodatihi kaIo laA tasoqT He bent and shortened himself to hold on his burodap with his neck, that it might not fall. (TA, from a trad.)
waqoSN: see what next follows.

hom.sense: waqaSN ‡ Fragments, or broken pieces, of sticks, which are thrown upon, (Ṣ,) or into, (Ḳ,) a fire: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or small pieces of fire-wood with which a fire is made to burn more vehemently; (A, TA;) as also waqaXN: so, says Aboo-Turáb, I heard Mubtekir say. (TA.)

Also, sing. of OawoqaASN, as used in relation to the [tax called] Sadaqap; signifying ‡ What is between one firiyDap and the next fariyDap: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as, for instance, when camels amount in number to five, one sheep or goat is to be given for them; and nothing is to be given for such as exceed that number until they amount to ten: thus, what is between the five and the ten is termed waqaSN: (Ṣ:) sometimes pronounced waqoSN↓: (Mṣb:) and in like manner, XanaqN: (Ṣ:) or (accord. to some of the learned, Ṣ) wqS relates to bulls and cows particularly, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) or to these and to sheep and goats, (Mṣb,) and Xnq [q. v.] to camels: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb:) both signifying what is between one fryDp and the next: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb:*) or, accord. to Aboo-ʼAmr, (Mgh, L,) i. e. Esh-Sheybánee, (L,) waqaSN signifies camels for which it is incumbent to give sheep or goats in payment of the Sadaqap, (Mgh, L,) when the camels are between five and twenty in number; (L;) but some disapprove of this: (Mgh, L:) accord. to IB, it signifies sheep or goats taken in payment of the Sadaqap for camels. (L.)

You also say, SaAruwA OawoqaASFA † They became scattered, or dispersed: and OataAnaA OawoqaASN mino baniI fulaAnK † There came to us separate portions of the tribe of the sons of such a one: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:*) AwqAS in these cases being a pl., [namely of waqaSN,] like OasobaAbN, pl. of sababN. (TA.)

entry.sense: waqiySapN: see mawoquwSN.
waAqiSapN: see mawoquwSN.

hom.sense: OawoqaSu A man (Ṣ, Mgh) short in the neck; (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ;) naturally so: (TA:) or having the neck inclining and short: (AʼObeyd, TA:) fem. waqoSaMCu. (A, TA.)
xudo OawoqaSa AlT-ariyqayoni ‡ Take thou the nearer of the two ways: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:*) or shorter thereof. (A, TA.)

entry.sense: mawoquwSN A man (Ṣ) having his neck broken: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and so mawoquwSu AlEunuqi: (A:) the fem. is with p {mawoquwSapN}: and waAqiSapN↓ occurs in the sense of mawoquwSapN in a trad. of ʼAlee, in which he is said to have given judgment in the case of the qaAriSap and the qaAmiSap and the waAqiSap↓, that the price of blood, or fine for homicide, should be paid in thirds; these being three girls, who were playing together, and mounted, one upon another; and the lowest pinched the middle one, who thereupon leaped off, so that the uppermost fell, and her neck broke; wherefore he imposed a third of the fine for the killing of the uppermost upon the lowest, and the like upon the middle one, annulling the third of the uppermost because she aided against herself: (Mgh, TA, in art. qrS, and Mṣb,) here, [accord. to those who hold that waqaSa is trans. only,] wAqSp↓ is like raADiyapN, in the phrase EiyXapN raADiyapN; (TA, in art. qrS and in the present art.;) and is used in the place of mwqwSp for the sake of agreement in form with the two other epithets: (Mgh, in art. qrS, and Mṣb:) waqiySapN↓, also, signifies having her neck broken; and its pl. is waqaAYiSu. (Meyd, as in Freytag's Lex., excepting that the pl. is there written waqaAyiSu.) You say also EunuqN mawoquwSapN A broken neck. (Mṣb.) And mawoquwSN is also applied to a camel, signifying, Become diseased in his back, and without motion. (Khálid Ibn-Jembeh.)
1: see 8.
3. wAkO EalaI yadayohi He leaned upon his hands, or arms. Moḥammad was seen to do so when he raised and extended his hands in supplication to God. (IAth.)
4. OawokaOahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiykaACN, (Ṣ,) He set up for him a thing upon which to recline (mut-akaON.) (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
OatokaOahu, (in which t is substituted for w,) inf. n. UitokaAhu, He propped him up by a cushion or other thing whereon to recline; made him recline upon a cushion, &c. (AZ, TA.)

Darabahu faOatokaOahu, (A,) or TaEanahu Hat-aI OatokaOahu, originally OawokaOahu, (Ṣ,) ‡ He smote him, (A,) or pierced him, (Ṣ,) so that he made him fall in a reclining posture: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:*) or, so that he threw him down upon his left side. (Ḳ.)
See 3.
5: see 8.

hom.sense: 8. Ait-akaOa He sat in a firm, or settled, manner: and he sat leaning upon one of his sides: (Mṣb, in art. tkO:) the vulgar know it only in the latter sense: but it signifies he leaned, rested, or stayed, his back, or his side, against, or upon, a thing: and he leaned, rested, or stayed, himself in any manner, upon a thing. (IAth, in Mṣb, art. wkO.)

Ait-akaOa EalaI XaIoCK, (Ṣ,) and twk-O↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and AwkO↓; (Ḳ;) and takiYa↓, [in which t is substituted for w,] aor. yatokaOu, inf. n. takoCN; (Lth;) and wakaOa↓; (CK;) He leaned, or reclined, upon a thing; supported, propped, or stayed, himself upon it. (Ḳ.)
Ait-akaOa He reclined upon a cushion, &c. (TA.)

Ait-akaOa He made for him [i. e., app., for himself,] a thing upon which to lean, or recline: (CK, and a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ:) or he made him to be a thing upon which to lean, or recline. (TA.) [The latter seems to be wrong, unless the verb be read OatokaOa.]
Ait-akaOonaA Einoda fulaAnK ‡ We ate a repast with, or at the abode of, such a one. (TA.)

Ait-akaOato (MF) and tawak-aOato↓ (Ḳ) She (a camel) was taken with the pains of labour, and cried out. (Ḳ.) Accord. to Lth, tawak-uWu Aln-aAqapi signifies tSl-fhA End mxADhA: (TA:) [but it is evident that the right reading is tSl-qhA; and the sense agreeable with the above explanation].

entry.sense: tukaOapN (in which t is substituted for w, TA) A staff, or stick, (Ḳ,) upon which one leans in walking; a walking-stick: (TA:) that upon which one leans or reclines. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
One who reclines much. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
‡ A heavy person [app., in disposition]. (TA.)
mut-akiYN act. part. n. of 8.

laA Mkulu mut-akiYFA I (said Moḥammad) eat not sitting in a firm, or settled, posture, cross-legged, or in such other similar manner as is adapted for much eating: for he used to eat sitting upon his hams, with his shanks erect, so as to be ready to rise. The meaning is not [only] “inclining on one side,” as the vulgar among students imagine. (Ḳ.)
mut-akaO A place in which one reclines: (Ṣ:) a chamber, or sitting-room. (Akh, Ṣ.)
That upon which one leans, or reclines, in eating, drinking, or talking. (Zj.)

‡ Food, or a repast: so called because people used to recline when they sat to eat: but the Muslims are forbidden to do so. [See mut-akiYN.] It is said to have this last meaning in the Ḳur. xii. 31. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. wakaba, aor. yakibu, inf. n. wukuwbN (Ḳ) and wakabaAnN (Ṣ) and wakobN (CK), He walked, went, or marched along, in a leisurely manner, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or, as in some copies of the Ṣ, in a grave and leisurely manner. (TA.) See mawokibN.

wakiba He (an antelope) proceeded at a quick pace, (IḲṭṭ,) [and with long steps: see wakuwbN]. [Thus the verb bears two contr. significations.] Hence the word mawokibN↓ (IḲṭṭ) [as meaning “a certain mode, or manner, of walking, &c.”].
wakaba, inf. n. wakobN, He, or it, stood erect; became erected, set up, raised, or reared: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) he stood. (Ḳ.)

wakaba EalaI AlOamori, and waAkaba↓, (in a copy of the Ṣ, wAkb, which is also mentioned in the sense here following by IḲṭṭ and IM, as stated in the TA,) He kept, attended, or applied himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to the thing, or affair. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

wakiba; and wk-b↓ inf. n. tawokiybN; It (a date) became black when ripe: (Ḳ:) or wakiba signifies, as below, “it (the skin, or a garment,) was dirty, or filthy;” and wk-b↓, it (a grape) became black: (TA: where it is said that this distinction [excepting that the second verb relates to the grape rather than the date] is meant in the Ḳ; the passage presenting what is termed laf-N wanaXorN murat-abN:) or the latter verb signifies it (a grape or a date) showed some degree of blackness. (Az.) See muwak-ibN.
wakiba, aor. yawokabu, inf. n. wakabN, It (the skin, or a garment,) was dirty, or filthy. (TA.) See wakabN.

entry.sense: 2. wak-b, inf. n. tawokiybN, [app., He pursued a middle or just, way with respect to the SiraAr; which is a cord, or a piece of rag, that is bound over a she-camel's udder, or teats, to prevent her young one from sucking her]. (Ḳ: the inf. n. is explained by the words AlmuqaArabapu fiI AlS-iraAri: written in the TA AlSrOr; to which is there added, with kesr.)
See 1.

3. waAkbhumo (inf. n. muwaAkabapN, TA,) He marched, or journeyed, or kept pace, with them; syn. saAyarahumo: or he hastened with them, and strove to be before them; syn. baAdarahumo: (Ḳ:) or he rode with them (Ṣ, Ḳ) in their mawokib [or procession]: (TA:) and also, he contended with them in a race or the like. (Ṣ.)
See 1.

hom.sense: 4. Awkb He (a camel) kept to the mode of walking, [&c.,] or kept with [the kind of procession, called] a mawokib. (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ: [but accord. to the Ḳ, the latter is the meaning intended; or, as said in the TA, he kept with the procession of riders or camels; for which, however, SM knows no authority.])
Awkb He (a bird) rose to fly; ex., Awkb vum-a TaAra. he rose to fly, and then flew: (Er-Riyáshee:) or prepared to fly; (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or flapped his wings while falling. (Ḳ.)
Awkbh He made him angry. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: wakabN The blackness of dates; (Ḳ;) or of grapes, &c., (T,) when they become ripe. (Ḳ, T.) Generally used with reference to grapes. (TA.)
Dirt, or filth, (Ḳ,) upon the skin or upon a garment. (TA.)
ZayobahN wakuwbN also An antelope that keeps to its herd. (TA.)

ZayobahN wakuwbN An antelope proceeding at a quick pace, with long steps; syn. Alt-I tuEoniqu fI sayorihaA: (Ṣ:) and in like manner naAqapN muwaAkibahN↓ a she-camel that proceeds in that manner: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) see wakaba: or the latter signifies a she-camel that journeys, or marches, or keeps pace, with the mawokib: (Ḳ:) that does not lag behind the [company of] riders. (A.)
wak-aAbN A man (TA) grieving, or mourning, much; very sorrowful, sad, or unhappy. (Ḳ.)
waAkibapN i. q. qaAYimapN [app. signifying The leg of a quadruped]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) from wakaba “he stood.” (TA.)
mawokibN A certain mode, or manner, of walking, marching, proceding, or journeying. (Ṣ.) See 1.

A company [or procession] of men, riding or walking [or marching by slow degrees, or gradually; or in a grave manner, and by slow degrees, or gradually]: (Ḳ:) or a party of people riding upon camels, for the sake of pomp, or parade, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or to go forth to the gardens or the like for amusement: (TA:) and in like manner, a company of horsemen, or a cavalcade: (Ṣ:) pl. mawaAkibu. (TA.)
saAra sayora Almawokibi He walked, marched, or journeyed [in the manner, or at the rate, of a ceremonious procession, or by slow degrees, or] without hastening. (TA, from a trad.)
muwak-ibN A date (or grape, TA,) becoming black, when ripe: (Ḳ:) or a grape or date in which the least blackness appears. (Az.)
Also An unripe date that is pricked with a thorn in order that it may ripen. (AḤn.)
muwaAkibapN: see wakuwbN.
mawokuwbN: see 1.

hom.sense: 1. wakata, aor. yakitu, (inf. n. wakatN,) He, or it, made a mark, or impression, or left a mark. (Ḳ.) You say wakata XayoYFA He, or it, made a mark, or impression, or left a mark, upon a thing. (TḲ.)
wakata aor. yakitu, inf. n. wakotN; and wik-t↓, inf. n. tawokiytN; He filled (Ḳ.) a qirobap, (Lḥ,) or a cup, or the like, as also zkt. (Fr.)
wakata, aor. yakitu, inf. n. wakotN, He walked, or went, with short steps. (Sh, Ḳ.)
He (a beast of carriage) raised and put down his feet quickly. (L.)
wakata AlmaXoIa, inf. n. wakotN and wakataAnN, He went, or walked, with short steps, but in a heavy and ugly manner. (L.)
wak-t↓ fiI sayorihi He went with a particular kind of pace. (L, from Kr.)
wakata AlkitaAba, inf. n. wakotN, He pointed, or dotted, the book, writing, or letter. (L.)
2. wak-avati Albusorapu inf. n. tawokiytN, The date became speckled, by reason of its ripening. (Ṣ, M, Ḳ.)
See 1.

entry.sense: wakotN, (Nh, &c.,) or wakotahN, (L,) A mark, (L,) or a small mark, (Nh,) in a thing, resembling a speck (nqTp), of a different colour from the thing itself: (Nh, L:) pl. of the latter [or rather coll. gen. n., of which the latter is the n. un.] wakotN. (L.)
wakotN A little; not much, a little thing. (Sh, Ḳ.)
wakotN and wakotapN A speck that appears in a date by reason of its ripening. (TA.)

wakotapN A speck (nuqoTap) in a thing: (Ḳ:) or what resembles a nuqoTap in a thing: (Ṣ:) a red speck, or spot, in the white of the eye, which, if neglected, becomes a wadoqap: (ISd:) or a white speck, or spot, in the black of the eye: (TA:) you say, fiI Eyonihi wktpN [In his eye is a speck, &c.]. (Ṣ.)
fiI qalobiI wakotapN mim-aA qulota ‡ On my heart is a slight impression made by what thou saidst. (A.)

wukotapN i. q. furoDapu zanodK (Ḳ: in the CK, faroDp) [app., The notch in a wooden instrument for striking fire; as understood by Golius: but accord. to the TA, the notch, or the like, in the joint called znd of a camel].
wakiytN The act of calumniating, or slandering, syn. siEaAyapN and wiXaAyapN, (Ḳ,) to one possessed of command, or power. (TA.)

rajalN wak-aAtN, mentioned by Kr; thought by ISd to be from wakata AlmaXoIa; [and therefore to signify A man who walks, or goes, with short steps, but in a heavy and ugly manner]; because were it by the phrase mentioned by Kr [i. e. wak-t fI syrh] it would be muwak-itN. (TA.)
waAkitN, in a camel, i. q. naAkitN. (Ḳ.)
mawokuwtN ‡ Changed in colour (kamidN) by reason of anxiety, or grief: (Ḳ:) or changed in colour (kamidN), and full of malevolence, and of anxiety, or grief. (TA.)
EayonN mawoquwtpN An eye in which is a wakotap. (A, &c.)

busorapN muwak-itapN, and muwak-itN, (the latter on the authority of Seer, TA) A date speckled, or becoming speckled, by reason of its ripening. (T, M, Ḳ.) When it is speckled in the part next the stalk, it is called mucan-ibapN (TA.) See busorN.
10. Astwkv He ate of what is called wkAv: (Ḳ:) he hastened, and ate somewhat of that which is called wkAv, thereby to attain the period of the morning-meal called AlgadaMC. (L.)

wikaAvN and wukaAvN Food, aliment, or nutriment, (gicaMCN: so in some copies of the Ḳ, and in the TA: in the CK, gadaMCN, or a morning meal:) that is prepared, or taken, in haste, (yusotaEojalu bihi,) [before the morning-meal called gadaMC: see 10]. (Ḳ.)
10. AstwkHt AlfiraAxu The young birds became big, bulky, or coarse. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
wukuHN Big, bulky, or coarse, young birds: (Ḳ:) after the manner of a rel. n., as though pl. of waAkiHN, or wakuwHN, since it cannot be pl. of musotawokiHN. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. wakada, aor. yakidu, inf. n. wukuwdN, He remained, continued, stayed, abode, or dwelt, (L, Ḳ,) bimakaAnK in a place. (L.)
See 2.

wakada OamorFA, (L, Ḳ,*) aor. yakidu, inf. n. wakodN, (L,) He aimed at a thing; sought, endeavoured after, or pursued, it; desired it; intended it, or purposed it; syn. qaSada (L, Ḳ) and Talaba. (L.) See also below.
wakada wakodahu He directed his course to, or towards, him, or it; or he pursued his (another's) course; syn. qaSada qaSodahu; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) doing as he did. (L.)
wakada OamorFA, aor. and inf. n. as above, also signifies He laboured at, and endeavoured after, a thing. (L.)
wakada, (L, Ḳ,) aor. yakidu, inf. n. wakodN, (L,) i. q. OaSaAba He, or it, did, or went, right; attained an object; hit, struck, smote, affected, hurt, befell; [&c.]. (L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2. wk-d, (Ṣ, L,) inf. n. tawokiydN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [and wakada↓ as is implied in the Ḳ, but app. by the unintentional omission of the word wak-ada;] and Awkd↓, inf. n. UiykaAdN; (Ṣ, L;) He made a horse's saddle, (Ṣ, L,) and a camel's, (L, Ḳ,) firm, fast, or strong; or bound or tied it firmly, fastly, or strongly; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) as also Oak-ada and Mkada: but more chaste with w. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.*)

Also, He confirmed, ratified, or corroborated, a compact, a contract, a covenant, or an engagement; as also Ak-d (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and Mkd: but, in this sense also, more chaste with w; (Ṣ, L;) or in this sense more approved with O: (L:) and in like manner wk-d he confirmed an oath: you say, UicaA Eaqadota faOak-ido wUicaA Halafota fawak-ido When thou makest a contract, ratify; and when thou swearest, confirm.
4: see 2.
OawokadataAhu yadaAhu His arms, or hands, exercised him with work. From a trad., relating to a seeker of knowledge. (L.)
5. twk-d AlOamoru and tOk-d signify the same, [The thing, or affair, became confirmed, ratified, or corroborated]. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.*)
wakodN Desire; purpose; intention; aim; endeavour. (L, Ḳ.) See also 1.
wukodN Work; labour; exertion; endeavour. (L, Ḳ.) Ex. maA zaAla celika wukodiI That ceased not to be my work, (L, Ḳ,) and endeavour. (L.)
wikaAdN A rope with which cows are tied on the occasion of milking. (Ṣ, L.)

Also wikaAdN and UikaAdN sings. of wakaAYidu [and OakaAYidu], (IDrd, L, Ḳ,) [pls. deviating from the constant course of speech in relation to the sings.; see art. Okd;] signifying, (i. e. the pls.,) Thongs, or straps, with which one binds (L, Ḳ) a camel's, or horse's saddle: (L:) or the thongs, or straps, by which the qarabuws is bound to the two side-boards of a horse's saddle; (IDrd, L;) as also mayaAkiydu↓ and taMkiydu and tawakiydu↓; (Ḳ;) or these are called myAkyd, but not twAkyd: (L:) and it [myAkyd] is a pl. that has no [proper] sing. (TA.)
muwaAkidapN A she-camel that strives, or exerts herself, in her progress, course, or pace. (Ḳ.)
mayaAkiydu and tawakiydu: see wikaAdN.
mutawak-idN biOamorK, (L,) or liOamorK, (Ḳ,) Standing ready, or prepared, for a thing, or an affair (L, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. wakara, aor. yakiru, inf. n. wakorN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and wukuwrN, (Ḳ,) He (a bird) came to the wakor [or nest]: (Ḳ:) or entered his wakor. (Ṣ.)

wakara, (Mgh, Mṣb,) aor. yakiru, (Mṣb,) He (a bird) took for himself, or made, or prepared, (Uit-axc,) a wakor; (Mgh, Mṣb;) as also wk-r↓, (A, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. tawokiyrN; (TA;) but the latter has an intensive signification; (Mṣb;) and Uit-akara↓. (Ḳ.) Oawokara in this sense is a mistake. (Mgh.)
wakara, aor. yakiru; (Ḳ;) or wk-r↓, (A, L, Mṣb,) inf. n. tawokiyrN; (Fr, Ṣ, L;) He made, or prepared, the food called wakiyrap; (Fr, Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb;) lahumo for them. (L, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, in two places.
See also wakiyrapN, in two places.
8: see 1.

wakorN The nest (EuX-) of a bird; (AA, Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) wherever it is; in a mountain or a tree; (AA, Ṣ, Mṣb;) and so if the bird is not in it; (M, A, Ḳ;) as also wakorapN↓: (Ḳ:) the place in which a bird lays its eggs, and has, or hatches, its young; being a hole in a wall, or in a tree: (T, TA:) the place into which the bird enters; as also wakonN: (Aṣ, TA:) [see also EuX-N; and sarabN:] pl. (of pauc., TA:) OawokurN (Ḳ) and OawokaArN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and (of mult., TA) wukuwrN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and wikaArN (Mṣb) and wukarN. (Ḳ.) You say, buyuwtN kaOawokAri AlT-ayori [Houses like the nests of birds]. (A.)
‡ [A house: as in the following saying,] maA daAra fiI fikoriInuzuwluka fiI wakoriI ‡ [Thine alighting at my house was not revolved in my mind]. (A.) See also wakiyrapN.
The faroD [q. v.] of a zanodap. (A, in art. frD.)
naAqapN wakaraI: see jam-aAzN.

hom.sense: wakorapN: see wakorN.
See also wakiyrapN.

entry.sense: wakarapN: see wakiyrapN.
wakiyrN: see wakiyrapN.

wakiyrapN Food that is prepared on account of the completion of a building; (Ṣ,* Mṣb,* Ḳ;) as also wakiyrN↓ and wakorapN↓ and wakarapN↓: (Ḳ:) food which a man prepares on the occasion of building his wakor [or house], or buying it, (A, TA,) and to which he invites [others]: (TA:) accord. to Fr, [food] prepared by a woman among the requisites for a bride or a traveller (fiI AljahaAzi); sometimes, he says, called tawokiyrN: which latter word also signifies the act of feeding [with the food called wikiyrap]. (TA.)

1. wakazahu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. yakizuhu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. wakozN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) He struck, or beat him, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) [with anything,] as, for ex., with a staff, or stick: (TA:) or it signifies, (Mṣb,) or signifies also (Ṣ) he struck, or beat, him with his fist upon his chin: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) or, accord. to Ks, i. q. lakamahu; (Mṣb;) [i. e.] he struck, or beat, him with his fist. (A, Ḳ.)
He pushed, or impelled, or repelled, him. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
He pierced him (Ks, Ḳ,* TḲ) with a spear. (TḲ.)
He goaded him. (TA.)
He broke his nose. (T, TA.)
wakozapN A blow with the fist. (A.)
wak-aAzN One who strikes, or beats, much with his fist. (A.)
mutawak-izN biOamorK Standing ready, or prepared, for a thing, or an affair. (L, art. wkd.)

1. wakasa, aor. yakisu, inf. n. wakosN, It (a thing, Ṣ, Mṣb) was, or became, defective, or deficient; it fell short; it diminished, or decreased. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.) It is said in a trad., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) of Ibn-Mesʼood, (TA,) lahaA mahoru mivolihaA laA wakos walaA XaTaTa She shall have the dowry of her like: there shall be no falling short nor exceeding: (Ṣ, A,* Mṣb,* TA:) or there shall be no diminishing nor exceeding of the limit. (Mgh.) [For] wakasahu, aor. and inf. n. as above, signifies He rendered it defective, or deficient; diminished it, or decreased it; (A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also wk-shu↓, (TḲ,) inf. n. tawokiysN. (Ḳ, TḲ.)

He made him (a man) to suffer loss; syn. naqaSahu; (Ṣ, TA;) as also wk-shu↓ inf. n. tawokiysN: (Ḳ,* TA:) or he cheated, or defrauded him. (IḲṭṭ, TA.) You say, wukisa fiI tijaAratihi, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. wakosN, (TA,) He suffered loss, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, TA,) or diminution of the price, (TA,) [in his traffic, or merchandise;] as also Ouwkisa↓, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiykaAsN; (TA;) and so wakasa, aor. (Ḳ) and inf. n. (TA) as above. (Ḳ, TA.)
2. wk-shu, inf. n. tawokiysN: see 1, in two places.
Also, He reproved, or blamed, him, or did so severely; or with the utmost severity; or he reproached, or upbraided him. (AA, Ḳ.)
4. Oawokasa, (A,) or Oawokasa maAluhu, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, A, Ḳ,) His property went away. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, A, Ḳ.)
Ouwkisa fiI tijaAratihi: see 1.

Oawokasu [More, and most, defective, or deficient: less, and least, in value]. The saying respecting the division of a building, yanoZaru UilaI SaAHibi AlOawokasi means, One shall look to see which is he whose place is of the less, or least, value. (Mgh.)
A man having a small portion, or little good fortune: (A:) or a low, an ignoble, or a mean, or sordid, man. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
1. walaba, aor. yalibu, inf. n. wuluwbN, He entered (Ḳ) into a house or tent, or into a tract, or quarter, or the like. (TA.)
walaba He hastened (Ḳ) in entering. (TA.)

walaba Uilayoka AlX-aIoCu, aor. yalibu, inf. n. wuluwbN, The thing, of whatever kind it was, came to thee, or reached thee. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ.) In the copies of the Ḳ, walaba AlX-aIoCa wUilayoka; accord. to which, the verb, in the sense of waSala, there assigned to it, is trans. both immediately and by means of UilaI: but the correct reading is wlb AlykAlXIC, as above. In an old, and generally correct, copy of the Tahdheeb el-Af'ál of IḲṭṭ, it is said that wlb Alyk AlX-ar-u signifies The evil reached thee: syn. tawaS-ala. (TA.)
walaba, inf. n. wuluwbN and walobN, It (corn or the like) germinated in offsets around the older plants. (IḲṭṭ.)
walaba bnw fulaAnK The sons of such a one multiplied, or increased. (IḲṭṭ.)
waAlibN, Going into a thing; entering into it. (Esh-Sheybánee, Ṣ.)

waAlibapN The offsets of the corn and the like: (Ḳ:) so called because they enter into the roots of the parent-plants: (TA:) or corn or the like growing from the roots of that which has preceded it: (Ṣ:) pl. OawaAlibu. (TA.)
waAlibapN The offspring of camels, (IAạr, Ṣ,) and of sheep or goats, (IAạr, Ḳ,) and of cows, (Ḳ,) and of a people. (IAạr.)
tawolabu: see art. tlb. Accord. to Suh, the t is substituted for w, and the word is derived from wAlyp, the “offsets of corn and the like:” and Ibn-ʼOsfoor and IḲṭṭ assert the same. (TA.)
4: see 1.
1. walavatonaA Als-amaACu, [aor. talivu,] inf. n. walovN, The sky wetted us with a little rain. (TA.)

walavahu, aor. yalivu, (Ṣ,) inf. n. walovN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He beat, struck, or smote, him, (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ,) with a staff, or stick, (AA, Ṣ,) a little: (Aṣ:) or he beat him, or struck him, without wounding him. (Aboo-Murrah El-Kusheyree.)

walava lahu EaqodFA He made with him a covenant, compact, or contract, that was unintentional, or not firmly concluded, or settled. (Ṣ.) walava lahumo, [aor. yalivu,] inf. n. walovN, He gave them, or granted them, somewhat of a covenant, compact, or contract. (TA.)
walava, [aor. yalivu?] inf. n. walovN, He concluded a covenant, compact, or contract. (TA.)
walava lahu, aor. yalivu, inf. n. walovN, He made to him a weak promise. (TA.)
walava fulaAnN lanaA mino OamorinaA, inf. n. walovN, Such a one appointed the manner of somewhat of our affair for us; syn. waj-aha. (TA.)
walava limamoluwkihi EitoqFA, [aor. yalivu, inf. n. walovN,] He promised his slave manumission after his death, saying, Thou art free after my death. (ISh.)
walovN A little of rain: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) ex. OaSaAbanaA walovN mino maTarK A little rain fell upon us. (Ṣ.)
walovu Als-aHaAbi A little rain. (TA.)

walovN A covenant, compact, or contract, between a people, that happens unintentionally, mino gayori qaSodK: (Ṣ:) or, not firmly concluded, or settled: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or somewhat, or a little, of a covenant, compact, or contract: ex., in a trad., lawo laA walovN laka mina AlEahodi laDarabotu Eunuqaka Were it not for somewhat, or a little, of a covenant granted to thee, I had beheaded thee: (TA:) or the remainder [or what remains unfulfilled] of a covenant, &c.: (T:) or a covenant, &c. firmly concluded, or settled. (TA.)
walovN A little of anything that is much in quantity. (IAạr.)
walovN What remains, of dough, in a platter. (Ḳ.)
What remains, of water, in a muXaq-ar. (Ḳ.)
What remains, of the beverage called nabiyc, in the vessel. (Ḳ.)
walovN A weak promise. (Ḳ [See 1. In the CK, and in a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, for AlwaEodu is put Alwagodu.])
You also say lahumo walovN DaEiyfN, and walovN muHokamN, [A weak promise has been made to them, and a firm promise]. (TA.)
walovN A vestige, or trace, of ophthalmia. (Ḳ.)
lamo Oara manohu Uil-aA walovapF↓ I saw not, of him, or it, aught save a small vestige, or trace. (A.)
walovN i. q. tawojiyhN; i. e., The saying to a slave (mamoluwk), Thou art free after my death. (Ḳ.)
walovapN: see walovN.
EinodiI walovapN mino xabarK I have a little news. (TA.)
Xar-N waAlivN A lasting, or constant, evil. (Ḳ.)

dayonN waAlivN, an expression used by Ru-beh, (TA,) A burdensome debt: (Ḳ:) or a lasting, or constant, debt: (IAạr:) or, as some say, a debt by which one constantly binds himself (yatafal-aduhu), as he does by a contract. (L.) Aṣ disapproves of the expression. (TA.)

1. walaja, aor. yaliju, inf. n. wuluwjN and lijapN; and Uit-alaja↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and twl-j↓; (L;) He, or it, entered. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say walaja Albayota, and At-ljh↓, and twl-jhu↓, He entered the house. (L.) And walaja AlX-aIoCu fiI gayrihi The thing entered into another thing. (Mṣb.) As is said in the Ṣ and L, Sb says that walaja has for its inf. n. wuluwjN, which is of one of the measures of the inf. ns. of intrans. verbs, because the meaning [of walajotu Albayota] is walajotu fiyhi: and it is said in the M, that Sb holds the intermediate particle to be dropped: but Moḥammad Ibn-Yezeed holds the verb to be trans. without an intermediate particle. MF observes, that Sb's words appear to make wlj a trans. verb, which no one asserts it to be: that if he mean that it has as its complement a noun in the acc. case as an adverbial noun of place, it is like daxalotu and other intrans. verbs: but if he mean that it governs a simple objective complement, like Darabotu zayodFA, his opinion is not correct. (TA.)

4. Awlj, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. UiylaAjN; (Mṣb;) and Uit-alaja↓, (as in the CK and in several MṢ. copies of the Ḳ) or Oatolaja, (as in the L, and all the copies of the Ḳ consulted by SM, in this art., and in art. tlj,) in which t is substituted for w, and this is the correct reading; (TA;) He, or it, caused to enter; introduced; inserted. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

The expression in the Ḳur. [xxii. 60; and other chapters,] yuwliju Qll-ayla fiI Aln-ahaAri wayuwliju Aln-ahaAra fiI Qll-ayoli signifies He maketh the night, by increasing it, to enter into, [or encroach upon,] the day, and maketh the day, in like manner, to enter into, [or encroach upon,] the night: (Jel:) or He increaseth the night with a part of the day, by taking from the latter and adding to the former, and in like manner increaseth the day with a part of the night. (Ṣ.)
[Awlj is often used for Awlj ckrh; and hence as meaning Inivit.]
5: see 1.
8: see 1 and 4.
rajulN xurajapN wulajahN, (Ṣ,) and xar-aAjN wal-aAjN↓, and xaruwjN waluwjN↓, (TA,) A man frequently going, or coming, out and in. (Ṣ, TA.) [This is the primary meaning: for others see art. xrj.]

walajapN A place, (Ṣ,) or a cavern, in which passengers shelter themselves from rain, &c.: pl. OawolaAjN and walajN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) [or rather the latter, which is omitted in the CK, is a coll. gen. n., of which wljp is the n. un.] or wulujN. (L.)
Also, A bend, or place of bending, of a valley: (IAạr:) pl. as above. (Ḳ.)
waluwjN and wal-aAjN: see wulojapN.
waliyjapN Anything that is introduced, or inserted, into a thing, and that does not belong to it: any such thing is termed a wlyjp of a thing. (AʼObeyd.)
huwa waliyjatuhumo He is an adherent to them; (Ḳ;) [one who has entered, or become introduced, or included, among them,] and not belonging to them. (TA.) Pl. walaAYiju. (TA.)

waliyjapN † A particular, or special, intimate, friend, or associate, of a man; syn. xaAS-apN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and biTaAnapN (Ṣ) and daxiylapN: (Ḳ:) by these syns. AʼObeyd explains it in the Ḳur. ix. 16: and it is applied to one and to more than one: (TA:) or one whom a person takes to rely upon, or to place confidence in, not being of his family: (Ḳ:) and so some explain the word in the verse above referred to: (TA:) or it there signifies an intimate friend who is one of the polytheists. (Fr.)

waAlijapN i. q. dubayolapN, (Ḳ,) i. e., A certain disease in the belly. (TA.) A pain that attacks a man; or a pain in a man; wajaEN yaOoxucu AlUinosaAna, (so in two copies of the Ṣ, and in the L,) or wajaEN fiI AlUinosaAni: (so in the TA and a MṢ. copy of the Ḳ:) or a pain that attacks the teeth; or a pain in the teeth; wjE yOxc AlOasonaAna, (so in a copy of the Ṣ,) or wjE fI AlOasonaAni. (So in the CK.)
Oawolaju [More, or most, penetrating]: applied to language or discourse. [TA, in art. jmE: see an ex. voce mujomaEN.]

tawolajN The hiding place of a wild beast, (or antelope, TA,) among trees, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) into which he enters (Al-aciI yalij fiyhi); like dawolajN: the t, says Sb, is substituted for w, and the word is of the measure fawoEalN; for tafoEalN is scarcely found in Arabic as the measure of a subst., whereas fawoEalN is frequent. (Ṣ.)
mawolijN A place of entrance; a place into which one enters: (TA:) pl. mawaAliju. (Ṣ.) [See its contr. maxorajN.]
mawoluwjN A man attacked by the disease called waAlijap, or dubayolap. (Ḳ, TA.)

waliyHapN A [sack of the kind called] giraArap: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) or such as is called a juwaAliq: or a large and wide jwAlq: (L:) and a date-basket of palm-leaves; syn. jul-apN: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) and a sack or the like forming one half of a beast's load, in which are carried perfumes and clothes (baz-) and the like: (L:) n. un. of waliyjN, pl. walaAYiHu. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)

1. waladato, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. talidu, (L, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. wilaAdahN and walaAdN (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and walaAdahN and walaAdN, but each is more common with kesr, (Mṣb,) and UilaAdahN and mawolidN (L, Ḳ) and lidapN, (Ḳ,) [and app. miylaAdN, like miqodaArN, (see an ex. voce tilaAdN, in art. tld,)] She (a woman, Ṣ, L, or mother, L, or any animal having an ear, as distinguished from one having merely an car-hole, Mṣb,) brought forth a child, or young one; or children, young, or offspring. (Mṣb.)
Also, wlada, (aor. as above, Mṣb,) He begot a child, or young one;, &c. (Th, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
OaroDu AlbaloqaMCi talidu Alz-aEofaraAna ‡ [The land of El-Balkà produces saffron]. (A.)
All-ayaAliI HabaAlaI layosa yudoraImaA yalidona ‡ [The nights are pregnant: it is not known what they will bring forth]. (A.)
[lamo yalodihi occurs in a verse cited voce rub-a, for lamo yalidohu; like lm Oajodi for lamo Oajido.]

2. wl-dhA, inf. n. tawoliydN, He assisted her [namely a woman, A, L, Mṣb, and a ewe or she-goat, Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, or other animal, Mṣb] in bringing forth; delivered her of her child or young one: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ *:) he acted as a midwife to her. (L.)
wldhA OawolaAdFA He made her to be the mother of children. (MA.) See 4.

wl-dhu, (inf. n. tawoliydN, Ḳ,) He reared him; educated him; brought him up. The Christians (as Th says, T, L) have corrupted, in the Gospel, God's saying to Jesus, on whom be peace! Oanota nabiy-aI waOanaA wal-adotuka [in the CK, erroneously, wladotk,] Thou art my prophet, and I reared thee: altering it thus, Ant bunay-aI wAnA waladotuka [Thou art my little son, and I begot thee]; attributing to Him a son. (T,* L, Ḳ.*)
wl-d ‡ He innovated, or originated, language, and a story or the like. (A.) † [It (a thing) generated, engendered, produced, or originated, another thing.]
4. Awldt, (inf. n. UiylaAdN, Mṣb,) She (a woman, Ṣ, L, Mṣb, and a ewe or goat, L) attained to the time of bringing forth; was about to bring forth. (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ.*)
Awld Alqawomu The people attained to the time of [their having] children. (IḲṭṭ.)
Awld AljaAriyapa He made the girl to be the mother of a child. (MA.) See 2.
5. twl-d AlX-aIoCu mina AlX-aIoCi, (Ṣ,) or Eano gayorihi, (Mṣb,) † The thing became generated, or engendered, or produced; it originated; from the other thing. (Mṣb.)
twl-dt AlEaSabiy-apu bayonahumo ‡ [Party-spirit originated, or became engendered, among them]. (A.)
6. twAldwA They multiplied, or became numerous, [by propagation,] and begot one another; (Ṣ, L;) as also At-ldwA↓. (TA.)
8: see 6.
10. AstwldhA He rendered her pregnant; got her with child. AwldhA in this sense is not of established authority; and some expressly disallow it. (Mṣb.)
walodN: see waladN.
wulodu rajulK, and wiloduhu↓, A man's people, tribe, or family. So, accord. to some, in the Ḳur. lxxi. 20. (T.)
See waladN.
wilodN: see wulod, and waladN.

waladN (of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, Mṣb) and wulodN↓ (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and wilodN↓ (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and walodN↓, (Ḳ,) each used alike as sing. and pl., (Ṣ, M, A, L, Ḳ,) and masc. and fem., (M, L, Mṣb,) A child, son, daughter, youngling, or young one; and children, sons, daughters, offspring, young, or younglings; of any kind: [often applied to an unborn child,, &c.; a fœtus:] (M, L, Mṣb:) pl. [of pauc.] of waladN, (M, L, Mṣb, TA,) and of wulodN, (M, L,) OawolaAdN; (M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and [pl. of pauc. of waladN,] wilodapN and UilodapN: (M, L, Ḳ:) and pl. of waladN, wulodN, (Ṣ, M, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) like as OusodN is pl. of OasadN, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb,) in the dial. of the tribe of Keys, (T, Mṣb,) who make waladN singular. (T.)

wuloduki↓ mano dam-aI Eaqibayoki, a proverb, (T, Ṣ, L; but in the Ṣ, Eaqibayoka;) of the Benoo-Asad, (Ṣ, L,) Thy son is he who made thy two heels to be smeared with blood; (TA;) i. e., whom thou thyself broughtest forth; (Ḳ, TA;) he is thy son really; not he whom thou hast taken from another, and adopted. (TA.)
maA OadoriI OaI-u waladi Alr-ajul huwa I know not what man he is. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

lidapN, in which the p is a substitute for the w that is elided from the beginning, for it is from AlwilaAdapu, (Ṣ, L,) or, accord. to some, it is from ladI, q. v., (TA,) applied to a male and to a female, (TA, voce tirobN,) i. q. tirobN; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) meaning One born at the same time with another; coëtanean, or a contemporary in birth (TA) of a man: (Ṣ, L:) dual lidaAni; (Ṣ, L;) [but lidapN occurs in a dual sense in the Jm and O and Ḳ, voce SawogN, q. v.;] pl. lidaAtN and liduwna: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) AḤei and other expositors of the Tesheel say, that words like ldp have the latter form of pl. when they become proper names. (TA.) The dim. [of the pl.] is wulayodaAtN and wulayoduwna, (Ḳ,) because the formation of a dim. restores a word to its original form; (TA;) not luday-aAtN and luday-uwna, as some of the Arabs erroneously make it: (Ḳ:) but this which F pronounces an error is accordant to the authority of the leading writers on inflexion, who say that by regarding the original form, and restoring it thereto, the word is made to depart from the meaning intended by it; for if its dim. were made wulayodN, there would be no difference between it and the dim. of waladN. (TA.) See also art. ldI.
See miylaAdN.
wilaAdN and walaAdN: see 1.
Pregnancy: (A, L, in which the former only is mentioned, and Mṣb:) the former is the more common. (Mṣb.)
waluwdN [Prolific; that breeds, or brings forth, plentifully.] (Ṣ, Ḳ, art. Obd.)
See waAlidN.

waliydN (of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, TA,) and mawoluwdN↓ signify the same, (T, L, Ḳ,) i. e., A new-born child: (M, L:) a young infant: (the former in the L, and the latter in the Mṣb:) the former, as well as the latter, masc.: (M, L:) or, accord. to some, the former is applied also to a female: as also waliydapN↓ and mawoluwdapN↓: pl. of wlyd, wilodaAnN; and of wlydp. (L.)
Alwaliydu fiI Aljan-api The child that dies in early infancy, or that is prematurely born, is in paradise. (L, from a trad.)

Also waliydN, walaAYidu. A boy: (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ:) a youth: (AHeyth, L:) ‡ a boy who has arrived at the age when he is fit for service, before he attains to puberty: (A, L:) a youthful servant; one is so called from the time of his birth until he attains to manhood:
the servant of a man in paradise is a wlyd always, never changing in age: (L:) a slave; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) or, as some say, one born in servitude: (TA:) fem. in these senses, with p {waliydapN}: (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ:) a female slave is called wlydp even if aged: (L:) pl. (of the masc., Ṣ, L) wilodaAnN (Ṣ, L, Ḳ) and wilodahN; (L;) and (of the fem.,: Ṣ, L) walaAYidu. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.)
See also muwal-adN.
Oum-u Alwaliydi The domestic hen. (Ḳ.)

humo fiI Oamori laA yunaAdaI waliyduhu (Ṣ, L, Ḳ *) [They are in a case, or an affair, wherein (lit. whereof) the boy, or servant-boy, or slave, will not be called out to]: a proverb, (L,) originally meaning, they are in a case of difficulty or distress, such that the mother forgets her child, and does not call out to him: and afterwards applied to any case of difficulty or distress: (M, L:) or they are in a formidable case, in which children are not called out to, but those advanced in age: (AO, or Aṣ, M, L:) and sometimes it means, they are in such a state of abundance and affluence that if a wlyd put forth his hand to take a thing he is not chidden away from it: (M, L:) or it is applied to a case of good and to one of evil, and means, they are so occupied with their case or affair that if a wlyd put forth his hand to the most valuable of things he is not called out to for the purpose of chiding him: (Ḳ:) some say, that its original reference is to the running of horses; because a fleet and excellent horse goes without being called out to; and that it is secondarily applied to any case of great moment, and to any case of abundance. (Ṣ, L.)

One also says, fiI AlOaroDi EuXobN laA yunaAdaI waliyduhu [In the land is fresh herbage respecting which the servant-boy, or slave, will not be called out to]; because it matters not in what part of such land the beasts are; the whole abounding with herbage: and jaAWuwA biTaEaAmK laA yunaAdaI waliyduhu [They brought food respecting which the servant-boy, or slave, would not be called out to]; meaning, that one would not care what injury he might do to it, nor when he ate of it. (ISk, L.)

Muzarrid Eth-Thaalebee says,
tabar-aOotu mano Xatomi Alr-ijaAli bitawobapK
UilaI Qll-ehi min-iI laA yunaAdaI waliyduhaA
[I have become clear of the vice of reviling men, by my turning unto God with repentance respecting which the servant (myself) will not be called out to]; meaning, respecting which I shall not be questioned. (ISk, L)
waliydapN: see waliydN.

wuluwdiy-apN, (IAạr, L, Ḳ,) an inf. n. which has no verb, (Th, L,) and waluwdiy-apN (Ḳ) and waliydiy-apN, which, accord. to Th, is the original form, and walaAdapN↓, (L,) Infancy: (IAạr, L, Ḳ:) boyhood; girlhood: the state of a waliyd or waliydap. (L.) Ex. faEala celika fiI wuluwdiy-atihi, and waluwdiy-atihi, He did that in his infancy: (El-Basáïr:) and fiI waliydiy-atihi when he was a waliyd. (L.)
wuluwdiy-apN (L, Ḳ) and waluwdiy-apN (L) Rudeness; coarseness; hardness; churlishness; deficiency in gentleness, (L, Ḳ,) and in knowledge of affairs: (L:) illiterateness. (L.)
SuHobapu fulaAnK wal-aAdapN liloxiyri ‡ [The society of such a one is very productive of good.] (A.)

waAlidN and waAlidapN, (M, L, Ḳ) the former as a possessive epithet, and the latter as an act. part. n. (M, L.) A woman, and any pregnant animal, having a child or young one, or children or young; and bringing forth. (Th, M, L.)

Also waAlidN A father: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb:) and a mother; (L;) as also waAlidapN; (Ṣ, L, Mṣb;) [which latter is the more common in this sense:] pl. of the former, waAliduwna; and of the latter, waAlidaAtN: (Mṣb:) the dual waAlidaAni signifies the two parents; the father and mother. (Ṣ, L, Mṣb.)

XaApN waAlidN A pregnant ewe or goat; (ISk, Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;*) as also waAlidapN and waluwdN↓: (L, Ḳ:) pl. wulodN, (as in the L, and most other lexicons, accord. to the TA, and in some copies of the Ḳ,) or wul-adN, (as in the A, and in other copies of the Ḳ,) each of which is correct. (TA.)
Also, A prolific ewe or goat; that breeds, or brings forth, plentifully; (Nh, L;) [as also waluwdN↓: see Ṣ, Ḳ, art. Obd: see also an ex. of waluwdN, applied to a woman, voce OasowaOu.]
