mino Xar-i waAlidK wamaA walada, occurring in a trad. respecting prayer for God's protection, [lit., From the evil of a parent and what he hath begotten,] is said to mean Iblees and the devils: (L:) or Adam and the true friends and the prophets and the martyrs and the believers whom he hath begotten. (El-Basáïr.)
mawolidN The place of birth (T, Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb) of a man. (Ṣ, L, &c.)
See also miylaAdN.
muwlidN [A woman, and] a ewe or she-goat, (L,) about to bring forth: (L, Ḳ:*) pl. mawaAlidu and mawaAliydu. (L, Ḳ.)

miylaAdN The time of birth (T, Ṣ, M, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) of a man; (Ṣ, L, &c.;) as also mawolidN↓, (T, M, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and lidapN↓: (Ḳ:) but this last is mentioned only in the Ḳ, and requires proof. (TA.)
[See also 1, of which it is app. an inf. n.]
mawoluwdN: see waliydN.

rajulN muwal-adN, (Ṣ, L, Mṣb,) and Earabiy-apN muwal-adapN, (Ṣ, L,) A man, and an Arab female, not of mere Arabian extraction: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb:) or muwal-adN (L) and its fem. muwal-adahN (M, L, Ḳ) signify a boy, or slave-boy, (L,) and a girl, or slave-girl, (M, L,) born among the Arabs; (M, L, Ḳ;) as also waliydN↓ (M, L) and waliydapN: (M, L, Ḳ:) or a boy, or slave-boy, and a girl, or slave-girl, who has been born among the Arabs, and has grown up with their children, and been educated, disciplined, or bred, in their manner: (A, L:) or the latter, mwl-dp, signifies one born in a country in [and of] which is only her father or her mother: (ISh, L:) or one born at thine own abode, or home; (ISh, T, Ṣ, in art. tld;) like tilaAdN: (Ṣ, art. tld:) or born in the territory of the Muslims. (Mgh, art. tld.)

XaAEir muwal-adN ‡ [A post-classical poet;] a poet of the last of the four classes; of the class next after the UisolaAmiy-uwn; also called muHodavN: (Mz, 49th nwE:) called by the former appellation [as well as the latter] because of his recent age. (L, Ḳ.) [It is difficult to mark the exact line of distinction between the Islámees and the Muwelleds, so as always to be certain to which of these two classes a poet belongs. The latter are those born, not merely since the first corruption of the Arabic language, which happened in, or before, the age of Moḥammad, (see Mz, 44th nwE,) but since the extensive corruption which happened after the Arabs had spread themselves, by their conquests, among foreigners, in consequence of which their language became simplified. This change took place in the latter half of the first century of the Flight. Hence the poetry of the Muwelleds in not cited as authoritative in lexicology or grammar, or as to the metres of verse, or rhymes. (See XaAhidN.)] Ibn-Rasheek mentions, as the most famous of the Muwelleds, El-Ḥasan (surnamed Aboo-Nuwás) Ḥabeeb, El-Bohturee, Ibn-Er-Roomee, Ibn-El-Moatezz, and El-Mutanebbee: [the first of whom died in the year of the Flight 195, or -6, or -8]. Aboo-ʼAmr Ibn-El-ʼAlà [who died in the year of the Flight 154, or -9,] termed El-Farezdaḳ and Jereer Muwelleds, in comparison with the Pagan poets and the Mukhadrams, though others call them Islámees. (Mz, 49th nwE.)

kalaAmN muwal-adN ‡ [Post-classical,] or innovated, or modern, or modernized, language; (L;) language which is not of the original dialect of the Arabs; (A;) language which is not genuine Arabic. (Mṣb.) And simply muwal-adN ‡ [A post-classical phrase or word;] a modernism; an innovated, or a modern, or modernized, phrase or word; a phrase or word innovated by any of the Muwelleds, whose phrases or words are not cited as authoritative [in lexicology, or grammar, or as to the metres of verse, or rhymes: see above]: the difference between it and the maSonuwE is, that the latter is given by its author as chaste (fSyH) Arabic; whereas this is the contrary [i. e., confessedly innovated]. (Mz, 21st nwE.) It is opposed to lugapN. (The lexicons passim.)
Also muwal-adN, (L,) and its fem. with p {muwal-adapN}, (Ḳ,) ‡ Anything innovated. (L, Ḳ.)
kitaAbN muwal-adN ‡ A forged writing. (L, Ḳ.)
bay-inahN muwal-adapN ‡ Evidence not verified. (L, Ḳ.)
muwal-idapN A midwife. (A, L, Ḳ.)

1. wamaOa Uilayohi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yamaOu, inf. n. wamoCN; (Ṣ;) and AwmO↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ, which is the chaste word, MF,) inf. n. UiymaMCN; (TA;) and wm-O↓; (Ḳ;) He made a sign to him. (Ḳ.) Oawomayotu [for OawomaOotu] is disallowed: (Ṣ:) [but see what follows in this paragraph]. Lth says, that AlAymAC is the making a sign with the head or the hand, as a sick man does with his head for the inclination and prostration in prayer: (TA:) and AwmO biraOosihi sometimes signifies He [made a sign with his head as though he] said “No:” Akh cites this verse:
UicaA qal-a maAlu AlmaroCi qal-a Sadiyquhu
waOawomato Uilayohi biAlEuyuwni AlOaSaAbiEu
[When the man's wealth becomes little, his friends become few; and the fingers, together with the eyes, make signs to him]; in which Awmt is for AwmOt. (TA.)
[For a further explanation of AwmO, and the manner in which it is said to differ from AwbO, see art. wbO.]
2. wam-aOa: see 1.
wm-I biAlX-aIoCi [for wm-O: as there is no such root as wmI:] He took away the thing. (TA.)

3. fulaAnN yuwaAmiYu fulaAnFA, and yuwaAYimu, [Such a one agrees, or vies, with such a one]. These two verbs are of two different dialects, or the former is formed by transposition from the latter. (Ḳ, TA.)

ISh quotes,
faOanaA AlgcaApa muwaAmiYuho
meaning, accord. to Abu-l-Khattáb, “And I, in the morning, shall see him, or it:” syn. muEaAyinuhu. (TA.)
4: see 1.
10. AstwmI EalaI AlOamori [for AstwmO: as there is no such root as wmI:] He made himself master of the thing: like AstwlI. (Fr.)
waAmiYapN A misfortune; calamity: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) thought by ISd to be a subst. [not an act. part. n.] because no verb from which it could be derived is known. (TA.)
waqaEa fiI waAmiYapK He fell into a misfortune or calamity. (Ṣ.)

cahaba vawobiI famaA OadoriImaA kaAnato waAmiYatuhu My garment is lost, and I know not what misfortune has taken it away: (M, Ḳ:) or, who has taken it. (Yaạḳoob, Ṣ.) The phrase without negation is also used. (L.) [See a similar phrase in art. lmO.]
XaIoCN mawomuwtN A thing that is known, and decided, or determined; syn. maEoruwfN muqad-arN. (Ḳ.)

1. wamidati All-ayolapu, (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.) aor. tawomadu, inf. n. wamadN, (L,) The night was, or became, one of wamad, i. e., intense heat, &c., as explained below. (Ṣ, L, Ḳ.*) One also says wamida Alyawomu: but the former is more common. (M, L.)

wamida Ealayohi, (Ṣ,* M, A, L, Ḳ *,) aor. yawomadu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. wamadN, (M, L, Ḳ;) ‡ He was angry with him; (Ṣ, M, A, L, Ḳ;) was incensed against him; i. q. wabida, (Ṣ, L,) of which it is a dial. form. (Ṣ.)

layolapN wamidN: (L, Ḳ:) and wamidapN↓, (T, M, A, L, Ḳ,) which latter is the more common, (TA,) A night of wamad, i. e., intense heat, &c., as explained above. (T, M, A, L, Ḳ.) One also says yawomN wamidN: but not so commonly. (M, L.)
huwa Ealayohi wamidN ‡ He is angry with him. (A.)
wamadapN: see wamadN.
wamidapN: see wamidN.
1: see 4.

hom.sense: 4. AwmD It (lightning) flashed, gleamed, or shone, slightly, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) not extending sideways in the adjacent tracts of cloud; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) for when it does thus, it is termed xafowN; and when it extends high in the sky, without extending sideways to the right and left, it is termed EaqiyqapN: (Ṣ:) it is also said of other things, beside lightning: (M:) and wamaDa↓, (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yamiDu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. wamiyDN and wamoDN (Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ) and wamaDaAnN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and tawomaADN, (M,) signifies the same; (Ṣ, M, A, Mṣb, Ḳ;) or it (lightning) flashed faintly or weakly, and then disappeared, and then flashed again; (IAạr;) and is also, sometimes, said of fire, (M, TA,) and of anything of a clear [or bright] colour: (El-ʼEyn:) or both verbs signify it (lightning) gleamed, or shone. (Ḥam, p. 785.)
Hence, OawomaDati AlmaroOapu ‡ The woman smiled, so as to display her teeth: the glistening of her front teeth being likened to the flashing of lightning. (A, TA.)
And ‡ The woman stole a glance, or glances; (Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also AwmDt biEayonihaA: (A:) or this last,† the woman looked, or gazed with widely opened eyes. (L.)
And AwmD lahu biEayonihi † He made a sign to him with his eye: (M:) or AwmD fulaAnN ‡ such a one made a private, or secret, sign, (Ḳ, TA,) Uilay-a to me. (TA.)
Also, He saw the slight flashing, or gleaming, or shining, of lightning, or of fire. (M, TA.)

entry.sense: wamoDapN [A slight flash of lightning, &c.] You say, Ximotu wamoDapa baroqK kanaboDapi EiroqK [I looked at a slight flash of lightning, like a single pulsation of an artery, to see whither it tended, and where it might rain]. (A, TA.)
baroqN wamiyDN i. q. waAmiDN↓ [Lightning flashing, gleaming, or shining, slightly;, &c.: wmyD in this case being app. an inf. n. used as an epithet.] (TA.)
waAmiDN: see what next precedes.
2. wn-bh, inf. n. tawoniybN, He reprehended, reproved, blamed, chid, or reproached, him severely;, &c.: (Ḳ:) a dial. form of Oan-abahu. (TA.)

1. wahaba lahu XayoYFA, (aor. yahabu, Ḳ; said to be originally yawohibu; which is changed into yahibu because of the kesr; and then, into yahabu because of the medial guttural letter; Mṣb, voce wasiEa;) inf. n. wahobN and wahabN and hibapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and mawohibN and mawohibapN, (Mṣb,) or the last two are substs., (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) He gave him a thing; properly, as a free gift, disinterestedly, and not for any compensation. (Mṣb, TA.)
You should not say wahabakahu [he gave it to thee], (Ḳ, &c.,) making the verb doubly trans.: (TA:) or [this is allowable, as it is said that] AA has related this on the authority of an Arab of the desert: so in the Ḳ: but in the L, it is said that Seer has related this, from ʼAmr, (meaning Sb,) from an Arab of the desert. (TA.) En-Nawawee allows the expression wahabutu kacaA minohu, meaning, I gave such a thing to him, &c.; (mn being redundant, as in biEotu kacaA minohu “I sold such a thing to him;”) as occurring in several trads. (MF.)
See 3.

wahabaniI Qll-ehu fidaAka May God make me [or give me as] thy ransom! (IAạr, Ḳ.) wuhibotu fidaAka May I be made [or given as] thy ransom! Ibn-Umm-Kásim says, that whb is one of the verbs which signify He caused to be, or to become: and he cites the above phrase from IAạr; and adds, that the verb is only used in the pret. tense. Others assert it to be rare. (TA.)

haboniI faEalotu celika Suppose me; syn. Zun-aniI; (AḤei, cited by Fei;) or count me, or reckon me; syn. OuHosuboniI waQEodudoniI; (M, Ḳ;) [or grant me;] to have done that. (M, Ḳ.*) habo zayodFA manoTaliqFA Suppose Zeyd to be going away, or gone away; syn. UiHosabo. (So in two copies of the Ṣ: in another, OuHosubo.) Thus this verb is doubly trans.: (Ṣ:) but it is not used in this sense in the pret., nor in the aor.: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) you do not say wahabotuka faEalota celika [I supposed thee to have done that]: nor (as some assert, Mṣb,) do you say habo Oan-iI faEalotu, (TA,) as say the vulgar, though what the grammarians say, respecting the class of verbs to which Zananotu belongs, that Oan-a and Uin-a [with what follows them] may supply the place of the two objective complements, [as when you say Zananotu Oan-a zayodFA qaAYimN, and Znnt Uin-a zayodFA laqaAYimN, “I thought Zeyd to be standing,”] affords matter for controverting this. (Mṣb.)

3. waAhabahu fawahabahu↓, aor. of the latter verb yahabu and yahibu, He strove to surpass him in giving, freely, or disinterestedly, and he surpassed him therein. (Ḳ.) [The former of the above aors., accord. to general opinion, is irregular; and the latter, regular; because the first radical letter is w; as in the case of waAEadahu fawaEadahu, aor. yaEidu: or, accord. to the rule laid down by Ks, the reverse is perhaps the case, because the medial radical letter is a guttural. See Lumsden's Ar. Gram., p. 171.]

hom.sense: 4. Awhb lahu AlX-aIoCa He prepared, or made ready, the thing for him. (Ḳ.)
Oawohabotuka AlT-aEaAma waAlX-araAba I prepared, or made ready, for thee the food and beverage, and abundance of them. (Tahdheeb el-Af'ál.) But see this verb in an intrans. sense.
Oawohaba AlT-aEaAmu ‡ The food, or corn, or the like, became abundant and ample, so that some of it was given away. (A.)
Oawohabotu liOamori kacaA ‡ I became capable of such a thing and able to do it. (A.)

Oawohaba laka AlX-aIoCu The thing was, or became, within thy power, or reach, so that thou mightest take it. (Ḳ.*) Related on the authority of IAạr alone, who says, They did not say Oawohabotuhu laka. (TA.)

Oawohaba lahu AlX-aIoCu The thing was lasting to him. (AʼObeyd, AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.) J cites the following verse:
EaZiymu AlqafaA rixowu AlxawaASiri Oawohabato
lahu EajowapN masomuwnapN waxamiyru
[Large in the back of the neck, soft (or loose or flabby) in the flanks: dates of the best that El-Medeeneh produces, prepared with clarified butter, and leaven, are lasting (provisions) to him]. But ʼAlee Ibn-Hamzeh says, that this is a mistake, and that the right reading is Ourohinato, meaning “are prepared, and continued.” So in a marginal note in a copy of the Ṣ. (TA.) [So too in the margin of one of my MṢ. copies of the Ṣ.]

entry.sense: 6. twAhbwA They gave gifts, one to another. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
fiyhimi Alt-awaAhubu [They have a habit of mutually giving gifts]. (TA.)
tawaAhabahu Aln-aAsu bayonahumo [The people gave it; one to another]. (TA.)
walaA Alt-awaAhubu fiymaA bayonahumo SEpN [Nor is their mutual giving of what is (possessed) among them (from fear of) humiliation]: i. e., they do not give by constraint. (TA, from a trad.)
8. Uithaba (originally Uiwotahaba, TA,) He accepted a hibap, or gift. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) At-hbh He accepted it [as a gift]. (Ḳ.) Uit-ahabotu minoka dirohamFA [I accepted from thee a dirhem, as a gift]. (L.)
10. Astwhb, (Ṣ,) or Astwhb hibpa, (Mṣb,) He asked for a hbp, or gift. (Ṣ, Mṣb.)
Astwhbhu xaAdimFA [He asked him to give him a servant.] (Ḳ, art. xdm.)

hibapN and mawohabapN↓ A gift (or thing bestowed); properly, one that is freely and disinterestedly given, not for any compensation; a free, or disinterested, gift. (L.) [In the Ḳ, the latter is explained as signifying simply a gift.] Pl. of the former hibaApN; and of the latter, mawaAhibu. (A, &c.)
[A hibaApN is of two kinds: mawaAhibu A free gift, for no requital, or compensation: and hibapu vawaAbK A gift for a requital, or compensation. This distinction is made in law, &c.]
hubapN i. q. OuhobapN q. v. (Ḳ, in art. Ahb.)
wahuwbN: see waAhibN.
wah-aAbN and wah-aAbapN: see waAhibN.

waAhibN and wahuwbN↓ (Ḳ) and wah-aAbN↓ and wah-aAbapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) epithets from wahaba, [“he gave, &c.”: the first signifies Giving; properly, as a free gift, disinterestedly; and not for any compensation: or one who gives;, &c.:] the others are intensive epithets, [as is said in the Ṣ of the third and fourth,] signifying one who gives liberally, or bountifully;, &c.: and in this sense Alwah-aAbu↓ is used as an epithet of God; or, accord. to the Nh, it signifies He who dispenses his bounties universally and perpetually, freely, or without constraint, and disinterestedly, for no compensation. The p in wh-Abp↓ is added to give more force to the intensiveness; as in Eal-aAmapN. (TA.)

mawohib and mawohibapN↓ substs. of wahaba [“he gave, &c.;” signifying A gift (or act of giving); properly, that is free and disinterested, not for any compensation; a free, or disinterested, donation]. (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.) See 1.
muwhabN A thing, such as food, prepared, ready, at one's hand. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: waAdK muwhibu AlHaTabi ‡ A valley abounding with fire-wood. (A.)
OaSobaHa fulaAnN muwhibFA Such a one became prepared, or ready, (muEad-FA; so in an excellent copy of the Ṣ: in another copy, muEid-FA:) and able. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: mawohabapN: see hibapN.
‡ A cloud falling [in rain] in any place: (Ḳ:) pl. mawaAhibu: you say kavurati AlmwAhibu fiI AlOaroDi The rains became abundant in the land. (TA.)

mawohabapN and mawohibapN↓ ‡ A small pool of water left by a torrent: or the former only is the correct word, and the meaning of which, as explained in the Ṣ, is a small hollow, or cavity, in a mountain, in which water stagnates: pl. mawaAhibu: and in the T it is said that a small cavity, or hollow, in a rock, is called mawohabapN, with fet-ḥ, being extr. [with respect to rule]. (TA.)
mawohibapN: see mawohibN and mawohabapN.
mawohuwb A thing given; properly, as a free gift, &c.: see the verb. (Mṣb.)
mawohuwbN lahu Having a thing given to him; properly, as a free gift, &c. (Mṣb.)
mawohuwbN A son; a child; offspring: and whatever is given to one by the Liberal, or Bountiful, Giver, i. e., by God. An epithet in which the character of a subst. is predominant. (TA.)
1. wahatahu, aor. yahitu, inf. n. wahotN, He trod, or stamped upon it vehemently. (L.)
He pressed, compressed, or pressed against, him; or it; syn. DagaTahu. (L, Ḳ.)
4. Awht It (flesh-meat) became stinking: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) dial. form of Ayht. (TA.)
wahotapN A depressed, or low, piece of ground: (Ḳ:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n. of which it is the n. un.] wahotN. (TA.)
1. wahava fiI XaIoCK, aor. yahivu, inf. n. wahovN, He was persevering, or assiduous, in the thing. (Ḳ.)
wahava XayoYFA, aor. yahivu, inf. n. wahovN, He trod, or trampled, vehemently upon a thing. (Ḳ.)
5. twh-v fiI AlOamori He went, or penetrated, far into the affair. (M, Ḳ.)
waAhivN One throwing himself into destruction. (TA.)

1. wahajati Aln-aAru, aor. tahiju, inf. n. wahojN and wahajaAnN; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) and wahajata, [app. a mistake for wahijat,] aor. tawohaju, [inf. n. wahajN;] (L;) The fire burned; syn. Ait-aqadat; (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.;) and so tawh-jt↓; (L;) syn. twq-dt; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) [or this last has an intensive sense, and signifies, as does the first accord. to the A, it burned fiercely; glowed].
Also, all these verbs, with the same inf. ns., It (the sun) burned, or was hot: and it (a fire) burned from a distance. (L.)
Also, all the above verbs, with the same inf. ns., ‡ It (a day, and a night,) was violently hot. (L.)
2: see 4.
4. Awhj He kindled a fire; made it to burn; syn. Oawoqada: (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [or made it to burn fiercely, or to glow:] in the M, wh-j↓. (L.)
5. twh-j: see 1.
‡ It (the odour of perfume) was hot, or strong; syn. twq-d. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
‡ It (a jewel) shone; glistened; glowed. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
‡ It (a day) was violently hot. (A.)
‡ It (heat) was violent. (A.)
yawomN wahijN, and wahajaAnN↓, and layolapN wahijapN, and wahajaAnapN↓, ‡ A violently hot day, and night. (L.)
wahajN and wahiyjN↓ The burning, or heat, of fire. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See 1.]
Also, The diffusion (in a neut. sense) of the odour of perfume; and the hot, or strong, odour, thereof. (L.)
Also, the latter, The shining, glistening, or glowing, of a jewel. (L.)
wahajaAnN and wamajaAnapN: see wahijN.
wahiyjN: see wahajN.
najomN wah-aAjN [A fiercely burning, or glowing, star]. (TA.) siraAjN wah-aAjN [A fiercely burning, or glowing, lamp: Ḳur. lxxviii. 13:] i. e., the sun. (TA.)
mutawah-ijapN, as an epithet applied to a woman, Hot in the pudendum; expl. by HaAr-apu AlmataAE. (L.)

wahodN (L) and wahodapN (Aṣ, Ṣ, A, L) A low, or depressed, place; (Aṣ, Ṣ, A L;) as though it were a hollow, or cavity, dug, or excavated, for which the latter is also a name: (L:) and both words, low, or depressed, ground: (L, Ḳ:) pl. OawohudN, (L, Ḳ,) a pl. [of pauc.] of the former, (TA,) and wihaAdN (Ṣ, A, L, Ḳ) and wuhodaAnN, or wihodaAnN, (as in different copies of the Ḳ, the former being the reading in the TA,) and wahodN of wahodapN: (Ṣ, L:) [or rather this last is a coll. gen. n., of which wahodapN is the n. un.:] also wahodapN a hollow, or cavity, or deep hollow or cavity, (huw-apN,) in the ground; (L, Ḳ;) and so makaAnN wahodN, and OaroDN wahodapN: (L:) and a round hollow excavated in the ground, deeper than what is called gaAYiTN, not having abrupt sides, in width two and three spear's lengths, and not producing any herbage. (L.)
Also wahodapN The hollow, in the ground, in which the weaver puts his legs, or feet. (Mgh.)
Also, i. q. xunoEubapN, (IAạr, L,) which latter, says Lth, signifies The part where the mustaches divide.

wayobN a word like wayolN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and wayoHN and wayosN: these four words agree in form and meaning, and have no fifth; although some of the lexicologists differ, in holding that some of them relate to what is good, and others to the falling into destruction. Accord. to what is said by Z, in the Fáïk, wyb and wyH and wys denote compassion: but wyl is used in reviling, and imprecating destruction. (MF.) IḲṭṭ says, in the Tahdheeb el-Af'ál, that the invariable verbs are nine in number: niEoma and biYosu and layosa and EasaI and the verb of wonder and wayoHa zayodK and wayobahu and wayolahu and wayosahu; but that El-Mázinee asserts the last four to be inf. ns. (TA.) You say wayobaka, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and wayobN laka, and wayobN lizayodK, and wayobFA lahu, and wayobK lahu, (Ḳ,) with the three different vowel-terminations, both in addressing a person and in speaking of one who is absent, (TA,) and wayobihi, and wayobi gayorihi, (Ḳ,) [and wayoba gayorika, (see below,)] and wayoba zayodK, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and wayobi zayodK, (TA,) [and wayobu zayodK, (see below,)] and wayobi fulaAnN on the authority of IAạr, (Ḳ,) who adds, except the bnw Asd, who, it appears, from his saying this, give fet-ḥ to the b: (TA:) the meaning of all which is, May God make woe (wyl) to cleave to thee!

[and to Zeyd!, &c.: or Woe to thee!, &c.: but see what is said above.] (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Dhu-l-Khirak Et-Tuhawee uses wyb in the sense of wyl, addressing to a wolf the ejaculation wayoba gayorika, [which is therefore the same in meaning as wayobaka]: (TA:) but accord. to what is said by Z, in the Fáïk, wayobaka and wayobN laka, &c. signify Mercy on thee! or the like. (MF.) When wyb is put in the acc. case, it is so put as an inf. n. (Ṣ.) This is the opinion generally obtaining: the opinion that wayoba is a verb is extraordinary. (TA.) When you use the prep. l, you [generally say] wayobN lizayodK (or wayobFA lizayodK, L): when you use l, it is more elegant to put wyb in the nom. case, as an inchoative, than in the acc. case: but when you use wyb as a prefixed noun, with its complement, the acc. is more elegant than the nom. case: [i. e., it is more elegant to say wayoba zayodK than wayobu zayodK]. (Ṣ, L.) Ks says, Some of the Arabs say wayobaka and wayoba gayorika; and some of them say wayobFA lizayodK, like wayolFA lizayodK. (TA.)
wayobFA lihacaA AlOamori (Ḳ,* TA) i. q. EajabFA lahu, [I] wonder at, or with respect to, this thing! (Ḳ,) and so wayobahu. (TA.)

wayobapN A measure consisting of twenty-two, or twenty-four, OamodaAd ( pl. of mud-N), which see in art. mk. (Ḳ.) Not mentioned by J nor by IF; and IDrd doubted respecting it. In truth it is a post-classical word, used by the people of Syria and Egypt and Africa Proper. (TA.) [At present, the wybp in Cairo is the sixth part of an Uirodab-, which latter is equivalent, very nearly, to five English bushels.]

wayoHN a word denoting compassion, or pity: (AZ, Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) wayolN denotes [an imprecation of] punishment; (Ṣ;) or [of] removal from good, or from prosperity: (AZ, Aṣ:) or [of] destruction: (AZ:) and wayosN denotes the same as wyH; (AZ;) or less than wyH: (Aṣ:) or wyH and wys denote compassion, or pity, and admiration of one's beauty; as when you say of a child, wayoHahu maA OamolaHahu, and wayosahu mA AmlHh, [Mercy on him! or the like: how beautiful is he!] (Kh) or, accord. to most of the lexicologists, wyl is a word said to, or of, any one who falls into destruction or trial, or misfortune, and on whom one does not wish God's mercy: and wyH is said to, or of, any one who falls into trial or misfortune, and for whom one wishes God's mercy, and his escape therefrom: the former word being so used in the Ḳur-án, and the latter by the Prophet: (T:) or wyl is said to, or of, him who falls into destruction: and wyH is a word by which one chides him who is at the point of falling into destruction: (Sb:) or wyH and wyl are syn., (Yz, En-Naḍr, Ṣ, Ibn-Et-Faraj,) and wys signifies the same: (Ibn-El-Faraj:) or wyH is a little softer, or more gentle, than wyl: (En-Naḍr:) [if so, wayoHahu signifies woe to him: in the same, or in a milder, manner than wayolahu:]
or the original of wyH is wayo; sometimes H being added to this latter word, and sometimes l and sometimes b, and sometimes s; (Ḳ;) so that it becomes wyH and wyl and wyb and wys. (TA.) [See wyl and wyb and wys and wI.] You say wayoHN lizayodK [Mercy on Zeyd! or woe to Zeyd!]; putting wyH in the nom. case as an inchoative; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and in like manner, wayolN lizayodK: (Ṣ:) and also wayoHFA lizayodK; putting wyH in the acc. case because of a verb understood; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as though you said Oalozamahu Qll-ehu wayoHFA [May God make mercy, or woe, to attend him constantly!]; and in like manner, wayolFA lizayodK: (Ṣ:) or [it is put in the acc. case as an absolute complement of a verb understood, i. e., as an inf. n., and] the meaning is OataraH-amuhu taraH-umFA. [I say, May God have mercy on him! emphatically]: (Z, in the Fáïk:) you also say wayoHaka, and wayoHa zayodK; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) making wyH a prefixed n.; (Ṣ;) and putting it in the acc. case again because of a verb understood; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and in like manner, wayolaka, and wayola zayodK: (Ṣ:) and also wayoHamaA zayodK in the same sense. (Ḳ.)

wayosN a word used to. denote compassion, or pity, and admiration of one's beauty; (M, Ḳ;) the object being a child; (Ḳ;) as when one says of a child, wayosahu maA OamolaHahu [Merry on him! or the like: how beautiful is he!]: (TA:) or wayosN and wayoHN are used in the place of wayolN; (TA;) and wayosN lahu signifies wayolN lahu [Woe to him!]: (M, TA:) or, as some say, wayosN is a word denoting contempt; and has no verb; analogy forbidding that it should have one: (IJ, M:) Aboo-Turáb says, I heard Abu-sSemeyda' say, wayosN and wayoHN and wayolN have one meaning: (TA:) or wayosaka is not said except to children; and wayolaka is an expression in which is roughness and reproach; and wyH is a gentle and good expression. (AḤát, TA.) See wyoHN and wayolN and wayobN.
It also signifies Poverty. (ISk, M.) And one may say, if it be right to say so to one, wayosN lahu as meaning Poverty be to him. (ISk.)

Also, What a man desires. (M, Ḳ.) So in the phrase laqiIa wayosFA He found, or met with, or experienced, what he desired; (M, Ḳ;) accord. to an explanation given by IAạr; so that it means much: but in one place he says that this phrase signifies he found,, &c., what he did not desire. (M.)
